(b)  No appropriation provided for in a prior capital improvements budget shall lapse until the purpose for which the appropriation was made shall have been accomplished or abandoned; provided, however, the city manager may submit amendments to the capital improvements budget at any time during the fiscal year, accompanied by his recommendations. Any such amendments to the capital improvements budget shall become effective only upon adoption by ordinance. 
Sec. 6.38. - Independent audit. 
There shall be an annual independent audit of all city accounts, funds, and financial transactions by a certified public accountant selected by the city council. The audit shall be conducted according to generally accepted accounting principles. Any audit of any funds by the state or federal governments may be accepted as satisfying the requirements of this charter. Copies of all audit reports shall be available at printing costs to the public. 
PART 4. - PROCUREMENT AND PROPERTY MANAGEMENT 

Sec. 6.40. - Contracting procedures. 
No contract with the city shall be binding on the city unless: 
(1)  it is in writing; and 
(2)  it meets all requirements of city ordinances concerning purchases and contracts. 
Sec. 6.41. - Centralized purchasing. 
The city council may by ordinance prescribe procedures for a system of purchasing for the city. 
Sec. 6.42. - Sale of city property. 
(a)  The city council may sell and convey any real or personal property owned or held by the city for governmental or other purposes as now or hereafter provided by law. 
(b)  The city council may quitclaim any rights it may have in property not needed for public purposes upon report by the city manager and adoption of a resolution, finding that the property is not needed for public or other purposes and that the interest of the city has no readily ascertainable monetary value. 
(c)  Whenever in opening, extending or widening any street, avenue, alley or public place of the city, a small parcel or tract of land is cut off or separated by such work from a larger tract or boundary of land owned by the city, the city council may authorize the city manager to execute and deliver in the name of the city a deed conveying the cut-off or separated parcel or tract of land to an abutting or adjoining property owner or owners in exchange for rights-of-way of the street, avenue, alley, or public place when such swap is deemed to be in the best interest of the city. All deeds and conveyances heretofore and hereafter so executed and delivered shall convey all title and interest the city has in such property, notwithstanding the fact that no public sale after advertisement was or is hereafter made. 
ARTICLE VII. - GENERAL PROVISIONS 

Sec. 7.10. - Prior ordinances. 
All ordinances, resolutions, rules, and regulations now in force in the city not inconsistent with this charter are hereby declared valid and of full effect and force until amended or repealed by the city council. 
Sec. 7.11. - Existing personnel and officers. 
Except as specifically provided otherwise by this charter, all personnel and officers of the city and their rights, privileges, and powers shall continue beyond the time this charter takes effect for a period of 180 days before or during which the existing city council shall pass a transition ordinance detailing the changes in personnel and appointive officers required or desired and arranging such titles, rights, privileges, and powers as may be required or desired to allow a reasonable transition. 
Sec. 7.12. - Pending matters. 
Except as specifically provided otherwise by this charter, all rights, claims, actions, orders, contracts, and legal or administrative proceedings shall continue and any such ongoing work or cases shall be completed by such city agencies, personnel, or offices as may be provided by the city council. 
Sec. 7.13. - Construction. 
(a)  Section captions in this charter are informative only and are not to be considered as a part thereof. 
(b)  The word "shall" is mandatory and the word "may" is permissive. 
(c)  The singular shall include the plural, the masculine shall include the feminine, and vice versa. 
Sec. 7.14. - Severability. 
If any article, section, subsection, paragraph, sentence, or part thereof [of] this charter shall be held to be invalid or unconstitutional, such invalidity or unconstitutionality shall not affect or impair other parts of this charter unless it clearly appears that such other parts are wholly and necessarily dependent upon the part held to be invalid or unconstitutional, it being the legislative intent in enacting this charter that each article, section, subsection, paragraph, sentence, or part thereof be enacted separately and independent of each other. 
Sec. 7.15. - Effective date. 
This charter shall become effective on [March 24, 1988]. 
Sec. 7.16. - Specific repealer. 
An Act incorporating the City of Forest Park in the County of Clayton, approved April 19, 1973 (Ga. L. 1973, p. 3701), is hereby repealed in its entirety and all amendatory Acts thereto are likewise repealed in their entirety. 
Sec. 7.17. - General repealer. 
All laws and parts of laws in conflict with this Act are repealed. 
CHARTER COMPARATIVE TABLE 
This table shows the location of the sections of the basic Charter and any amendments thereto. 

 
Title 1 - General Provisions 
Chapter 1.  Use of Code 
CHAPTER 1. - USE OF CODE 

Sec. 1-1-1. - How Code designated and cited. 
The ordinances embraced in the following chapters and sections shall constitute and be designated "Code of Ordinances, City of Forest Park, Georgia," and may be so cited. 
(Code 1959, § 1-1) 
Sec. 1-1-2. - Rules of construction. 
In the construction of this Code, and of all ordinances, the following rules shall be observed, unless such construction would be inconsistent with the manifest intent of the governing body: 
Building and zoning administrator: Whenever the words "building and zoning administrator" are used, they shall mean the building inspector of the City of Forest Park, Georgia. 
City: The words "the city" or "this city" shall mean the City of Forest Park, Georgia. 
Computation of time: Unless otherwise specifically provided, the time within which an act is required to be done shall be computed by excluding the first day and including the last; except that the last day shall be excluded if it is Sunday. 
County: The words "the county" or "this county" shall mean the County of Clayton, Georgia. 
Delegation of authority: Whenever a provision appears requiring the head of a department or other officer of the city to do some act or perform some duty, it shall be construed to authorize such department head or officer to designate, delegate and authorize subordinates to do the required act or perform the required duty unless the terms of the provision designate otherwise. 
Department of planning, building and zoning: Whenever the words "department of public services" are used, they shall mean the department of planning, building and zoning. 
Director of planning, building and zoning: Whenever the words "director of public services" are used, they shall mean the director of planning, building and zoning. 
Gender: A word importing the masculine gender only shall extend and be applied to females and to firms, partnerships and corporations as well as to males. 
Governing body: Whenever the words "governing body" are used, they shall mean the mayor and council of the City of Forest Park, Georgia. 
Joint authority: Whenever a joint authority is given to three (3) or more persons or officers, it shall be construed as giving such authority to a majority of them. 
Month: The word "month" shall mean a calendar month. 
Number: Words used in the singular include the plural, and the plural includes the singular number. 
Oath: The word "oath" shall be construed to include an affirmation in all cases in which, by law, an affirmation may be substituted for an oath, and in such cases the words "swear" and "sworn" shall be equivalent to the words "affirm" and"affirmed." 
Or, and: "Or" may be read "and" and "and" may be read "or" if the sense requires it. 
Other officials or officers, etc.: Whenever reference is made to officials, boards, commissions, departments, etc., by title only (i.e., "city clerk," "director of public works," etc.), they shall be deemed to refer to the officials, boards, commissions and departments of the City of Forest Park. 
Owner: The word "owner" applied to real estate shall include any part owner, joint owner, tenant in common, tenant in partnership, joint interest or other fee interest in the whole or a part of such real estate. 
Person: The word "person" shall extend and be applied to firms, partnerships, associations, organizations and bodies politic and corporate, or any combination thereof, as well as to individuals. 
Preceding, following: The words "preceding" and "following" shall mean next before and next after, respectively. 
Signature or subscription includes a mark when the person cannot write. 
State: The words "the state" or "this state" shall be construed to mean the State of Georgia. 
Street: The word "street" shall be construed to embrace streets, avenues, boulevards, roads, alleys, lanes, viaducts and all other public streets and ways in the city and shall embrace all parts thereof constituting the designated right-of-way. 
Week: The word "week" shall mean seven (7) days. 
Year: The word "year" shall mean a calendar year. 
Department of police services: Wherever the words "department of police services" are used herein, same shall mean the department providing police services for the City of Forest Park, Georgia and which shall hereafter be known as the "department of police services of the City of Forest Park, Georgia." 
Department of fire and emergency medical services: Whenever the words "department of fire and emergency medical services" are used herein, same shall mean fire protection services and emergency medical services, together with the services of emergency management administration and all services providing thereby and shall hereafter be known as "the department of fire and emergency medical services." 
Director of police services: Whenever the words "director of police services" are used, they shall mean the director of public safety of the City of Forest Park, Georgia. 
Director of police and fire services: Whenever the words "director of police and fire services" are used, they shall mean the director of public safety of the City of Forest Park, Georgia. 
Planning commission: Whenever the words "planning commission" are used they shall mean the planning and zoning board. 
(Code 1986, § 1-1-2; Ord. No. 86-010, 5-19-86; Ord. No. 87-016, 11-2-87; Ord. No. 95-003, 5-1-95; Ord. No. 96-003, § 5, 2-5-96) 
Sec. 1-1-3. - Catchlines of sections. 
The boldfaced catchlines of sections of this Code are intended as mere catchwords to indicate the contents of the section and shall not be deemed or taken to be titles of such sections, nor as any part of the section, nor, unless expressly so provided, shall they be so deemed when any of such sections, including the catchlines, are amended or re-enacted. 
(Code 1959, § 1-3) 
Sec. 1-1-4. - Effect of repeal of ordinances. 
(a)  The repeal of an ordinance shall not revive any ordinances in force before or at the time the ordinance repealed took effect. 
(b)  The repeal of an ordinance shall not affect any punishment or penalty incurred before the repeal took effect, nor any suit, prosecution or proceeding pending at the time of the repeal, for an offense committed under the ordinances repealed. 
(Code 1959, § 1-4) 
Sec. 1-1-5. - Severability of parts of Code. 
It is hereby declared to be the intention of the governing body that the sections, paragraphs, sentences, clauses and phrases of this Code are severable, and if any phrase, clause, sentence, paragraph or section of this Code shall be declared unconstitutional by the valid judgment or decree of a court of competent jurisdiction, such unconstitutionality shall not affect any of the remaining phrases, clauses, sentences, paragraphs and sections of this Code. 
(Code 1959, § 1-5) 
Sec. 1-1-6. - Amendment to Code; effect of new ordinances; amendatory language. 
(a)  Conformity to numbering system; omission of repealed portions. All ordinances passed subsequent to this Code of Ordinances which amend, repeal or in any way affect this Code of Ordinances may be numbered in accordance with the numbering system of this Code and printed for inclusion therein. When subsequent ordinances repeal any chapter, section or subsection or any portion thereof, such repealed portions may be excluded from this Code by omission from reprinted pages. 
(b)  Form of amendments generally. Amendments to any of the provisions of this Code should be made by amending such provisions by specific reference to the section of this Code in substantially the following language: "That section ____________ of the Code of Ordinances of the City of Forest Park, Georgia, is hereby amended to read as follows: … (Set out new provisions in full)." 
(c)  Form for incorporation of new material. When the governing body desires to enact an ordinance of a general and permanent nature on a subject not heretofore existing in the Code which the governing body desires to incorporate into the Code a section in substantially the following language shall be made a part of the ordinance: "Section ____________ . It is the intention of the governing body, and it is hereby ordained that the provisions of this ordinance shall become and be made a part of the Code of Ordinances of the City of Forest Park, Georgia, and the sections of this ordinance may be renumbered to accomplish such intention." 
(d)  Repeal. All sections, articles, chapters or provisions of this Code desired to be repealed should be specifically repealed by section or chapter number, as the case may be. 
(e)  Renumbering. When necessary, sections and subsections to the Code may be renumbered by the official codifier for the city to fulfill the intent of the governing body but all such changes shall be approved in advance by the city attorney. 
Sec. 1-1-7. - Altering Code prohibited; penalty for violation. 
It shall be unlawful for any person in the city to change or amend by additions or deletions any part or portion of this Code, or to insert or delete pages or portions thereof, or to alter or tamper with such Code in any manner whatsoever which will cause the law of the City of Forest Park, Georgia, to be misrepresented thereby. Any person violating this section shall be punished as provided in section 1-1-8 hereof. 
(Code 1959, § 1-7) 
Sec. 1-1-8. - General penalty. 
Any person who violates any section or provision in this Code or in any ordinance of the city by doing any act which is prohibited or is made or declared to be unlawful or an offense, or who fails to do any act which is required by said Code or ordinance, shall, after trial and if convicted in the appropriate Forest Park Municipal Court, be guilty of a misdemeanor and punished by a fine in an amount not to exceed one thousand dollars ($1,000.00) and/or imprisoned for a period not to exceed six (6) months and one (1) day, unless otherwise noted in this Code or other specific ordinance. 
(Ord. No. 94-004, 10-17-94; Ord. No. 11-09, § 1, 3-7-2011; Ord. No. 14-21, § 1, 9-2-2014) 
Title 2 - General Government 
Chapter 1.  Mayor and Council 
Chapter 2.  Elections 
Chapter 3.  Administration

CHAPTER 1. - MAYOR AND COUNCIL[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Charter reference— Establishment of governing body, City Charter, Art. II. 

ARTICLE A. - MEETINGS OF GOVERNING BODY[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
State Law reference— Open meetings law, O.C.G.A., § 50-14-1 et seq. 

Sec. 2-1-1. - Time, date and location of regular meetings. 
(a)  The governing body shall establish from time to time by resolution the times, dates, and locations of regular meetings. Such regular meetings shall occur no less often than twice per month. 
(b)  At any regular meeting, the time, date or location of the next regular meeting may be changed by action of the city council. 
(c)  Unless otherwise changed by action of the city council, any regular meeting which falls on a legal holiday shall be held on the first work day following said holiday. 
(Ord. No. 17-03, § 1, 1-3-2017) 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 17-03, § 1, adopted Jan. 3, 2017, repealed the former section and enacted a new section as set out herein. The former section pertained to similar subject matter. For prior history, see Ordinance Disposition Table. 
Sec. 2-1-2. - Presiding officer; rules of order. 
(a)  The mayor, or in his absence, the mayor pro tem, or in the absence of both mayor and mayor pro tem, any member of the governing body who may be designated by the members present, a quorum being present, shall preside at all meetings of the governing body. 
(b)  The presiding officer shall enforce "Robert's Rules of Order" relating to parliamentary procedure during all meetings of the governing body; however, should such "Robert's Rules of Order" conflict with the provisions of this code the provisions of this code shall prevail. 
(Code 1959, § 2-2) 
Sec. 2-1-3. - Agenda. 
(a)  All reports, communications, ordinances, resolutions, petitions, contract documents, request(s) for personal visitation, or other matter to be submitted to the governing body shall, at least one (1) week prior to each meeting of the governing body be delivered to the city manager, whereupon the city manager shall immediately arrange a list of such matters according to the order of business and shall furnish each member of the governing body with a copy of the same at least ninety-six (96) hours prior to the meeting. 
(b)  The section shall apply to regularly scheduled meetings of the governing body scheduled pursuant to section 2.20(a) of the Charter of the City of Forest Park and not to specially called meetings called pursuant to section 2.20(b) of the aforesaid Charter section. Additionally this section should be read in conjunction with section 2.24 of the charter of the City of Forest Park giving the city council the authority to establish its own rules and procedures. 
(Code 1959, § 2-3; Ord. No. 97-002, 2-3-97; Ord. No. 97-005, 3-17-97) 
Sec. 2-1-4. - Roll call. 
Before proceeding with the business of the governing body, the city clerk or his duty shall call the roll of the members, and the names of those present shall be entered in the minutes. 
(Code 1959, § 2-4) 
Sec. 2-1-5. - Reasons for vote in minutes. 
Any member of the governing body shall have the right to have entered in the minutes the reasons for his vote or action pertaining to any matter of city business. 
(Code 1959, § 2-5) 
Sec. 2-1-6. - Oath. 
(a)  No member of a board, commission, or authority shall assume office until he has executed and filed with the clerk of the city the oath hereinafter set forth. 
(b)  Before a person takes any office, elective or appointive, in the city government, he shall take the following oath or affirmation before an officer of the state authorized to administer oaths. 
(c)  Said oath shall read: 
"I, ____________ (state your name) solemnly swear (or affirm) that I will support the Constitution of the United States and of the State of Georgia; and that I will in all respects observe the provisions of the Charter and Ordinances of the City of Forest Park, and I will well and truly perform the duties of the office of ____________ (insert name of office), and that I will to the utmost of my skill and ability endeavor to promote the interests and property of said city, without fear, favor, or affection. So help me God." 
_____ Signature of Office Holder 
Signature of Administering Officer 
(d)  The signed oath shall be permanent records and shall be kept as such by the city manager. 
(Ord. No. 88-014, 9-19-88) 
Sec. 2-1-7. - Rules of procedure and decorum. 
The following rules of procedure and decorum are hereby adopted to be applicable to all regular and special meetings of the city's governing body: 
(1)  Getting the floor. 
(a)  Each member of the governing body shall have a right to speak and address any matter or issue before the governing body, for up to a total initial time limit of three (3) minutes per matter or issue. However, when a member of the governing body wishes to make a motion or speak during a discussion or debate, he or she must first be recognized by the presiding officer in order to speak. Council members are not permitted to call out or interrupt another speaker. The order in which members of the governing body are to be recognized for the purpose of addressing or speaking to any particular issue or subject matter shall be determined by the presiding officer in his or her discretion, provided that the presiding officer shall not be entitled to prohibit a member of the governing body from speaking regarding each issue or matter under discussion, for up to a total of three minutes for each issue or matter. The only manner in which any member of the governing body may be recognized by the presiding officer for the purpose of speaking during a meeting is to first raise a hand and be recognized by the presiding officer, in accordance with this subsection. 
(b)  When making remarks at a meeting, each member of the governing body shall confine his or her remarks to the topic being discussed or debated, and shall avoid personal attacks upon other members of the governing body or upon the motives or character of other members. 
(c)  After all members of the governing body who wish to speak on a single topic have been allowed to speak, then the presiding officer shall have the right, but not the obligation, to allow a member of the governing body to speak a second time on the subject or topic being discussed, for up to a total of two (2) additional minutes for each topic or subject being discussed. 
(d)  A second is required for any motion to assure minimum support for the motion. 
(e)  When a second is not forthcoming, the motion will "die for lack of a second," and the presiding officer shall so announce. Then the next order of business will be taken up without further debate or discussion. 
(f)  The presiding officer has the right to rule remarks or comments out of order and thereby terminate them, if a council member has already made essentially the same point, or if the council member is repeating something he or she has already stated. The purpose of this rule is to avoid redundancies and repeating the same point more than once, and to avoid wasting time during debate and discussion. 
(g)  No council member shall be allowed to speak on any one (1) topic for more than a total of five (5) minutes during any single meeting. 
(2)  Decorum during meetings. 
(a)  All requests for recognition by the presiding officer must be done by first raising a hand and waiting for the presiding officer to recognize the council member in order to begin speaking. Except for raising a "point of order," at no time shall any council member be allowed to interrupt the presiding officer if he or she is speaking, for any purpose. 
(b)  All comments of any council member shall be addressed to the presiding officer or to the general public in attendance at the meeting; provided however that it shall be the privilege of a council member to ask any question to the city manager, any city staff person or the city attorneys. 
(c)  No council member shall be permitted to make rude, obnoxious, slanderous, or personal attacks on anyone, including but not limited to any other member of council or the presiding officer. All council members shall also refrain from side discussions or other distractions during a meeting. 
(3)  Point of inquiry. 
(a)  A member of the city council may raise a "point of inquiry" if a simple clarification of a motion (a motion that is already before the council for consideration) is needed. This should be done by raising a hand and stating to the presiding officer, "point of inquiry," and at that time the presiding officer may in his or her discretion, recognize the council member by stating "state your point." 
(b)  Points of inquiry are used sparingly and only in case of honest confusion as to the intent or meaning of a then pending motion. A point of inquiry may not be used to simply add to the debate or discussion. 
(c)  Clarification cannot take longer than three (3) minutes. 
(4)  Point of order. 
(a)  A council member may interrupt a speaker in order to raise a "point of order," if the council member reasonably believes a meeting is being conducted in a manner inconsistent with these rules or Robert's Rules of Order. 
(b)  If a point of order is properly raised by the council member being recognized by the presiding officer to speak, then the council member who was speaking will upon request of the presiding officer yield the floor for the limited purpose of hearing the point of order. 
(c)  The mayor would then say "state your point". 
(5)  Public comments. 
(a)  Public comments will be allowed only during the "public comments" period of each regular meeting of the governing body at the time shown on the agenda. Members of the public are not allowed to participate in any debate or discussion being conducted by the members of the governing body. 
(b)  Public comments will be limited in time to a total of three (3) minutes per speaker, and a total time limit at any one meeting of fifteen (15) minutes. If more than five (5) potential speakers sign up to make public comments, then the total amount of time permitted for each individual speaker will be reduced by an announcement of the presiding officer, so as to limit the total time to fifteen (15) minutes. 
(c)  No person may sign up more than once in an effort to gain more time for a public comment. 
(d)  Public comments during a meeting of the city governing body will only be allowed to residents of the City of Forest Park or to owners of businesses maintaining a business site physically situated within the corporate limits of the City of Forest Park. 
(e)  Persons not residing within the City of Forest Park who do not own a business as specified in subsection (d) above who wish to address the governing body during any regular meeting must first request that they be placed on the agenda for the upcoming regular meeting, such request to be made in writing by close of business at city hall on the Wednesday immediately preceding the regular meeting at which they wish to speak. 
(f)  All public comments must be limited to matters on the agenda or over which the governing body has jurisdiction. 
(g)  Nonresidents who do not own a business as specified in subsection (d) above will also be limited to three (3) minutes per speaker, and a total of fifteen (15) minutes for an entire group of speakers at any single meeting, whether they are speaking on the same topic or not. If more than five (5) potential nonresident speakers are placed on the agenda in order to address the governing body, the time permitted for each individual speaker shall be reduced so as to limit the total time for speaking for such nonresidents to fifteen (15) minutes at any one (1) meeting. 
(6)  Addressing the city council and citizens. 
(a)  Speakers may raise any point of concern regarding any matter on the agenda or any matter over which the governing body has jurisdiction, but each speaker must maintain a decorous demeanor and refrain from personal attacks upon members of the governing body, shouting and using obscene language. 
(b)  The presiding officer may interrupt and take the floor away from individuals who violate subsection (a) above. 
(c)  Comments which are redundant or repetitive from previous statements made in the same meeting may be ruled out of order and terminated by the presiding officer. 
(7)  Removal for violation of these rules. Any council member who violates these rules must first be orally warned by the presiding officer, and if the council member then interrupts another speaker or speaks out without being recognized, or violates these rules in any other way for a second time in a single meeting, then the presiding officer may ask the sergeant at arms (a sworn City of Forest Park Police Officer) to remove the offending council member from the city council chambers for the remainder of the meeting. 
(8)  Purpose of these rules. It is not the intent of these rules to in any way hinder or impair the full and free expression of all competing viewpoints in discussions and debates. Instead it is the intent of this section to foster confidence in government through encouraging civil and respectful meetings. The failure to strictly observe these rules and procedures shall not affect the jurisdiction of the governing body and shall not be deemed to in any way invalidate or impair the legal validity and effect of official action taken by the governing body at any meeting that is otherwise held and conducted in accordance with law. 
(Ord. No. 11-02, § 1, 2-7-2011; Ord. No. 14-07, §§ 1—3, 3-17-2014) 
Sec. 2-1-8. - Qualifications for office of mayor and council member. 
In addition to the qualifications set forth in Section 2.11 of the City Charter, in order to qualify to run for election to the office of mayor or council member of the City of Forest Park, Georgia, the person seeking to qualify shall not have been involuntarily removed from any elective office within the five (5) years immediately preceding the date the person seeks to qualify for such office. 
(Ord. No. 11-35, § 1, 9-6-2011) 
Secs. 2-1-9, 2-1-10. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE B. - EMERGENCY POWERS OF MAYOR[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
Cross reference— Additional civil defense emergency powers of mayor, § 4-3-4. 

Sec. 2-1-11. - Power of mayor to declare the existence of emergency conditions. 
In the event the mayor, as the chief executive officer of the city, determines that an emergency condition or emergency conditions exist, he shall issue a declaration and proclamation declaring the emergency. He may proclaim and declare an emergency when in his opinion there is reasonable danger to life or property due to the presence or likelihood of unusual weather conditions, fire, civil unrest, unforeseen disaster or the stoppage or loss of utility service or services in the city. 
(Code 1959, § 9A-1) 
Sec. 2-1-12. - Powers of mayor after declaration of emergency conditions. 
After the mayor has declared the existence of an emergency as set forth above, he shall have the power in all or a portion of the city to: 
(1)  Direct the work, actions, and activities of city employees to assist in preserving life, limb, and property; 
(2)  Close streets and sidewalks to vehicular and pedestrian movement; 
(3)  Impose curfews; 
(4)  Close business establishments; 
(5)  Close public buildings and other public facilities; 
(6)  Cooperate with and assist personnel of the United States of America, the State of Georgia, Clayton County, and other municipalities to the end of preserving life, limb and property in Forest Park. 
(Code 1959, § 9A-2) 
Sec. 2-1-13. - Limitation of emergency powers. 
The mayor shall have the authority to exercise the powers set forth above only for a period of seventy-two (72) hours after the declaration of emergency or until the next regular or called meeting of council, whichever occurs first. However, should emergency conditions exist at the expiration of seventy-two (72) hours after the initial declaration and no council meeting has occurred he shall exercise emergency powers until the emergency no longer exists or until council meets, whichever is first. 
(Code 1959, § 9A-3) 
Sec. 2-1-14. - Memorandums of understanding. 
The mayor shall have the power to enter into "Memorandums of Understanding" with the proper authorities of the United States of America, the State of Georgia, Clayton County, and other municipalities in order to effectively carry out the intent and purpose of this chapter. Such memorandums shall first be reviewed by the city council and receive the approval of same. 
(Code 1959, § 9A-4) 
Secs. 2-1-15—2-1-20. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE C. - ORDINANCES AND RESOLUTIONS[4] 

Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
Cross reference— Ordinance book to be maintained, City Charter, § 2.16; Code of Ordinances, Title 1. 

Sec. 2-1-21. - Preparation. 
All ordinances and resolutions shall be approved as to form by the city attorney prior to council consideration. No ordinance or resolution shall be prepared for presentation to the governing body unless ordered by a member of the governing body or the city manager or prepared by the city attorney on his own initiative. No ordinance shall be changed in any form whatsoever by the governing body except by ordinance, and specifically, no ordinance shall be changed by motion or resolution. 
Sec. 2-1-22. - Introduction and approval. 
Ordinances, resolutions and other matters or subjects requiring action by the governing body must be introduced and sponsored by a member of the governing body, except that the city manager or city attorney may present ordinances, resolutions and other matters or subjects to the governing body, and any member may assume sponsorship thereof by moving that such ordinances, resolutions, matters or subjects be adopted; otherwise, they shall not be considered. 
(Code 1959, § 2-9) 
Sec. 2-1-23. - Limitation on subject matter; enacting clause. 
No ordinance shall relate to more than one (1) subject, except ordinances making appropriations and ordinances codifying or rearranging existing ordinances, and the subject of all ordinances shall be clearly expressed in the title. The enacting clause of all ordinances introduced to governing body shall be: "Be it ordained by the governing body of the City of Forest Park, Georgia." 
(Code 1959, § 2-10) 
Sec. 2-1-24. - Signing. 
All ordinances shall be signed by the mayor and attested by the city clerk who shall also affix the seal of the city, and shall be approved as to form by the city attorney. 
(Code 1959, § 2-11) 
Secs. 2-1-25—2-1-30. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE D. - COMPENSATION FOR THE MAYOR AND COUNCIL[5] 

Footnotes: 
--- (5) --- 
Editor's note— This article was originally designated as Article D, comprised of §§ 2-4-32—2-4-34. Numbering was changed by the codifier to fall with other provisions relating to the governing body. 

Sec. 2-1-31. - Time for determining compensation. 
The salary for the mayor and members of the council shall be set by the governing body from time to time. In any event, any action to increase the salary or compensation of the elected members of the governing body shall not be effective until after the taking of office of those elected at the next regular municipal election held immediately following the date on which the action to increase the compensation was taken. Further, the governing body shall take no action during the period of time beginning with the date that candidates for election to membership on the municipal governing body may first qualify as such candidates and ending with the date members of the municipal governing body take office following their election. No action shall be taken until notice of intent to take said action has been published in the legal organ of Clayton County, Georgia at least once a week for three (3) consecutive weeks immediately preceding the week during which the action is to be taken. 
(Ord. No. 88-017, 10-17-88) 
Sec. 2-1-32. - Annual compensation and monthly expense allowance for the mayor. 
(a)  The mayor shall receive an annual compensation that shall be set by resolution of the governing body, and shall be paid on a monthly basis. In any month that the mayor shall be absent without just cause from a regular meeting or a regular work session held during that month, then there shall be a deduction of ten (10) percent from the mayor's gross monthly compensation for that month for each regular meeting missed by the mayor without just cause that month, and a deduction of ten (10) percent from said gross compensation for each regular work session missed by the mayor without just cause that month. 
(b)  For purposes of this section, "just cause" shall mean and include an absence due to personal illness of the mayor or a member of the mayor's immediate family, an absence due to attending the funeral of an immediate family member, or any absence deemed justified and reasonable by a vote of the governing body. In all cases, the question of whether there was "just cause" for an absence shall be determined by a vote of the governing body based on information provided by the mayor. 
(c)  The mayor, in addition to his or her annual salary, shall receive payment up to an amount set by resolution of the governing body on a monthly basis so as to reimburse the mayor for expenses actually and necessarily incurred by the mayor for carrying out his or her duties during the preceding month. 
(Ord. No. 93-017, 7-6-93; Ord. No. 05-58, 9-6-2005; Ord. No. 05-59, § 1, 9-6-2005; Ord. No. 09-55, § 1, 10-19-2009) 
Sec. 2-1-33. - Compensation and expenses of members of the city council. 
(a)  Each member of the city council shall receive an annual compensation that shall be set by resolution of the governing body, and shall be paid on a monthly basis. In any month that a councilmember shall be absent without just cause from a regular meeting or a regular work session held during that month, then there shall be a deduction of ten (10) percent from the councilmember's gross monthly compensation for that month for each regular meeting missed by said councilmember without just cause that month, and a deduction of ten (10) percent from said gross compensation for each regular work session missed by said councilmember without just cause for that month. 
(b)  For purposes of this section, "just cause" shall mean and include an absence due to personal illness of the councilmember or a member of the councilmember's immediate family, an absence due to attending the funeral of an immediate family member, or any absence deemed justified and reasonable by a vote of the governing body. In all cases, the question of whether there was "just cause" for an absence shall be determined by a vote of the governing body based on information provided by the councilmember. 
(c)  Each member of the city council, in addition to his or her annual salary, shall receive payment up to an amount set by resolution of the governing body on a monthly basis so as to reimburse said councilmember for expenses actually and necessarily incurred by the councilmember for carrying out his or her duties during the preceding month. 
(Ord. No. 99-016, § 2, 9-7-99; Ord. No. 09-55, § 1, 10-19-2009) 
Secs. 2-1-34—2-1-40. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE E. - CODE OF ETHICS[6] 

Footnotes: 
--- (6) --- 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 12-37, § 1, adopted Dec. 21, 2012, repealed former Art. E, §§ 2-1-41—2-1-69, and enacted a new Art. E as set out herein. The former article pertained to similar subject matter and derived from Ord. No. 01-01, § 1, 3-19-2001; Ord. No. 01-04, 4-16-2001; Ord. No. 04-05, 1-20-2004; Ord. No. 04-10, § 1, 2-16-2004; Ord. No. 08-19, § 1, 5-5-2008. 

Sec. 2-1-41. - Purpose. 
The purpose of this Code of Ethics is to: 
(1)  Encourage ethical standards of official conduct by city officials; 
(2)  Establish guidelines for ethical standards of conduct for all such officials by setting forth those acts or actions that are incompatible with the interest of the city; 
(3)  Require disclosure by such officials of private financial or other interest in matters affecting the city; and 
(4)  Serve as a basis for disciplining those who do not abide by its terms. 
(Ord. No. 12-37, § 1, 12-21-2012) 
Sec. 2-1-42. - Scope. 
The provisions of this Code of Ethics shall be applicable to all elected or appointed city officials. Notwithstanding anything herein to the contrary, state law and the charter of the city shall be controlling in the event of an actual conflict with the provisions of this Code of Ethics. This article shall be interpreted to supplement, and not replace, said provisions of state law and the charter. 
(Ord. No. 12-37, § 1, 12-21-2012) 
Sec. 2-1-43. - Definitions. 
Solely for the purpose of this Code of Ethics: 
(1)  Board of ethics or board means the entity created by section 2-1-46 of this article. 
(2)  Business means any corporation, company, partnership, proprietorship, firm, enterprise, franchise, association, organization, self-employed individual, trust or other legal entity carrying on an enterprise for profit. 
(3)  Business transaction means to convey, acquire or lease (for compensation or by gratuity) any personal property, real property, or provide services (for compensation or by gratuity) on behalf of oneself or any third party as an agent, broker, dealer, or representative. 
(4)  City means the City of Forest Park. 
(5)  City employee means any person who is a full-time or part-time employee of the city. 
(6)  City official or official , unless otherwise expressly defined elsewhere, does not include city employees, but does mean the mayor and members of the city council. The term "city official" also includes all individuals, including city employees, appointed by the mayor and/or city council, as appropriate, to city authorities, commissions, committees, boards, task forces, or other bodies which can or may vote or take formal action or make official recommendations to the mayor and/or city council. 
(7)  Confidential information means any information which by law or practice is not available to the public. 
(8)  Consultant means any person not a member of the governing authority and who is not an employee of the city who is retained to render personal services of a technical or professional nature, whether paid or unpaid, and who has other personal or private employment. The term "consultant" includes, but is not limited to, attorneys, architects, engineers, surveyors, accountants, brokers, financial advisors, and title abstractors. 
(9)  Contract means any claim or demand against or any lease, account, or agreement with any person, whether express or implied, executed or executory, verbal, or in writing. 
(10)  Decision means any ordinance, resolution, contract, franchise, formal action or other matter voted on by the city council or other city board or commission, as well as the discussions or deliberations of the council, board, or commission which can or may lead to a vote or formal action by that body. 
(11)  Governing authority or city council means the mayor or any council member of the city. 
(12)  Immediate family means the spouse, mother, father, grandparent, brother, sister, son or daughter of any city official related by blood, adoption or marriage. The relationship by marriage shall include in-laws and step-children. 
(13)  Incidental interest means an interest of a person or entity, including a city official, which is acquired merely by chance or without intention or calculation, and which has insignificant value, if any. 
(14)  Interest means any direct pecuniary or gratuity benefit, which is not a remote interest, held by or accruing to a member of the governing authority or to a member of city authorities, commissions, committees, boards, task forces, or other bodies as a result of a contract or transaction which is or may be the subject of an official act or action by or with the city. All such members shall be deemed to have an interest in transactions involving: 
a.  Any person in the member's immediate family; 
b.  Any person with whom a contractual relationship exists whereby the member may receive any payment or other benefit unless the member is receiving a benefit for goods or services in the normal course of business for which the member has paid a commercially reasonable rate; 
c.  Any business in which the member is a director, officer, employee, or shareholder except as otherwise provided herein; or 
d.  Any person of whom the member is a creditor, whether secured or unsecured. 
(15)  Official act or action means any legislative, administrative, appointive, or discretionary act of a city official or official as defined in (6) above. 
(16)  Paid means the receipt of, or right to receive, a salary, a commission, a dividend, or percentage, brokerage, or contingent fee. 
(17)  Participate means to take part in official acts, actions, or proceedings personally as a city official or official through approval, disapproval, decision, discussion, recommendation, investigation, the rendering of advice or the failure to perform a duty or the failure to act; provided, however, abstention required by this article shall not be considered as participation. 
(18)  Person means any individual, business, labor organization, representative, fiduciary, trust, or association, whether paid or unpaid, and includes any city official or official. 
(19)  Property means any property, whether real or personal, or tangible or intangible, and includes currency and commercial paper. 
(20)  Remote interest means an interest of a person or entity, including a city official or official, which would be affected in the same way as the general public. This generally includes, but is not limited to, the adoption of the general budget and adoption or substantial revision of the land use plan or zoning ordinance of the city, the interest of an official in the property tax rate, general city fees, city garbage charges or similar matters. Such are deemed remote to the extent that the official would be affected in common with the general public. 
(21)  Substantial interest means an interest, either directly or indirectly, which is not a remote interest, which results in a pecuniary (monetary) or non-monetary benefit accruing to the official as a result of an official act or action taken by the official, involving a contract or other transaction with: 
a.  Any immediate family member; 
b.  Any business or entity in which the official receives compensation or other benefits in lieu of compensation; 
c.  Any business or entity where the official serves as a corporate officer or member of the board of directors or other governing board of a for-profit entity other than a corporate entity owned or created by the city council; or 
d.  Any person or entity in which the official is a creditor, debtor, or guarantor thereof. 
(22)  Transaction means the conduct of any activity that results in or may result in an official act or action by an official of the city. 
(Ord. No. 12-37, § 1, 12-21-2012) 
Sec. 2-1-44. - Prohibitions. 
(a)  No city official shall use such position to secure special privileges or exemptions for themselves or others, or to secure confidential information for any purpose other than in their official duties on behalf of the city. 
(b)  No city official, in any matter before the council or other city body, relating to a person or entity in which the official has a substantial interest, shall fail to disclose for the record, such interest prior to any discussion or vote or fail to recuse themselves from such discussion or vote as applicable. 
(c)  No city official shall act as an agent or attorney for another in any matter before the city council or other city body. 
(d)  No city official shall directly or indirectly receive, or agree to receive, any compensation, gift, reward, or gratuity in any matter or proceeding connected with, or related to, the duties of their office except as may be provided by law. 
(e)  No city official shall enter into any contract, or have any interest in, either directly or indirectly, any such contract, with the city except as authorized by state law. 
(1)  This prohibition shall not be applicable to the professional activities of the city attorney in their work as an independent contractor and legal advisor on behalf of the city. 
(2)  This prohibition shall not be applicable to an otherwise valid employment contract between the city and a city official who is not elected (such as, by way of example, a city manager, city administrator or chief of police). 
(3)  This prohibition shall not apply in the case of the designation of a bank or trust company as a depository for city funds. 
(4)  This prohibition shall not apply in the case of borrowing of funds from any bank or lending institution which offers the lowest available rate of interest in the community for such loan. 
(5)  This prohibition shall not apply in the case of contracts entered into in accordance with O.C.G.A. § 16-10-6 (Sale of real or personal property) as now or hereafter amended. 
(6)  This prohibition shall not apply in the case of contracts for services which are awarded pursuant to sealed competitive bids subsequent to an advertised competitive bid process in accordance with the purchasing ordinance of the city. 
(7)  This prohibition shall not apply in the case of contracts with former city officials except that the city shall not enter into any contract with, or take any official act or action favorably affecting, any person, or business represented by a former city official when such person has been a city official within the twenty-four-month period preceding such action, unless: 
a.  The city had a contract with such person or business prior to the member leaving office; 
b.  The business received the contract for having the lowest and best bid pursuant to the purchasing procedures established by the city and the city official did not represent the business in its discussions with or submissions to the mayor and council; or 
c.  The contract is an exception recognized under this section of the ethics ordinance. 
(8)  Any official who has a proprietary interest in an agency doing business with the city shall make that interest known verbally on the record or in writing to the city council and the city clerk prior to any discussion or vote related to such agency. 
(f)  All public funds shall be used for the general welfare of the people and not for personal economic or political gain. 
(g)  Public property shall be disposed of in accordance with state law. 
(h)  No city official shall solicit or accept other employment to be performed, or compensation or gratuity to be received, while still a city official if the employment or compensation or gratuity could reasonably be expected to impair or call into question such official's judgment or performance of city duties. 
(i)  If a city official accepts or is soliciting a promise of future employment from any person or entity who has a substantial interest in a person, entity or property which would be affected by any decision upon which the official might reasonably be expected to act, investigate, advise, or make a recommendation, the official shall disclose the fact to the city council and shall recuse themselves and take no further action on matters regarding the potential future employer. 
(j)  No city official shall use city facilities, personnel, equipment, or supplies for private or political purposes, except to the extent such are lawfully available to the public. 
(k)  No city official shall grant or make available to any person any consideration, treatment, advantage, or favor beyond that which it is the general practice of the city to grant or make available to the public at large. 
(l)  A city official shall not directly or indirectly make use of, or permit others to make use of, official information not made available to the general public, for the purpose of furthering a private interest. 
(m)  A city official shall not use their position in any way to coerce, or give the appearance of coercing, another person to provide any financial or any other benefit to such official or persons within the official's immediate family, or those with whom the official has business or financial ties amounting to a substantial interest. 
(n)  A city official shall not order any goods and services for the city, nor shall a city official attempt to or obligate the city or give the impression of obligating the city to any obligation whatsoever without proper prior authorization. 
(o)  No city official shall draw travel funds or per diem from the city for attendance at meetings, seminars, training, or other educational events, and fail to attend such events without promptly reimbursing the city therefor. 
(p)  No city official shall attempt to unduly influence the outcome of a case before the municipal court of the city nor shall any city official engage in ex parte communication with a municipal court judge of the city on any matter pending before the municipal court of the city. 
(q)  No city official shall, by such member's conduct, give reasonable basis for the impression that any person can improperly influence or unduly enjoy favor in the performance of official acts or actions by the official or that such member is affected unduly by the rank or position of or kinship or association with any person. 
(r)  No city official shall directly or indirectly request, exact, receive, or agree to receive a gift, loan, favor, promise, or thing of value for him/herself or another person if it could reasonably be considered to influence the member in the discharge of their official duties. This section shall not apply in the case of: 
(1)  A non-pecuniary gift of insignificant value (value of twenty-five dollars ($25.00) or less); 
(2)  An award publicly presented in recognition of public service; 
(3)  A transaction authorized by and performed in accordance with O.C.G.A. § 16-10-6 (Sale of real or personal property) as now or hereafter amended; 
(4)  A commercially reasonable loan or other financial transaction made in the ordinary course of business by an institution or individual authorized by the laws of Georgia to engage in the making of such a loan or financial transaction; and 
(5)  Campaign contributions made and reported in accordance with Georgia law. 
(s)  Except as required by Georgia's Open Records Act (O.C.G.A. § 50-18-90 et seq.) or other properly enacted statutory authority, no city official, whether paid or unpaid, shall disseminate nonpublic information or undisclosable information concerning the property, governing operations, policies, decisions, plans, or affairs of the city, nor shall such official use such information or any information acquired in his/her official capacity to advance his/her financial or personal or political interest or that of others under any circumstances. 
(t)  No city official shall engage in any activity or transaction that is prohibited by law now existing or hereafter enacted which is applicable to him/her by virtue of being a city official. 
(u)  No city official shall use his/her superior position to require an employee of the city to: 
(1)  Do clerical work on behalf of his/her family, business, social, church, or fraternal interests; 
(2)  Purchase goods or services to be used for personal, business, or political purposes; and 
(3)  Work for him/her personally without paying him/her just compensation. 
(v)  No city official shall use city property of any kind for purposes other than officially approved activities, nor shall he/she direct employees to use such property for these purposes or any other purposes. 
(Ord. No. 12-37, § 1, 12-21-2012) 
Sec. 2-1-45. - Conflict of interest. 
(a)  A city official may not participate in a vote or decision or discussion on any matter affecting an immediate family member or any person, entity, or property in which the official has a substantial interest. 
(b)  A city official who serves as a corporate officer or member of the board of directors of a nonprofit entity must disclose their interest in said entity to the mayor and city council prior to participating in a vote or decision or discussion regarding funding of the entity by or through the city. 
(c)  No city official shall engage in, accept employment with, or render services for any private business or professional activity when such employment or rendering of services is adverse to and incompatible with the proper discharge of official duties of the official. For the purposes of this paragraph, the employment of a city official as a consultant by any business involving matters unrelated to any contract or transaction by or with the city shall not be deemed incompatible with such official's official duties. 
(d)  Where the interest of a city official in the subject matter of a vote or decision or discussion is remote or incidental, the city official may participate in the vote or decision or discussion, and need not disclose the interest. 
(e)  Any city official who has an interest which said official has reason to believe may be affected by such official's acts or actions or by the official acts or actions of the city shall disclose the precise nature and value of such interest prior to the city officials taking official action on a matter affecting such interest by making a verbal statement on the record or by providing a sworn written statement to the city council and the city clerk. Such statements shall be deemed a public record. Further, such official shall abstain from participating in any official acts or actions related to such interest. 
(f)  Any city official who has an ongoing relationship with a business or individual arising out of the normal course of commerce for which such official receives compensation at a commercially reasonable rate, shall disclose such relationship if the city has or can be reasonably anticipated to purchase goods or services from such business or individual. A disclosure of such relationship shall be made once each year during the month of January on a disclosure form provided by the city clerk. Such disclosure shall describe the nature of the relationship, the official and other parties in the relationship, and the financial interest of the official in such relationship. Such disclosure forms shall be kept on file in city hall by the city clerk and shall be deemed a public record. 
(Ord. No. 12-37, § 1, 12-21-2012) 
Sec. 2-1-46. - Board of ethics. 
(a)  Creation; qualification of members. There is hereby created a board of ethics (the "board") consisting of five (5) members who are residents of the city, and have been residents of the city for at least one (1) year immediately preceding the date of being appointed to the board, and shall remain residents of the city while serving as a member of the board. Members of the board shall not be elected officials, persons appointed to elective office, full-time appointed officials whether exempt or nonexempt, or city employees, nor shall they be currently serving on any other board or commission or authority of the city. Further: 
(1)  No person shall serve as a member of the board if the person has, or has had within the preceding one-year period, any interest in any contract or contracting opportunity with the city or has been employed by the city. 
(2)  Members of the board with any matter pending before the city, or any pending or potential litigation against the city or any city official charged in the complaint, shall be disqualified from serving on the board for that complaint. In such an event, the mayor and council shall qualify and appoint an alternate member of the board to serve in the place of the disqualified individual, for that complaint only. 
(3)  No person shall serve on the board who has been convicted of a felony involving moral turpitude (an offense that is contrary to justice, honesty, modesty, good morals, or man's duty to man) in this state or any other state, unless such person's civil rights have been restored and at least five (5) years have elapsed from the date of the restoration of such rights. 
(4)  No person shall serve on the board who is less than twenty-one (21) years of age or who is physically or mentally unable to discharge the duties of a member of the board, or who is not qualified to be a registered voter in the city. 
(5)  Upon appointment, members of the board shall sign an affidavit attesting to their qualification to serve as a member of the board of ethics. 
(6)  Members of the board serve at the pleasure of the mayor and council, and may be removed by majority vote of the mayor and council, with or without cause. 
(b)  Composition of board; term of office. Each member of the board shall be appointed by the mayor and council, with one (1) member being from each of the five (5) wards of the city. Members appointed to the board from odd wards (1, 3, and 5) shall have an initial term of two (2) years, and those appointed from even wards (2 and 4) shall have an initial term of three (3) years. Successors to the first members of the board and all future successors thereof shall be appointed for two-year terms upon the expiration of their respective terms of office. All members of the board shall serve until their successors are appointed. No person may serve more than three (3) consecutive terms as a member of the board. 
(c)  Presiding officer and other officers. The board shall select its own presiding officer, and any other officers it feels are necessary, from among its members. 
(d)  Vacancy; removal from board. A vacancy of the board shall exist by reason of death, resignation, loss of ward and/or city residency, or removal by the mayor and council. If a member of the board ceases to be a resident of the ward for which they were appointed or of the city, that member's position on the board shall become vacant. If a member's residency is contested, the member's position on the board, by operation of law, shall become vacant upon the establishment of the fact of such non-residency by a court of competent jurisdiction. A member of the board challenged on the basis of non-residency in the city or ward shall file an affidavit with the city clerk within thirty (30) days of receiving the challenge, setting forth the facts supporting the residency of such member. A member of the board may also be removed from the board during a term if the member becomes ineligible to hold civil office within the meaning of O.C.G.A. § 45-2-1 and that ineligibility is established by a decision of a court of competent jurisdiction which declares the office vacant because of such ineligibility. Any vacancy on the board shall be filled for the unexpired term or new term by the mayor and council qualifying and appointing a person residing in the respective ward of the vacancy. 
(e)  Staff; legal advisor. The mayor and council shall provide such staff support for the board as they determine to be necessary for the board to fulfill its duties. The city attorney is hereby designated to be the legal advisor for the board, except that the city attorney is not authorized to represent the board in any legal action if doing so would create a conflict which would prevent the city attorney from also representing the mayor, the city council, or the city manager. The city clerk shall serve as recording secretary to the board and shall provide such administrative services to the board as may be necessary. Neither the city attorney nor the city clerk shall be eligible for appointment as members of the board. 
(f)  Compensation of members of the board of ethics. The presiding officer of the board shall receive compensation in the amount of one hundred dollars ($100.00) per meeting. Other members of the board shall receive compensation in the amount of seventy-five dollars ($75.00) per meeting. 
(g)  Duties and powers of the board. 
(1)  The board shall have the following duties and powers: 
a.  Adopt written rules governing its procedures and providing for the holding of regular and special meetings, which rules shall be subject to the approval of the city council, and a copy of the rules, if any, shall be filed with the city clerk; 
b.  Administer oaths; 
c.  Conduct hearings as needed to hear and decide specific cases in which a violation of this article is alleged, whether such cases arise from a complaint or are brought on the board's own motion; 
d.  When it deems it appropriate, request the city attorney for assistance in compelling the production of documents and witnesses to assist the board in the conduct of any investigation; 
e.  When circumstances make it necessary to do so, request outside legal counsel, a hearing officer or panel, and other experts as needed after solicitation of recommendations from the city attorney (unless the need to retain outside counsel is caused by a conflict involving the city attorney's office), which must first be approved by the city council, who, upon approval, shall enter into a contract for such services. 
f.  Serve as legal custodian of the board's records, and accept, file, maintain, and administer, in accordance with all applicable laws, any information related to the purposes of this article; 
g.  File all open opinions of the board with the city clerk, which shall be open to public inspection. To the extent permitted by law, confidential opinions and any records obtained or filed in connection with requests for confidential opinions, whether the records are written, tape recorded, videotaped, or otherwise recorded, shall be kept confidential; and confidential advisory opinions rendered shall be closed in whole to public inspection. Confidential opinions and summaries of them or open references to them shall be drafted in such a way as not to reveal confidential information; 
h.  In coordination with the city attorney and other appropriate personnel of the city, ensure that each member attends or has attended a workshop on ethics as conducted by the city attorney. Attendance at this workshop is a condition of service as a member of the board, and, each board member shall commit themselves to attend the workshop within ninety (90) days of taking office. 
(2)  The board does not have the authority to reverse or otherwise modify a prior action of the city council or an officer or employee of the city. If the board finds a prior action of the city council, officer or employee to have been ethically improper, the board shall render an initial decision advising that the action should be reconsidered. 
(Ord. No. 12-37, § 1, 12-21-2012) 
Sec. 2-1-47. - Receipt of complaints. 
(a)  Who may request board action. 
(1)  Any person or persons may file a complaint with the board, by filing the complaint with the city clerk, against any city official, prospective city official, or former city official, either personally or on behalf of an organization. 
(2)  Any request for board action shall be in writing and signed under oath by the person or persons making the complaint, and shall be legibly drawn. Further, the complaint shall specify the provisions of this article alleged to have been violated, with specific and detailed facts alleged to constitute a violation of this article. 
(3)  There shall be a filing fee in an amount established by the city council, from time to time, for each ethics complaint filed with the board, with said fee being initially set at fifty dollars ($50.00). Said filing fee must be paid in advance before any ethics complaint is received or accepted for consideration by the board. If the ethics complaint is sustained, in full or in part, then the filing fee shall be refunded to the complaining party. However, if the ethics complaint is denied or dismissed, then the filing fee shall be retained by the city to help defray administrative costs associated with processing the ethics complaint. 
(4)  After a complaint has been filed and during the pendency of a complaint before the board, no member of the board may communicate directly or indirectly with any party or other person about anything regarding the complaint, except that: 
a.  The members of the board may obtain legal advice from the city attorney; 
b.  The members of the board may discuss the complaint at a lawfully conducted meeting. 
c.  If any person attempts to communicate with a board member regarding the pending complaint, the board member shall report the substance of the communication to the board on the public record at the next regular meeting of the board, and the board may take any actions it deems appropriate under the circumstances to deter such communications. 
(b)  Procedures for hearing ethics complaint. 
(1)  Upon receipt of such a complaint, but in any event not later than three (3) business days after receipt thereof, the city clerk shall date-stamp receipt of the complaint and forward the complaint simultaneously to the board, the person against whom the complaint is filed, and the city attorney. 
(2)  The city attorney shall provide the board with a preliminary written analysis of the ethics complaint no later than thirty (30) days from the date the complaint is filed with the city clerk. 
(3)  During any investigation and during any hearing which is conducted to determine whether a violation of this article has occurred: 
a.  The person under investigation or the accused may be represented by counsel of his or her own choosing and expense; and 
b.  The accused or his or her representative, if any, shall have an opportunity to: 
1.  Challenge the sufficiency of any complaint which has been filed against him or her; 
2.  Bring witnesses to testify on their behalf and offer any other evidence on their behalf; 
3.  Establish all pertinent facts and circumstances related to the complaint; 
4.  Question or refute testimony or evidence, including the opportunity to confront and cross-examine adverse witnesses; and 
5.  To the extent the board or its appointed hearing officer or panel, in their discretion, determines it to be just and reasonable under the given circumstances of each complaint, the accused may conduct pretrial discovery in the manner usually available in civil actions, however, such discovery shall be limited to interrogatories and requests for production of documents. 
(4)  The following principles shall apply to evidence taken and presented in connection with hearings conducted by the board: 
a.  The board shall not be bound to adhere strictly to the statutory rules of evidence, except that hearsay, verbally or written, shall not be admissible into evidence, and the board shall be fundamentally fair in its administration of evidence; 
b.  During any hearing conducted by the board to determine whether a violation of this article has occurred, all evidence, including certified copies of records, which the board considers shall be fully offered and made a part of the record in the proceedings; 
c.  The accused or any other person under investigation shall be afforded adequate opportunity to rebut or offer countervailing evidence; 
d.  The board shall inform the accused or his or her counsel of any and all exculpatory evidence in its possession; and 
e.  The standard of proof in hearings conducted under this article shall be the preponderance of the evidence admitted at the hearing. 
(5)  The board, in addition to its other duties and powers, may: 
a.  Appoint a hearing officer or a panel consisting of three (3) members, who must first be approved by the city council, to conduct hearings under this article; 
b.  With the approval of the city council, retain outside legal counsel and other experts as needed with respect to hearings in accordance with its policies. Any contract regarding the selection and retaining of a hearing officer or panel or retaining of outside counsel and other experts, shall be made after solicitation of recommendations from the city attorney and upon approval by the city council of a contract for services approved as to form by the city attorney; 
c.  Order testimony to be taken by deposition before an authorized court reporter by any individual who is designated by the board and, in such instances, to compel testimony and the production of evidence to the extent it is otherwise lawfully authorized to do so, by having document and/or witness subpoenas issued by the judge of the municipal court. Further the board may, upon request of the accused, on its own motion, or upon request of the complainant(s) or city attorney, the board may have the judge of the municipal court issue subpoenas to compel the attendance of witnesses who are necessary for the hearing; 
d.  Require any person to submit in writing such reports and answers to questions relevant to the proceedings conducted under this article as the board may prescribe, such submission to be made within such period and under oath or otherwise as the board may determine; and 
e.  Request and obtain from the department of revenue copies of state income tax returns and access to other appropriate information as permitted under state law regarding all persons who are the subject of such complaint and investigation. 
(6)  The person against whom the complaint is filed, shall have ten (10) days from the day the city clerk received the complaint, to submit a written response to the complaint prior to the board deciding whether to hold a hearing. 
a.  If the ethics complaint is dismissed, the complainant(s) who filed the ethics complaint shall have only one (1) opportunity, within fifteen (15) days of the dismissal, to amend and re-file the ethics complaint with the board. 
b.  If the complainant(s) who filed the ethics complaint fail to amend and re-file their dismissed ethics complaint within fifteen (15) days of the date of dismissal, then the complainant(s) shall be forever barred from bringing the dismissed accusation(s) against the accused again. 
(7)  Within ten (10) days following receipt of the city attorney's analysis, the board shall review and consider the ethics complaint and the city attorney's analysis, and, determine, solely in the board's opinion, if a hearing should be held. If the board determine that a hearing should be held, then the board shall set a date certain for the hearing to take place within forty (40) days of receipt of the analysis from the city attorney, unless the accused petitions for and the board consents to a later date. 
(c)  Decision of board. 
(1)  As soon as practicable after giving due consideration to the ethics complaint, or, if a hearing was held, within thirty (30) days after the hearing, the board shall take any action or combination of actions which it deems appropriate and which it is lawfully empowered to take, including, but not limited to the following: 
a.  Dismiss the complaint based on one (1) or more of the following grounds: 
1.  The complaint does not allege facts sufficient to constitute a violation of this article; 
2.  The board has no jurisdiction over the matter complained of in the complaint; 
3.  Failure of the complainant to cooperate in the board's review and consideration of the complaint; and 
4.  The complaint is defective in a manner which results in the board being unable to make any sound determination as to the occurrence of an ethics violation. 
5.  However, a rejection or dismissal of a complaint by the board of ethics shall not deprive the complaining party of any action such party might otherwise have at law or in equity against the city official. 
b.  Determine that no violation of this article has occurred; 
c.  Determine that the complaint alleges facts sufficient to constitute a violation of this article and that the board will conduct a hearing, in which case the board shall promptly send written notice of such determination to the accused and to the party who made the complaint; 
d.  Determine that further information must be obtained in order for the board to determine whether the complaint alleges facts sufficient to constitute a violation of the article; or 
e.  Schedule the complaint for further review and consideration at a future time certain, in which case the board shall promptly send written notice of such determination to the accused and to the party who made the complaint. 
(2)  After it has made its decision, the board shall issue its written findings of fact and conclusions in the form of an initial decision, and may issue any additional reports, opinions and recommendations as it deems advisable under the circumstances, to the city council. All such reports shall be reviewed by the city attorney prior to their issuance to the city council. 
(3)  Once a decision has been rendered by the board, either the complainant or the accused shall have thirty (30) days to request a review of the board's decision by the city council. In absence of an application for review to the city council within thirty (30) days from the date of notice of the board's decision, the board decision shall, without further proceedings, become the decision of the city council, and shall be rendered in writing, affirming the board's decision, within thirty (30) days of the date the request for review would have expired. In the event the city council receives a request for review of the board's decision within the time period prescribed, the city council shall review the board's decision and the record of the board's hearing and render its decision in writing, either affirming the board's decision or reversing the board's decision, within thirty (30) days of receipt of the request for review. However, the city council, may extend such period in any case in which it finds that the complexity of the issues and the length of the record require an extension of the period, and in such an event the city council shall render a decision within ninety (90) days of receipt of the request for review. A copy of the city council's decision shall be promptly mailed to each party or their attorney of record. 
(d)  Statute of limitations. No action shall be taken on any complaint which is filed more than six (6) months after a violation of this Article is alleged to have occurred, and a complaint alleging a violation must be filed within six (6) months from the date the complainant(s) knew or should have known of the action alleged to be a violation of this article. 
(e)  Penalties . Any person[s] violating any provision of this article shall be subject to: 
(1)  A written and oral reprimand by the city council, requiring an apology to the public; 
(2)  A fine not to exceed five hundred dollars ($500.00) for a first offense and not to exceed one thousand dollars ($1,000.00) for each subsequent offense; 
(3)  A request for resignation; 
(4)  A suspension, without pay, of not less than thirty (30) days and not more than ninety (90) days; and/or 
(5)  Removal from office upon the affirmative vote of three (3) members of the city council, with the mayor casting a vote in the event of a tie vote. However, if the individual is an elected official, such removal shall not occur until after notice has been given and a hearing has been held in accordance with the city's charter, and upon the affirmative vote of three (3) members of the city council, with the mayor casting a vote in the event of a tie vote. 
(6)  The penalties prescribed in this article shall be cumulative and not exclusive of each other or of any other penalties which may be imposed pursuant to any other laws or policies of the state or city. 
(f)  Appeals . 
(1)  Any city official or complainant adversely affected by a final decision of the city council may obtain judicial review of such decision as provided in this section: 
a.  Any final decision by the city council shall be reviewable by the Superior Court of Clayton County. The review by the superior court shall be limited to an inquiry of whether there was any evidence before the city council which supported the decision of the city council, provided, however, no action of the city council shall be reviewable by the superior court if neither party requests the city council to review the decision of the board.
