b.  An action for judicial review shall be commenced by filing an application for a writ of certiorari in the Superior Court of Clayton County, within thirty (30) days after the decision of the city council. 
c.  Any penalties imposed by the city council shall not be stayed during the pendency of the judicial review provided for in this section. 
(2)  There shall be a filing fee in an amount established by the city council, from time to time, for each city council decision which is appealed to the Superior Court of Clayton County, with said fee being initially set at two hundred and fifty dollars ($250.00) to help defray administrative costs associated with preparing the record for appeal. 
(3)  The provisions of this article are to be construed liberally, to the end that the public interest be fully protected, and shall be construed in a manner consistent with all applicable federal and state laws and applicable provisions of the city charter. In the event of a conflict between any provision of this article and any applicable federal, state or city charter provision which does not expressly provide otherwise, the federal, state or city charter provision shall control. To the extent permitted by law, all ordinances, resolutions or rules, and parts of ordinances, resolutions or rules inconsistent with this article are hereby repealed. Further, the propriety of any official act or action taken by or transaction involving any city official prior to the effective date of this article shall not be affected by the enactment of this article. 
(Ord. No. 12-37, § 1, 12-21-2012) 
Secs. 2-1-48—2-1-90. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE F. - PAYMENT OF TRAVEL EXPENSES FOR MAYOR AND COUNCIL 

Sec. 2-1-91. - Purpose. 
This legislation is enacted to set forth guidelines for the payment and/or reimbursement of expenses incurred by the mayor and council in connection with travel for required training or other business activity which is directly related to or required for the carrying out of their duties for the city. It is the intent of this legislation to ensure that its elected officials are fully reimbursed for any and all reasonable out-of-pocket expenses paid by them in connection with the business of the city. 
(Ord. No. 99-013, § 1, 8-2-99; Ord. No. 01-01, § 2, 3-19-2001; Ord. No. 11-41, § 1, 10-17-2011) 
Sec. 2-1-92. - General requirements. 
(a)  The city shall make all necessary hotel accommodations for the mayor and members of council when such is required, upon request. 
(b)  Travel within the State of Georgia shall be by personal vehicle, and the city shall pay mileage based upon the prevailing rate established by the Internal Revenue Service. All trip mileage shall be calculated using the city's City Hall as the starting and returning point, and shall be paid in advance for each such trip. 
(c)  Should travel outside the State of Georgia be required, the city shall make reservations and pay for all air travel, at coach fare. All such air travel should be scheduled sufficiently in advance in order to take advantage of any discount fares whenever possible. 
(d)  The city shall pay for all lodging, parking, valet service, and registration fees, if any, for all officials. 
(Ord. No. 99-013, § 1, 8-2-99; Ord. No. 01-01, § 2, 3-19-2001; Ord. No. 11-41, § 1, 10-17-2011) 
Sec. 2-1-93. - Reimbursable expenses. 
It is intended for the city to pay all known and required expenses for the officials so as to minimize the need for reimbursement. However, in the event an official incurs a necessary expense in connection with the business they are transacting on behalf of the city, then such expense shall be reimbursable and paid by the city. 
(Ord. No. 99-013, § 1, 8-2-99; Ord. No. 01-01, § 2, 3-19-2001; Ord. No. 11-41, § 1, 10-17-2011) 
Sec. 2-1-94. - Per diem. 
(a)  Officials shall receive a per diem as may be established from time to time by the mayor and council, which is related to official business for the city. Said per diem shall be established as a part of the city's annual budgetary process, and shall not exceed a reasonable amount that would be needed for subsistence expenses such as three (3) meals per day and tipping while attending the training, seminar, conference, or other business activity related to official business for the city. 
(b)  Until changed or modified, the per diem is established at ninety dollars ($90.00) per day. Such per diem is to minimize any out-of-pocket expenses of the elected officials and shall be included as income on the officials' W-2 forms. 
(Ord. No. 99-013, § 1, 8-2-99; Ord. No. 01-01, § 2, 3-19-2001; Ord. No. 11-41, § 1, 10-17-2011) 
Sec. 2-1-95. - Nonreimbursable expenses. 
Expenditures for rental cars, entertainment, and any expenses incurred for personal activities and personal uses while on city business are not reimbursable. Further, the city shall not reimburse an official for any expenses incurred for a spouse or other companion. 
(Ord. No. 99-013, § 1, 8-2-99; Ord. No. 01-01, § 2, 3-19-2001; Ord. No. 11-41, § 1, 10-17-2011) 
CHAPTER 2. - ELECTIONS[7] 

Footnotes: 
--- (7) --- 
State Law reference— Georgia Municipal Elections, O.C.G.A., Title 21, Ch. 3. 

Sec. 2-2-1. - Election officials. 
The mayor and council shall by resolution annually appoint a municipal election superintendent, election managers, registrars, absentee ballot clerk and any other officials as are necessary, all of whom shall exercise those powers and duties set forth in the Georgia Municipal Election Code (O.C.G.A., Title 21, Chapter 3), as now or hereafter amended. 
State Law reference— Municipal powers, etc., O.C.G.A., §§ 21-3-8, 21-3-31, 21-3-32, 21-3-120, 21-3-227(b), 21-3-251 and 21-3-283. 
Sec. 2-2-2. - Voter registration deadline. 
The deadline for registration of voters in city elections shall be as set forth in the Official Code of Georgia Annotated, Section 21-3-126(b)(1), as it now exists or is hereafter amended. 
(Ord. No. 93-024, 11-15-93) 
State Law reference— Registration, O.C.G.A., § 21-3-126. 
Sec. 2-2-3. - Notice of candidacy; filing dates. 
Notices of candidacy shall be filed by candidates for offices of the governing authority not sooner than 52 days prior to the election in the case of a general election and not sooner than 30 days prior to the election in the case of a special election. The deadline for filing the foregoing notices of candidacy shall be 22 days prior to the election in the case of a general election; and 15 days prior to the election in the case of a special election. Notices of candidacy shall be filed in the office of the municipal election superintendent during normal business hours. 
State Law reference— Filing notice of candidacy, O.C.G.A., § 21-3-91. 
Sec. 2-2-4. - Qualification fees. 
The qualification fee for candidates filing a notice of candidacy in any general or special election shall be three percent (3%) of the annual compensation of the office sought, which fees shall be received by the municipal election superintendent at the time of filing the notice of candidacy and paid over to the city. 
State Law reference— Qualification fees, O.C.G.A., § 21-3-90. 
Sec. 2-2-5. - Polling place. 
The polling place shall be as fixed from time to time by resolution of the mayor and council. 
State Law reference— Polling places, O.C.G.A., § 21-3-163. 
CHAPTER 3. - ADMINISTRATION 
ARTICLE A. - GENERAL PROVISIONS[8] 

Footnotes: 
--- (8) --- 
State Law reference— Loyalty oath required of municipal officers and employees, O.C.G.A., § 45-3-11 et seq. 

Sec. 2-3-1. - Departments established. 
(a)  The following departments of the city are hereby established: 
(1)  Police; 
(2)  Finance; 
(3)  Public works; 
(4)  Parks and recreation; 
(5)  Public services; 
(6)  Fire; and 
(7)  Technology services. 
(b)  Each department may be headed by a director who shall exercise such powers and perform such duties as provided by law or as prescribed from time to time by the city manager. Department directors shall report to the city manager. 
(Ord. No. 17-11, § 1, 3-20-2017) 
Sec. 2-3-2. - City manager. 
(a)  The position of city manager is hereby created. The city manager shall devote his time and attention to the affairs of the city and shall be responsible to the mayor and council for the efficient administration of all the affairs of the city over which he has jurisdiction. 
(b)  The city manager may, in consultation with each agency and department of the city, propose written agency or department rules and regulations, or amendments thereto, to organize and operate each agency or department of the city in the most efficient manner reasonably possible, consistent with the charter and ordinances of the city. 
(c)  The city manager may propose written rules and regulations, or amendments thereto, for city government wide application on subjects under the city manager's responsibilities to organize and operate the city in the most efficient manner reasonably possible, consistent with the charter and ordinances of the city. 
(d)  All such rules and regulations, or amendments thereto, shall become effective thirty (30) days after being sent to the mayor and council for review unless, by motion, such rules and regulations are disapproved in whole or in part within such time by the mayor and council. 
(e)  All such rules and regulations may be amended by a resolution of the mayor and council. 
Sec. 2-3-3. - City clerk. 
(a)  The city clerk, in his dual capacity as clerk and treasurer of the city, shall: 
(1)  Issue warrants, summons, receipts, executions, and other processes in the name of the city. 
(2)  Maintain an accurate and legible minute book in which is recorded every official act of the governing body and reveals which persons were present. The minute book shall be in sufficient detail to allow ready reference and shall reflect the proper adoption of resolutions, motions and ordinances as required by law. 
(3)  Be the official custodian of city records. 
(4)  Be the tax collector for the city. 
(5)  Be the official custodian of city property, real and personal, seeing that it is maintained, insured and protected. 
(6)  Receive, collect, and deposit all funds due the city from every source. 
(7)  Maintain the city's bank accounts and see that no withdrawal or payment is made from same except as authorized by the governing body. 
(8)  Pay the legitimate and due bills of the city taking advantage at all times of discounts. 
(9)  Require adherence to the city budget unless deviation is authorized by the governing body. 
(10)  Require the finance director to provide monthly reports of every account and claim payable to the city which has remained unpaid for thirty (30) days after the same became due. 
(11)  Perform such other duties and functions as are required by the code of ordinances, and the motions and resolutions of the governing body. 
(b)  The city clerk shall delegate to such deputies, as authorized by the governing authority, such of his duties as good judgment dictates should be so delegated. 
(Code 1959, § 2-6) 
Sec. 2-3-4. - Monies belonging to city; receipt and deposit. 
In accordance with Georgia law, all funds received by officers and employees of the city shall be properly receipted and promptly deposited into the appropriate account under the direction of the director of finance. 
Sec. 2-3-5. - Collection of money due the city. 
The city manager is authorized to engage the services of any reputable collection agency to collect money due the city and to compensate the agency or agencies as is customary in the trade whenever in his judgment such services are the most advantageous to collect the money. 
(Code 1959, § 2-71) 
Sec. 2-3-6. - Bonds required of certain officers and employees. 
Any elected official, appointed officer or employee who, in the course of his duties, handles funds belonging to the city, shall give good and sufficient bond to the city, in accordance with applicable administrative regulations, conditioned upon the faithful performance and discharge of his duties, and for proper application of all monies or property coming into his hands by virtue of his office or employment in an amount as established by the mayor and council. 
Sec. 2-3-7. - Use of city labor or property for private purposes. 
It shall be unlawful to use, furnish, cause or permit any city labor or property to be used or furnished for the benefit of anyone except the city, unless such use is authorized by the governing body and entered on the minutes. 
(Code 1959, § 2-27) 
Sec. 2-3-8. - Code enforcement. 
(a)  There is hereby created within the City of Forest Park a position known as "code enforcement officer." 
(b)  The duties of the code enforcement officer shall be as follows: 
(1)  The enforcement of all ordinances contained within the Code of Ordinances for the City of Forest Park. 
(2)  To issue citations for violations of said Code of Ordinances, in order to insure compliance with said Code. 
a.  Any person found to be in violation of said ordinance may receive a warning citation in the first instance, 
b.  In the event said violation is not corrected, the code enforcement officer shall then cite that person for violation of said ordinance, 
c.  Any citations issued by the code enforcement officer shall contain a summons and shall be prosecuted as set forth in section 2-5-4 et seq. of the Code of Ordinances of the City of Forest Park. 
(c)  Retention of authority. Each and every department head, where otherwise authorized to do so, shall retain their individual authority to cite persons for violations of same, and nothing contained herein shall in any manner delete or remove any authority given to any other person pursuant to the Code of Ordinances of the City of Forest Park. Further, the position of code enforcement officer and the authority to cite persons for violations of the code is created in order to provide an additional source by which persons found to be in violation of any part or parts of the code of ordinances shall be compelled to comply with same. 
(Ord. No. 87-014, 8-7-87) 
Sec. 2-3-9. - Use of credit card to pay monies due city. 
(a)  All sums due to the city including, but not limited to, ad valorem taxes, occupation taxes, fines, forfeitures, penalties, license fees, permit fees and registration fees, may be paid by the use of credit cards. The city finance director, with the approval of the city manager, shall establish the procedures for acceptance of credit card payments for amounts due the city. The mayor is authorized to enter into agreements with credit card issuers to facilitate the acceptance of credit card payments by the city. 
(b)  A credit card agreement may provide for the acceptance of the credit card payments from the credit card company at a discount from the face amount of the payment or for the withholding of administrative fees from the face amount of the payment. Such discounted fee is granted in exchange for the improved governmental cash flow, reduction of administrative expenses and increased public convenience as a result of credit card payments. 
(c)  A surcharge equal to the administrative fees charged by the credit card issuer to the city shall be imposed upon any person making a payment by credit card, when such surcharges are permitted by the operating rules and regulations of credit card issuer. 
(d)  Any agreement with a credit card issuer for the acceptance of payments via credit shall contain a provision that the agreement may be canceled at any time by the city. 
(e)  No person making payment by credit card to the city is relieved from liability from the underlying obligation except to the extent that the city actually receives final payment of the obligation in cash or its equivalent. If final payment is not made by the credit card issuer or other guarantor of payment in the credit card transaction, the unpaid amount shall be due from the person making the payment by credit card. 
Such penalties, interest and fees on an unpaid amount shall accrue from the date the unpaid obligation was first due under the applicable statute or ordinance. The city shall follow the collection procedure for the unpaid amount that would otherwise have been applicable had the credit card payment not been attempted. 
(Ord. No. 99-014, § 1, 8-2-99) 
Secs. 2-3-10—2-3-20. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE B. - PUBLIC RECORDS[9] 

Footnotes: 
--- (9) --- 
Cross reference— Records of traffic violations bureau, § 2-5-23. 

Sec. 2-3-21. - Official records of city; keeping and maintaining. 
It shall be the policy of the governing body to make each and every record kept and maintained by the governing body and the officers, agents, and employees of the city available to the public for reading, inspecting, examining and copying the same, provided that those records which by order of a court of this state or by law are prohibited from being open to inspection by the public shall be exempt from the provisions of this article. 
Sec. 2-3-22. - Custodian designated. 
The city clerk is hereby made the official custodian of the records of the city, including records made by its officers, agents and employees of every nature whatsoever. 
(Code 1959, § 2-14) 
Sec. 2-3-23. - Removal from city hall restricted. 
The custodian of the records of the city shall not allow any person to take away from the city hall or any other place where the records are lawfully stored any records for any purpose whatsoever, unless by competent and lawful court order, except by motion of the governing body. 
(Code 1959, § 2-15) 
Sec. 2-3-24. - Examination or inspection. 
Any person desiring to see, inspect, examine, or copy any record made by any officer, agent, or employee of the city or any record of the governing body of the city shall make written request and present the same in person to the city clerk, and it shall be the duty of the record custodian at that time to designate a time certain within a period of seventy-two (72) hours from the date of such request when such records will be available to the applicant; provided that persons desiring to inspect records of the police and fire services departments which are open to public inspection shall present the inspection request directly to the appropriate department. 
State Law reference— Inspection of public records, O.C.G.A., § 50-18-70 et seq. 
Sec. 2-3-25. - Inspection, examination or copying, presence of custodian required, hours limited. 
In order to preserve the authenticity and correctness of any and all records of the city no person shall be allowed to see, inspect, examine or copy the same unless within the presence of the records custodian of the city or some person designated by the records custodian, and such examination shall be made during regular business hours when city offices are kept open to the public. 
Sec. 2-3-26. - Cost of certified copies. 
When the city clerk is called upon from time to time to prepare and certify any copies of official records in his office, the costs of said preparation and certification shall be paid at the rate of one dollar ($1.00) per page. 
(Code 1986, § 2-3-26; Ord. No. 88-015, 10-17-88) 
Sec. 2-3-27. - "Records" construed. 
The records referred to in this article shall include not only the minutes of the governing body, all contracts of the city, all ordinances and resolutions enacted by the governing body, all memoranda and records kept by the city clerk of every nature whatsoever, all records of the public services department, all records of every other department of the city, all records of the police and fire services departments, including municipal court records and police docket, but shall also include all other records kept and maintained by any officer, agent, servant or employee of the city concerning matters pertaining to the city except those records not open to public inspection by order of a court of this state or by law. 
Sec. 2-3-28. - Retention of public records; destruction of obsolete records. 
(a)  Pursuant to O.C.G.A. § 50-18-99, the city has adopted the Records Retention Schedule for Local Government Records as published by the Georgia Secretary of State's Department of Archives and History, and any such amendments or updates as may be made to such retention schedule for local government records. 
(b)  All city records shall be maintained in accordance with approved retention schedules, in the most updated version of the retention schedule for local government records. 
(c)  The support services director shall serve as the coordinator of the records management plan and is authorized to act for and on behalf of the city in directing and coordinating all records management matters under the Georgia Records Retention Act. In discharging the records management and records destruction duties, the director shall, whether personally or by delegation, maintain all records in accordance with the Georgia Secretary of State Retention Schedules for Local Government Records adopted by the mayor and council, and shall not destroy, allow, or direct any employee to destroy, any record except as provided on the aforesaid retention schedule. 
(d)  Whenever any records are destroyed, a certificate of destruction shall be prepared and forwarded to the mayor and council which shall show the type of records destroyed, the approved retention schedule number, the dates covered, and the volume destroyed. These memoranda of destruction shall be kept by the support services director in a central location, and may be viewed by any member of the public as provided by law. 
(Ord. No. 98-009, § 1, 6-1-98; Ord. No. 05-27, 5-25-2005) 
State Law reference— Records management programs for local governments, O.C.G.A., § 50-18-99. 
Sec. 2-3-29. - Records management committee. 
(a)  Creation: A records management committee consisting of the following; director of support services, director of finance, director of public works, director of recreation and leisure services, director of planning, building and zoning, director of police, director of fire and city manager shall be established. 
(b)  The committee shall be responsible for assisting the support services director in the development of policies and procedures governing the city's records management program; reviewing the performance of the program on an annual basis; proposing changes and improvements to the records retention policy if needed; planning, formulating and prescribing records disposition policies, systems, standards, and procedures; monitoring records retention schedules in compliance with the State of Georgia Records Retention Schedule for Local Government Records. 
(c)  The committee will review all lists of records proposed to be destroyed, for pending open records requests, records pertinent to a pending law suits, or when a department head requests in writing to the records management committee that certain records be retained for a period longer than that established by ordinance. 
(Ord. No. 05-35, § 1, 6-20-2005) 
CHAPTER 4. - PERSONNEL 
ARTICLE A. - GENERAL PROVISIONS 

Sec. 2-4-1. - Personnel regulations. 
The personnel regulations of the city, adopted May 15, 1967, as now or hereafter amended, establishing comprehensive personnel policies for employees of the City of Forest Park, is hereby incorporated by reference herein. An up-to-date copy of the personnel regulations is maintained in the office of the city clerk for inspection by the public. 
Sec. 2-4-2. - Official holidays for city employees. 
(a)  The following days shall be observed as holidays for the city: 
(1)  New Year's Day; 
(2)  Martin Luther King, Jr. Day; 
(3)  Memorial Day; 
(4)  Independence Day; 
(5)  Labor Day; 
(6)  Thanksgiving Day; 
(7)  The day following Thanksgiving; 
(8)  Christmas Eve Day; 
(9)  Christmas Day; and, 
(10)  One personal holiday. 
(b)  The granting of a personal holiday shall be subject to the approval of the employee's department head and only one (1) such holiday shall be granted in any calendar year. 
(c)  Any officer or employee may, at the discretion of his immediate supervisor, be required to work on any of said holidays, and in that event, shall be entitled to an additional day of compensation, or, at the option of the supervisor, shall receive compensatory time off at a later date. 
(Code 1986, § 2-4-2; Ord. No. 87-018, 11-2-87; Ord. No. 98-015, § 1, 10-5-98) 
Sec. 2-4-3. - Drug free workplace policy; elimination of substance abuse; employee assistance. 
The document entitled "City of Forest Park, Georgia Drug-Free Workplace Policies and Procedures for Elimination of Substance Abuse and Employee Assistance," which is attached hereto as Exhibit A and incorporated herein by reference, is hereby adopted to apply to all officers and employees of the City of Forest Park, Georgia. An up-to-date copy of the foregoing policy is maintained in the office of the city clerk for inspection by the public and all officers and employees of the city. 
(Ord. No. 13-07, § 1, 3-18-2013) 
Sec. 2-4-4. - Secret recording by city employees prohibited. 
The document entitled "Policy Against Secret Recording," which is attached hereto as Exhibit A and incorporated herein by reference, is hereby adopted to apply to all officers and employees of the City of Forest Park, Georgia. An up-to-date copy of the foregoing policy is maintained in the office of the city clerk for inspection by the public and all officers and employees of the city. 
(Ord. No. 13-08, § 1, 3-18-2013) 
Secs. 2-4-5—2-4-10. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE B. - SOCIAL SECURITY 

Sec. 2-4-11. - Extended to city employees. 
It is hereby declared to be the policy and purpose of the city to extend at the earliest date possible under the agreement entered into by the State of Georgia and the Federal Security Administration, to the employees and officials thereof, and its instrumentalities, not excluded by law or by this article, the benefits of the System of Old Age and Survivors' Insurance as authorized by the Federal Social Security Act, the state enabling act, and amendments thereto. In pursuance of said policy, and for that purpose, the city shall take such action as may be required by applicable state or federal laws or regulations. 
(Code 1959, § 2-80) 
State Law reference— State enabling act, O.C.G.A., § 47-18-1 et seq. 
Sec. 2-4-12. - Authority to execute agreements. 
The mayor of the city is hereby authorized and directed to execute all necessary agreements and amendments thereto with the Employees' Retirement System of Georgia for coverage of said employees and officials as provided for in section 2-4-11 hereof, to include any employees that are in positions covered by a public retirement system, in the manner by said law provided. 
(Code 1959, § 2-81) 
Editor's note— Persons performing services to the city on a fee basis, such as the city attorney, are excluded from coverage under social security. 
Sec. 2-4-13. - Withholdings from salaries or wages. 
Withholdings from salaries or wages of employees and officials for the purpose provided for in section 2-4-11 hereof are hereby authorized to be made in the amounts and at such times as may be required by applicable state or federal laws or regulations, and shall be paid over to the state agency. 
(Code 1959, § 2-82) 
Sec. 2-4-14. - Contributions by city. 
There shall be appropriated from the general funds such amounts at such times as may be required by applicable state or federal laws or regulations for employer's contributions, administrative expenses, and a guaranty fund to assure that the state will not incur any debt or loss as a result of the agreement referred to in section 2-4-12 of this article. Such funds shall be paid over to the Employees' Retirement System of Georgia in accordance with regulations established by said agency. 
(Code 1959, § 2-83) 
Sec. 2-4-15. - Records to be kept by city. 
The city shall keep such records and make such reports as may be required by applicable state or federal laws or regulations. 
(Code 1959, § 2-84) 
Sec. 2-4-16. - Exclusion of employees not authorized to be covered. 
There is hereby excluded from this article any authority to make any agreement with respect to any position, or any employee or official not authorized to be covered by applicable state or federal laws or regulations. 
(Code 1959, § 2-85) 
Sec. 2-4-17. - Agreement with the Employees Retirement System of Georgia. 
(a)  The mayor of the city is hereby authorized and directed to execute an agreement amending the original plan and agreement with the Employees' Retirement System of Georgia, in substantially the form attached hereto as exhibit A, providing for the release of social security escrow deposits. 
(b)  The City of Forest Park, hereinafter referred to as "the city," agrees to abide by the rules and regulations of the Employees' Retirement System of Georgia, hereinafter called the state agency, in regard to collections from city employees and in making reports and payments to the state agency. 
(c)  The city hereby pledges an amount which it would receive in state grant funds as security for assurance that it will make collections from its employees, submit required reports, and remit payments to the state agency as agreed to in its plan of coverage of employees for social security benefits. The city further agrees that if the amount of state grant funds which it is entitled to receive in a calendar year is less than its annual payment to the state agency, as may be determined by the state agency, then the city shall deposit in escrow, when so notified in writing by the state agency and in accordance with its rules and regulations, an amount which, when added to the city's state grant funds, would total an amount sufficient to meet its obligations of reporting and remitting collections to the state agency. 
(Code 1959, § 2-88) 
Editor's note— Exhibit A, setting out the text of the agreement, is not included in this codification. 
Secs. 2-4-18—2-4-30. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE C. - EMPLOYEE BENEFITS[10] 

Footnotes: 
--- (10) --- 
Editor's note— An employees' health and accident fund was adopted for the city by Resolution No. 83-163, 7-18-83. The city also adopted a death benefit fund by Resolution No. 83-160, 6-20-83. 

Sec. 2-4-31. - City thrift and savings plan. 
The provisions of the City of Forest Park thrift and savings plan as set forth in that agreement by and between the City of Forest Park, a governmental unit established under the laws of the State of Georgia, and Bank South, N.A. as trustee, executed by the parties on or about July 1, 1983, that set forth a City of Forest Park thrift and savings plan consisting of eleven (11) sections and containing provisions for definitions, participation and service, contributions, interest of participants, benefits, designation of beneficiary, administration, powers, duties and responsibilities of trustee, amendment of the plan, discontinuance of contributions and termination of the plan, together with that amendment to the City of Forest Park employees' retirement plan, executed and dated by the City of Forest Park, a governmental unit established under the laws of the State of Georgia and referred to therein as "employee" on July 1, 1983, the provisions of said agreement and amendment are set forth in their entirety and copies are available for inspection by the members of the general public, as well as the employees of the city on the bulletin board at the entry to the meeting area of city hall, where the mayor and council conduct their regular public meetings, as well as in the office of the city manager, where the same will be available for inspection and copying, and the provisions of both the agreement and the amendment are hereby referred to and incorporated by reference as if fully set forth herein. 
(Ord. No. 83-284, 11-21-84) 
Sec. 2-4-32. - Life insurance benefits for city officials and employees. 
(a)  There is hereby adopted and implemented a self insurance program to provide for life insurance benefits for officials and employees of the City of Forest Park, Georgia, to be payable to beneficiaries designated by said officials and employees, in the following amounts: 
Mayor and members of city council: $150,000.00 
City manager: $150,000.00 
LRA executive director: $150,000.00 
Department heads—Directors: $150,000.00 
Deputy directors, colonels and majors: $40,000.00 
Management analyst(s): $40,000.00 
All other employees $20,000.00 
(b)  This self insurance program is intended to be in lieu of the former death benefit fund established by Resolution No. 83-160, adopted July 18, 1983. 
(c)  The benefits under this life insurance program are extended only to active officials and full time employees of the city during their terms of office or their full time employment with the city. 
(Ord. No. 08-31, § 1, 7-7-2008) 
CHAPTER 5. - MUNICIPAL COURT[11] 
Footnotes: 
--- (11) --- 
Cross reference— Establishment of municipal court, appointment and qualifications of judge, jurisdiction, etc., City Charter, Art. VI. 

ARTICLE A. - GENERAL PROVISIONS 

Sec. 2-5-1. - Time, place for holding court. 
(a)  The chief judge of the municipal court shall convene court on Wednesday between the hours of 8:00 a.m. and 12:00 p.m. in the morning, and from 1:30 p.m. until 5:00 p.m. in the afternoon. 
(b)  In the event that there is insufficient time within which to dispose of cases pending, or in the event that a national holiday falls on said date, the chief judge may convene such additional court sessions as may be necessary in order that all cases may be tried or otherwise disposed of in a timely manner. 
(c)  The assistant municipal court judge assigned to the environmental division shall convene court on Thursday between the hours of 8:00 a.m. and 12:00 p.m. in the morning, and further, shall have the same authority as that given to the chief judge in subsection 2-5-1(b) hereinabove. 
(1)  Sessions of the environmental division of the municipal court shall be convened at 785 Forest Parkway, Forest Park, Georgia, or at such other times and places as the chief judge of the municipal court shall designate. 
(Code 1986, § 2-5-1, as amended by Ord. No. 88-013, 9-19-88; Ord. No. 96-004, 2-19-96) 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 88-013 rewrote the above section in its entirety to provide specifically for the time and place for court. 
Sec. 2-5-2. - Contents of copies of charges. 
All copies of charges requiring persons to appear in the municipal court shall be properly dated the day they are issued, and shall be signed by the officer making the case, and shall notify the person summoned of the day and hour for his appearance and the charges against the accused. 
Sec. 2-5-3. - Disposal of cases. 
Every case entered on the municipal court docket shall be promptly disposed of by the court on the call of the case in its regular order or as soon thereafter as is reasonable by trial, continuance, dismissal, forfeiture of bond, attachment for contempt or by any other lawful order or judgment. 
(Code 1959, § 14-7) 
Sec. 2-5-4. - Summons—Issuance. 
(a)  It shall be the duty of any member of the police department, in all cases where complaint is made or information obtained of any violation of any of the laws or ordinances of the city, to issue a summons, bearing test in the name of the city and directed to the accused, requiring him to appear before the municipal court to answer such charge, which summons shall designate the time and place of trial. It shall be signed by the patrolman or officer issuing same and a copy thereof shall be served upon the accused either personally or by leaving a copy at his place of residence by the issuing officer. 
(b)  It shall be the duty of any code enforcement officer as set forth in section 2-3-8 of this Code, in all cases where complaint is made or information obtained of any violations of the ordinances of the city or of a party's failure to comply with the ordinance of the city, to issue a summons bearing test in the name of the city and directed to the accused, requiring him to appear before the environmental division of the municipal court to answer such charge, which summons shall designate the time and place of trial. It shall be signed by the code enforcement officer issuing same and a copy thereof shall be served upon the accused either personally or by leaving the copy at his place of residence by the issuing code enforcement officer. 
(Code 1959, § 14-8; Ord. No. 96-004, 2-19-96) 
Sec. 2-5-5. - Same—Contempt for failure to appear. 
Any person summoned as provided herein who shall fail, neglect or refuse to appear, or to make a satisfactory showing for such failure, neglect or refusal to appear and answer the charge specified, may be punished as provided in section 4.13 of the city charter. The case may be continued to such time as the municipal court may direct, and the court shall issue an order requiring the chief of police, or other member of the police force, to arrest the offender and bring him before the court to answer the contempt, and it shall be the duty of such police chief to keep the offender in custody until he is brought before the court, unless he gives bond for his appearance as provided by law. 
(Ord. No. 96-004, 2-19-96) 
Sec. 2-5-6. - Rights of accused. 
Any person charged with an offense against any of the provisions of this code or other ordinances of the city shall be informed by summons in writing served on him of the nature of the cause of his accusation; shall have compulsory process for obtaining witnesses in his behalf; shall have a speedy trial before the judge; shall be confronted with the witnesses against him and have the privilege of cross-examination, as in the superior courts of the state; and shall have the privilege of defending himself, by counsel or by himself, or both, as to him shall seem proper. No one shall be condemned, fined or punished without full opportunity of being heard in his own defense. 
(Code 1959, § 14-10) 
Sec. 2-5-7. - Witnesses—Subpoenas. 
Whenever the attendance of any witness may be required before the municipal court to establish any fact, the court or the clerk of court, or the deputy clerk of the environmental division of the municipal court, or such person as designated by the municipal judge shall issue a subpoena directed to the witness, stating the time and place of trial and the parties to the case, which shall be served as other process by the chief of police, or other officer, policeman or code enforcement officer. 
(Ord. No. 96-004, 2-19-96) 
Sec. 2-5-8. - Same—Contempt for failure to appear. 
If any person summoned as a witness shall fail, neglect or refuse to attend the trial, or render an excuse, insufficient in the judgment of the judge, the defaulting witness shall be liable to such punishment as provided by the city charter for contempt. If the case shall be continued on account of the absence of the witness, the court may issue attachment against the witness, requiring him to show cause on the day appointed for trial, why he should not be further dealt with for contempt. The chief of police shall, by virtue of the attachment, arrest such witness, or cause him to be arrested by some other officer or police officer, and shall confine him, so as to have him before the judge at such time as may be appointed for further hearing of the original complaint. 
Sec. 2-5-9. - Continuances. 
Where the ends of justice may require, all cases may be continued. Applications for continuance shall be addressed to the sound discretion of the judge, under the rules governing in the superior courts of this state. All motions in the municipal court for a continuance of any case, where the defendant is at liberty on bond shall be made by the defendant, his attorney at law or his attorney in fact, which designation shall not include the surety of his appearance bond. No motion to continue a case shall be entertained except in open court and on the day set for trial. Where an appearance bond has been forfeited and the forfeiture is subsequently set aside for cause, no further motion to continue the case for trial shall be entertained until a forfeiture fee as provided in the schedule of court fees has been paid. 
(Code 1959, § 14-13) 
Sec. 2-5-10. - Rules of practice. 
The rules of evidence and examination of witnesses shall be the same as in the superior courts, so far as such rules are applicable to the case on trial. All officers, informers and persons injured shall be competent witnesses. In general, the municipal court shall be controlled by the rules of practice governing the superior courts, so far as they are applicable to municipal courts, and by a sound construction of the charter and ordinances of the city. 
Sec. 2-5-11. - Contempt. 
Any person who, during a session of the municipal court or any division thereof, shall be guilty of a contempt of court, or who refuses to abide by any sentence or order of the court, shall be punished as provided in section 4.13 of the city charter or section 1-1-8 of this Code. 
(Ord. No. 96-004, 2-19-96) 
Sec. 2-5-12. - Docket—Required. 
(a)  A court record of all cases coming before the court clerk and made by persons other than code enforcement officers, shall be kept in the office of the court clerk, records bureau, on which shall appear the name of every defendant charged with a violation of this code or any city ordinance, and at the trial of all cases in the municipal court, the court clerk or other designated person shall record on the original copy of charges the punishment inflicted and the date, and an entry shall be made under the judge's sentence showing the final disposition of the case, that is, whether the fine, if any, was collected, the date of such collection and the disposition of such amounts. The original copy of charges, showing the within described information, shall constitute the permanent record of the court and shall be maintained in the order as directed by the judge. 
(b)  A court record of all cases issued by code enforcement officers and coming before the deputy clerk of the environmental division of the municipal court shall be kept in the office of said deputy clerk, on which shall appear the name of every defendant charged with a violation of any city ordinance, and at the trial of all cases in the environmental division of the municipal court, the deputy court clerk or other designated person shall record on the original copy of the charges the punishment inflicted and the date, and an entry shall be made under the judge's sentence showing the final disposition of the case, that is, whether the fine, if any, was collected, the date of such collection and the disposition of such amounts. The original copy of charges, showing the within described information, shall constitute the permanent record of the environmental division of the municipal court and shall be maintained in the order as directed by the assistant judge of the municipal court with the approval of the chief judge of the municipal court. 
(Ord. No. 96-004, 2-19-96) 
Sec. 2-5-13. - Same—Docketing under false name. 
All cases must be docketed in the correct name of the accused where such name is ascertainable and shall correctly describe the offense charged. The docketing of a defendant under a false or assumed name, or under a false charge, shall be sufficient ground for the removal of any officer guilty thereof who has any knowledge of the true name or the true charge. 
(Code 1959, § 14-17) 
Sec. 2-5-14. - Trying person under fictitious name. 
It shall be unlawful for the judge to knowingly try a person under a feigned name, where he has reason to believe a fraud is being practiced on the court and on the public. 
Sec. 2-5-15. - Court costs. 
(a)  The costs in all cases tried before the municipal court shall be set at the discretion of the judge or by resolution of the mayor and council. 
(b)  The costs may be charged and collected from the defendant upon conviction or forfeiture at the discretion of the judge. 
State Law reference— Payments made from fines and bonds to peace officers' annuity and benefit fund and such other fund as required by the state code, O.C.G.A., § 47-17-60. 
Sec. 2-5-16. - Appearance bonds. 
(a)  The officer on duty and in charge of the police station when any arrest is made may take bond with or without security, as per schedule, payable to the city, for the appearance of any person accused or suspected of being guilty of the violation of any ordinance of the city, to stand to and abide his trial; and also of witnesses to testify in any case pending or about to be commenced. 
(b)  If any arrested person or necessary witness shall fail to give the bond and security required of him, such person so refusing may be confined in the jail of the city or the common jail of the county, or be kept under guard so as to be present at his trial or to testify as the case may be. 
(c)  All bail taken under the provisions of this section shall be special bail and the power of the security over the principal shall be the same as in special bail. Upon failure of any principal in any bond to appear where such principal is charged with a violation of any of the provisions of this code or other ordinances of the city or upon the failure of any principal, who is a witness, to appear and testify as engaged, the judge of the municipal court shall pass a rule requiring the principal and sureties on such bond or recognizance to show cause before him on any date named therein, not to be less than ten (10) days from the passage of such rule, why they should not be required to pay the amount of such bond or recognizance and all costs of forfeiture. 
(d)  Any member of the police force of the city shall serve a copy of the rule described in subsection (c) upon the principal and surety, if to be found in the city, personally or by leaving a copy at their usual place of abode, at least five (5) days before the time named therein for hearing the cause. 
(e)  If no sufficient cause is shown to the contrary, the judge of the municipal court shall proceed to enter up judgment against the principal and sureties for the amount of such bond and costs, and the court clerk shall issue execution for the amount of the judgment and costs, which execution shall bear teste in the name of the judge, and place the same in the hands of the chief of police who shall proceed to collect the same by levy and sale. 
(f)  Any surety upon any bail bond of any person charged with a violation of any provision of this code or other ordinance of the city may petition the judge at any time for release, and if such release is granted, the judge shall issue an order to the chief of police of the city, who shall confine such principal until discharged by order of the municipal court, or until such principal shall give other good and acceptable security and such release shall discharge such surety from all liability upon the bond. 
(g)  No officer of the city shall accept on any bail bond any surety residing beyond the limits of the county except as authorized by the court, but in case he shall do so, the surety will be bound and upon entry of judgment against such surety, the judgment shall be collected as provided by law. 
(h)  If the person arrested shall fail to appear at the place and time of trial so appointed, it shall be the duty of the judge to declare any pledge forfeited and to order the money to be paid into the city treasury as in other fines and forfeitures if it has not already been deposited in such treasury. If the person so arrested shall appear as engaged and is adjudged not guilty, the money and the property thus deposited shall be ordered by court delivered up to the person depositing same. Should any accused person be adjudged guilty and fined on his trial the amount of the fine and costs of the trial shall be paid into the city treasury, and the remainder, if any, refunded to the accused or to the person entitled thereto. 
(Code 1959, §§ 14-29—14-35) 
Sec. 2-5-17. - Appointment and duties of municipal court judges. 
(a)  The mayor and council may appoint a chief judge to preside over the city's municipal court. 
(1)  The chief judge shall be responsible for the general supervision of the municipal court and shall promulgate all rules necessary for the supervision, conduct, and administration of the court. 
(2)  A member of the governing body shall nominate any qualified person for the office of chief judge, said nomination shall be seconded, and, in the event more than one (1) qualified person is nominated, the person obtaining the vote of the majority of the governing body shall be appointed chief judge. 
(b)  The governing body shall also appoint an assistant judge who shall preside over sessions of a division of the municipal court to be known as the environmental division. 
(1)  Said appointment shall follow the same procedure for appointment as that of the chief judge. 
(c)  The governing body shall also appoint as many judges pro tempore as it may deem necessary from time to time. 
(1)  Said appointments shall follow the same procedure for appointment as that of the chief judge. 
(2)  Such judges pro tempore shall be acting chief municipal court judge or assistant municipal court judge in the absence, disability or disqualification of such judges. 
The judges pro tempore shall have all the powers and perform all the duties of the chief or assistant judge. 
(Ord. No. 17-07, § 1, 2-20-2017) 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 17-07, § 1, adopted Feb. 20, 2017, repealed the former section and enacted a new section as set out herein. The former section pertained to similar subject matter. For prior history, see Ordinance Disposition Table. 
Sec. 2-5-18. - Terms of municipal court judges. 
Municipal judges shall serve a term of one year, unless modified by written agreement between the governing body and the judges, which agreements shall otherwise comply with state law. 
(Ord. No. 17-07, § 2, 2-20-2017) 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 17-07, § 2, adopted Feb. 20, 2017, repealed the former section and enacted a new section as set out herein. The former section pertained to similar subject matter. For prior history, see Ordinance Disposition Table. 
Sec. 2-5-18.1. - Reserved. 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 17-07, § 3, adopted Feb. 20, 2017, repealed § 2-5-18.1, which pertained to municipal court judge pro tem, and derived from Ord. No. 17-01, § 3, adopted Jan. 3, 2017. 
Sec. 2-5-19. - Compensation of municipal court judges. 
The amount and frequency of compensation of municipal judges shall be established from time to time by resolution of the governing authority. 
(Ord. No. 17-07, § 4, 2-20-2017) 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 17-07, § 4, adopted Feb. 20, 2017, repealed the former section and enacted a new section as set out herein. The former section pertained to similar subject matter. For prior history, see Ordinance Disposition Table. 
Sec. 2-5-20. - Environmental division of municipal court; records; deputy clerk; reporting. 
(a)  The environmental division of the municipal court is charged with the responsibility of adjudicating those cases made for violations of the city ordinances by code enforcement officers. All matters coming before this division of the municipal court shall remain under the general supervision of the chief judge of the municipal court. 
(b)  Records of all proceedings conducted by the environmental division of the municipal court, including but not limited to dockets, original citations and records of disposition thereof, sentences, assessments of fines, punishment and performance or payment thereof, shall be maintained by the environmental division of the municipal court and not merged with the records of the municipal court. However, a copy of the docket book shall be maintained in the offices of the clerk of the municipal court. 
(c)  A person shall be designated by the chief judge of the municipal court to serve in the capacity of deputy clerk of the environmental division of the municipal court, and that person shall be charged with the same responsibilities within the confines of the environmental division of the municipal court as are charged to the clerk of the municipal court. 
(Ord. No. 96-004, 2-19-96) 
ARTICLE B. - TRAFFIC VIOLATIONS BUREAU[12] 

Footnotes: 
--- (12) --- 
Cross reference— Handling of traffic violations, § 10-4-1 et seq. 

Sec. 2-5-21. - Created; administration; schedule of fines. 
There is hereby established a traffic violations bureau to assist the court with the clerical work of traffic cases and the disposition of the same. Such bureau shall have such duties and responsibilities as the judge and the chief of police designate. The judge shall designate specific offenses in respect to which payments of fines may be accepted by the traffic violations bureau (or person so designated as herein set forth) in satisfaction thereof, and shall specify by suitable schedules the amount of such fines for first, second and subsequent offenses, provided such fines are within the limits declared by law or ordinance, and shall further specify what number of such offenses shall require appearances before the judge. 
Sec. 2-5-22. - Duties of bureau. 
The following duties are hereby imposed upon the traffic violations bureau in reference to traffic offenses: 
(1)  It shall accept designated fines, issue receipts, and represent in court such violators as are permitted and desire to plead guilty, waive court appearance, and give power of attorney. 
(2)  It shall receive and issue receipts for cash bail from the persons who must or wish to be heard in court, enter the time of their appearance on the court docket, and notify the arresting officer and witnesses, if any, to be present. 
(3)  It shall keep an easily accessible record of all violations of which each person has been guilty during the preceding 12 months, whether such guilt was established in court or in the traffic violations bureau. 
(Code 1959, § 20-241) 
Sec. 2-5-23. - Records. 
The traffic violations bureau shall keep records of all the fines collected by the traffic violations bureau or the court, and of the final disposition or present status of every case or violation of the provisions of this code and other laws and ordinances. Such records shall be so maintained as to show all types of violations and the total of each. 
Cross reference— Public records, § 2-3-21 et seq. 
Sec. 2-5-24. - Procedure. 
The traffic violations bureau shall follow such procedure as may be prescribed by this article and other traffic ordinances of this city or as may be required by any laws of this state. 
(Code 1959, § 20-243) 
Title 3 - Finance

CHAPTER 1. - PURCHASES AND CONTRACTS 
ARTICLE A. - GENERAL PROVISIONS 

Sec. 3-1-1. - Purchasing agent; city manager. 
The city manager shall be the purchasing agent for the city. 
(Code 1959, § 2-47) 
Sec. 3-1-2. - Same—Duties. 
The purchasing agent shall have the power and it shall be his duty to purchase or contract for the purchase of all supplies and contractual services needed by any agency of the city, except as otherwise provided by law, or the governing body. The purchasing agent shall act to procure for the city the highest quality of supplies and contractual services at the least expense to the city, discourage uniform bidding and endeavor to obtain as full and open competition as possible on all purchases and sales, keep informed of current developments in the field of purchasing by other governmental jurisdictions, prescribe and maintain such forms as he shall find reasonably necessary to the operation of this article, exploit the possibilities of buying in bulk so as to take full advantage of discounts, and act so as to procure for the city all federal tax exemptions to which it is entitled. The purchasing agent shall have the authority to declare vendors who default on their quotations irresponsible bidders and to disqualify them from receiving any business from the city for a stated period of time. 
(Code 1959, § 2-48) 
Sec. 3-1-3. - Unauthorized purchases. 
Except as herein otherwise provided, it shall be unlawful for any city officer or officers to order the purchase of any supplies or make any contract within the purview of this article unless the provisions of this article are complied with, and any purchase ordered or contract made contrary to the provisions hereof shall not be approved by the city, and the city shall not be bound thereby. 
(Code 1959, § 2-49) 
Sec. 3-1-4. - Requisitions and estimates. 
All departments of the city, either by or with the authorization of the department head thereof, shall file with the purchasing agent detailed requisitions or estimates of their requirements in supplies and contractual services in such manner, at such times, and for such future periods as the purchasing agent may prescribe. 
(Code 1959, § 2-50) 
Sec. 3-1-5. - Revisory power. 
The purchasing agent, or his designated representative, shall examine each requisition or estimate and shall have the authority to revise it as to quantity, quality, or estimated cost. 
Sec. 3-1-6. - Encumbrance of funds. 
(a)  Except in cases of emergency, the purchasing agent shall not issue any order for delivery on a contract or any market purchases until he has determined, after preaudit, that there is to the credit of the using department concerned a sufficient unencumbered appropriation balance, in excess of all unpaid obligations, to defray the amount of such order. 
(b)  Nothing in this section shall prevent the purchasing agent from issuing an order for the purchase of any goods or services where funds to cover such purchase are not immediately available, provided that the provisions of subsection (a) concerning determination of sufficient unencumbered balance have been complied with and the means of defraying the amount of such order are available. 
Sec. 3-1-7. - Discounted or competitive prices. 
The city manager is hereby directed and authorized to engage in purchasing goods and materials needed by the city from any person, firm, partnership, or corporation who will make said goods and materials available to the city at a price which is discounted or competitive with prices being charged on the open market. Subject to the preference for local bidders prescribed by section 3-1-18, the city manager is further directed to obtain all goods and materials purchased on behalf of the city and for use by the city at the lowest price obtainable, provided, however, that said goods shall be of similar or approved quality for like merchandise available for sale throughout the city. 
(Ord. No. 91-010, § 1, 5-20-91) 
Sec. 3-1-8. - Competitive bids favored. 
All purchases of, and contracts for supplies and contractual services, and all sales of personal property which has become obsolete and unusable shall, except as otherwise provided herein, be based wherever possible on competitive bids. 
(Code 1959, § 2-54) 
Sec. 3-1-9. - Formal contract procedure; maximum without bids. 
(a)  Generally. Subject to the local preference provided by section 3-1-18, all items, equipment, services and supplies, except as otherwise herein provided, when the cost thereof shall exceed ten thousand dollars ($10,000.00), shall be purchased by formal, written contract from the lowest responsible bidder, after due notice inviting proposals. 
(b)  Other limitations and procedures. The limitations and requirements contained in subsection (a) of this section shall not be applied to the purchase of the following goods and services: 
(1)  Professional services. Professional services such as medical, architectural, legal, etc., may be contracted by negotiation, upon approval of the governing body; 
(2)  Sole source. All items, equipment, services and supplies for which there is only a sole source may be contracted by negotiation, upon approval of the governing body; 
(3)  State contract. Any item which may be purchased pursuant to a state contract for purchase of goods and materials, upon approval of the governing body; 
(4)  Market conditions. Any item, the cost of which does not exceed thirty thousand dollars ($30,000.00), which due to its scarcity or other unusual market conditions, either temporary or permanent, is unavailable for purchase on the market if the requirements of subsection (a) are complied with, upon approval of the mayor, or in his absence, the mayor pro tem; and, 
(5)  Noncompetitive negotiation. When as determined by the mayor and council prior to an award, the needs of the city cannot be met by the other methods of procedure outlined herein, a contract may be made by noncompetitive negotiation. 
(Ord. No. 91-010, § 2, 5-20-91; Ord. No. 96-014, 10-7-96; Ord. No. 98-012, § 1, 7-20-98; Ord. No. 98-014, § 1, 9-21-98) 
Sec. 3-1-10. - Notice inviting bids. 
Notice inviting bids shall be published once in the official newspaper of the city and at least four (4) days preceding the last day set for the receipt of proposals. 
(Code 1959, § 2-56) 
Sec. 3-1-11. - Scope of notice. 
The newspaper notice required herein shall include a general description of the articles to be purchased or sold, shall state where bid blanks and specifications may be secured, and the time and place for opening bids. 
(Code 1959, § 2-57) 
Sec. 3-1-12. - Bidder's list. 
The purchasing agent may also solicit bids from all responsible prospective suppliers by sending them a copy of such notice as will acquaint them with the proposed purchase or sale. 
(Code 1959, § 2-58) 
Sec. 3-1-13. - Notice on bulletin board in city hall. 
The purchasing agent may also advertise all pending purchases or sales by a notice posted on a public bulletin board in the city hall. 
(Code 1959, § 2-59) 
Sec. 3-1-14. - Bid deposits. 
When deemed necessary by the purchasing agent, bid deposits shall be prescribed in the public notice inviting bids. Unsuccessful bidders shall be entitled to return of any deposit and/or release of any surety where the agent has required such. A successful bidder shall forfeit any deposits and/or require performance of the surety required by the purchasing agent upon failure on his part to enter a contract within fourteen (14) days after the award, or such other time as may be designated by the purchasing agent. 
Sec. 3-1-15. - Bid opening procedure. 
Bids shall be submitted sealed to the purchasing agent and shall be identified as bids on the envelope. Bids shall be opened in public at the time and place stated in the public notices. A tabulation of all bids received shall be posted for public inspection, and a copy furnished to the governing body. 
(Code 1959, § 2-61) 
Sec. 3-1-16. - Rejection of bids. 
The purchasing agent shall have the authority to reject all bids, parts of all bids, or all-bids for one (1) or more supplies or contractual services included in the proposed contract, when the public interest will be served thereby. 
(Code 1959, § 2-62) 
Sec. 3-1-17. - Lowest responsible bidder. 
Contracts shall be awarded to the lowest responsible bidder. In determining "lowest responsible bidder," in addition to price, the purchasing agent shall consider: 
(1)  The ability, capacity and skill of the bidder to perform the contract or provide the service required; 
(2)  Whether the bidder can perform the contract or provide the service promptly, or within the time specified, without delay or interference; 
(3)  The character, integrity, reputation, judgment, experience and efficiency of the bidder; 
(4)  The quality of performance of previous contracts or services; 
(5)  The previous and existing compliance by the bidder with laws and ordinances relating to the contract or service; 
(6)  The sufficiency of the financial resources and ability of the bidder to perform the contract or provide the service; 
(7)  The quality, availability and adaptability of the supplies, or contractual services to the particular use required; 
(8)  The ability of the bidder to provide future maintenance and service for the use of the subject of the contract; and 
(9)  The number and scope of conditions attached to the bid. 
(Code 1959, § 2-63) 
Sec. 3-1-18. - Award to other than low bidder. 
Business[es] which maintain a permanent location within the city and secure an annual business license from the city are designated as "local businesses." A purchasing preference is established in favor of local businesses. In the event a bid is received from a local business which is no more than five (5) percent higher than the low bid, such local business shall be considered the lowest bidder for purposes of this chapter. Except as provided in the preceding sentence, no award shall be given to any bidder other than the lowest bidder without the consent and approval of the governing body. 
(Ord. No. 91-010, § 3, 5-20-91) 
Sec. 3-1-19. - Tie bids. 
If all bids received are for the same total amount or unit price, quality and service being equal, and after adjustment for local preference as provided in section 3-1-18, the contract shall be awarded to a local bidder. Where no local bidder is involved, the purchasing agent shall award the contract to one of the tie bidders by drawing lots in public. 
(Ord. No. 91-010, § 4, 5-20-91) 
Sec. 3-1-20. - Subdividing contracts. 
No contract or purchase shall be subdivided to avoid the requirements of this article. 
(Code 1959, § 2-66) 
Sec. 3-1-21. - Sale of city property. 
(a)  When the governing body shall determine that it is in the best interest of the city to sell or otherwise dispose of any property belonging to the city, not needed for public use or that may have become unsuited for public use, it shall be the duty of the governing body to declare such facts, and to list or describe the property. All real property to be sold, and all personal property, the estimated resale value of which shall exceed five hundred dollars ($500.00), shall be sold at public auction or by formal written contract to the highest responsible bidder, after reasonable notice inviting proposals. 
(b)  Surplus property of the city with an estimated resale value of five hundred dollars ($500.00) or less may be sold at the discretion of the purchasing agent by negotiated sale without advertisement and the acceptance of bids. 
State Law reference— Sale of municipal property, O.C.G.A., § 36-37-6. 
Secs. 3-1-22—3-1-30. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE B. - IMPROVEMENT CONTRACTS 

Sec. 3-1-31. - When required. 
All public improvement projects costing in the aggregate of five thousand dollars ($5,000.00) or more should be completed and performed under and by virtue of a written contract by and between the city and the performing party and which contract shall be drawn, prepared and executed in accordance with ordinances and resolutions in effect in the city. 
Sec. 3-1-32. - Procedure for awarding. 
Whenever the governing body deems it necessary or desirable to undertake any public works or other public improvements costing in the aggregate twenty-five thousand dollars ($25,000.00) or more, they shall by motion declare such work or improvements necessary. Such motion shall state the type of work or improvement to be done, as well as define the extent and character of the same. Upon the adoption of such motion, it shall be the duty of the director of public works or an engineering firm designated by the governing body to proceed to prepare an estimate of the cost of such proposed improvements, as well as all plans and specifications as may be necessary. Said plans, specifications and cost estimates shall thereupon be delivered to the governing body, who, after examining the same, shall determine whether to proceed with the improvements. 
(Ord. No. 96-014, 10-7-96) 
Sec. 3-1-33. - Resolution; advertisement for bids. 
Should the governing body determine, after studying the estimate furnished by the director of public works or the engineering firm, to proceed with the improvements, they shall pass a motion setting forth said facts. The motion shall set forth such terms and conditions as they shall deem proper or necessary with reference to the letting of the contract and the provisions thereof. Such motion shall also direct the city manager to advertise for sealed proposals for furnishing the materials and performing the work necessary in making such improvements. The notice for such proposals shall be published once a week for two (2) weeks prior to the date set for opening bids. The city manager may also solicit bids from any responsible parties by sending a copy of such notice that will acquaint them with the proposed improvements. 
Sec. 3-1-34. - Bid deposits. 
The city shall require a bid deposit of at least five (5) percent on proposed improvement contracts with the city. All unsuccessful bidders shall be entitled to return of any deposit and/or release of any surety. A successful bidder shall forfeit any bid deposit and/or penalty imposed against a surety on said contract upon failure of the contracting party with the city to enter a contract within fourteen (14) days after the award to said party, or such other time as the city manager shall direct. 
Sec. 3-1-35. - Bid opening procedure. 
All bids on proposed improvement contracts with the city shall be submitted sealed to the city manager and shall be identified as bids on the envelope. Bids shall be opened in public at the time and place stated in the public notices. A tabulation of all bids received shall be posted for public inspection, and a copy furnished to the governing body. 
(Code 1959, § 2-72) 
Sec. 3-1-36. - Rejection of bids. 
The city shall reserve the right to reject all bids or parts of all bids, when the public interest will be served thereby, and shall have the further right to waive all technicalities. 
(Code 1959, § 2-73) 
Sec. 3-1-37. - Lowest responsible bidder. 
Contracts for municipal improvements shall be awarded to the lowest responsible bidder. In determining the "lowest responsible bidder," in addition to price, the city manager shall be governed by the provisions of section 3-1-17. 
(Code 1959, § 2-74) 
Sec. 3-1-38. - Award to other than low bidder. 
No award for a contract for municipal improvements shall be given to other than the lowest bidder without the express consent of the governing body. 
(Code 1959, § 2-75) 
Sec. 3-1-39. - Tie bids. 
If all low bids received are for the same amount or unit price, all other things being equal, the contract shall be awarded to a local bidder. Where no local bidders are involved, the city manager shall award the contract for municipal improvements to one of the tie bidders by drawing lots in public. 
(Code 1959, § 2-76) 
Sec. 3-1-40. - Professional engineer for certain work. 
In all public works costing twenty-five thousand dollars ($25,000.00) or more, the plans and specifications and estimates of cost shall be prepared by, and the construction executed under the direct supervision of a registered professional engineer, when expertise is not available in the city. 
(Ord. No. 96-04, 10-7-96) 
Sec. 3-1-41. - Bond of contractor. 
No contract for any public works or improvements, costing more than twenty-five thousand dollars ($25,000.00), shall become valid until the contract therefor shall have been duly executed and the contractor shall have executed and delivered to the city good and sufficient surety bond conditioned for the faithful performance and completion of such contract and said bond shall have been approved by the city attorney. 
(Ord. No. 96-014, 10-7-96) 
State Law reference— Bonds required of contractors for public works in excess of $5,000, O.C.G.A., § 36-82-101 et seq. 
Sec. 3-1-42. - Contracts for less than $25,000. 
All public works contracts costing less than twenty-five thousand dollars ($25,000.00) shall be awarded in such manner as shall be directed by the governing body. 
(Ord. No. 96-014, 10-7-96) 
Sec. 3-1-43. - Cooperative ventures for water and sewer line installation. 
(a)  Nothing contained in section 3-1-31 through section 3-1-42 shall prevent the city from entering into agreements with property owners or developers for joint participation in the costs of installation of water mains and sanitary sewers, when such agreements are in the best interests of the city. 
(b)  When such ventures are contemplated, it shall be the responsibility of the department head under whose jurisdiction the work is to be done to fully inform the city manager in writing of the details of the proposal together with the estimated costs to the city. The city manager, together with the director of public works or engineering firm designated by the city, shall review the proposal in detail and submit the matter together with their recommendations to the governing body for approval or rejection. 
(c)  In all instances where city participation as to the furnishing of labor or materials is contemplated as outlined above, any contracts for the installation of water mains and sanitary sewers shall be between the property owner or developer and the contractor who actually performs the work. This section is intended merely to allow city participation where feasible in furnishing labor or materials without the necessity of advertising for bids and entering into a contract. 
Sec. 3-1-44. - Emergency public works contracts costing less than $100,000.00. 
(a)  All public works or public improvement contracts necessitated by an emergency that can be performed at a cost of less than one hundred thousand ($100,000.00) shall not be required to comply with the competitive bid award requirements and instead shall be awarded in such manner as shall be directed by the governing body. 
(b)  The nature of the emergency shall be described in the minutes of the city council. 
(c)  The public works or public improvement project shall not be subdivided in an effort to evade the competitive bid award requirements. 
(Ord. No. 01-02, § 1, 3-19-2001) 
CHAPTER 2. - AD VALOREM TAXES 

Sec. 3-2-1. - Ad valorem taxation to be levied and collected. 
As described in the city charter, there shall be levied and collected an annual ad valorem tax upon all property in the city subject to municipal taxation under the law of the State of Georgia. 
(Code 1959, § 19-1) 
Sec. 3-2-2. - Assessment of property for the purpose of ad valorem taxation; owner-occupied tax exemption; exemption for disabled residents; and exemption for persons above the age of 65 years. 
(a)  The city hereby declares that it elects to use the same assessments as are used by Clayton County, Georgia, for the purpose of taxing real property in the City of Forest Park, Georgia, as provided by the law of the State of Georgia. By the enactment of this section, the city manager is directed to procure from the county the assessment made by said county on real property located in the corporate limits. 
(b)  Exemption for owner-occupied single family dwellings. 
(1)  The city shall allow an exemption in the amount of one thousand dollars ($1,000.00) for purposes of determining the amount of ad valorem taxes to be paid on real property of a dwelling which is owned and occupied by the owner of said real property provided that said owner-occupier shall make application to the city as herein set forth. 
(2)  In order to qualify for this tax exemption, the owner of said real property shall complete an application provided for by the city and file same with the tax clerk of the city. The form shall require the name of the owner of the real property, the name of the occupant of the real property, and the address of the real property. 
(3)  The forms shall be filed when the initial exemption is claimed, and shall be automatically renewed by the city in each subsequent year for so long as the premises are occupied by the owner. 
(c)  Special exemptions for disabled persons and persons above the age of 65 years. 
(1)  The city shall allow an exemption in the amount of $4,000 for purposes of determining the amount of ad valorem taxes to be paid on real property of any person who owns said real property and provides the tax clerk with a letter from a licensed physician stating that said person is totally and permanently disabled for all purposes whatsoever. The city shall also allow an exemption in the amount of $4,000 for purposes of determining the amount of ad valorem taxes to be paid on real property of any person who owns said real property and provides the tax clerk with a copy of a birth certificate, valid Georgia driver's license, or other form of identification which is acceptable to the tax clerk of the city, which shows that person having attained the age of 65 years prior to January 1 of the next year for which ad valorem taxes will be assessed. However, no owner of real property within the city shall be entitled to claim more than one of the tax exemptions set forth in this code section. 
(2)  The tax clerk shall make proper notation on the tax records in order to reflect such disability, or age. 
(Code 1959, § 19-2, as amended by Ord. No. 82-266, 6/21/82; Ord. No. 86-008, 5/5/86) 
Sec. 3-2-3. - Time for fixing tax rate. 
The governing body shall, on or before the first regular meeting in July of each year, prescribe, fix, and levy an ad valorem rate of taxation against all the property returned and assessed as provided in this code of ordinances, the charter of the city and the law of the state. 
Editor's note— The ad valorem tax rate is generally set at the second council meeting in June following adoption of the annual budget. 
Sec. 3-2-4. - Date taxes due and payable; interest on delinquent taxes. 
All ad valorem taxes due the city on all property in the city subject to taxation shall be due and payable annually. Any such tax not paid by December 20 shall be declared delinquent. Delinquent taxes shall accrue interest at the highest legal rate per annum authorized by state law from December 20 to the date payment is made. 
All ad valorem tax payments shall be first applied to the oldest taxes due until all ad valorem taxes, past due and current, are fully paid. 
(Ord. No. 08-02, § 1, 1-7-2008) 
Editor's note— At the city's instruction Ord. No. 08-02, § 1, adopted Jan. 7, 2008 was placed in § 3-2-4. 
State Law reference— Rate of interest (one percent (1%) per month) on past due taxes, O.C.G.A., § 48-2-40. 
Sec. 3-2-5. - Executions for unpaid taxes; sales. 
(a)  For any and all unpaid taxes during any year, executions shall be issued against the property and the owners thereof on or after December 20 of each year for the amount of taxes due, the interest thereon and such fee for the issuance of the execution as provided by law. Such execution shall be issued by the city clerk and bear teste in the name of the mayor and shall be levied by the chief of police or any other police officer of the city. Such execution shall bind all the property, real and personal, of the defendant; and the costs thereof shall be the same as on tax collector's executions by the laws of this state. 
(b)  The execution shall be levied by the chief of police or any other police officer of the city, upon such property as in the discretion of the levying officer may be suitable or available for such purposes, and the same shall be advertised once a week for four (4) weeks next preceding the date of sale in the official organ of Clayton County or in a newspaper having general circulation in the city. Sales of such property shall be conducted on the first Tuesday of the month before the door of the city hall, or in the council chambers, between the hours of 10:00 a.m. and 4:00 p.m., and the same shall be conducted by the chief of police, or any other police officer. All property shall be sold at public outcry to the highest bidder for cash.
