Licensees collecting the tax shall be allowed a percentage of the tax due and accounted for, and shall be reimbursed in the form of a deduction in submitting, reporting and paying the amount due, if said amount is not delinquent at the time of payment. The rate of the deduction shall be the same rate authorized for deductions from state tax under the Georgia Retailers' and Consumers' Sales and Use Tax Act, approved February 20, 1951 (Georgia Laws, p. 360), as now or hereafter amended. 
(Ord. No. 83-275, 3-21-83, as amended by Ord. No. 83-277, 5-2-83) 
Sec. 3-4-10. - Determination if no return made. 
Estimate of gross receipts. If any licensee fails to make a return, the city manager shall make an estimate of the amount of the gross receipts of the licensee, or as the case may be, of the total sales in the city which are subject to the tax. The estimate shall be made for the period or periods in respect to which the licensee failed to make the return and shall be based upon any information which is or may come into the possession of the city manager. Upon the basis of this estimate, the city manager shall compute and determine the amount required to be paid to the city, adding to the sum thus determined a penalty equal to 15 percent thereof. One or more determinations may be made for one or more than one period. 
(Ord. No. 83-275, 3-21-83) 
Sec. 3-4-11. - Collection of delinquent tax by city; duty of assignees to withhold taxes; liability, offsetting erroneous collections. 
(a)  Action for tax; time for. At any time within three (3) years after any tax or any amount of tax required to be collected becomes due and payable, and at any time within three (3) years after the delinquency of any tax or any amount of tax required to be collected, the city may bring an action in the courts of this state, or any other state, or of the United States, to collect the amount delinquent, together with penalties and interest, court fees, filing fees, attorneys' fees, and other legal fees incident thereto. 
(b)  Duty of successors or assignees of operator to withhold tax from purchase money. If any licensee liable for any amount under this chapter sells out his business or quits the business, his successors or assigns shall withhold sufficient of the purchase price to cover such amount until the former owner produces a receipt from the city showing that he has been paid, or a certificate stating that no amount is due. 
(c)  Liability for failure to withhold; certificate of notice of amount due; time to enforce successor's liability. If the purchaser of a business fails to withhold the necessary amount from the purchase price as heretofore required, he becomes personally liable for the payment of the amount required to be withheld by him to the extent of the purchase price, valued in money. Within 30 days after receiving a written request from the purchaser for a certificate, the city shall either issue the certificate or mail notice to the purchaser at his address as it appears on the records of the city of the amount that must be paid as a condition of issuing the certificate. The time within which the obligation of a successor may be enforced shall begin at the time the licensee sells out his business or at the time that the determination against the licensee becomes final, whichever event occurs the later. 
(Ord. No. 83-275, 3-21-83) 
Sec. 3-4-12. - Administration; enforcement; rules; records; confidentiality of reports. 
(a)  Authority of the city manager. The city manager shall administer and enforce the provisions of this chapter for the levy and collection of the tax imposed by this chapter. 
(b)  Rules and regulations. The city manager shall have the power and authority to make and publish reasonable rules and regulations pursuant to section 2-3-2 not inconsistent with this chapter or other ordinances of the city and the laws of the State of Georgia, or the constitution of this state or the United States, for the administration and enforcement of the provisions of this chapter and the collection of the taxes hereunder. 
(c)  Records required from licensee; form. Every licensee for the sale of alcoholic beverages by the drink in the city to a person shall keep such records, receipts, invoices, and other pertinent papers in such form as the city manager may require. 
(d)  Examination of records; audits. The city manager or the chief of police, or any person authorized in writing by the mayor, may examine the books, papers, records, financial reports, equipment and other facilities of any licensee liable for the tax, in order to verify the accuracy of any return made, or if no return is made by the licensee, to ascertain and determine the amount required to be paid. 
(e)  Authority to require reports, contents. In the administration of the provisions of this chapter, the city manager may require the filing of reports by any person or class of persons having in such person's or persons' possession or custody information relating to sales of alcoholic beverages which are subject to the tax. The reports shall be filed with the city manager and shall set forth the price charged for each sale, the date or dates of sales, and such other information as the city manager may require. 
(f)  Disclosure of business of operators, etc.; limitation on rule. The city manager or any person having an administrative duty under this chapter, shall not make known in any manner the business affairs, operations or information obtained by an audit of books, papers, records, financial reports, equipment and other facilities of any licensee or any other person visited or examined in the discharge of official duty, or the amount or source of income, profits, losses, expenditures or any particular thereof, set forth or disclosed in any return, or to permit any return or copy thereof or any book containing any abstract or particulars thereof to be seen or examined by any person not having such administrative duty under this chapter, except in the case of judicial proceedings, or other proceedings necessary to collect the tax hereby levied and assessed. Successors, receivers, trustees, executors, administrators, assignees and guarantors, if directly interested, upon satisfactory proof of interest, may be given information as to the items included in the measure and amount of unpaid tax or amounts of tax required to be collected, interest and penalties. 
(Ord. No. 83-275, 3-21-83) 
CHAPTER 5. - HOTEL, MOTEL, LODGING EXCISE TAX 

Sec. 3-5-1. - Assessment. 
Pursuant to O.C.G.A. § 48-13-51(a)(1)(A) there is hereby assessed and levied an excise tax upon the furnishing for value to the public of any room, lodging or accommodations furnished by any person licensed by the city for operating a hotel, motel, inn, lodge, tourist camp, tourist cabin or any other place in which rooms, lodging or accommodations are regularly furnished for value. Said tax shall be three (3) percent of the charge to the public for such rooms, lodgings or accommodations. This tax shall not apply to the charges for the use of meeting rooms or for any rooms, lodgings or accommodations furnished to and occupied by the same person for a period of more than ten (10) consecutive days. 
(Ord. No. 87-019, 11-2-87; Ord. No. 05-36, § 1, 6-20-2005) 
Sec. 3-5-2. - Owner/operator to collect taxes. 
The owner or operator of the lodging facility shall collect the excise taxes as set forth in this chapter and shall remit the same to the city as hereinafter provided. Any owner or operator who shall neglect, fail or refuse to collect the tax herein provided shall be liable for and pay the tax personally. 
(Ord. No. 87-019, 11-2-87) 
Sec. 3-5-3. - Returns and payment of taxes. 
The owner or operator liable for the taxes set out herein shall on or before the 20th day of each month, for the preceding calendar month, transmit to the city clerk a statement showing the gross sales and gross taxes collected by authority of this chapter. Along with said statement, the owner or operator shall submit payment to the city clerk for the net taxes due. 
(Ord. No. 87-019, 11-2-87) 
Sec. 3-5-4. - Compensation for collecting tax. 
For the purpose of compensating the owner or operator for collecting, accounting for and remitting the tax levied by the chapter, such owner or operator shall be allowed three (3) percent of the amount of the tax due and accounted for and remitted to the city in the form of a deduction when submitting the report and paying the amount due. 
(Ord. No. 87-019, 11-2-87) 
Sec. 3-5-5. - Penalty for failure to make return for payment. 
When any owner or operator shall fail to make any return or pay the full amount of the tax required by this chapter, there shall be imposed a specific penalty to be added to the tax in the amount of five (5) percent or five dollars ($5.00), whichever is greater, if the failure is for not more than ten (10) days, with an additional five (5) percent or five dollars ($5.00), whichever is greater, for each additional ten (10) days or fraction thereof during which the failure continues. 
(Ord. No. 87-019, 11-2-87) 
Sec. 3-5-6. - Records inspection. 
In order to aid in the administration and enforcement of the provisions of this chapter and to collect all of the tax imposed, all owners or operators are hereby required to keep a record of all sales and charges for rooms or lodging and the taxes collected. Said records shall be open for inspection by any duly authorized agent of the city at all reasonable hours during the day. 
(Ord. No. 87-019, 11-2-87) 
CHAPTER 6. - BUDGET 

Sec. 3-6-1. - Fiscal year. 
The fiscal year for the City of Forest Park shall commence on July 1 of each year and shall terminate at midnight on June 30 of each year. 
(Ord. No. 89-002, 1-16-89) 
Sec. 3-6-2. - Budget ordinance. 
The final budget, when approved by the governing body, shall be adopted as the city's budget by ordinance. This ordinance shall take the form of an appropriations ordinance setting out the estimated revenues in detail by sources and making appropriations according to fund and by organizational unit, purpose, or activity. 
(Ord. No. 89-002, 1-16-89) 
Sec. 3-6-3. - Budget contents. 
(a)  The scope of any and all budgets acted upon by the governing body shall address itself to the projected revenues and expenses to be incurred by the city for the upcoming fiscal year. 
(b)  Content of the budget. The final budget, as well as the preliminary budgets and worksheets shall contain a breakdown of projected revenues by fund source and a breakdown of departmental expenses for the upcoming fiscal year. They may also contain any item that the department head deems appropriate for inclusion in its budget. 
(c)  The form of the final budget, when passed and adopted by the governing body, shall take the form of an appropriations ordinance and shall set out the estimated revenues in detail by sources and make appropriations according to fund and by organizational unit, purpose, or activity, so that the budget, in its final form, will contain a complete and accurate disclosure of the city's anticipated revenues and expenses for the upcoming fiscal year. 
(Ord. No. 89-002, 1-16-89) 
Sec. 3-6-4. - Preparation of annual budget. 
The annual budget for the city shall be prepared substantially as follows: 
(1)  On or before February 10 of each year, budget worksheets and preliminary budget instructions shall be distributed to operating departments for use in preparing their respective budget requests. 
(2)  The city manager shall publish, or cause to be published, a calendar schedule for various elements and phases of preparation and review essential to the completion of a proposed annual budget for the city. 
(3)  Not less than thirty (30) days prior to the first regularly scheduled council meeting in June of each year, the city manager shall provide the mayor and council with a proposed operating budget for the next fiscal year commencing July 1. 
(4)  Not later than the first regularly scheduled council meeting in June of each year, the city manager shall provide the mayor and council with a recommended budget for the next fiscal year commencing July 1. 
(5)  Along with a general operating budget for the city, the city manager shall prepare, in accordance with the same schedule, a capital budget for the city. 
(Ord. No. 89-002, 1-16-89) 
Sec. 3-6-5. - Capital improvement budget. 
In the event that same becomes necessary, a budget shall also be prepared following the procedures set forth [in section 3-6-4] above for a capital improvement program. 
(Ord. No. 89-002, 1-16-89) 
Sec. 3-6-6. - Line item transfers by the city administrator. 
(a)  Subject to the exception contained in subsection (c) below, the city council, by majority vote, may make changes in the appropriations contained in the current operating budget at any regular meeting, special or emergency meeting called for such purpose. Any additional appropriations may be made only from an existing unexpended surplus, with the same reflected in the minutes. Subject to the exception contained in subsection (c) below, the council only shall have the authority to make changes in the adopted budget to shift funds from one (1) line item to another. 
(b)  Changes to the original budget ordinance. In the event that the financial affairs of the city require material alterations from the original budget ordinance, then, upon a finding by the governing body that changes need to be made in the budget, the governing body is authorized to change the budget by the enactment of an ordinance which shall set forth the reason that the change is being made and what part or parts of the budget are to be changed. 
(c)  Notwithstanding subsections (a) and (b) above, the city manager shall be authorized, without further action by the mayor and council, to transfer funds from one (1) line item in a department to another line item within the same department. His authorization to transfer funds from one (1) line item to another line item shall be limited to the amount of five thousand dollars ($5,000.00) or less. Further, this authorization shall not be used directly or indirectly to add positions of employment with the city. 
Any such transfer of funds shall be promptly reported to the mayor and council at the next regular meeting or work session. 
(Ord. No. 89-002, 1-16-89; Ord. No. 99-004, 3-1-99)

Sec. 3-7-2. - Fees and charges, department of public works. 
That certain document entitled "Public Works Department," identified as Addendum A, and attached hereto, is hereby incorporated herein by reference, and each of the fees, charges, and penalties is hereby adopted and approved by the governing body. 
(Ord. No. 08-12, § 1, 3-17-2008)

That certain document entitled "Department of Parks, Recreation, and Cultural Affairs," identified as Addendum B, and attached hereto, is hereby incorporated herein by reference, and each of the fees, charges and penalties is hereby adopted and approved by the governing body. 
(Ord. No. 08-12, § 1, 3-17-2008)

Title 4 - Police and Fire Services 
Chapter 1.  Law Enforcement 
Chapter 2.  Fire Prevention and Protection 
Chapter 3.  Civil Defense 
Chapter 4.  Alarm Systems; False Alarms 
Chapter 5.  Emergency Management 
CHAPTER 1. - LAW ENFORCEMENT 

Sec. 4-1-1. - Department established; powers; duties and responsibilities of director. 
(a)  There is hereby established a department of police services for the city. The department shall be composed of a director and such other officers and employees as are from time to time deemed necessary by the mayor and council. The director of the department of police services shall be appointed by the city manager in accordance with the provisions of section 3.14 of the Charter of the city. The director of the department of police services shall serve at the pleasure of the city manager and the mayor and council. 
(b)  The director of police services shall be the head of the department of police services and responsible for overseeing the organization, operation and administration of the department of police services and be responsible for overseeing the enforcement of all criminal violations of the Code of Ordinances of the city and the laws of the state. Among other duties of the director, by himself or his designee, he shall oversee the equipment and personnel training, and see that equipment is maintained in a proper condition, and all rules and regulations of the department are carried out. The director shall in person or by duly designated representative, attend all meetings of the governing authority and see to the fulfillment of all other duties and responsibilities imposed upon the department of police services and the director of the department of police services for the city by city charter, state law, ordinances of the city and any and all other lawful charges upon the department of police services. Wherever, in the city charter, this code or in any state law, the chief of police or marshal is directed to perform a certain duty or exercise a certain power, the director shall be responsible for the performance of such duty or the exercise of such power, unless otherwise provided by the governing body. 
(Ord. No. 96-003, § 1, 2-5-96; Ord. No. 99-021, § 1, 12-20-99) 
Sec. 4-1-2. - Traffic division; established. 
There is hereby established in the department of police services for the city a traffic division to be under the supervision and control of a police officer appointed by and directly responsible to the director of police services. 
(Ord. No. 96-003, § 2, 2-5-96) 
Sec. 4-1-3. - Same—Duty of traffic division. 
It shall be the responsibility and duty of the traffic division to see to the enforcement of all applicable city and state traffic and motor vehicle laws, rules, regulations and ordinances, to enforce criminal violations of city and state traffic and motor vehicle ordinances, statutes, rules and regulations, to investigate and prepare all required reports relating to traffic accidents and to cooperate with city traffic engineer and other officers and employees of the city in the administration of the traffic laws, rules and regulations and in developing methods to improve traffic and to carry out all other duties and responsibilities now or hereafter imposed upon this division by this chapter, or other traffic ordinances or state statutes, rules, and regulations. 
(Code 1959, § 20-39; Ord. No. 96-003, § 3, 2-5-96) 
Sec. 4-1-4. - Same—Investigate accidents. 
It shall be the duty of the traffic division, assisted by other police officers of the department of police services, to investigate traffic accidents, to arrest and to assist in the prosecution of those persons charged with violations of law causing or contributing to such accidents. 
(Code 1959, § 20-40) 
Sec. 4-1-5. - Same—Traffic accident studies. 
The traffic division shall cooperate with the city traffic engineer in conducting studies of accidents and determining remedial measures. 
(Code 1959, § 20-41) 
Sec. 4-1-6. - Same—Traffic accident reports. 
(a)  It shall be the duty of every member of the department of police services investigating a traffic accident to make a written report of his findings as soon as practicable after completing his investigation. 
(b)  The traffic division shall maintain a suitable system of filing traffic reports, as required by this section. Accident reports or cards referring to them shall be filed alphabetically by location. Such reports shall be available for the use and information of the city traffic engineer. 
(Code 1959, § 20-42) 
Sec. 4-1-7. - Traffic division to submit annual traffic safety report. 
The director of police services shall annually prepare a traffic report which shall be filed with the governing body. Such report shall contain information on traffic matters in this city as follows: 
(1)  The number of traffic accidents, the number of persons killed, the number of persons injured, and other pertinent traffic accident data; 
(2)  The number of traffic accidents investigated and other pertinent data on the safety activities of the police; and 
(3)  The plans and recommendations of the division for future traffic safety activities. 
(Code 1959, § 20-43; Ord. No. 96-003, § 4, 2-5-96) 
Sec. 4-1-8. - Reserved. 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 10-06, adopted Mar. 1, 2010, repealed § 4-1-8, which pertained to alarm systems and derived from Code 1959, § 9A-5). 
CHAPTER 2. - FIRE PREVENTION AND PROTECTION 
ARTICLE A. - DEPARTMENT OF FIRE SERVICES[1] 

Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference— Additional charges for false alarms, § 4-1-8. 

Sec. 4-2-1. - Powers and duties of director of fire and emergency medical services. 
(a)  There is hereby established a department of fire and emergency medical services for the city which shall include the city's emergency management administration. The department shall be composed of a director of fire and emergency medical services and such other officers and employees as may from time to time be appointed and authorized by the mayor and council. The director of the department of fire and emergency medical services shall be appointed by the city manager in accordance with section 3.14 of the Charter of the city. The director of the department of fire and emergency medical services shall serve at the pleasure of the city manager and the mayor and council. The director shall oversee the day-to-day administration of the department. Assistant directors/assistant chiefs may be appointed, along with such other officers and employees as are deemed appropriate and authorized by the mayor and council. Wherever in the city charter, this or other city ordinance, the term "fire department" is used, it shall mean the department of fire and emergency medical services. 
(b)  The director/chief or designee shall be present at all fires or alarms of fire, fully equipped. It shall be his duty to visit the fire houses regularly and see that the houses, apparatus, personnel training and equipment are in proper condition, and that all rules and regulations established for the department of fire and emergency medical services are being carried out. Should the director/chief find anything out of order, or any member derelict in his duty, he shall have authority to recommend immediate suspension of such member. The director of fire and emergency medical services shall report such matter to the personnel director who shall proceed to hear and determine the issues in accordance with the rules and regulations established by the personnel board. The director/chief shall exercise all power and authority conferred upon him by this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 96-003, § 6, 2-5-96; Ord. No. 99-021, § 2, 12-20-99) 
Sec. 4-2-2. - Department rules and regulations. 
The city manager, pursuant to section 2-3-2 of this Code shall establish rules and regulations for the general operation of the department, which shall be obeyed by all members of the department. Any member of the department who violates any such rule or regulation shall be subject to immediate suspension as provided in section 4-2-1. 
Sec. 4-2-3. - Training of firefighters. 
Each and every firefighter shall undergo special training and study in order to be able to better perform his duties, and a training schedule shall be established by the fire chief. 
(Code 1959, § 8-18) 
State Law reference— Firefighter standards and training act, O.C.G.A., § 25-5-14 et seq. 
Sec. 4-2-4. - Persons allowed in vicinity of fire. 
No person, except firefighters, members of the governing body of the city, members of the department of police services, the owners of the property, their agents, and the agents of insurance companies, shall be allowed within the immediate vicinity of any fire without being ordered there by the fire chief or officer in charge of the department of fire services at the time. Any person refusing to obey the orders and directions of the fire chief or other person in charge at the fire shall be arrested, and on conviction therefor, shall be punished as provided in section 1-1-8 of this Code. 
(Code 1959, § 8-8) 
Sec. 4-2-5. - Electric wires, authority to cut. 
The fire chief, or other authority acting under him, is hereby authorized to cut any electric wire which he shall deem necessary to cut on the occurrence of any fire, without expense to the city for doing so; provided that nothing herein contained shall imply that the city authorizes any person to undertake the risk of cutting any such wires or renders itself liable for any injury to the person so doing. 
(Code 1959, § 8-5) 
Sec. 4-2-6. - Obstructing fire house. 
It shall be unlawful for any person willfully or knowingly to put trash or obstruction of any nature whatsoever in front of any engine house or hook and ladder house or place where fire equipment is located. 
(Code 1959, § 8-9) 
Sec. 4-2-7. - Obstructing fire hydrants. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to obstruct with building material or in any other manner whatsoever any cistern or fire hydrant which would obstruct approaches to the same by any member of the department of fire services. No person shall put any posts or installation of any nature whatsoever nearer than eighteen (18) inches to any fire hydrant without first obtaining written permission from the fire chief. 
Sec. 4-2-8. - Fire lanes. 
Fire lanes shall be provided for all buildings that are set back more than one hundred fifty (150) feet (45.75 m) from a public road or exceed thirty (30) feet (9.14 m) in height and are set back over fifty (50) feet (15.25 m) from a public road. 
(Ord. No. 00-01, § 1, 1-18-2000) 
Sec. 4-2-9. - Turnaround for fire apparatus. 
Fire lanes shall be not less than twenty (20) feet (6.1 m) of unobstructed width, able to withstand live loads of fire apparatus and have a minimum of thirteen (13) feet six (6) inches (4.1 m) of vertical clearance. An approved turnaround for fire apparatus shall be provided where an access road is a dead end and is in excess of one hundred fifty (150) feet (45.8 m) in length. The turnaround shall have a minimum centerline radius of fifty (50) feet (15.3 m). The grade of the fire lane shall be within the limits established by the authority having jurisdiction. 
(Ord. No. 00-01, § 1, 1-18-2000) 
Sec. 4-2-10. - Marking of fire lanes. 
Fire lanes shall be marked with freestanding signs or marked curbs, sidewalks, or other traffic surfaces that have the words "FIRE LANE—NO PARKING" painted in contrasting colors at a size and spacing approved by the authority having jurisdiction. 
(Ord. No. 00-01, § 1, 1-18-2000) 
Sec. 4-2-11. - Fire lanes to be free from obstructions. 
Fire lanes shall be maintained free of all obstructions at all times, including parking of vehicles. It shall be unlawful for any person to obstruct a fire lane at any time. 
(Ord. No. 00-01, § 1, 1-18-2000) 
Secs. 4-2-12—4-2-20. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE B. - FIRE PREVENTION CODE AND SAFETY STANDARDS[2] 

Footnotes:

B pertained to similar subject matter and derived from Code 1959, § 8-2; Res. No. 84-181, adopted Sept. 4, 1984; Ord. No. 96-012, adopted Aug. 5, 1996; Ord. Sec. 4-2-21. - Fire prevention code; adoption. 
There is hereby adopted by the city for the purpose of prescribing regulations governing conditions hazardous to life and property from fire or explosion, that certain code known as the National Fire Protection Association (NFPA) Codes and Standards, 2009 edition, which shall include referenced publications and their appendices in their entirety, with all subsequent revisions and updated editions thereto, save and except such portions as are hereinafter deleted, modified or amended, a copy of which code is to be filed in the office of the city clerk, and the same is hereby adopted and incorporated as fully as if set out at length herein, and from the date on which this section shall take effect, the provisions thereof shall be controlling within the limits of the city; provided, however, that should any provisions of the fire prevention code as adopted hereby be in conflict with any other provisions of this Code of Ordinances, the provisions of this Code of Ordinances shall prevail and be controlling. 
Additionally, the city hereby adopts the 2009 International Residential Code (IRC) for the purpose of prescribing regulations governing requirements for sprinklers and energy efficiency standards for residential properties, with all subsequent revisions and updated editions thereto, and same is hereby adopted and incorporated as fully as if set out at length herein, and from the date on which the section shall take effect, the provisions thereof shall be controlling within the limits of the city. 
(Ord. No. 10-08, § 1, 4-5-2010) 
Sec. 4-2-22. - State safety fire rules and regulations adopted. 
The rules and regulations promulgated for the prevention and destruction of life and property by fire, explosion and related hazards in this state by the state safety fire commissioner, under authority of the powers vested in and duties imposed upon the state safety fire commissioner by O.C.G.A., Title 25, chapter 2, (O.C.G.A. § 25-2-1 et seq.) are adopted as the rules and regulations of the city. The rules and regulations of such statute shall govern inspections made for the purpose of eliminating fire hazards in the city. 
The city also adopts all amendments, which the state safety fire commissioner may make from time to time to the rules and regulations promulgated by that office unless such amendments are specifically excluded or superseded by this Code. 
(Ord. No. 10-08, § 1, 4-5-2010) 
Sec. 4-2-23. - Definitions. 
(a)  Wherever the word "municipality" is used in the fire prevention code, it shall be held to mean the City of Forest Park, Georgia. 
(b)  Wherever the term "corporate counsel" is used in the fire prevention code, it shall be held to mean the city attorney. 
(Ord. No. 10-08, § 1, 4-5-2010) 
Sec. 4-2-24. - New processes, materials or occupancies which may require permits. 
The building inspector, fire marshal, fire chief, and the city manager shall act as a committee to determine and specify, after giving affected persons an opportunity to be heard, any new materials, processes or occupancies, which shall require permits, in addition to those now enumerated in said Code. The city clerk shall maintain such list with the fire prevention code for public inspection. 
(Ord. No. 10-08, § 1, 4-5-2010) 
Sec. 4-2-25. - Outdoor burning. 
There shall be no open burning after sunset till sunrise. All other open burning shall be performed only after notification and permission of the fire department, and shall be conducted in accordance with such conditions as required by the department. Open burning, as used in this section, shall not include fireplaces, charcoal grills or small recreational campfires provided they create no fire hazard or smoke nuisance. 
(Ord. No. 10-08, § 1, 4-5-2010) 
Sec. 4-2-26. - Power to cite for violations. 
(a)  The following persons shall have the power and authority to issue citations for violations of any and all provisions of this article: 
(1)  Fire chief; 
(2)  Fire marshal; and 
(3)  Deputy fire marshal. 
(b)  The municipal court of the City of Forest Park shall have jurisdiction over violations of this article. 
(Ord. No. 10-08, § 1, 4-5-2010) 
Secs. 4-2-27—4-2-31. - Reserved. 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 16-11, §§ 1—5, adopted Aug. 17, 2016, repealed §§ 4-2-27—4-2-31, which pertained to sprinklers. For prior history, see Code Comparative Table. 
Sec. 4-2-32. - Penalties. 
Any person or legal entity, upon being found guilty by a court of competent jurisdiction of violation of this article, shall be guilty of a misdemeanor and may be punished in accordance with section 1-1-8. 
(Ord. No. 10-08, § 1, 4-5-2010) 
Secs. 4-2-33, 4-2-34. - Reserved. 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 16-11, §§ 6, 7, adopted Aug. 17, 2016, repealed §§ 4-2-33, 4-2-34, which pertained to appeals and standards of review. For prior history, see Code Comparative Table. 
Sec. 4-2-35. - Automatic sprinkler system not to be disabled. 
No person shall shut off or disable any automatic fire sprinkler system, and no owner, occupant, or resident of any building shall disarm such system. Provided, however, a sprinkler system may be shut off in order to perform maintenance work on the system during the time that qualified maintenance personnel are on the premises performing necessary maintenance work. Such maintenance work shall be conducted after notice to and approval by the fire department. 
A fire watch may be required during the time the water-based fire protection system is removed from service as outlined above. If required by the fire officials, the fire watch shall remain in place until such time as the system(s) are returned to their full capacity. 
(Ord. No. 10-08, § 1, 4-5-2010) 
Sec. 4-2-36. - Fire alarm systems. 
No person shall shut off or disable any fire alarm system, and no owner, occupant, or resident of any building shall disarm such system. Provided, however, an alarm system may be shut off in order to perform maintenance work on the system during the time that qualified maintenance personnel are on the premises performing necessary maintenance work. Such maintenance work shall be conducted after notice to and approval by the fire department. 
A fire watch may be required during the time the water-based fire protection system is removed from service as outlined above. If required by the fire officials, the fire watch shall remain in place until such time as the system(s) are returned to their full capacity. 
(Ord. No. 10-08, § 1, 4-5-2010) 
Sec. 4-2-37. - Key boxes. 
Key boxes shall be required on all new and existing commercial building sites and any and all gated facilities to allow public safety personnel to enter a building quickly in case of an emergency. The key boxes shall be marked, conspicuous, and accessible. The fire officials shall approve the key boxes used and locations. 
(Ord. No. 10-08, § 1, 4-5-2010) 
Secs. 4-2-38—4-2-49. - Reserved. 
Sec. 4-2-50. - Reserved. 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 15-11, § 1, adopted Oct. 5, 2015, repealed § 4-2-50, which pertained to prohibition of fireworks, and derived from Ord. No. 10-08, § 1, 4-5-2010. 
CHAPTER 3. - CIVIL DEFENSE[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
Cross reference— Emergency powers of mayor, § 2-1-11. 
State Law reference— Emergency management responsibilities of local governments, O.C.G.A., § 38-3-27. 

Sec. 4-3-1. - Definition. 
As used in this chapter the term "civil defense" shall mean the preparation for and the carrying out of all emergency functions, other than the functions for which the state and federal governments are primarily responsible, to prevent, minimize, and repair injury and damage resulting from disasters caused by enemy nuclear attack, sabotage, or other hostile action, or by acts of nature, fire, explosion, civil disorders or other causes. These functions include, without limitation, firefighting services, law enforcement services, medical and health services, rescue services, engineering services, warning services, communications, defense from radiological fallout, welfare services, evacuation when and where necessary, emergency transportation, plant and utility protection, restoration of public utility services, and other functions related to protection and well being of the population of the city, together with all other activities necessary or incidental to preparation for the carrying out of the above functions. 
(Code 1959, § 7-1) 
Sec. 4-3-2. - Office of the city civil defense director. 
There is hereby established for the city of an office of emergency management administration. The mayor and council shall nominate for appointment by the governor, the city administrator for emergency management administration for the city. The appointed administrator of emergency management administration shall serve under the supervision and direction of the director of fire and emergency medical services. When appointed, the administrator of emergency management administration is charged: 
(1)  To represent the governing officials of the city on matters pertaining to civil defense. 
(2)  With assisting city officials in organizing city departments for emergency operations. 
(3)  With developing in conjunction with other city departments, the plan for emergency functions set forth in section 4-3-1 of this chapter. Such plan will be in consonance with the state emergency plan and shall be submitted to the mayor and council for approval and thence to the state director for approval. 
(4)  With maintaining the civil defense office in carrying out the day-to-day administration of the civil defense and disaster program including the rendering of required reports to the state emergency management office. 
(5)  Rendering reports such as financial, daily activities, etc., as required by governing officials in keeping with good business practices. 
(6)  Procuring, with authority of governing officials, a facility to be used as the city emergency operating center. 
(7)  During periods of a declared emergency, and under the supervision of governing officials, coordinate the activities of the city emergency operating center staff. 
(Code 1959, § 7-2) 
Sec. 4-3-3. - City civil defense organization. 
(a)  The city civil defense organization shall be established around existing city departments and agencies, and the emergency functions listed in section 4-3-1 above are assigned as provided in the annual program papers as approved by state and federal agencies. 
(b)  Heads of departments are responsible for developing the plan for their assigned emergency function. Such plans will be submitted through the civil defense director to the mayor and council for approval. 
Sec. 4-3-4. - Emergency powers. 
In the event of an actual enemy attack upon the United States or any other disaster which may affect the lives and property of the citizens of the city, the mayor, or in his absence, his legally appointed successor, may declare that a state of emergency exists and thereafter shall have and may exercise for such period as such state of emergency exists or continues, the following emergency powers in addition to those emergency powers granted by section 2-1-12 of this Code: 
(1)  To enforce all rules, laws, and regulations relating to civil defense and to assume direct operational control over all civil defense forces. 
(2)  To seize, take for temporary use, or condemn any property for the protection of the public. 
(2)  To seize, take for temporary use, or condemn any property for the protection of the public. 
(3)  To sell, lend, give, or distribute all or any such property or supplies among the inhabitants of the city, to maintain a strict accounting of property or supplies distributed and for funds received for such property or supplies. 
(4)  To perform and exercise such other functions and duties and take such emergency actions as may be necessary to promote and secure the safety, protection and well being of the inhabitants of the city. 
(Code 1959, § 7-4) 
Sec. 4-3-5. - Volunteers. 
All persons, other than officers and employees of the city, performing emergency functions pursuant to this chapter, shall serve with or without compensation. While engaged in such emergency functions volunteers shall have the same immunities as city officers and employees. 
(Code 1959, § 7-5) 
State Law reference— Immunity of emergency management workers, O.C.G.A., § 38-3-35. 
Sec. 4-3-6. - Penalties. 
Any person violating any provision of this chapter, or any rule, order or regulation made pursuant to this chapter, shall, upon conviction thereof, be punished as provided by law for the punishment of violators of city ordinances. 
(Code 1959, § 7-6) 
Cross reference— General penalty for code violations, § 1-1-8. 
Sec. 4-3-7. - Liberality of construction. 
This chapter shall be construed liberally in order to effectuate its purposes. 
(Code 1959, § 7-7) 
Sec. 4-4-1. - Purpose. 
The purpose of this article is to encourage alarm users and alarm companies to use and maintain alarms and alarm systems properly and to reduce or eliminate false alarms, which unduly divert Forest Park law enforcement and fire personnel from responding to actual threats and emergencies. This article governs systems intended to summon law enforcement and fire fighter responses, requires registration, establishes fees, provides for penalties for violations, establishes a system of administration and sets conditions and procedures for revocation of registration. 
(Ord. No. 10-06, § 1, 3-1-2010) 
Sec. 4-4-2. - Definitions. 
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the text clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Alarm administrator means a person or persons designated by the city chief of police to administer, control and review false alarm reduction efforts, and to administer this article A. 
Alarm company means any business, whether operated by an individual, partnership, corporation or other entity, which is in the business of, or is licensed to, sell, lease, maintain, service, repair, alter, replace, remove, move, install or monitor alarm systems at an alarm site. 
Alarm dispatch request means a notification to the city police department or fire department that an alarm, whether manual or automated, has been activated at an alarm site. 
Alarm site means a single fixed location served by an alarm system or systems. 
Alarm or alarm system means any mechanized and/or electronic device or set of devices intended to detect and signal the need for police or fire personnel at the premises or the alarm site within or upon which such device or set of devices is installed. 
Alarm user means, with respect to any premises or alarm site, any person who owns, leases, manages, or otherwise controls such premises or alarm site, whether such ownership, leasing, management, or control is shared with other persons and whether it is direct or indirect. 
Applicant means the individual who signs and files an application for an alarm registration certificate under this article. 
Automatic dialer or auto-dialer means any electrical, electronic, mechanical or other device designed or intended to call a pre-designated telephone number in the event of activation of an alarm system. 
Chief of police shall mean the director of the department of police services as set forth in Section 4-1-1 of this Code of Ordinances. 
City or Forest Park shall mean the City of Forest Park, Georgia. 
City police department or police department shall mean the city's department of police services as set forth in Title 4, Chapter 1 of this Code of Ordinances. 
Duress alarm means a silent alarm system signal generated by the manual activation of a device intended to signal a life-threatening situation or crime in progress requiring law enforcement response. 
False alarm means an alarm dispatch request resulting in the responding police officer or fire fighter finding no evidence of a criminal offense, attempted criminal offense, or fire, smoke, or other life or property threatening situation after having completed a timely investigation of the alarm site. 
Holdup alarm means a silent alarm signal generated by the manual activation of a device intended to signal a robbery in progress. 
Individual means an individual human being. 
Local alarm system means any alarm system that annunciates an alarm only by an internal or external audio device. 
Notice or notification means sending written notice via U.S. mail, First Class postage pre-paid, addressed to the address provided by the addressee to the city under this article, including but not limited to the address provided to the city by an applicant for an alarm registration certificate as provided in Section 4-4-3 of this Code. 
Panic alarm means an audible alarm system signal generated by the manual activation of a device intended to signal a life-threatening or emergency situation requiring law enforcement response. 
Person means an individual, corporation, partnership, association, organization or similar entity. 
Premises means an individual parcel of real estate devoted to a common land use, or occupied by a building or group of buildings devoted to a common use, together with customary accessories and open spaces devoted to such use. There may be more than one (1) alarm site on a single premises. 
Response means whenever an alarm is activated in the city, police personnel or fire personnel respond to and inspect the alarm site, and determine whether the response was in fact necessary or whether the alarm was a false alarm. 
Takeover means the transaction or process by which an alarm user assumes control of an existing alarm system, which was previously controlled by another alarm user. 
(Ord. No. 10-06, § 1, 3-1-2010) 
Sec. 4-4-3. - Registration required. 
(1)  No alarm user shall operate, or cause to be operated, an alarm system at any alarm site within the city without first obtaining a valid alarm registration certificate issued by the city police department. A separate registration certificate is required for each alarm site. 
(2)  A tenant of any commercial or residential unit within a multi-unit complex shall obtain an alarm registration certificate from the city police department before operating or causing the operation of an alarm or an alarm system in the tenant's individual unit. The owner or property manager of a commercial or residential multi-unit complex shall obtain a separate alarm registration certificate for any alarm system operated in an office or in any common areas of the multi-unit complex. Each individual unit within a commercial or residential multi-unit complex shall be considered an alarm site if served by a separate alarm or alarm system. 
(3)  A registration application must be submitted to the city within thirty (30) days after any alarm installation or alarm takeover. An alarm registration certificate cannot be transferred to another person or alarm site. 
(4)  Upon receipt of a completed application and applicable fee, the alarm administrator shall register the applicant and issue a registration certificate unless the applicant has: 
(a)  Failed to pay a fine or fee assessed under this article; or 
(b)  Had an alarm registration certificate revoked and the violation causing the revocation has not been corrected. 
(c)  Each alarm registration application shall include the following information: 
(1)  The name, complete address and telephone number(s) of the individual who will be the registration holder and who will be responsible for the proper maintenance and operation of the alarm system and payment of fees and fines assessed under this article; 
(2)  The alarm site shall be identified as either residential (includes condominium, mobile home, apartment home, separate dwelling, etc.) or commercial (includes churches, schools, offices, businesses, retail establishments, etc.); 
(3)  The classification of each alarm system (i.e., burglary, holdup, duress, panic or other) at the alarm site; 
(4)  The complete physical address of the alarm site to include any suite, building or apartment number, letter, and any other identifying information; 
(5)  Any dangerous or special conditions present at the alarm site; 
(6)  The name, address and telephone number of at least two (2) individuals who are able and have agreed to: 
a.  Receive notification of an alarm activation at any time; and 
b.  Respond to the alarm site within thirty (30) minutes; and 
c.  Grant access to the alarm site and deactivate the alarm system if necessary. 
(7)  The type of business, if any, conducted at the alarm site; 
(8)  A signed certification from the alarm user stating: 
a.  The date of installation, conversion or takeover of the alarm system; 
b.  The name, address, phone number and low voltage license number of the alarm company performing the alarm system installation, conversion or takeover and which is responsible for providing repair service to the alarm system, and whether the alarm company will be responsible for monitoring the alarm system; 
c.  The full name, address, and telephone number of the alarm company monitoring the alarm system if different from the installing alarm company; 
d.  That the applicant possesses a current set of written operating instructions for the alarm system, including written guidelines on how to avoid false alarms; 
e.  That the alarm company has trained the applicant in proper use of the alarm system, including instructions on how to avoid false alarms. 
(d)  Any false statement of a material fact made by an applicant for the purpose of obtaining an alarm registration shall be sufficient cause for refusal to issue a registration or to revoke a registration previously granted. 
(e)  An alarm user shall inform the city's alarm administrator of any change that alters any information listed on the alarm registration application within thirty (30) business days following the change. 
(Ord. No. 10-06, § 1, 3-1-2010) 
Sec. 4-4-4. - Government immunity. 
Registration of an alarm system is not intended to, nor does it, create any contract, duty or obligation, either expressed or implied, of a response, or any particular level or time of response, by the city's police department or fire department. Any and all liability and damage resulting from the failure to respond to an alarm dispatch request is disclaimed and all governmental immunity as well as official immunity as provided by law is retained. By registering an alarm system, the alarm user acknowledges that law enforcement response and fire fighter response may be based on numerous variable factors, including but not limited to availability of police units, fire units and equipment, priority of calls, weather conditions, traffic conditions, emergency conditions and staffing levels. 
(Ord. No. 10-06, § 1, 3-1-2010) 
Sec. 4-4-5. - Duties of an alarm user. 
(1)  An alarm user shall: 
(a)  Maintain the premises and the alarm system in a manner that will minimize or eliminate false alarms; and 
(b)  Arrive or cause a representative to arrive, at an alarm site within thirty (30) minutes following a request from any city police officer or fire fighter so as to deactivate a malfunctioning alarm system, or to provide access to the premises, or to provide alternative security for the premises. 
(c)  An alarm user shall adjust the alarm system or cause the alarm system to be adjusted so that an alarm signal audible on the exterior of an alarm site will sound for no longer than ten (10) minutes after being activated, or fifteen (15) minutes for alarm systems operating under Underwriter Laboratories, Inc. Standards 365, 609, and 611. 
(d)  An alarm user shall have an alarm company inspect the alarm system after two (2) false alarms in any calendar year. In such instances, the alarm user must submit to the city's alarm administrator written certification from an alarm company stating that the alarm system has been inspected and that repairs or modifications, if necessary, have been made so as to prevent or minimize false alarms in the future. The alarm administrator may waive an inspection requirement if he or she determines that a false alarm(s) could not have been related to a defect or malfunction in the alarm system. After four (4) false alarms within any one (1) calendar year, the alarm user must have an alarm company modify the alarm system to be more false alarm resistant and/or to provide additional alarm user training as appropriate. 
(2)  An alarm user shall maintain at each alarm site a set of written operating instructions for each alarm or alarm system. 
(Ord. No. 10-06, § 1, 3-1-2010) 
Sec. 4-4-6. - Prohibited acts. 
(1)  It shall be a violation of this article for any person to: 
(a)  Operate an alarm system during the period in which the applicable alarm registration is revoked or suspended or otherwise not in effect; or 
(b)  Transmit or cause to be transmitted a false alarm; or 
(c)  Activate, except in the event of an actual emergency, any alarm system for the purpose of summoning a law enforcement or fire fighter response; or 
(d)  Notify the city police department through the E-911 system of any alarm activation by means of an auto-dialer, or telephonic recording, message, signal or warning; or 
(e)  Aid or abet in the commission of any act prohibited in this section. 
(2)  Any person violating or failing to comply with any of the provisions of this article may be summoned to the city's municipal court for each violation and/or instance of noncompliance and, upon conviction, shall be punished as provided by a fine not to exceed one thousand dollars ($1,000.00), or by imprisonment not to exceed sixty (60) days, or both, for each individual offense. 
(Ord. No. 10-06, § 1, 3-1-2010) 
Sec. 4-4-7. - Fees and fines. 
For each police or fire fighter response to a false alarm under this article, a city police officer may issue a written citation for the offender to appear in the city's municipal court at a designated time and place to answer the charge or charges against him or her for violating this article; in lieu of or in addition the issuance of a citation, the police officer or the fire fighter shall also notify the alarm administrator of the false alarm, who shall then charge and collect fees from the alarm user as follows: 
Alarm registration fees: 
*Residential alarm systems: Free 
*Commercial alarm systems: $25.00 
Registered alarms fines: 
*First, second, and third false alarm in a calendar year: No fee. 
*Fourth false alarm in a calendar year: $50.00. 
*Fifth false alarm in a calendar year: $75.00. 
*Sixth and each subsequent alarm thereafter in a calendar year: $100.00. 
Un-registered alarms fines: 
*For the first false alarm in a calendar year, a registered or certified letter will be sent via U.S. mail giving the person ten (10) calendar days to register his or her alarm or alarm system. If the person fails to register the alarm or alarm system within the time allotted, a fee of one hundred dollars ($100.00) will be assessed. 
*Second false alarm in a calendar year: $100.00. 
*Third false alarm in a calendar year: $200.00. 
*Fourth false alarm and each subsequent alarm thereafter in a calendar year: $300.00. 
Such fees shall be remitted to the alarm administrator not later than thirty (30) days after the date on which notification is mailed to the alarm user. 
In the event an alarm user is convicted for transmitting a false alarm pursuant to this article and is thereby required to pay a fine assessed by the city's municipal court, the alarm user shall nevertheless be required to pay any fees under this article in addition to the criminal penalty assessed. 
Failure to remit payment of fees or fines assessed pursuant to this section within thirty (30) days following notice may result in a citation to appear in the city's municipal court, and may also result in the revocation of the applicable registration certificate under this article. 
(Ord. No. 10-06, § 1, 3-1-2010) 
Sec. 4-4-8. - Duties of the alarm administrator. 
The city's alarm administrator shall be appointed by the chief of police. The alarm administrator shall: 
(1)  Designate the manner, form and telephone numbers for the communication of alarm dispatch requests; and 
(2)  Establish a procedure to accept cancellation of alarm dispatch requests. 
(3)  The alarm administrator shall establish procedures for recording and maintaining information on alarm dispatch requests, and procedures for notifying alarm users of false alarms. 
(4)  If there is reason to believe that an alarm system is not being used or maintained in a manner that ensures proper operation and suppresses false alarms, the alarm administrator may require a conference with an alarm user and/or the alarm company to review the circumstances of each false alarm. Failure to participate in such a conference may result in revocation of the alarm user's alarm registration. 
(5)  The alarm administrator shall oversee the creation and implementation of an alarm user awareness class for the purpose of informing alarm users of problems created by false alarms and teach alarm users how to operate their alarm system without generating false alarms. 
(Ord. No. 10-06, § 1, 3-1-2010) 
Sec. 4-4-9. - Multiple false alarms; notice and revocation. 
(1)  The alarm administrator shall notify in writing the alarm user of any fees assessed under this article. Notice shall be deemed received if sent via United States mail, First Class postage pre-paid, addressed to the alarm user at the address that has been provided to the city by the alarm user pursuant to this article. The notification shall include the amount of the fees for each false alarm, notice that the alarm user can attend alarm user awareness class to abate the fee for the second false alarm, if applicable, and a description of the appeals procedure. 
(2)  The alarm administrator shall notify the alarm user in writing that the applicable alarm registration is revoked and the reasons therefore as listed in Section 4-4-10. This notice of revocation shall include a description of the appeals procedure. 
(Ord. No. 10-06, § 1, 3-1-2010) 
Sec. 4-4-10. - Revocation. 
An alarm registration may be revoked if: 
(1)  The alarm user has five (5) or more false alarms in any calendar year; or 
(2)  The alarm user habitually fails to comply with Sections 4-4-5 or 4-4-6, or both; or 
(3)  There is a false statement of a material fact in the application for registration; or 
(4)  The alarm user has failed to make timely payment of a fine or fee assessed under Section 4-4-7 of this article; or 
(5)  The alarm user has failed to timely submit to the alarm administrator a written certification from an alarm company, in compliance with the requirements of this article, stating that the alarm system has been inspected, and repaired if necessary, by the alarm company; or 
(6)  The commission of one (1) or more of the acts prohibited under Section 4-4-6. 
(Ord. No. 10-06, § 1, 3-1-2010) 
Sec. 4-4-11. - Appeals. 
(a)  An alarm user may appeal the assessment of a fee, the denial of alarm registration, or the revocation of alarm registration by the alarm administrator, to the chief of police. An appeal fee of twenty-five dollars ($25.00) shall accompany the appeal. The appeal fee will be returned to the alarm user if the appeal is successful. The filing of an appeal with the chief of police shall stay the assessment of a fee or suspension or revocation until the chief of police can make a decision on the appeal. 
(b)  Appeals must be submitted to the chief of police within ten (10) days of the date on which notice of a fee, revocation, or denial of alarm registration is mailed. 
(c)  If the appeal is denied, the chief of police shall send written notice to the appellant of the action and a statement of the right to further appeal. An alarm user may appeal the decision of the chief of police to the city manager by filing a written request within ten (10) days of the date of the decision by the chief of police. 
(1)  Upon receiving an appeal, the city manager shall conduct a hearing and consider evidence presented by interested parties. The city manager shall make his decision in writing based upon his determination of all relevant facts based on a preponderance of evidence presented at the hearing and shall render a decision within thirty (30) days after the hearing. The city manager shall affirm or reverse the action of the chief of police. The decision of the city manager shall be final and binding upon the parties to the appeal, but either party may appeal the city manager's decision by applying for a writ of certiorari to the Superior Court of Clayton County, Georgia, within the time allowed by Georgia law. 
(2)  The filing of a request for appeal to the city manager shall stay an action by the alarm administrator or the chief of police until the city manager reaches a decision. If a request for appeal is not made to the city manager within the ten-day period, the decision of the chief of police will be final. 
(Ord. No. 10-06, § 1, 3-1-2010) 
Sec. 4-4-12. - Reinstatement. 
(a)  A person whose alarm registration has been revoked may submit a request for reinstatement of an alarm registration to the alarm administrator. The request shall be granted if the person: 
(1)  Submits an updated application; 
(2)  Pays all outstanding alarm fees and/or fines that have been assessed under this article; 
(3)  Submits certification from an alarm company showing proof, including the nature and cost, of repairs intended to eliminate the incidence of false alarms; 
(4)  Successfully completes the alarm user awareness class; 
(5)  Pays a reinstatement fee of one hundred dollars ($100.00); and 
(6)  Submits proof of judicial resolution of charges, if any, which were made under this article and which resulted in the revocation. 
(Ord. No. 10-06, § 1, 3-1-2010) 
Sec. 4-4-13. - Confidentiality. 
Information obtained by the city pursuant to this article shall be held in confidence by employees or representatives of city, and access to such information shall be permitted only to the extent required by the Georgia Open Records Law, O.C.G.A. § 50-18-70 et seq., including but not limited to O.C.G.A. § 50-18-72(a)(11.2). 
(Ord. No. 10-06, § 1, 3-1-2010) 
Sec. 4-4-14. - Exemptions. 
The provisions of this article shall not apply to the City of Forest Park, Georgia, or to any city agency, board, or authority. This article shall apply to other governmental agencies and entities. 
(Ord. No. 10-06, § 1, 3-1-2010) 
Sec. 4-4-15. - Implementation. 
Any alarm system installed in any location prior to the effective date of this article, must register upon receiving notification. However, any alarm system that is unable to meet the standards contained in this article, must meet such standards on or before September 1, 2010. Proof of such compliance must be submitted to the alarm administrator. Failure to comply with this section will result in revocation of registration as outlined in Section 4-4-10. 
(Ord. No. 10-06, § 1, 3-1-2010) 
Sec. 4-4-16. - Standards for installation and alteration of alarm systems. 
The installation and alteration of alarm systems shall be in accordance with Article 760 "Fire Protective Signaling Systems" of the National Electrical Code, NFPA #70-1975 and the following NFPA standards: 
(1)  Standard 71—Standard for the installation, maintenance, and use of central station signaling systems. 
(2)  Standard 72-B—Standard for the installation, maintenance, and use of auxiliary protective signaling systems for fire alarm service. 
(3)  Standard 72-C—Standard for the installation, maintenance, and use of remote station protective signaling system. 
(4)  Standard 72-D—Standard for the installation, maintenance, and use of remote station protective signaling systems for watchman, fire alarm, and supervisory service. 
(5)  Standard 72-E—Standard on automatic fire detectors. 
(6)  Standard 74—Standard for the installation, maintenance, and use of household fire warning equipment. 
(Ord. No. 10-06, § 1, 3-1-2010) 
CHAPTER 5. - EMERGENCY MANAGEMENT 

Sec. 4-5-1. - Regulations continued in effect. 
All ordinances, resolutions, motions and orders pertaining to civil defense, emergency management and disaster relief, which are not in conflict with this chapter, are continued in full force and effect. Such ordinances, etc., are on file in the office of the city clerk. 
(Ord. No. 13-17, § 1, 8-19-2013) 
Sec. 4-5-2. - Emergency management and response powers. 
(a)  Declaration of local emergency. 
(1)  Grant of authority. In the event of an actual or threatened occurrence of a disaster or emergency, which may result in the large-scale loss of life, injury, property damage or destruction or in the major disruption of routine community affairs, business or governmental operations in the city and which is of sufficient severity and magnitude to warrant extraordinary assistance by federal, state and local departments and agencies to supplement the efforts of available public and private resources, the mayor may declare a local emergency for City of Forest Park. The form of the declaration shall be similar to that provided in subsection (b) of this Code section. 
(2)  Request for state assistance. Consistent with a declaration of local emergency, the mayor may request the governor to provide assistance, provided that the disaster or emergency is beyond the capacity of the city to meet adequately and state assistance is necessary to supplement local efforts to save lives and protect property, public health and safety, or to avert or lessen the threat of a disaster. 
(3)  Continuance . The declaration of local emergency shall continue until the mayor finds that emergency conditions no longer exist, at which time, the mayor shall execute and file with the clerk of the city a document marking the end of the state of emergency. No state of local emergency shall continue for longer than thirty (30) days unless renewed by the mayor. The city council may by resolution, end a state of local emergency at any time. 
(4)  Effect of declaration of emergency. 
a.  Activation of emergency operations plan. A declaration of emergency by the governor or a declaration of local emergency by the mayor shall automatically activate the city emergency operations plan and shall be the authority for deployment of personnel and use of any forces to which the plan applies and for use or distribution of any supplies, equipment, materials, and facilities assembled, stockpiled or arranged to be made available pursuant to the Georgia Emergency Management Act or any other laws applicable to emergencies or disasters. 
1.  The Forest Park Emergency Management Agency (EMA) Director shall have the legal authority to exercise the powers and discharge the duties conferred upon emergency management agency, including the implementation of the emergency operations plan, coordination of the emergency responses of public and private agencies and organizations, coordination of recovery efforts with state and federal officials, and inspection of emergency or disaster sites. 
2.  In responding and conducting necessary and appropriate investigations, the director or his/her designee is authorized to enter at a reasonable time upon any property, public or private, for the purpose of investigating and inspecting sites involved with emergency management functions. The director is authorized to execute a right of entry and/or agreement to use property for these purposes on behalf of the city; however, any such document shall be later presented for ratification at a meeting of the city council. 
3.  No person shall refuse entry or access to any authorized representative or agent of the city who requests entry for purposes of inspection, and who presents appropriate credentials. Nor shall any person obstruct, hamper or interfere with any such representative while that individual is in the process of carrying out his or her official duties. 
b.  Emergency powers. Following a declaration of emergency and during the continuance of such state of emergency, the mayor is authorized to implement local emergency measures to protect life and property or to bring the emergency situation under control. In exercising this authority, the mayor may cause to become effective any of the following sections of this chapter as appropriate: Section 4-5-5 (registration of building and repair services) to become effective if the governor declares a state of emergency; and section 4-5-6 (closed or restricted areas and curfews). If any of these sections are included in a declaration of local emergency, the same shall be filed in the office of the Clerk of the City of Forest Park and shall be in effect until the declaration of local emergency has terminated. 
c.  Authority to waive procedures and fees. Pursuant to a declaration of emergency, the city council is authorized to cause to be effective any of the subsections of section 4-5-4 of this chapter as appropriate. The implementation of such subsections shall be filed in the Office of the Clerk of the City of Forest Park. 
d.  Additional emergency powers. The Mayor of the City of Forest Park shall have, and may exercise for such period as the declared emergency exists or continues, the following additional emergency powers: 
1.  To direct and compel the evacuation of all or part of the population from any stricken or threatened area, for the preservation of life or other disaster mitigation, response or recovery; 
2.  To prescribe routes, modes of transportation and destinations in connection with evacuation; 
3.  To suspend or limit the sale, dispensing or transportation of alcoholic beverages, firearms, explosives and flammable liquids or substances; 
4.  To make provision for the availability and use of temporary emergency housing, emergency shelters and/or emergency medical shelters; 
5.  To transfer the direction, personnel or functions of any city departments and agencies or units thereof for the purpose of performing or facilitating emergency services; 
6.  To utilize all available resources of the city and subordinate agencies over which the city has budgetary control as reasonably necessary to cope with the emergency or disaster; 
7.  To utilize public property when necessary to cope with the emergency or disaster or when there is compelling necessity for the protection of lives, health and welfare, and/or the property of citizens; 
8.  To suspend any law, code provision or regulation prescribing the procedures for conduct or city business, or the orders, rules or regulations of any city agency, if strict compliance with any ordinance, resolution, order, rule or regulation would in any way prevent, hinder or delay necessary action in coping with the emergency or disaster, provided that such suspension shall provide for the minimum deviation from the requirements under the circumstances and further provided that, when practicable, specialists shall be assigned to avoid adverse effects resulting from such suspension; 
9.  To provide benefits to citizens upon execution of an intergovernmental agreement for grants to meet disaster-related necessary expenses or serious needs of individuals or families adversely affected by an emergency or disaster in cases where the individuals or families are unable to meet the expenses or needs from other means, provided that such grants are authorized only when matching state or federal funds are available for such purposes; 
10.  To perform and exercise such other functions, powers and duties as may be deemed necessary to promote and secure the safety and protection of the civilian population, including individuals with household pets and service animals prior to, during and following a major disaster or emergency. 
(b)  Form of declaration of local emergency. Upon the declaration of local emergency, an official "Declaration of Local Emergency," in substantially the same form set forth below, shall be signed and filed in the office of the city clerk and shall be communicated to the citizens of the affected area using the most effective and efficient means available. The declaration shall state the nature of the emergency or disaster, the conditions that require the declaration and any sections of this chapter which shall be in effect. 
DECLARATION OF LOCAL EMERGENCY 
WHEREAS, City of Forest Park, Clayton County, Georgia has experienced an event of critical significance as a result of [description of event] on [date]; and 
WHEREAS, in judgment of the Mayor of the City of Forest Park, with advice from the Forest Park Emergency Management Agency, there exist emergency circumstances located in the City of Forest Park requiring extraordinary and immediate corrective actions for the protection of the health, safety and welfare of the citizens of Forest Park, Clayton County, including individuals with household pets and service animals; and 
WHEREAS, to prevent or minimize injury to people and damage to property resulting from this event 
NOW, THEREFORE, pursuant to authority vested in me by local and state law; 
IT IS HEREBY DECLARED that a local state of emergency exists and shall continue until the conditions requiring this declaration are abated. 
THEREFORE, IT IS ORDERED: 
(1)  That the City of Forest Park Emergency Management Agency activates the Emergency Operations Plan; 
(2)  That the following sections of the City of Forest Park Code be implemented: [if deemed appropriate, choose from the following: Section 4-5-5 Registration of Building and Repair Services to be effective only if the Governor has declared a state of emergency; and/or Section 4-5-6 Closed or Restricted Areas or Curfews]; and 
(3)  That the following measures also be implemented: [If deemed appropriate, select items from subsection (a)(4)d. of this section or other such measures as appropriate.] 
ENTERED at [time] on [date] 
[Signed] 
Mayor, ____________ City of Forest Park 
(c)  Contracts with other agencies. In addition to the normal agreements embodied in the city's emergency operations plan for mutual emergency assistance, the city council may contract with any other agencies for the administration of an emergency response program. 
(Ord. No. 13-17, § 2, 8-19-2013) 
Sec. 4-5-3. - Enforcement and remedies. 
(a)  Law enforcement. In accordance with O.C.G.A. § 38-3-4, the City of Forest Park Police Department shall be authorized to enforce the orders, rules and regulations contained in this chapter and/or implemented by the mayor or local governing authority during a declared emergency. 
(b)  Penalties . Failure to comply with any of the requirements or provisions of the regulations contained in this chapter, or with any code section, order, rule or regulation made effective by the mayor or local governing authority upon or after the declaration of an emergency shall constitute a violation of the provisions of this chapter. Any person who violates any provision in this chapter shall, upon conviction thereof, be guilty of a misdemeanor punishable by a fine not exceeding one thousand dollars ($1,000.00), imprisonment for a term not exceeding sixty (60) days, or both such fine and imprisonment, for each violation. Each person assisting in the commission of a violation shall be guilty of separate offenses. Each day during which a violation or failure to comply continues shall constitute a separate violation. 
(c)  Injunctive relief. In accordance with O.C.G.A. § 38-3-5, in addition to the remedies prescribed in this section, the EMA director is authorized to obtain an injunction to restrain violation of laws, code sections, orders, rules and regulations which are contained in the Georgia Emergency Management Act and/or this Code, and/or which are implemented by the local governing authority during a declared emergency. 
(d)  Enforcement . Except as otherwise provided in this chapter, this chapter may be enforced by the EMA director and Forest Park Police Chief. 
(Ord. No. 13-17, § 3, 8-19-2013) 
Sec. 4-5-4. - Authority to waive procedures and fee structures. 
(a)  City business. Upon declaration of an emergency or disaster by the Governor or Mayor of the City of Forest Park, the affairs and business of the city may be conducted at places other than the regular or usual location, within or outside of the city, when it is not prudent, expedient or possible to conduct business at the regular location. When such meetings occur outside of the city, all actions taken by the city council shall be as valid and binding as if performed within the city. Such meetings may be called by the presiding officer or any two (2) members of the governing body without regard to or compliance with time-consuming procedures and formalities otherwise required by law. 
(b)  Public works contracts. Upon declaration of an emergency or disaster by the Governor or Mayor of the City of Forest Park, the city council may contract for public works without letting such contract out to the lowest, responsible bidder and without advertising and posting notification of such contract for four (4) weeks; provided, however, that the emergency must be of such nature that immediate action is required and that the action is necessary for the protection of the public health, safety and welfare. Any public works contract entered into pursuant to this subsection shall be entered on the minutes of the city as soon as practical and the nature of the emergency described therein in accordance with O.C.G.A. § 36-91-22(e). Any e-verify affidavit or other state required affidavit shall be obtained from any contractor if otherwise required by law. 
(c)  Purchasing . Upon declaration of an emergency or disaster by the Governor or Mayor of the City of Forest Park, the purchasing ordinances, regulations or policies may be suspended. City officials shall continue to seek to obtain the best prices during the state of local emergency. 
(d)  Code enforcement. Upon declaration of a state of emergency or disaster by the Governor or the Mayor of the City of Forest Park, the city council may temporarily suspend the enforcement of the ordinances of the city, or any portion thereof, where the emergency is of such nature that immediate action outside the code is required, such suspension is consistent with the protection of the public health, safety and welfare, and such suspension is not inconsistent with any federal or state statutes or regulations. 
(e)  Fees . Upon declaration of state of emergency or disaster by the Governor or the Mayor of the City of Forest Park, the city council may temporarily reduce or suspend any permit fees, application fees or other rate structures as necessary to encourage the rebuilding of the areas impacted by the disaster or emergency. The term "fees" includes fees or rates charged by the city for building permits, land disturbance permits, zoning applications, special land use permits, temporary land use permits and other fees relating to the reconstruction, repair and clean up of areas impacted by the disaster or emergency. The term "fees" does not include fees collected by the city on behalf of the state or federal government or fees charged by the city pursuant to a state or federal statute or regulation. 
(f)  Temporary dwellings. Upon the declaration of a state of emergency or disaster by the Governor or Mayor of the City of Forest Park, the city council or its designees may issue temporary mobile home, trailer, recreational vehicle or other temporary dwelling structures or parks in any zoning district, even though not otherwise permitted by development code, while the primary dwelling is being repaired, provided that such temporary dwellings or parks are designed by an engineer and the plans are approved by the county health department and development services. The temporary permit shall not exceed six (6) months in duration. In the case of a continuing hardship, and in the discretion of the city council or its designee, the permit may be extended for a period of up to an additional six (6) months. Upon expiration of the temporary permit and/or extension, the temporary dwelling must be removed. 
(Ord. No. 13-17, § 4, 8-19-2013) 
Sec. 4-5-5. - Registration of building and repair services.
