(a)  In accordance with O.C.G.A. § 38-3-56, before building, constructing, repairing, renovating or making improvements to any real property, including dwellings, homes, buildings, structures or fixtures within an area in the corporate city limits designated in a declared emergency or disaster, any person, firm, partnership, corporation or other entity must register with the Forest Park Planning, Building and Zoning Department and secure a building permit that is posted at the work site. Each day any such entity does business in the incorporated areas of the city without complying with this chapter constitutes a separate offense. 
(b)  The cost of registration fees in a declared emergency or disaster is fixed at $_____ per annum. Registration is nontransferable. The cost of the emergency building permit shall be equal to the cost for a building permit under existing regulations. The permit shall only be authorized for repairs. 
(c)  When registering, any person, partnership, corporation or other entity making application must, under oath, complete an application, providing the following information: 
(1)  Name of applicant; 
(2)  Permanent address and phone number of applicant; 
(3)  Applicant's Social Security number or federal employer identification number; 
(4)  If applicant is a corporation, the state and date of incorporation; 
(5)  Tag registration information for each vehicle to be used in the business; 
(6)  List of cities and/or counties where the applicant has conducted business within the past twelve (12) months; 
(7)  Georgia sales tax number or authorization; 
(8)  Georgia business license number, if required; 
(9)  Copy of license from the secretary of state, if required; 
(10)  A signed and sworn affidavit verifying the applicant's legal presence in the United States as required by O.C.G.A. § 50-36-1; and 
(11)  At least one (1) secure and verifiable document as defined in O.C.G.A. § 50-36-2. 
(d)  Effective date. This section shall become effective only upon a declaration of emergency by the governor and a local declaration stating this section is in effect. Unless otherwise specified in the declaration of emergency or otherwise extended by the city council, the provisions of this Code section shall remain in effect during the state of emergency and for a subsequent recovery period of three (3) months. 
(Ord. No. 13-17, § 5, 8-19-2013) 
Sec. 4-5-6. - Closed or restricted areas and curfews during emergency. 
(a)  To preserve, protect or sustain the life, health, welfare or safety of persons, or their property, within a designated area under a declaration of emergency, it shall be unlawful for any person to travel, loiter, wander or stroll in or upon the public streets, highways, roads, lanes, parks or other public grounds, public places, public buildings, places of amusement, eating places, vacant lots or any other place during a declared emergency between hours specified by the mayor until the curfew is lifted. 
(b)  To promote order, protect lives, minimize the potential for looting and other crimes, and facilitate recovery operations during an emergency, the mayor shall have discretion to impose reentry restrictions on certain areas. The mayor shall exercise such discretion in accordance with the city emergency operations plan, which shall be followed during emergencies. 
(c)  The provisions of this section shall not apply to persons acting in the following capacities: 
(1)  Authorized and essential law enforcement personnel; 
(2)  Authorized and essential health care providers; 
(3)  Authorized and essential personnel of the city; 
(4)  Authorized National Guard or federal military personnel; 
(5)  Authorized and essential firefighters; 
(6)  Authorized and essential emergency response personnel; 
(7)  Authorized and essential personnel or volunteers working with or through the city emergency management agency; 
(8)  Authorized and essential utility repair crews; 
(9)  Citizens seeking to restore order to their homes or businesses while on their own property or place of business; and 
(10)  Other authorized and essential persons as designated on a list compiled by EMA and/or the chief of police. 
(d)  Enforceability . This section shall be enforced by officers of the law enforcement personnel approved to provide aid and assistance during the emergency. Nothing contained in this section shall prohibit a law enforcement officer from bringing other charges under state law. 
(e)  Effective date. This section shall become effective only upon the signing of a declaration of emergency, stating this section is in effect. 
(Ord. No. 13-17, § 6, 8-19-2013) 
Sec. 4-5-7. - Regulations continued in effect. 
All ordinances, resolutions, motions and orders pertaining to civil defense, emergency management and disaster relief that are not in conflict with this chapter are continued in full force and effect. Such ordinances, etc., are on file in the office of the city clerk. 
(Ord. No. 13-17, § 7, 8-19-2013) 
Title 5 - Public Works 
Chapter 1.  Streets and Sidewalks 
Chapter 2.  Solid Waste 
Chapter 3.  Drainage Improvements 
Chapter 4.  Stormwater Utility Ordinance 
CHAPTER 1. - STREETS AND SIDEWALKS 
ARTICLE A. - GENERAL PROVISIONS 

Sec. 5-1-1. - House numbering—Assigning by city manager; duty of property owner or tenant. 
It shall be the duty of the city manager to provide a uniform numbering system for all houses and structures, including business establishments, in the city. It shall be the duty of all owners and/or tenants of all houses and structures in the city to obtain from the city manager or his designated representative the correct number assigned to his house or structure, and thereafter to post the assigned number in a conspicuous place on the house or structure, or on the property, so that the same may be seen from the street. 
Sec. 5-1-2. - Same—Prerequisite to issuance of building permit. 
The building inspector is hereby prohibited from issuing any permit for the construction of any house of any kind to any person until a number shall have been assigned to such structure by the city manager. 
(Code 1959, § 16-2) 
Sec. 5-1-3. - Dedication of streets. 
No dedication to the city by any owner of property to be used as a street, alley or other public use shall be valid until the same shall have been accepted in writing by the governing body. The director of public works shall be charged with the responsibility of inspecting streets that are to be offered for dedication to the city. 
Sec. 5-1-4. - Downspouts and drains of water on sidewalks. 
No person shall erect any drain, gutter, downspout, valley or any flat or sloping roof of any character that will in any manner drain or shed water on any sidewalk of the city. 
(Code 1959, § 16-4) 
Sec. 5-1-5. - Obstructing drainage. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to place or cause to be placed in any street or alley, any dirt, trash or other material so as to interfere with the drainage or use of said street or alley, without first obtaining a permit to do so from the director of public works. 
Cross reference— Obstructing drains with solid waste, § 5-2-6. 
Sec. 5-1-6. - Disposing of liquids on streets and sidewalks. 
(a)  No person shall cause any water or other liquids to be disposed of on the streets or sidewalks of the city without the written permission of the director of public works. 
(b)  The terms of this section shall not be applicable to the members of the fire department or any officer, agent, or employee of the city in the performance of a designated municipal duty. 
Sec. 5-1-7. - Sidewalks, cleanliness responsibility of abutting property owners, enforcement. 
It shall be the duty of all occupants of improved property and owners of vacant property, in front of which the sidewalks have been paved, to keep such sidewalks clean, and to do such sweeping and scraping as may be necessary to remove clay, dirt and trash therefrom, and to render the same passable, comfortable and sightly. In addition, it shall be the duty of the city manager, after five (5) days' written notice to any such person of the necessity for cleaning such sidewalk, to have done such work as may be necessary to render such walk clean and to render a bill covering the cost of such cleaning to the owner or agent of such property in person, or if such person or agent be a nonresident, then by mail. Upon the nonpayment of such bill within ten (10) days after service of same as aforesaid, the city clerk shall issue an execution therefor against the owner of the abutting property, and such execution shall be a lien upon such property and shall be collected as other executions issued by the city. 
(Code 1959, § 16-7) 
Sec. 5-1-8. - Driveway installations. 
(a)  New driveways shall be installed at the expense of the property owner after obtaining the approval as to curb cut and driveway design by the city manager or his/her designee. 
(1)  The following are the design requirements for residential developments, whether single or multiple dwellings. 
(2)  All driveways shall be constructed of concrete, asphalt or the like and subject to the specifications on file in the public works department. Gravel mix, two-track driveways and shared parking in residential developments may be built pending approval from the city manager or his/her designee. As employed in this section, the phrase "two-track driveway" means a driveway made of two (2) narrow, parallel, paved wheel tracks that are separated by an unpaved area containing stone, grass or other low growing landscaping. Wheel tracks in any two-track driveway must be installed flush with the ground and constructed with materials capable of supporting all vehicle/equipment tires without driving onto or over an unapproved parking surface. 
Note: Illustration of two-track driveway below: 

(3)  All buildings, structures and uses of land shall provide off-street parking in an amount sufficient to meet the needs caused by the building or use of land. 
(4)  All off-street parking shall be on a dust-free surface. 
(5)  All impervious areas shall comply with maximum ground coverage and setback requirements in accordance with the applicable zoning district regulations. 
(6)  Parking on the street, sidewalk or grass is prohibited. 
(7)  Parking in any multiple residential development is permitted only in designated parking spaces. 
(b)  Where driveway repairs are needed on that portion of the driveway which is on the city right-of-way, such repairs will be made only in those cases where the property owner pays in advance for the materials and the city performs the repairs. The repairs performed by the city shall only extend to the property line of the subject property. 
(c)  The city shall bear all costs of material and labor for the replacement and maintenance of any driveway drainage pipe located within the city right-of-way. Excepted herefrom are any repairs which are needed due to any negligent act or willful destruction of said drainage pipe by the property owner or his lessee. Driveway drainage pipes willfully destroyed or damaged by the negligent acts of the property owner will be replaced by the city at the expense of said property owner. The property owner shall bear the cost of administration, labor, and materials needed for this purpose. 
(d)  The city shall assume the responsibility when performing new construction of tying the driveway to the existing property owner's improvements on the city's right-of-way in a workmanship manner at no cost whatsoever to the property owner. The city assumes no responsibility or liability which may result from any change in the water flow or any damage that may occur in the future due to the placement of said tie. 
(Res. No. 83-157, 6-6-83; Ord. No. 05-45, § 1, 7-5-2005; Ord. No. 16-02, § 1, 1-19-2016) 
Sec. 5-1-9. - Sidewalk design. 
Sidewalks shall be designed and constructed with a minimum width of four (4) feet and will be sloped towards front yards when practicable. Alternate mediums for pedestrian travel, such as paving stones, may be substituted for sidewalks when they are not located adjacent to a road. When possible, a two-foot grass strip shall be included. Final approval of sidewalk widths will be determined in accordance with the recommendations of the city manager or his/her designee. 
(Ord. No. 16-02, § 2, 1-19-2016) 
Secs. 5-1-10—5-1-20. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE B. - EXCAVATIONS 

Sec. 5-1-21. - Definition. 
The phrase "public place," as employed in this article, shall be construed to mean a street, alley, sidewalk or other public property owned by the city or under its supervision. 
(Code 1959, § 16-16) 
Sec. 5-1-22. - Permit to excavate; required. 
(a)  No person shall dig or excavate in any public place within the city or install, repair or replace any of his property or equipment in such public place, or do any other work in or on any public place, which requires the removal or breaking of the surface or underpart of any such public place, unless and until such person shall have first secured, in the manner provided in this article, permission to do so. 
(b)  If any person shall do any of the acts referred to in this section without first having secured in the manner provided in this article, permission so to do, he shall, upon conviction thereof, be punished as provided in section 1-1-8 of this code. 
(Code 1959, § 16-17) 
Sec. 5-1-23. - Same; application. 
Each person desiring permission to dig or excavate in any public place shall file with the director of public works or his designated representative, a printed application, as furnished by the director, setting forth the character and location of such work to be done in any such public place, the probable number of square yards of surface to be removed and the probable date of beginning and the completion of the work. 
Sec. 5-1-24. - Same; fees and deposits. 
In the event the applicant for the permit to excavate is authorized to perform the work himself, including replacing the street to its condition prior to the excavation, there shall be no charge for the issuance of the permit. But the director of public works, or his designated representative may, if the situation warrants it, require a deposit at the time of application. The deposit shall be in the sum of money that shall be fixed by the director of public works and it shall be based on the cost per square yard of replacement, plus 10 percent. 
Sec. 5-1-25. - Same; grant or refusal. 
Each application, as referred to in section 5-1-23, shall be received by the director of public works or his designated representative, who shall, without unreasonable delay, either grant or reject such application. In the absence of the director of public works or his authorized representative, the application may be delivered to the city manager, or his designated agent. Upon rejection of the application, the applicant shall have the right to present the matter to the governing body, the order of which shall be final in such matter, and upon final rejection, the deposit of money referred to in section 5-1-24 shall be returned to the person who deposited the same. 
Sec. 5-1-26. - Failure to complete or restore. 
Upon the failure of any person, whose application to dig or excavate shall have been granted and who shall have begun the work, to complete the same without delay, or upon the completion of such work, to restore the public place to the same or as good a condition as the same was before such work was done, or to comply with any reasonable rules or regulations of the director of public works from time to time given to such person for the completion and restoration of such public place, such person shall, upon conviction, in addition to other penalties, forfeit to the city any deposit of money so made with the city. All cuts shall be replaced with six (6) inches of 3,000 pounds per square inch concrete, plus two (2) inches of asphalt topping, provided that on residential streets there may be a variance from these standards on approval of the director of public works. 
Sec. 5-1-27. - Restoration by city. 
Upon the failure of any person to make such repairs as herein required in the manner or in the time required, the director of public works is empowered and authorized to cause such repairs to be made and such public place to be restored to its original condition, and the cost thereof, plus 10 percent thereof, shall be charged to and paid by such person who so failed to make such repairs, and such sum of money shall constitute and be a debt due from such person to the city. 
Sec. 5-1-28. - Use or refund of deposit. 
The deposit of money made under section 5-1-24 shall stand as a guarantee and may be employed by the city for the replacement of such public place in as good condition as the same was immediately before the excavation or digging, and upon default of the person so making such deposit to restore immediately the public place to as good condition as the same was immediately before such excavation or digging was done by him, the director of public works may employ the whole or any part of such deposit of money necessary for such restoration. Upon the restoration of the public place to such condition as the same was immediately before such digging or excavating, the director of finance, or his designated representative shall, upon the certificate of the city manager, restore to the person so making such deposit such sum of money so deposited, or in case any part thereof is employed by the city for such restoration of such public place, upon such certificate, the director of finance, or his designated representative, shall refund such part of such sum of money so remaining. 
Sec. 5-1-29. - Prompt work. 
All digging or excavating to be done, as provided in this article, shall be promptly started and completed without delay after permission shall have been granted, and such public place shall be, immediately upon the completion of such work, restored to the same or as good condition as the same was before such work was done thereon. Such work or restoration shall be at all times and in all respects in compliance with the orders and supervision of the director of public works, or his designated agent, from time to time given to such person for such purpose. 
Sec. 5-1-30. - Warning devices; posting permit. 
Upon the granting of an application for permission to dig or excavate in any public place, and in all other cases provided for in this article, it shall be the duty of the applicant, before beginning any such work, to enclose the place where such work is being done or otherwise afford adequate protection to street traffic. He shall post and keep posted at such place a placard showing that the work is being done under a permit granted by the city, with sufficient other information thereon to give ample warning to those using such public place that the same is out of repair or being repaired, and in addition thereto, he shall place sufficient markings at night by an amber light, to notify those having the right to use the same that such public place, or part thereof, is closed. The contractor shall furnish the director of public works, or his designated representative, with a telephone number of someone that can be contacted twenty-four (24) hours a day in the event a problem arises due to the street being cut. 
Sec. 5-1-31. - Decision of governing body final. 
Any controversy between the person making a deposit in order to dig or excavate in any public place and the finance director or director of public works, or the city manager, respecting any of the duties to be performed by any of them, may be submitted to the governing body by any of the parties, and when so submitted, the action of the governing body thereon shall be binding on all the parties. 
CHAPTER 2. - SOLID WASTE 

Sec. 5-2-1. - Short title and applicability of chapter. 
This chapter shall be known as the "Forest Park Sanitation Ordinance of 1971." It shall apply to the preparation, storage, collection and disposal of all refuse and shall prohibit unsanitary conditions in the corporate limits as presently or hereafter established. 
(Code 1959, § 9-1) 
Sec. 5-2-2. - Definitions. 
For purposes of this chapter, the following words and phrases shall have the meaning respectively ascribed to them by this section. When not inconsistent with the context, words used in the present tense include the future, works in the plural number include singular number and words in the singular number include the plural number. The word "shall" is always mandatory and not merely directory. 
(1)  Approved receptacle: The approved receptacle is a ninety-five-gallon cart capable of being emptied by mechanical means. All garbage in the cart shall be in plastic bags so that loose garbage is in the approved receptacle. The approved receptacle will be furnished by the city and issued by the department of public works or the city's designee. 
(2)  City: Forest Park, Georgia. 
(3)  Commercial container: A manufactured container suitable for emptying by mechanical equipment and approved by the director of public works. 
(4)  Commercial establishment: Any hotel, motel, business, industrial, public or semipublic establishment of any nature or kind whatsoever other than a residential unit or multiple dwelling units. 
(5)  Compactor: A mechanical devise to shred or compact solid waste. 
(6)  Compactor container: Any manufactured container of any size, which is used in conjunction with a mechanical devise, which shreds and/or compacts refuse. 
(7)  Garbage: Putrescible animal and vegetable wastes resulting from the preparation, cooking and servicing of food and the storage and sale of produce, tin cans, glass containers and newspapers. 
(8)  Garbage container: A durable plastic container of a capacity not less than sixty-five (65) gallons and not to exceed ninety-five (95) gallons as approved and issued by the director of public works or the city's designee. 
(9)  Multiple dwelling: A building designed for or occupied exclusively by two (2) or more families. 
(10)  Owner: Any person, firm or corporation owning, leasing, renting, occupying or managing any premises in the jurisdiction of the city. 
(11)  Person: Any individual, firm, partnership, association, trust, corporation, company, instruction, society, organization, executor, administrator, trustee or other legal entity. 
(12)  Refuse: Garbage and trash collectively. 
(13)  Residential unit: Any structure or shelter or any part thereof used or constructed for use as a residence for one (1) family. 
(14)  Sanitary landfill: Any refuse disposal area operated by the city. 
(15)  Scavenger: Any person collecting or disposing of refuse. 
(16)  Special industrial waste container: Any container such as a metal box, bucket, an open bed container or special container used for transporting chemicals, paint, metals, glass, oil products, plastics or any type material that requires special handling and cannot be incinerated. 
(17)  Trash: Nonputrescible solid wastes consisting of combustible and noncombustible material such as, but not limited to, paper, cardboard, glass, crockery and similar materials. 
(18)  Classification "A": This classification shall consist of commercial establishments as defined in subparagraph (4) of this section, excepting apartment houses and rooming houses. 
(19)  Classification "B": This classification shall consist of multiple dwellings as defined by subparagraph (9) of this section. 
(20)  Classification "C": This classification shall consist of all residential units as defined in subparagraph (13) of this section. 
(21)  Handicapped/disabled customer: Household with no able-bodied member capable of transferring garbage container to curb for pickup. Handicapped/disabled household must be certified by a physician and by signed affidavit of the customer. 
(22)  Yard trimmings means leaves, brush, grass clippings, shrub and tree prunings, discarded Christmas trees, nursery and greenhouse vegetative residuals, and vegetative matter resulting from landscaping development and maintenance other than mining, agricultural, and silvicultural operations. 
(Code 1959, § 9-2; Ord. No. 95-005, § 2, 8-21-95; Ord. No. 97-011, § 1, 12-15-97; Ord. No. 05-10, § 1, 4-4-2005; Ord. No. 15-12, § 1, 10-5-2015) 
Sec. 5-2-3. - Unhealthy and unsanitary conditions prohibited. 
To protect the health and property of persons in the city and to prevent conditions which might lead to fire or the breeding of reptiles, rodents, and insects, it shall be unlawful for the owner or occupant of any property in the city to allow garbage, trash, refuse, rubbish, stagnant water, filth, carrion, weeds, debris, vines, grass or other vegetation to accumulate thereon. 
(Code 1959, § 9-3) 
Cross reference— Keeping junk, abandoned appliances, etc., on property, § 11-1-1. 
Sec. 5-2-4. - Notice to remove. 
When the director of public works or his designee determines that conditions as described in section 5-2-3 above exist in the city, it shall be the director's or his designee's duty to notify the owner and/or the occupant of the premises of such conditions. Such notice shall be in writing and posted at the address and shall advise the addressee of the condition or conditions complained of, shall advise the addressee that such conditions must be eliminated within seventy-two (72) hours, and that addressee's failure to act accordingly may result in prosecution under this chapter and correction by the city at the expense of the owner and/or occupant. 
(Code 1959, § 9-4; Ord. No. 02-10, § 1, 11-4-2002) 
Sec. 5-2-5. - Failure to correct within time specified. 
If the owner or occupant fails to act in accordance with the notice given him, the city may issue a citation charging him with a violation of this chapter and in addition thereto, the city may, at its option, proceed to remedy the situation and accomplish the necessary work. The owner or occupant or both shall be liable to the city for the actual costs of such work. 
(Code 1959, § 9-5; Ord. No. 05-11, § 1, 4-4-2005) 
Sec. 5-2-6. - Diverting natural flow of water and obstructing drains and gutters. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to place or cause to be placed any rocks, dirt, or any other object in any stream, drain, drainage ditch, culvert, catch basin, or drainage easement in the city in such manner as to divert or obstruct the natural flow of water therein. 
(Code 1959, § 9-6) 
Cross reference— Placing of similar objects in streets or sidewalks, § 5-1-5. 
Sec. 5-2-7. - Collection of refuse generally; conditions for collection by the city; prohibited refuse. 
(a)  All refuse accumulated in the city shall be collected, conveyed and disposed of by the city, or its designee, except as otherwise expressly authorized in this chapter. 
(b)  The city, or its designee, will collect refuse in accordance with a schedule as established from time to time by the mayor and council and kept on file in the department of public works and the office of the city clerk. 
(c)  Dead animals, other than dogs and house pets, will not be collected. 
(d)  Acid, explosive material, flammable liquids, and dangerous or corrosive material of any kind will not be collected, and it shall be a violation of this chapter for any person to place any such item, product or material in any refuse can or container for collection. 
(e)  Except for the roll-off container services and compactor services provided by the city or its designee in accordance with section 5-2-11 of this Code, neither the city nor its designee shall be responsible for collecting or hauling discarded building materials, dirt, broken concrete, bricks, rock or other debris resulting from construction or similar activities in the city, and any such materials shall be disposed of in a safe and lawful manner by the owner of the real estate on which such activities are conducted or his contractor. 
(f)  Neither the city nor its designee shall be responsible for collecting or hauling of trees, bushes or other vegetation from commercial tree trimmers, landscapers, grading contractors or building contractors. The hauling of the debris is the sole responsibility of the property owner or the owner's contractor. 
(g)  Collection service for classification "C" customers shall be curbside unless household is disabled or customer has elected to pay an extra charge for continued back door service. Such collection service will be for periods of one (1) year as measured from January 1 through December 31. All new customers applying for first time collection service will be offered curbside service only unless the occupant is disabled and there is no person residing on the premises physically able to pull the container curbside. All disabled persons requesting back door service shall provide a written notice from a physician indicating such disability to the department of public works. The city may charge an additional fee for such services as established by the mayor and city council. 
(h)  It shall be a violation of the City Code to place any refuse items on the right-of-way at any time other than the designated times for collection. Such violations shall be subject to the issuance of a citation punishable under the general penalty of Code section 1-1-8. 
(Ord. No. 97-011, § 1, 12-15-97; Ord. No. 02-11, § 1, 11-4-2002; Ord. No. 05-12, § 1, 4-4-2005; Ord. No. 07-39, § 2, 11-5-2007) 
Sec. 5-2-8. - Preparation and storage of residential refuse for collection. 
(a)  Garbage shall be stored in an approved receptacle. Each household may be issued two (2) approved containers which shall remain the property of the city or its designee. Each household may choose to be issued two (2) approved receptacles for the collection of refuse or, alternatively, may choose to be issued one (1) approved receptacle for the collection of garbage and one (1) approved receptacle for the collection of recycling materials. Customer is responsible for maintaining in good condition each approved receptacle issued to him. Customer is solely responsible for the replacement of any approved receptacle that occurs within five (5) years following the issuance of that receptacle. Customer is responsible at a prorated cost for the replacement of any approved receptacle that occurs more than five (5) years, but less than ten (10) years, following the issuance of that receptacle. Any customer who has been issued any approved receptacle, subsequently moves outside the city's limits, and takes the approved receptacle with him may be prosecuted for theft by the city or its designee. 
(b)  Garbage containers shall be placed curbside no earlier than 6:00 p.m. of the day before collection and must be removed from curbside no later that [than] 8:00 p.m. the day of collection. Violation of this Code more than three (3) times per year will result in a citation by public works officials or code enforcement that shall carry a minimum twenty-five dollar ($25.00) fine. Exception will be handicapped/disabled customers and customers that have elected to continue back yard service and pay additional fees. 
(c)  Large amounts of trash must be placed at curb beside the wheeled garbage container. Trash should be bagged or boxed. 
(d)  Refuse containers that are inside secured fenced areas will not be picked up. 
(e)  Pet liter must be placed in a securely tied plastic bag. 
(f)  Garbage containers shall be stored in the rear of the residential structure. "Rear" shall be considered as any area of the property behind the parallel face of the structure facing the roadway, or side street if it is a corner lot. Any deviation or change of the storage allocation from what is required herein must be approved. Such approval shall be at the discretion of the public works director or his designee. 
(g)  Yard trimmings shall not be mixed with household garbage or trash, but shall be placed curbside no sooner than the day before pickup is scheduled. Leaves, pine straw and grass clippings shall be disposed of in paper recycle bags manufactured for yard trimming disposal and when full not to exceed thirty (30) pounds in weight, or in a separate container marked "yard waste". Limbs, twigs and heavy brush shall not exceed four (4) feet in length and four (4) inches in diameter and shall be bundled and tied with rope or string. Bundles may not exceed thirty (30) pounds and must be stacked in a compact pile on the owner's property in front of the residence adjoining the curb or curb line, but such pile shall not extend into the street or onto the sidewalks or driveway and shall not be located so as to impede or obstruct or divert the flow of traffic, surface water or block drains. There shall be a weekly limit of fifteen (15) recycle paper bags, bundles or a combination of the two (2). Violations will delay pickup of these items and could result in the issuance of a citation for noncompliance. 
(Code 1959, § 9-8; Ord. No. 97-011, § 1, 12-15-97; Ord. No. 01-11, § 1, 10-1-2001; Ord. No. 05-13, § 1, 4-4-2005; Ord. No. 15-12, § 2, 10-5-2015) 
Sec. 5-2-9. - Preparation and storage of industrial, commercial and multiple dwelling refuse for collection. 
(a)  The building inspector of the city shall not issue a building permit for industrial, commercial or multifamily dwellings until the director of public works gives his approval to proposed plans for the storage of refuse. 
(b)  The city will not collect refuse from industrial, commercial or multifamily dwellings unless the refuse is placed in containers approved by the director of public works and located at a place approved by the director. Cardboard boxes must be flattened and placed in containers. 
(c)  Commercial front and rear load containers' doors and lids are to be left closed at all times except when loading or unloading. 
(Code 1959, § 9-9; Ord. No. 05-14, § 1, 4-4-2005) 
Sec. 5-2-10. - Regulation of private transportation of refuse. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to transport his own refuse or with a permit to transport the refuse of another over the streets of the city when the material transported is inadequately secured and allows any of the material to fall, leak, or be blown from the vehicle. The operator of the offending vehicle shall be personally responsible for any violation of this section. 
(Code 1959, § 9-10; Ord. No. 82-267, 6-12-82) 
Sec. 5-2-11. - Roll-off container service, compactor service and "special needs" roll-off container service. 
(a)  The city or its designee shall be the exclusive provider of all roll-off container and compactor services within the limits of the city. This subsection shall not apply to the following: 
(1)  A "special needs" roll-off container service or compactor service as determined and permitted by the director of public works under the terms and the conditions set forth in this section; 
(2)  A roll-off container service that consists entirely and exclusively of recycling materials in lieu of otherwise disposing of them, or an open top container; or 
(3)  An open-top container, such as those used by residential contractors, roofers, and construction or renovation companies, used in conjunction with a residential construction project. 
(b)  "Special needs" roll-off container service or compactor service may be permitted by the director of public works under this Code section whenever, in his judgment, the solid waste to be generated shall be of a kind and character, or in such form, size or bulk, that it cannot be safely and adequately handled or transported by the city or its designee. In order for the director of public works to make such determination in each case, the person or firm who plans to generate such solid waste shall make application to the director for a permit under this Code section, accompanied by a detailed plan for removal and transportation of such solid waste to a safe and legally authorized disposal site. If the director of public works shall determine that the plan is sufficient and adequate to provide for the orderly, timely, and safe disposition of the solid waste, then he shall approve such plan and issue the permit or permits requested in conjunction with such plan, as provided in this Code section. 
(c)  In the event that the director of public works shall issue a permit under this code section, or shall determine that the city or its designee does not offer or provide the equipment or service to meet the needs of any industrial or commercial establishments operating within the city, then he may grant a permit, on a case by case basis, for "special needs" roll-off container service or industrial or commercial compactor service, in accordance with the terms and conditions of this Code section. 
(d)  Any person or firm granted a "special needs" roll-off container service or industrial or commercial compactor service shall comply with the following requirements: 
(1)  Such person or firm shall file an appropriate application for such a permit on forms provided by the director of public works and shall pay an application fee for such permit in an amount fixed by the governing body of the city. 
(2)  In addition to the application fee, such person or firm shall also pay a monthly fee as established by the governing body of the city for each such "special needs" roll-off container service or compactor service. A document identifying the location of each such roll-off container or compactor shall accompany the payment of such fees. 
(3)  Any firm or person who shall obtain a permit for operating a "special needs" roll-off container service or an industrial or commercial compactor service shall not be required to pay a sanitary service fee or charge, except for the fees provided for in subsections (d)(1) and (2) above. 
(4)  Each "special needs" roll-off container and compactor container authorized under this Code section shall carry in a conspicuous place the name, telephone number, and address of the person or firm who is responsible for the roll-off container or compactor. 
(5)  The city shall not be responsible for placing, emptying or maintaining any roll-off container or compactor permitted under this Code section, and each person or firm who is granted a permit to use or service such roll-off container or compactor shall indemnify and hold harmless the city and its officers, agents and employees from any and all liability for personal injury or property damage arising out of such use or service. 
(6)  Prior to being granted a permit, each person or firm permitted to use and operate a roll-off container or compactor under this Code section shall provide to the director of public works satisfactory evidence of liability insurance coverage in amounts determined by the city. 
(e)  "Recycling roll-off container service" (that is, roll-off container service that consists entirely and exclusively of recycling materials instead of otherwise disposing of them), shall be permitted in the city under the following terms and conditions: 
(1)  Any person or firm desiring to provide "recycling roll-off container service" in the city shall first obtain an annual permit to do so from the director of public works by making application on forms to be prepared and made available by the director and by paying the application fee required for such permit in an amount fixed by the governing body of the city. 
(2)  In addition to the annual permit fee specified above, any person desiring to provide "recycling roll-off container service" in the city shall also pay a "drop fee" for each single "recycling roll-off container" each time a "recycling roll-off container" is dropped or left in the city. Said "drop fee" shall be in an amount to be determined by the governing body of the city in a separate ordinance. 
(3)  Any person or firm who has obtained an annual permit for providing "recycling roll-off container service" shall not be required to pay any additional fees for providing such recycling service other than the annual fee specified in subsection (1) above and the "drop fee" specified in subsection (2) above, but no person or firm shall be relieved of paying any sanitary service fees and charges when applicable and due to the city. 
(4)  Each "recycling roll-off container" authorized under this Code section shall carry in a conspicuous place the name, address, telephone number, of the person or firm who is responsible for the recycling roll-off container service. 
(5)  The city shall not be responsible for placing, emptying, or maintaining any "recycling roll-off container" authorized under this subsection. 
(6)  Each person or firm granted an annual permit to provide "recycling roll-off container service" in the city shall indemnify and hold harmless the city and all of its officers, agents, and employees from any and all liability for personal injury or property damage arising out of the provision of said service. 
(7)  Prior to being granted the annual permit provided for in subsection (1) above, each person or firm permitted to provide "recycling roll-off container service" in the city shall provide to the director of public works satisfactory evidence of liability insurance coverage in amounts determined by the city. 
(8)  Not later than ten (10) calendar days after being issued a drop permit under this section, the holder of the drop permit shall provide to the director of public works a true and correct copy of the manifest that was issued to allow or accept the delivery of the recycling materials that were collected in the recycling roll-off container. Failure to provide the manifest within the time required by this subsection shall be grounds for the director of public works to deny any future drop permits to the person or firm failing to provide said manifest, until all outstanding manifests have been provided to him. 
(f)  Except as provided in this Code section, no person or firm shall use or contract for the use of any roll-off containers or compactors within the city, and the city or its designee shall be the exclusive provider of all roll-container services and compact or services in the city. 
(Ord. No. 05-14, § 1, 4-4-2005; Ord. No. 07-39, § 1, 11-5-2007; Ord. No. 11-07, §§ 1, 2, 2-21-2011; Ord. No. 15-12, § 3, 10-5-2015) 
Sec. 5-2-11.1. - Stop work order for violation of section 5-2-11, roll-off container services. 
(a)  Whenever the director of public works or any of his designees shall find any activity ongoing in the city for which a permit is required under Title 8, Chapter 2 of this Code, and shall find a roll-off container being used in connection with such activity in violation of section 5-2-11, then the director or any of his designees shall be authorized to issue a stop work order in accordance with this section. 
(b)  The stop work order shall be in writing and may be given to the owner of the property involved, or to the owner's agent, or to any person performing the work. 
(c)  Upon issuance of the stop work order, the work shall immediately cease. The stop work order shall state clearly the reason for the order and shall state the conditions under which the work shall be allowed to resume. 
(d)  The stop work order may be appealed to the Construction Codes Board of Adjustments and Appeals in accordance with section 8-2-3 of this Code. 
(e)  Any person who shall continue to perform any work after having been served with a stop work order, except for work necessary to comply with any of the conditions specified in subparagraph (c) above, shall be subject to the penalties provided for in section 1-1-8 of this Code of Ordinances. 
(Ord. No. 11-05, § 1, 2-21-2011) 
Sec. 5-2-12. - Disposal of refuse and garbage generally. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person, firm or corporation to dump or to cause to be dumped any garbage, refuse, litter, junk, appliances, equipment, cans, bottles, paper, lumber, trees, tree limbs, brush or parts thereof anywhere in the incorporated area of the city, except as may be permitted by city ordinance. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for any person, firm or corporation to dump or cause to be dumped or buried on any private property any garbage, refuse or other materials described in subsection (a) above. 
(c)  The provisions of subsections (a) and (b) above do not apply to dumping on private property with the owner's permission of sand, dirt, broken bricks, blocks or broken pavement or other suitable material for use as a fill to raise the elevation of the land provided the same is not maintained in an unsightly condition and provided the owner or owners of the property on which such material is dumped agrees to level such dumped material with appropriate grading equipment, and to cover it with dirt, upon direction of the governing body of the city. 
(d)  If any of the matter or material dumped in violation of the provisions of subsection (a) above can be identified as having last belonged to, been in the possession of, sent to or received by, or to have been the property of any person, firm or corporation prior to its being dumped as prohibited therein, such identification shall be presumed to be prima facie evidence that such owner dumped or caused to be dumped such matter and material in violation of this chapter. 
(Code 1959, § 9-12; Ord. No. 02-12, § 1, 11-4-2002) 
Sec. 5-2-13. - Operation of private landfills. 
In accordance with section 5-2-12, no sanitary landfill or dump shall be operated within the city without written approval of the governing body. 
(Code 1959, § 9-13) 
Sec. 5-2-14. - Charges for sanitary service. 
(a)  A sanitary service charge shall be made to occupants, tenants and property owners for the collection services outlined in this chapter. The charge will be made and collected where the service is available unless the service is performed under a permit from the director of public works (see section 5-2-11). Each residential unit and each business establishment in the city is required to use the sanitary services provided by the city; provided, if the solid waste created by any commercial entity be in such form, size or bulk that it cannot be physically handled by equipment employed by the city, or its designee, for the removal of such waste, then, upon application to the city for a plan of private removal, and upon the approval of such a plan, such commercial establishment may be allowed to remove such oversized solid waste material, along with any other waste normally generated by such establishment. The application for permission to make private disposition of such solid waste shall be made through the director of public works, who shall approve any plan designed to make orderly and timely disposition of such outsized solid waste that cannot be collected and disposed of by the city or its designee. Such permit must be renewed annually. 
(b)  Sanitary service charges shall be made by the city in accordance with the schedule as fixed from time to time by the mayor and council. 
(1)  Fees shall be billed according to the classification of the subscriber as follows: 
a.  Classification "A" subscribers shall be billed on the first day of each month and said bill shall be directed to each individual subscriber. 
b.  Classification "B" subscribers shall be billed on the first day of each month and said bill shall be directed to the owner of record of the real estate as reflected in the office of the Clerk of the Superior Court of Clayton County, Georgia, Land Records. This bill shall contain the monthly fee for each apartment or space rented therein or available for rent. In the event a building or section of the apartments or spaces are no longer available for rent, the owner shall notify the department of public works, in writing by certified mail, no later than the tenth day of the month preceding the net billing cycle in order to receive an adjustment for the number of apartments no longer available for rent. 
c.  Classification "C" subscribers shall be billed on an annual basis. Said bill shall be provided to the owner of the real estate at such time as the owners receive their annual tax bill. The charge for the annual billing shall be reflected on said tax bill as a "sanitation fee." 
(2)  In the event any charge remains unpaid after the fifteenth day of each month for classifications "A" or "B", a late charge will be assessed as may be determined from time to time by the mayor and council. In the event any class "C" subscriber charge remains unpaid after the date for which the annual taxes become delinquent, a late charge will be assessed as may be determined from time to time by the mayor and council. Negotiable checks mailed at the Forest Park Post Office and postmarked prior to midnight of the next day prior to the assessment of a late charge will be acceptable and no late charge assessed. 
(3)  Classification "C" subscribers who are suffering under an economic hardship, (which shall include, but not be limited to, recipients of Social Security old age benefits, social security disability benefits, or retirement benefits, so long as such individuals have no other substantial income or substantial assets, other than their principal residence) may pay their sanitation fee for their principal residence over a twelve-month period that shall begin on the date of the issuance of the tax bill, provided such classification subscribers obtain a certificate of appreciation from the finance director. The holder of said certificate may elect to pay his/her sanitation fee monthly, quarterly, biannually, or as otherwise agreed upon by the certificate holder and the finance director. Subscribers seeking to obtain a certificate must present proof of economic hardship to the finance director or such other person designated by the finance director to issue certificates. Proof shall be in the form of any legal document evidencing the limited income of the applicant and a sworn statement by the applicant that he/she has no other substantial assets, other than a principal residence, or income, other than the limited income delineated. 
(4)  Notwithstanding the exception of subparagraph (3) above, the schedule of charges, fees and deposits for sanitation services shall be in accordance with those fixed from time to time by the mayor and council and shall be kept on file in the offices of the city clerk and the city's public works department. 
(5)  Any other provisions of this section notwithstanding, a charge shall be fixed from time to time by the mayor and council and same will be added to the sanitation bill when the same is paid with a check which fails for any reason to clear the payer's bank when presented for payment. 
(6)  In the event any sanitation charges remain unpaid that were provided to the real estate owner of record as reflected in the officer of the Superior Court of Clayton County, Georgia, Land Records, said charge shall constitute a lien against the real estate. In the event the sanitation charges herein have been provided to a subscriber who is not he owner of record title as referenced above, said charges shall constitute a lien against the personal property of the subscriber. The city shall be authorized to accomplish collection pursuant to chapter 3 of title 45 of the Official Code of Georgia Annotated. 
(7)  In the event the owner, as defined in section 5-2-2-(11) of this Code fails to pay sanitation fees as same become due on more than three (3) occasions within a period of one (1) year, as measured from January 1 through December 31, the director of public works may require the owner to post a deposit in the amount sufficient to cover the next twelve (12) months' charges. Upon notice to the director of public works, in the event the owner transfer his interest in the property, the city shall promptly refund any unused part of the aforesaid deposit. 
(c)  For those residential users whose collection needs are greater than those specified below, a special rate will be agreed upon by the customer and the director of public works, or his designee, and the customer charged accordingly. 
(1)  Residential trash: Three (3) additional bags or boxes per each pickup. This means any items that will not fit inside the residential container and shall include bagged items, boxes, or other disposable containers. 
(2)  Residential garbage: One (1) residential container as described in section 5-2-2(8) emptied twice weekly. Residential customers requesting and being assigned more than one (1) such container shall pay, prior to receiving such additional residential container, the city, a refundable deposit for such container as may be set from time to time by the mayor and council and pay an additional fifteen dollars ($15.00) per month for collection of said additional container. 
(3)  Residential garbage: Nonhandicapped customers who elect to continue back yard service will pay an additional fee as determined from time to time by the mayor and city council. 
(4)  Bulk trash items; i.e. furniture, sofas, chairs, appliances, etc. will be picked up on Wednesdays. These items must be placed curbside no earlier than Tuesday after 12:00 noon and requires a call to the public works department for the scheduling of a pickup. Limits on the amount of bulk items will be set from time to time and additional fees may be required per item. 
(d)  Monthly charges for commercial users will be assessed according to weight, volume and type of refuse to be disposed of. 
(e)  The city shall impose and collect an additional fee for the pickup of used tires. Such fee is based on disposal fees charged the city by the landfill. 
(f)  Failure to pay any sanitation charges will be a violation of this Code. Citation(s) for violation(s) of this article will be issued by the city, and said citation(s) will be returnable to and tried before the environmental court of the city. 
(Code 1986, § 5-2-14; Ord. No. 88-007, 4-4-88; Ord. No. 93-026, 12-20-93; Ord. No. 95-007, 8-21-95; Ord. No. 96-017, § 1, 10-21-96; Ord. No. 97-011, § 1, 12-15-97; Ord. No. 05-16, § 1, 4-4-2005; Ord. No. 16-04, § 1, 4-18-2016) 
Cross reference— Billing and collection of utility charges, § 6-1-1 et seq. 
Sec. 5-2-15. - Sanitary service outside the corporate limits. 
The public works department is not authorized to extend sanitation service to residences or commercial establishments outside the corporate limits of the city. 
(Code 1959, § 9-15; Ord. No. 02-13, § 1, 11-4-2002) 
Sec. 5-2-16. - Night collection. 
Should the best interest of the public be served by collection of refuse from certain areas in the city at night, the city manager shall be authorized to make such collections. The occupants of all residences or places of business within the designated area shall be notified of the hours of such collection. All person[s] so notified shall comply with such order and shall place the containers as designated within such hours. 
(Code 1959, § 9-16) 
Sec. 5-2-17. - Administration and enforcement of chapter. 
(a)  The director of public works shall be responsible, subject to the supervision of the city manager, for the administration and enforcement of the provision of this chapter. He may call upon the chief of police for assistance. 
(b)  The director of public works shall have the right to appoint sanitation supervisors who shall have the authority, and whose duty it shall be, to make routine inspections of garbage cans, containers and garbage collection areas and determine the serviceability and conditions of the same. The director or the sanitation supervisors shall issue a written notice to the owner or occupant of the premises informing the owner or occupant of an unacceptable condition, specifying same. The owner or occupant shall be given a reasonable time to correct the condition which the notice specifies, and upon failure to correct same, the director or the supervisor shall have the duty of issuing a summons directed to the responsible party to appear in the Forest Park Municipal Court, Environmental Division to answer the charge of violation of the appropriate section of this chapter. Supervisors appointed by the director of public works shall have concurrent authority with the said director to enforce all the provisions of this chapter and any such person shall have the authority to issue a summons to any violator of any provisions hereof to appear in the Forest Park Municipal Court, Environmental Division of the city to answer to the charge of violation of the appropriate section of this chapter. 
(c)  Any homeowner who violates any section or provision of this chapter, shall, upon failure to correct the specified condition after being given notice thereof to do so, be issued a citation for said violation and be required to appear in the Forest Park Municipal Court, Environmental Division, to answer said citation, and after trial and if convicted, shall be guilty of a misdemeanor and required to pay a fine in an amount not less than two hundred fifty dollars ($250.00) on a first conviction; a fine not less than five hundred dollars ($500.00) on a second conviction; and a fine of not less than one thousand dollars ($1,000.00) on a third or more conviction; and/or imprisoned for a period not to exceed six (6) months and one (1) day. Each container obtained in violation of this chapter shall constitute a separate violation and offense hereunder, and punished accordingly. 
(d)  Any commercial establishment or entity or any of its agents, who violate any section or provision of this chapter, shall, upon failure to correct the specified condition within twenty-four (24) hours after being given notice thereof to do so, be issued a citation and required to appear in the Forest Park Municipal Court, Environmental Division, to answer said citation, and after trial and if convicted, shall pay a fine in an amount not to exceed one thousand dollars ($1,000.00) for each violation. Additionally, for any such violation by the commercial establishment or entity or any of its agents, the director of public works may also cause said establishment or entity to cease operations, construction, or development, as the case may be, until the violation has been corrected by said establishment or entity or its agents. Each container obtained in violation of this chapter shall constitute a separate violation and offense hereunder, and punished accordingly. 
(Code 1959, § 9-17; Ord. No. 05-17, § 1, 4-4-2005; Ord. No. 10-22, § 1, 10-4-2010; Ord. No. 14-21, § 2, 9-2-2014) 
CHAPTER 3. - DRAINAGE IMPROVEMENTS 

Sec. 5-3-1. - Legislative findings. 
(a)  Due to the type and age of development in Forest Park, and also due to the lack of coordinated engineering ensuring that the drainage improvements would not cause an undue problem downstream, numerous properties in Forest Park are now experiencing or are expected to experience in the future a partial or complete failure of the drainage structures located thereon. 
(b)  While most of these drainage structures were built according to accepted engineering practices at the time of construction, experience in urban development has revealed serious flaws in surface-water management for both individual properties and for the City as a whole. 
(c)  The failure to properly manage the flow of surface water has the potential to adversely affect the following public interests: 
(1)  The health and safety of citizens, including minors and others laboring under disabilities, is imperiled by the creation of flooding conditions and situations conducive to the attraction of vermin, rats, disease-transmitting insects, and other waterborne and airborne-health risks; 
(2)  Periodic flooding conditions may undermine public improvements such as roads, streets, sanitary-sewer systems and other city facilities with the resulting impediment to the delivery of emergency and other city services; and 
(3)  The integrity of the city-wide drainage system may be affected by the failure, refusal or inability of individual property owners to deal with situations that create adverse conditions either upstream or downstream. 
(d)  While some of these unsatisfactory conditions exist on private property, they may have adverse implications on both public and other private property. 
(e)  From time to time, situations arise for which sufficient justification exists for the city to participate in resolving or ameliorating the adverse conditions. 
(f)  The mayor and council find that an analytical process may be designed to enable the staff to identify those conditions that warrant action by or the participation of the city, and that the utilization of such process should ensure that the city funds are not utilized to improve private property in those circumstances where legitimate public interests do not exist. 
The sections set out in this chapter are enacted in reliance upon these findings. 
(Ord. No. 91-002, 4-15-91, ¶ 1) 
Sec. 5-3-2. - Drainage improvements on public right-of-way. 
The director of public works shall have the authority to improve drainage structures on public right-of-way immediately adjacent to public streets under the following conditions: 
(1)  The drainage structure is working improperly resulting in an actual or threatened public safety hazard; or 
(2)  If both of the above conditions do not exist, and if the adjoining property requests improvement: 
a.  Provided the adjoining property owner agrees to furnish at his or her own expense all required materials, including but not limited to pipe, concrete, grates, blocks, grass, seed and fertilizer; and 
b.  Provided installation of the improvement would not, in the judgment of the director, increase the likelihood of a drainage system malfunction either upstream or downstream; and 
c.  Provided sufficient funds have been budgeted to complete such repairs and also carry on all other budgeted functions of the department. 
Then the director may use city labor and equipment to complete such repairs provided that the projected expense for the use of such equipment and the cost of such labor does not exceed an amount established by the governing body from time to time in a separate ordinance. Requests for improvements with a projected equipment and labor expense in excess of the amount established by the governing body shall be approved individually by the governing body on a case by case basis. 
(Ord. No. 91-002, 4-15-91, ¶ 2; Ord. No. 08-11, § 13, 3-17-2008) 
Sec. 5-3-3. - Drainage improvements on nonpublic property. 
(a)  The city of Forest Park cannot use public funds to improve private property. However, as a consequence of the conditions delineated by section 5-3-1, the mayor and council may approve, at their sole discretion, the utilization of the city assets to ameliorate existing or potential public safety hazards. 
(b)  The following provisions shall control the exercise of discretion by the mayor and council: 
(1)  No affirmative obligation shall exist, nor should one be construed to be created, to address all drainage failures or malfunctions in the city. The mayor and council retain sole discretion to determine if the costs to the city are justified by a corresponding benefit to the public. 
(2)  No improvements, installations, modifications or repairs shall be performed by the city unless the property owner thereof shall agree in advance to furnish at his or her expense all materials, supplies, studies or reports, including, but not limited to, surveys and legal expenses. 
(3)  The property owner shall execute in advance of any work all legal documents deemed necessary by the city including a release and indemnification. 
(4)  The department of public works shall prepare and submit a report based on the criteria outlined in section 5-3-4 for consideration by the mayor and council. Based upon this report, the mayor and council may approve, disapprove or approve with modifications the proposed project. 
(Ord. No. 91-002, 4-15-91, ¶ 2) 
Sec. 5-3-4. - Report by the department of public works. 
(a)  For each request for drainage improvements on nonpublic property, the department of public works shall prepare for consideration by the mayor and council a report of feasibility and necessity based upon the following criteria: 
(1)  What, if any structure, public improvements or persons remain at risk without the proposed project; 
(2)  Is the proposed project designed to prevent or lessen flooding and consequential destruction of private or public property that might occur under normal rainfall conditions; 
(3)  Are the existing flooding conditions and consequential destruction of property limited to the property of the owner or are they also expanding or contain the potential to expand onto adjoining public or private property; 
(4)  What potential public health and safety risks would be reduced by the project; 
(5)  Is the project to be performed for purely aesthetic purposes; 
(6)  Is the project designed to address only astatic movement of a creek or drainage ditch; 
(7)  Is the proposed project likely to positively affect, adversely affect or neutrally affect upstream and downstream drainage; 
(8)  What is the projected costs to the city; 
(9)  Has the project been made necessary as a consequence of the negligence or inattention of the owner of the property and could it have been avoided by the exercise of reasonable diligence by the property owner. 
(Ord. No. 91-002, 4-15-92, ¶ 2) 
CHAPTER 4. - STORMWATER UTILITY ORDINANCE[1] 

Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 06-15, § I, adopted Apr. 3, 2006, amended the former Title 5, Ch. 4, §§ 5-4-1—5-4-14, and enacted a new Title 5, Ch. 4 as set out herein. The former Title 5, Ch. 4 pertained to stormwater management for new development and redevelopment. Formerly, Ord. No. 04-18, § 1, adopted Mar. 30, 2004, deleted the former Title 5, Ch. 4 in its entirety and enacted new provisions as herein set out. Former Title 5, Ch. 4 pertained to similar subject matter and derived from Ord. No. 95-002, § 1 adopted Apr. 3, 1995. 

Sec. 5-4-1. - Title. 
This chapter shall be known as the "City of Forest Park Stormwater Utility Ordinance." 
(Ord. No. 06-15, § I, 4-3-2006) 
Sec. 5-4-2. Findings. 
The mayor and city council make the following findings: 
(a)  Stormwater management is needed throughout the City of Forest Park. While specific service and system demands may differ from area to area at any given point in time, a stormwater management service area encompassing all lands and water bodies within the city is consistent with the present and future needs of the community. 
(b)  Addressing the stormwater management needs in the City of Forest Park is essential to protecting the public's health, safety, and welfare. Provisioning of stormwater management programs and systems results in both service and benefit to all properties, property owners, citizens, and residents of the city in a variety of ways. 
(c)  Failure to effectively manage stormwater runoff can result in flooding, streambank and ditch erosion, property damage and degradation of water quality, aquatic habitat and biological communities. Failure to manage these impacts can put the city's ability to receive state and federal grants and permits at risk. 
(d)  The volume and quantity of stormwater generated by a development has been proven to be most closely associated with the amount of impervious surface on the property, therefore, the square footage of impervious surface is the most appropriate factor for calculating stormwater utility fees. 
(e)  Clayton County, Forest Park, Jonesboro, Lake City, Lovejoy, Morrow, and Riverdale, presently own and operate stormwater management systems which have been developed over many years. The future usefulness of the existing stormwater systems owned and operated by these entities, and of additions and improvements thereto, rests on the ability of the entities to effectively manage, protect, control, regulate, use, and enhance stormwater systems in Clayton County in concert with the management of other water resources in the county. In order to do so, there must be adequate and stable funding for Clayton County's stormwater management program's operating needs and capital. 
(f)  The feasibility report submitted to the county, cities, and Clayton County Water Authority (CCWA) properly assesses and defines the stormwater management problems, needs, goals, program priorities, and funding opportunities of the stormwater utility. 
(g)  As a result, the city's governing authority finds that a utility provides the most practical and appropriate means of properly delivering stormwater management services and the city's governing authority finds that a utility fee provides the most practical and appropriate means of funding stormwater management services in the City of Forest Park. 
(Ord. No. 06-15, § I, 4-3-2006) 
Sec. 5-4-3. - Definitions. 
The following definitions shall apply to this chapter. Any word or phrase not defined below, but otherwise defined in the Code of Ordinances, shall be given that meaning. All other words or phrases shall be given their common ordinary meaning unless the context clearly requires otherwise. 
Credit shall mean a conditional reduction in the amount of a stormwater service charge to an individual property based on the provision and continuing presence of an effectively maintained and operational on-site stormwater system or facility or the provision of a service or activity by a property owner, which system, facility, service, or activity reduces the stormwater utility's cost of providing stormwater services and facilities. The basis of such credits, if granted, will be defined by a specific written agreement at the determination of the stormwater official in accordance with the stormwater utility. 
Customer shall mean all persons or entities to whom the stormwater service charge is billed. 
Detached dwelling unit shall mean developed land containing one (1) structure which is not attached to another dwelling and which contains one (1) or more bedrooms, with a bathroom and kitchen facilities, designed for occupancy by one (1) family. Detached dwelling units may include houses, manufactured homes, and mobile homes located on one (1) or more individual lots or parcels of land. Developed land may be classified as a detached dwelling unit despite the presence of incidental structures associated with residential uses such as garages, carports, or small storage buildings, or the presence of a commercial use within the dwelling unit so long as such use does not result in additional impervious areas such as parking spaces, playgrounds, or structures or additions to the building which are used as offices, storage facilities, meeting rooms, classrooms, houses of worship, or similar non-residential uses. Detached dwelling unit shall not include developed land containing: structures used primarily for non-residential purposes, manufactured homes and mobile homes located within manufactured home or mobile home parks where the land is owned by persons or entities other than the owners of the manufactured homes or mobile homes, or multiple dwelling unit residential properties. 
Developed land means real property which has been altered from its "natural" state by addition of any improvements, such as grading, paving, compaction, construction of structures or impervious surfaces greater than two hundred (200) square feet, or drainage works so that hydrologic response of the property is changed from that which would occur in the natural undeveloped conditions. For new construction, property shall be considered developed pursuant to this chapter upon issuance of a certificate of occupancy, or upon completion of construction or final inspection if no such certificate is issued. 
Hydrologic response of a property is the manner and means whereby stormwater collects, remains, infiltrates, and is conveyed from a property. It is dependent on several factors including, but not limited to, the presence of impervious area; the size, shape, topographic, vegetative, and geologic conditions of a property; antecedent moisture conditions; and groundwater conditions on a property. 
Impervious surfaces shall mean those areas which prevent or impede the infiltration of stormwater into the soil as it entered in natural conditions prior to development. The following types of surfaces will be considered "impervious surfaces" for purposes of the stormwater utility: the projected area of buildings; asphalt-, concrete-, brick-, or stone-paved areas; improved vehicular drives and parking areas; compacted gravel and soil surfaces; fabric or plastic coverings; and other surfaces that prevent or impede the natural infiltration of stormwater runoff or that change the hydrologic response of the property that existed prior to development. 
Multi-family residential shall mean developed land where more than one (1) attached or detached residential dwelling units are located, including, but not limited to, apartment houses, condominiums, townhomes, attached single-family homes, boarding houses, group homes, hotels and motels, retirement centers, and other structures in which more than one family group commonly and normally reside or could reside. 
Service charges shall mean the stormwater management service charges applicable to a parcel of developed land, which charge shall be reflective of the service provided by CCWA Stormwater Utility. The charge shall be used to fund the City of Forest Park Stormwater Utility's cost of providing stormwater management services and systems. Service charges are based on measurable parameters that influence the stormwater utility's cost of providing services and facilities, with the most important factor being the amount of impervious area on each parcel of land. The use of impervious area as a service charge rate parameter shall not preclude the use of other parameters, or the grouping of properties having similar characteristics through the use of ranges or rounding up or down to a consistent numerical interval, or the use of flat-rate charges for one (1) or more classes of similarly-situated properties whose impact on the stormwater utility's cost of providing stormwater management services and facilities is relatively consistent. Stormwater service charges may also include special charges to the owners of particular properties for services or facilities uniquely related to stormwater management of that property, including but not limited to, charges for development plan review, inspection of development projects and on-site stormwater control systems, and enhanced level of stormwater services above those normally provided by CCWA. 
Single-family residential shall mean a developed lot containing one (1) dwelling structure with its principal use being residential. 
Stormwater development guidelines are those guidelines established by CCWA which specify approved design criteria, construction materials, and construction methods for components of the stormwater management system. 
Stormwater management system means any one (1) or more of the various devices used in the collection, treatment, or conveyance of storm, flood or surface drainage waters, including all manmade structures or natural watercourse for the conveyance or transportation of runoff, such as: detention areas, lakes, berms, swales, improved watercourses, open channels, streams, culverts, pipes, catch basins inlets, collection, or drainage. 
Stormwater official is the CCWA General Manager or their appointee, who has direct responsibility for the management of the CCWA Stormwater Utility. 
Stormwater unit (SU) shall mean the unit of measurement which provides the basis for comparing the runoff generated by customer's developed land with that generated by another's. An SU shall be the average impervious coverage of a statistical sampling of single-family residential lots in City of Forest Park. A stormwater unit has been determined through engineering and analysis to be two thousand nine hundred fifty (2,950) square feet of impervious surface. This unit will be used to determine and compute the service charge for all developed land served by the CCWA Stormwater Utility. 
Stormwater utility guidebook shall mean the document that defines the basis for the stormwater utility, policies and procedures for operating the utility, and other necessary information determined to help document how the utility was developed and how it is operated. 
Undeveloped land is land in its unaltered natural state or which has been modified to such minimal degree as to have a hydrologic response comparable to land in an unaltered natural state shall be deemed undeveloped. Undeveloped land shall have no pavement, asphalt, or compacted gravel surfaces or structures in excess of two hundred (200) square feet which create an impervious surface that would prevent infiltration of stormwater or cause stormwater to collect, concentrate, or flow in a manner materially different than that which would occur if the land was in an unaltered natural state. 
(Ord. No. 06-15, § I, 4-3-2006) 
Sec. 5-4-4. - Establishment of a utility. 
(a)  The City of Forest Park hereby consents to the establishment of a county-wide stormwater utility (the "stormwater utility") by the CCWA which shall be responsible for stormwater management county-wide, and shall provide for the management, protection, control, regulation, use, and enhancement of stormwater management systems. Specific areas of regulation and maintenance are established in the stormwater utility guidebook so long as they are not in conflict with the terms of this chapter or that certain intergovernmental agreement dated July 5, 2005, as amended from time to time, between CCWA and the City of Forest Park. 
(b)  Pursuant to the terms of this chapter and that certain intergovernmental agreement dated July 5, 2005, as amended from time to time, between CCWA and the City of Forest Park, the CCWA shall carry out and perform on behalf of the City of Forest Park, all of the city's duties and responsibilities with respect to stormwater management services, enforcement, and systems heretofore owned and operated by the City of Forest Park. 
(Ord. No. 06-15, § I, 4-3-2006) 
Sec. 5-4-5. - Scope of responsibility for the stormwater utility. 
(a)  The stormwater utility shall monitor the design, operation, maintenance, inspection, construction, and use of all stormwater management systems in the county. The stormwater utility shall be responsible for the design and construction of public stormwater facilities owned by the city and shall inspect, operate, and maintain them as prescribed herein. The stormwater utility shall provide services which relate to the: 
• Transfer, control, conveyance or movement of stormwater runoff through the City of Forest Park; 
• Maintenance, repair, and replacement of existing city or county owned stormwater management systems; 
• Planning, development, design, and construction of additional stormwater management systems and facilities to meet current and anticipated needs; 
• Maintenance and/or improvement of water quality in waterways throughout the City of Forest Park; 
• Regulation of the use of stormwater management services, and systems; 
• Compliance with federal and state regulations related to stormwater management, including the Metropolitan North Georgia Water Planning District (MNGWPD) watershed management requirements; and 
• Education of the public regarding stormwater issues. 
The stormwater utility shall not provide stormwater services related to Erosion and Sedimentation Control (E&SC). 
(b)  The stormwater utility shall be responsible for plan approval and construction inspection of both private stormwater systems and public stormwater systems not owned by the county.
