(23)  Lot . A portion or parcel of land devoted to a single principal use, or occupied by a building or group of buildings devoted to a common use, together with the customary accessories and open spaces belonging to same. 
(24)  Lot width . The distance between the side boundaries of the lot measured at the front building line. 
(25)  Major street . A street or highway designated as a major street on the zoning map of the city. 
(25a)  Manufactured home . A structure defined by and constructed in accordance with the National Manufactured Housing Construction and Safety Standards Act of 1974, as amended, 42 U.S.C. § 5401 et seq. The definition of the date of adoption of this section is as follows: 
"Manufactured home" means a structure, transportable in one (1) or more sections, which, in the traveling mode, is eight (8) body feet or more in width or forty (40) body feet or more in length, or, when erected on site, is three hundred twenty (320) or more square feet, and which is built on a permanent chassis and designed to be used as a dwelling, with or without a permanent foundation, when connected to the required utilities, and includes the plumbing, heating, air-conditioning, and electrical systems contained therein; except that such term shall include any structure which meets all the requirements of this paragraph except the size requirements, and with respect to which the manufacturer voluntarily files a verification required by the Secretary of the United States Department of Housing and Urban Development and complies with the standards established under this title. 
(25b)  Mobile home . A structure, transportable in one (1) or more sections, which, in the traveling mode, is eight (8) body feet or more in width or forty (40) body feet or more in length or, when erected on site, is three hundred twenty (320) or more square feet and which is built on a permanent chassis and designed to be used as a dwelling with or without a permanent foundation when connected to the required utilities and includes the plumbing, heating, air conditioning and electrical systems contained therein, and manufactured prior to June 15, 1976. 
(25c)  Modular home . A factory fabricated transportable building consisting of units designed to be incorporated at a building site on a permanent foundation into a permanent structure to be used for residential purposes and which bears a seal of compliance with regulations of either the Southern Building Code Congress International or the Georgia Industrialized Building Act. 
(26)  Motel . A building containing a minimum of twenty (20) units in which lodging or boarding are provided and offered to the public for compensation. A building shall not be a motel if more than twenty (20) percent of the total units of the motel are efficiency motel units. Ingress and egress to and from each sleeping room is generally to the outside of the building. 
(27)  Motel, efficiency . A building which otherwise meets the definition of motel, but in which cooking facilities are included in more than twenty (20) percent of the total units. For the purposes of this section, "cooking facilities" shall mean any room in which equipment is placed or allowed which facilities the heating and refrigeration of food. 
(28)  New development . A development upon a previously unimproved or undeveloped tract of land, or a tract of land that has had previously existing structures demolished. 
(29)  Nonconforming use or structure . Any building, structure, or use of land lawful at the time of passage of this chapter which does not conform, after the passage or amendment of this chapter, with the regulations of the district in which it is located. 
(30)  Nursing home . Any dwelling in which aged, chronically ill or incurable persons are housed and furnished with meals and nursing care for compensation. 
(31)  Outdoor advertising sign . An attached or freestanding structure conveying some information, knowledge, or idea to the public. 
(32)  Planted buffer strip . A screen of shrubs, trees, or similar plants at least eight (8) feet high and dense enough to preclude uninterrupted vision from one (1) side to the other. 
(33)  Rear yard . An open space on the same lot with a principal building, unoccupied except by a permitted accessory building, or use, extending the full width of the lot and located between the rear line of the lot and the rear line of the building projected to the side lines of the lot. 
(34)  Side yard . An open, unoccupied space on the same lot with a principal building located between the side of the building and the side line of the lot and extending from the rear line of the front yard to the front line of the rear yard. 
(35)  Street right-of-way line . The dividing line between a lot, tract or parcel of land and a street right-of-way. 
(36)  Structure . Anything constructed or erected with a fixed location on or in the ground, or attached to something having a fixed location on the ground. Structures include, but are not limited to, the following: Site-built buildings, industrialized buildings, modular homes, manufactured homes, mobile homes, billboards, swimming pools, advertising signs, satellite dishes and fallout shelters. 
(Ord. No. 14-18, § 1, 8-18-2014; Ord. No. 15-11, § 2, 10-5-2015) 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 14-18, § 1, adopted Aug. 18, 2014, repealed former § 8-8-2 and enacted a new § 8-8-2 as set out herein. The former section pertained to similar subject matter. For prior history, see the Ordinance Disposition Table. 
Sec. 8-8-3. - Conflict with other laws. 
Whenever the regulations of this chapter require a greater width or size of yards, or require a lower height of buildings or smaller number of stories, or require a greater percentage of lot to be left unoccupied, or impose other more restrictive standards than are required in or under any other statute, the requirements of this chapter shall govern. Whenever the provisions of any other statute require more restrictive standards than are required by this chapter, the provisions of such statute shall govern. 
(Code 1959, § 24-3) 
Secs. 8-8-4—8-8-10. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE B. - ESTABLISHMENT OF DISTRICTS 

Sec. 8-8-11. - Number designated. 
For the purposes of this chapter, the city is divided into fifteen (15) districts designated as follows: 
(1)  R-80 Residential District; 
(2)  R-95 Residential District; 
(3)  RM-85 Residential District; 
(4)  RM-100 Apartment Dwelling District; 
(5)  RM-125 Condominium-Townhouse District; 
(6)  C-1 General Commercial District; 
(7)  C-2 Central Commercial District; 
(8)  C-3 Institutional-Commercial District; 
(9)  LI Light Industrial District; 
(10)  HI Heavy Industrial District; 
(11)  PI Planned Industrial District; 
(12)  ADO Architectural Design Overlay District; 
(13)  PUD Planned Unit Development District; 
(14)  GZ Gillem Zoning District; and 
(15)  X-1 Railroad District. 
(Ord. No. 14-18, § 2, 8-18-2014) 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 14-18, § 2, adopted Aug. 18, 2014, repealed former § 8-8-11 and enacted a new § 8-8-11 as set out herein. The former section pertained to similar subject matter. For prior history, see the Ordinance Disposition Table. 
Sec. 8-8-12. - Zoning map. 
The boundaries of these districts are hereby established as shown on the map entitled "Official Zoning Map City of Forest Park, Clayton County, Georgia," dated September 16, 1991 and certified by the city clerk on that date. Said map is hereby made a part of this chapter; it shall be on file in the office of the city clerk. 
(Code 1959, § 24-6; Ord. No. 91-016, § 1, 9-16-91) 
Sec. 8-8-13. - Map amendment. 
If, in accordance with the provisions of this chapter, changes are made in district boundaries or other subject matter portrayed on the zoning map, such change shall be made on the official zoning map promptly after the amendment has been approved by the mayor and council. 
(Code 1959, § 24-7) 
Sec. 8-8-14. - Interpretation of district boundaries. 
Where uncertainty exists with respect to the boundaries of any of the aforesaid districts as shown on the zoning map, the following rules shall apply: 
(1)  Where district boundaries are indicated as approximately following the center lines of streets or highways, street lines, or highway right-of-way lines, such center lines, street lines, or highway right-of-way lines shall be construed to be such boundaries. 
(2)  Where district boundaries are so indicated that they approximately follow the lot lines, such lot lines shall be construed to be said boundaries. 
(3)  Where district boundaries are so indicated that they are approximately parallel to the center lines of streets, highway, or railroads, or rights-of-way of same, such district boundaries shall be construed as being parallel thereto and at such distance therefrom as indicated on the zoning map. If no distance is given, such dimension shall be determined by the use of the scale shown on said zoning map. 
(4)  Where a district boundary line as appearing on the zoning map divides a lot in single ownership at the time of enactment of this chapter, the district requirements for the least restricted portion of such lot shall be deemed to apply to the whole thereof, provided that such extension shall not include any part of such a lot more than thirty-five (35) feet beyond the district boundary line. 
(Code 1959, § 24-8) 
Sec. 8-8-15. - Measurement of distance requirements. 
All distance limitations required by the Forest Park Zoning Ordinance shall be measured in all cases by a straight line from the closest point of the property line of the proposed use being measured to the closest point of the property line of the site occupied by the other use from which the measurement is being taken. In those cases involving a single parcel of property within which more than one use, or various uses, are permitted and in use (such as a strip mall), such distance limitations shall be measured by a straight line from the closest point of the building space rented or in use for the proposed use to the closest point of the building space rented or in use and occupied by the other use from which the measurement is taken. 
(Ord. No. 07-10, § 1, 3-19-2007) 
Secs. 8-8-16—8-8-20. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE C. - APPLICATION OF REGULATIONS 

Sec. 8-8-21. - Use. 
No building or structure or land shall hereafter be used or occupied and no building or structure or part thereof shall be erected, constructed, reconstructed, moved, or altered except in conformity with the regulations herein specified for the district in which it is located. 
(Code 1959, § 24-9) 
Sec. 8-8-22. - Height and density. 
No building or structure shall hereafter be erected, constructed, reconstructed, or altered to: 
(1)  Exceed the height limits; 
(2)  House a greater number of families or occupy a smaller lot area per family; or 
(3)  Have narrower or smaller front or side yards than are herein required. 
(Code 1959, § 24-10) 
Sec. 8-8-23. - Lot size and occupancy. 
No lot, even though it may consist of one (1) or more adjacent lots in the same ownership at the time of passage of this chapter, shall be reduced in size so that lot width or size of yards or lot area per family or any other requirement of this chapter is not maintained. This section shall not apply when a portion of a lot is acquired for a public purpose. 
(Code 1959, § 24-11) 
Sec. 8-8-24. - Yards and other spaces. 
No part of a yard or other open space or the off-street parking or loading space required about any building for the purpose of complying with the provisions of this chapter shall be included as a part of the yard or off-street parking or loading space required for another building. 
(Code 1959, § 24-12) 
Sec. 8-8-25. - Number of buildings per lot. 
Within any district, more than one (1) building (housing a permitted use together with accessory buildings) may be constructed upon any tract provided that yard and other requirements are complied with for each structure as though each structure were on an individual lot. 
(Code 1959, § 24-13) 
Sec. 8-8-26. - Public street frontage. 
No building shall be erected on a lot which does not abut for at least twenty-five (25) feet on a public street. 
(Code 1959, § 24-14) 
Sec. 8-8-27. - Mobile homes. 
Mobile homes are prohibited within the city, except as a special use in all residential zoning districts, if approved by the city council based upon the standards contained in section 8-8-2(15), for security purposes, for developments under construction, or for other purposes. 
(Ord. No. 92-024, § 6, 11-2-92) 
Secs. 8-8-28—8-8-30. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE D. - PROVISIONS APPLICABLE TO ALL DISTRICTS 

Sec. 8-8-31. - Continuance of nonconforming uses. 
(a)  Intent. Within the districts established by this part or amendments that may have previously been adopted or may later be adopted, there exist lots, structures, uses of land and structures, and characteristics of use which were lawful before the ordinance was passed or amended but which would be prohibited, regulated or restricted under the terms of the present or future amendments. 
(1)  For purposes of this section, the term "nonconforming use" shall mean a lawful lot, structure, use of land and structure that existed at the time of the adoption of "The Zoning Ordinance of the City of Forest Park, Georgia" (Title 8, Chapter 8 of the "Code of Ordinances, City of Forest Park, Georgia") (hereinafter referred to as the "zoning ordinance"), or at the time of the adoption of an amendment to the zoning ordinance, that no longer conforms to those regulations and restrictions contained in the zoning ordinance because of the adoption of the zoning ordinance or the adoption of an amendment to the zoning ordinance. 
(2)  It is the intent of this chapter to require removal or cessation of certain of these nonconformities, and to permit others to continue until they are otherwise removed or ceased. It is further the intent of this chapter that nonconformities shall not be used as grounds for adding other structures or uses prohibited elsewhere in the same district, nor enlarged upon, extended or expanded except as herein provided. 
(3)  Nonconforming uses are declared by this chapter to be incompatible with permitted uses in the districts involved. Nonconforming use of land, structures, or land and structures in combination shall not be extended or enlarged after passage of this chapter by attachment on a building or premises of signs intended to be seen from off the premises, or by addition of other uses, of a nature generally prohibited in the district involved. 
(4)  To avoid undue hardship, nothing in this chapter shall be deemed to require a change in the plans, construction or designated use of any building on which construction was lawfully begun prior to the effective date of adoption or amendment of this chapter, and upon which actual building construction has been carried on diligently. "Actual construction" is hereby defined to include the placing of construction materials in permanent position and fastened in a permanent manner. Where excavation or demolition or removal of an existing building has been substantially begun preparatory to rebuilding, such excavation or demolition or removal shall be deemed to be actual construction provided that work shall be carried on diligently. 
(b)  Nonconforming lots of record. In any district in which single-family dwellings are permitted, a single-family dwelling and customary accessory building may be erected on any single lot of record at the effective date of adoption or amendment of this section, notwithstanding limitation imposed by other provisions of this chapter. Such lot must be in separate ownership and not of continuous frontage with other lots in the same ownership. This provision shall apply even though such lots fail to meet the requirements for area or width, or both, that are generally applicable in the district; provided, that yard dimensions and requirements, including but not limited to square footage, other than those applying to area or width, or both, of the lots shall conform to the regulations for the district in which such lot is located. 
If two (2) or more lots or combinations of lots and portions of lots with continuous frontage in single ownership are of record at the time of passage or amendment of this section, and if all or part of the lots do not meet the requirements established for lot width and area, the lands involved shall be considered to be an undivided parcel for the purposes of this chapter, and no portion of said parcel shall be used or sold in a manner which diminishes compliance with lot width and area requirements established by this chapter, nor shall any division of any parcel be made which creates a lot with width or area less than the requirements stated in this chapter. 
(c)  Nonconforming uses of land (or land with minor structures only). Where at the time of passage of this chapter or amendment thereto lawful use of land exists which would not be permitted by the regulations imposed by this part and where such use involves no permanent individual structure with a fixed foundation and with a replacement cost exceeding five thousand dollars ($5,000.00), the use may be continued for a period of not more than two (2) years after the effective date, of this chapter or amendment thereto creating nonconforming status so long as it remains otherwise lawful, provided: 
(1)  No such nonconforming use of land or land with minor structures shall be enlarged or increased, nor extended to occupy a greater area of land than was occupied at the effective date of adoption or amendment of this chapter. 
(2)  No such nonconforming use shall be moved in whole or in part into any portion of the lot or parcel other than that occupied by such use at the effective date of adoption or amendment of this chapter. 
(3)  If any such nonconforming use of land ceases for any reason for a period of more than thirty (30) days, any subsequent use of land shall conform to the regulations specified by this chapter for the district in which such land is located. 
(4)  No additional structure not conforming to the requirements of this chapter shall be erected in connection with such nonconforming use of land. 
(5)  At the end of the above-prescribed two-year period, the nonconforming use of land shall cease and the nonconforming use of any minor structures as defined above shall cease, and the land or land and minor structures in combination shall thereafter be used for purposes permitted in the district in which they are located. 
(d)  Nonconforming structures. Where a lawful structure exists at the effective date of adoption or amendment of this chapter that could not be built under the terms of this chapter by reasons of restriction on area, lot coverage, height, yards, its location on the lot, or other requirements concerning the structure, such structure may be continued so long as it is and remains otherwise lawful subject to the following provisions: 
(1)  No such nonconforming structure may be enlarged or altered in a way which increases its nonconformity; but any structure or portion thereof may be enlarged or altered if the degree of its nonconformity remains the same or is decreased, provided such structure is used for a permitted use. 
(2)  a.  One- and two-family residential structures: Should such nonconforming one- or two-family residential structure or nonconforming portion of structure be destroyed, by any means, in whole or in part, it may be reconstructed in the same location and upon its previous foundation and to its previously existing height, provided said reconstruction does not increase the previously existing degree of nonconformity and further provided that said reconstructed structure is used for a permitted use. 
b.  All other structures: Should such nonconforming multifamily residential, commercial or industrial structure or nonconforming portion of structure be destroyed by any means to an extent of more than sixty (60) percent of its replacement cost at the time of destruction, it shall not be reconstructed except in conformity with the provisions of this chapter. 
c.  Accessory structures: When nonconforming, shall be subject to the same provisions as govern the primary structure to which they are an accessory. 
(3)  Moving: A nonconforming structure may be moved on its own lot only if the administrative official determines that such movement reduces the degree of nonconformity to the maximum extent reasonably feasible, or eliminates such nonconformity, but shall in no case be moved on its own lot in such a manner as to increase the degree of nonconformity. 
Where a nonconforming structure is moved off its previous lot, it shall thereafter conform to the regulations for the district in which it is located after it is moved. 
Nothing contained herein shall prevent the strengthening or restoring to safe condition of any structure or part thereof declared unsafe by any public official charged with protecting the public safety, upon order of such official. 
(4)  In cases where land is taken for public purposes from legal lots of record at the time of such taking in such manner as to reduce yards previously provided in relation to a portion of a structure below yard requirements generally applicable within the district, the portion of the structure involved shall be construed to be nonconforming. 
(5)  Removal of abandoned antennas. Any antenna that is not operated for a continuous period of one (1) year shall be considered abandoned, and the owner of such antenna shall remove same within ninety (90) days of receipt of notice from the department of planning, building and zoning about such abandonment. If such antenna is not removed within said ninety (90) days, the city may, in the manner provided in sections 41-2-8 through 41-2-17 of the Official Code of Georgia, remove such antenna at the owner's expense. If there are two (2) or more users of a single antenna, then this provision shall not become effective until all users cease using the antenna. 
(e)  Nonconforming uses or major structures or of major structures and premises in combination. 
If lawful use involving individual structures with a replacement cost of five thousand dollars ($5,000.00) or more, or of structures and premises in combination, exists at the effective date of adoption or amendment of this chapter that would not be allowed in the district under the terms of this chapter, the lawful use may be continued so long as it remains otherwise lawful, subject to the following provisions: 
(1)  No existing structure devoted to a use not permitted by this chapter in the district in which it is located shall be enlarged, extended or moved, except in changing the use of a structure to a use permitted in the district in which it is located. 
a.  Intent: Although the general intent not to permit expansion of nonconformities set forth in subsection 8-8-31(a) is reaffirmed, where indefinite continuation of nonconforming uses in major permanent structures with fixed foundations and with replacement costs exceeding five thousand dollars ($5,000.00) seems assured, it is hereby found to be adverse to the general public interest to require that such uses remain in mislocated buildings, or to prohibit enclosure of existing outdoor sales, service or storage operations. 
b.  Special exception authorized: The board of zoning appeals may, therefore, by special exception, permit enlargement, extension or moving on the same lot, subject to general requirements and procedures applying to special exceptions and with the following special requirements, limitations and considerations. No such special exception shall be issued on locations and for classes of cases indicated in subsection 8-8-31(c). 
c.  Materials to be submitted with application: Applications shall be accompanied by site and building plans, photographs of the property and of surrounding property, evidence of continued use, extent of present outdoor sales, service or storage operations, and such other material as may be appropriate in the circumstances of the case. During processing of the application, additional information reasonably necessary to the making of required findings may be called for and shall be provided before decisions are made. 
d.  Limitations on extension or expansion: Floor area shall not be increased except to provide for interior sales, service or storage operations replacing existing outdoor sales, storage or service; and outdoor sales, storage or service thus replaced shall not be resumed in the future. In no case shall floor area be increased by more than thirty-five (35) percent of that existing at the time the use became nonconforming. No floor area increase shall be permitted which is likely to have the effect of intensifying the nonconforming use by increasing traffic, number of customers or employees, or other means. At nonconforming service stations, no floor area increase shall be permitted which would allow total floor area to exceed two thousand (2,000) square feet. 
e.  Screening: Where the lot adjoins or abuts a lot in a residential district directly or with an intervening alley (but not with an intervening street), a solid screening fence or wall not less than six (6) nor more than eight (8) feet in height, or approved vegetative screening, shall be provided and maintained in good condition and appearance; except that such screening shall not be located in required yards adjacent to streets or where it could interfere with visibility at intersections or traffic ways. 
f.  Access, parking and service area: Before such special exceptions are granted, the board shall seek the advice of appropriate city agencies or officials concerning adequacy of design, scale, location and improvement of existing access and parking and service areas, and shall require correction of any deficiencies it finds to be of substantial significance as a condition to the granting of the exception. 
g.  Signs, lighting of premises: Where such special exceptions are granted, limitations appropriate to the nature of the surrounding area shall be placed on the number, size, character and location of signs and the nature of lighting of signs and premises. Such limitations may require removal, redesign and/or relocation of existing signs and lighting. 
h.  Hours and conditions of operation: As a condition to the granting of the special exception, the board may establish such limitations on hours and conditions of operations as it finds reasonably necessary to protect the safety, security, comfort and tranquility of the area, and particularly of nearby residential uses. 
i.  Findings required: No such special exception shall be granted except upon findings by the board that the nonconforming use has continued and is likely to continue indefinitely, and that the actions proposed in the application as submitted, and with the conditions and safeguards attached and accepted by the applicant, would result in substantial reduction of existing adverse effects on surrounding property and/or in other substantial public advantage. 
(2)  Any nonconforming use may be extended throughout any parts of a building which were manifestly arranged or designed for such use at the time of adoption or amendment of this chapter, but no such use shall be extended to occupy any land outside such building. 
(3)  Changes in nonconforming uses of major structures or of major structures and uses in combination shall be permitted as follows: 
a.  To any use conforming to the regulations of the district in which located; or 
b.  To any use permitted in the most restrictive district in which such original nonconforming use is first permitted by this part, subject to the requirements and regulations concerning such use in the district; provided however, that no nonconforming nonresidential use shall be changed to a residential use in any district in which similar residential uses are not permitted. 
(4)  Any major structure, or major structure and land in combination, in or on which a nonconforming use is superseded by a permitted use, shall thereafter conform to the regulations for the districting in which it located; and the nonconforming use may not thereafter be resumed. 
(5)  When a nonconforming use of a major structure or major structure and premises in combination is discontinued for a continuous period of one (1) year, the structure, or structure and premises in combination, shall not thereafter be used except in conformity with the regulations of the district in which it is located. Such restriction shall not apply if such cessation is as a direct result of governmental action impeding access to the premises. 
(6)  Where nonconforming use status applies to a major structure and premises in combination, removal or destruction of the structure shall eliminate the nonconforming status of the land. "Destruction," for the purpose of this subsection, is defined as damage to an extent of more than sixty (60) percent of the replacement cost at the time of destruction. 
a.  Where damage is to an extent sixty (60) percent or less of replacement cost, such structures may be restored to the same or lesser size in the same location; provided however, that restoration shall begin within twelve (12) months of damage and be diligently carried to completion; and nonconforming use may be resumed and continued as before, or on a lesser scale, but shall not be enlarged or intensified. Unless restoration is so initiated and completed, the use shall terminate and not be resumed. Remodeling shall not be deemed removal or destruction. Destruction made necessary by repairs, maintenance and/or remodeling shall not be construed to be removal or destruction. 
b.  Special exception for replacement or reconstruction of destroyed major structures containing nonconforming uses: Where a major structure containing a nonconforming use is destroyed to an extent of more than fifty (50) percent of replacement cost at time of destruction, the board of zoning appeals may, by special exception, permit its replacement or reconstruction in whole or in part upon making all of the following findings: 
(i)  That the cause of destruction was not the deliberate action of the owner or occupant of the structure or their agents; and 
(ii)  That nothing contained in the provisions of subsection 8-8-31(c) required termination of such nonconforming use; and 
(iii)  That the board finds substantial public advantage in continuance of the nonconforming use; and 
(iv)  That the primary purpose of continuing the nonconforming use is not to continue a monopoly; and 
(v)  That replacement or reconstruction in the manner proposed, with related actions imposed in conditions and safeguards by the board, would reduce any previous adverse effects of the use on neighboring properties. 
(f)  Uses permissible by special use permit or special exception not to be construed as nonconforming uses. Except as otherwise provided herein, any use which is permissible by special use permit or special exception in a district shall not be considered a nonconforming use in the district if in lawful existence prior to passage of the requirement for such special permit or special exception, but shall without further action be considered a conforming use. So long as such use remains the same, structural alterations within the general limits of the regulations of this chapter shall be permitted on the premises of such use; but any enlargement, extension, movement or replacement of such use, with respect to land or structures, shall require a special exception or special use permit, as appropriate to the case, as though it were a new use. 
(Code 1959, § 24-15; Ord. No. 86-017, 9-15-86; Ord. No. 89-004, 2-20-89; Ord. No. 93-003, 4-19-93; Ord. No. 96-005, 3-18-96; Ord. No. 05-42, § 1, 7-5-2005; Ord. No. 07-02, § 1, 1-16-2007) 
Sec. 8-8-32. - Off-street automobile parking. 
(a)  Off-street automobile parking space shall be provided on every lot on which any of the following uses are hereafter established. The number of automobile parking spaces provided shall be at least as great as the number specified below for various uses. Each space shall be at least one hundred ninety (190) square feet in area and shall have vehicular access to a public street. Turning space shall be provided (except for single-family residences) so that no vehicle will be required to back into the street. The number of parking spaces required under this subsection may be reduced by no more than ten (10) percent for any lot within one thousand (1,000) feet of a public bus stop or other mass transit location. 
(1)  Automobile repair garages . One (1) space for each regular employee plus one (1) space for each two hundred fifty (250) square feet of floor area used for repair work. 
(2)  Gasoline filling stations . Three (3) spaces for each grease rack or similar facility plus two (2) spaces for each gas pump attendant. 
(3)  Hospitals and nursing homes or similar institutions . One (1) space for each two (2) beds plus one (1) space for each staff or visiting doctor plus one (1) space for each three (3) employees. 
(4)  Lodges and clubs . One (1) space for each ten (10) members. 
(5)  Offices . One (1) space for each three hundred (300) square feet of floor space. 
(6)  Places of amusement or assembly without fixed seats . One (1) space for each two hundred (200) square feet of floor space devoted to patron use. 
(7)  Places of public assembly . One (1) space for each four (4) seats in the principal assembly room. 
(8)  Residential . At least one (1) space for each dwelling unit. 
(9)  Restaurants . One (1) space for each seventy-five (75) square feet of floor area devoted to patron use, plus one (1) space for each four (4) employees. 
(10)  Retail business . One (1) space for each two hundred fifty (250) square feet of sales space. 
(11)  Rooming and boarding houses . One (1) space for each two (2) bedrooms. 
(12)  Tourist courts, hotels, and motels . One (1) space for each accommodation. 
(13)  Wholesale business . One (1) space for each two (2) employees. 
(b)  The owners of property either previously developed or being developed which would be covered by subsection (a) of this section may petition the mayor and council for the right to expand the existing or proposed development or to develop potential out parcels onto property that would otherwise be required for parking under the requirements of subsection (a) hereof. Such petitions would be considered by the mayor and council applying the following criteria: 
(1)  Whether or not the parking spaces presently existing are underutilized or in the case of a new development, whether or not the parking spaces which would otherwise be required by subsection (a) are likely to be underutilized; 
(2)  Whether or not the parking requirements for the total development are sufficient; and 
(3)  In the case of an existing development, what renovations and/or rehabilitation will be done to the existing development, in order to enhance the viability of the property. 
(c)  A petition filed under subsection (b) hereof shall be in a form as may be developed by the department of planning, building and zoning of the city, shall be accompanied by a landscape plan for the entire development including parking facilities; a written acknowledgment from the applicant that over-flow parking onto city streets or rights-of-way or adjacent properties from the development will not be permitted; and with regard to additions to existing developments or to out-parcels adjacent to existing developments shall include a plan for the renovation or rehabilitation of the existing development. 
(d)  Shared parking arrangements may be made, in which case the number of parking space required under subsection (a) may be reduced by no more than ten (10) percent. Any off-street automobile parking area under a shared parking arrangement shall include one (1) two-sided bicycle rack. Shared parking arrangements may be used for out parcels. Any shared parking arrangement involving two (2) or more lots must be committed to writing in an instrument acceptable to the department of planning, building and zoning and approved by the owners of each of the affected lots or uses. A copy of the instrument shall be filed for record with the Clerk of the Superior Court of Clayton County. 
(e)  An applicant under this chapter shall be allowed: (1) an additional 0.5 square feet of floor area above the maximum allowed floor area ratio for every one (1) square foot of structured parking provided that is a minimum of three (3) stories in height; or (2) an additional three hundred fifty (350) square feet of building space for each parking space in a parking structure which is a minimum of three (3) stories in height that will be available for public use. The applicant shall meet the other requirements of the development standards for the base zone in which the subject of the application is to be located. 
(Code 1959, § 24-16; Ord. No. 89-004, 2-20-89; Ord. No. 00-16, § 1, 10-2-2000; Ord. No. 05-43, § 1, 7-5-2005; Ord. No. 16-02, § 6, 1-19-2016) 
Sec. 8-8-33. - Location of parking space on other property. 
If the required automobile parking spaces cannot be reasonably provided on the same lot on which the principal use is conducted, such spaces may be provided on other off-street property provided such property lies within four hundred (400) feet of the main entrance to such principal use. Such automobile parking space shall be associated with the principal use and shall not thereafter be reduced or encroached upon in any manner. 
(Code 1959, § 24-17) 
Sec. 8-8-34. - Extension of parking space into a residential district. 
Required parking space may extend up to one hundred twenty (120) feet into a residential zoning district, provided that: 
(1)  the parking space adjoins a commercial or industrial district; 
(2)  has its only access to or fronts upon the same street as the property in the commercial or industrial district for which it provides the required parking space; and 
(3)  is visually separated from abutting properties in the adjoining residential district by suitable screening devices. 
(Code 1959, § 24-18) 
Sec. 8-8-35. - Off-street loading and unloading space. 
(a)  Every building or structure used for business, trade or industry shall provide space as indicated herein for the loading and unloading of vehicles off the street or public alley. Such space shall have access to an alley or, if there is no alley, to a street. 
(b)  Minimum loading and unloading space required: 
(1)  Retail business. One (1) space of three hundred (300) square feet for each three thousand (3,000) square feet of floor area or fraction thereof. 
(2)  Wholesale and industry. One (1) space of five hundred (500) square feet for each ten thousand (10,000) square feet of floor area or fraction thereof. 
(3)  Bus and truck terminals. Sufficient space to accommodate the maximum number of buses or trucks to be stored or to be loaded or unloaded at the terminal at any one time. 
(Code 1959, § 24-19) 
Sec. 8-8-36. - Vision clearance. 
(a)  In all use districts except the C-1 General Commercial District, no fence, wall; shrubbery, or other obstruction to vision between the heights of three (3) feet and fifteen (15) feet shall be permitted within twenty (20) feet of the intersection of the right-of-way lines of streets or of streets and railroads. 
(b)  No fence, wall or other similar obstruction to vision shall be constructed or erected to a height in excess of fifteen (15) feet within any use district, except that such structures may be erected in excess of fifteen (15) feet in height within the ADO district upon approval by the ADR board and may be erected in excess of fifteen (15) feet in height for the purpose of screening junk yards under section 8-2-95 upon approval of the ADR board where such increased height is necessary to effectively screen the use of the property. 
(c)  Notwithstanding subsection (a) or subsection (b) of this section, or any other ordinance of the city, no fence, wall, or other obstruction to vision shall be constructed or erected to a height in excess of eight (8) feet within the following residential use districts: R-80, R-95, RM-85, RM-100 and RM-125. 
(Code 1959, § 24-20; Ord. No. 89-004, 2-20-89; Ord. No. 93-011, 6-7-93; Ord. No. 10-14, § 1, 6-6-2010) 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 89-004 added subsection (b) to the above section. Ord. No. 93-011 amended subsection (b) of the above section. 
Sec. 8-8-37. - Accessory use or structure restrictions. 
(a)  Any person desiring to install or construct an accessory use or structure shall first submit to the building inspector a plan or sketch of such accessory use or structure as same is to be located on a zoned lot. 
(b)  Prior to construction of said accessory use or structure, a permit must be purchased from the building inspector before installation of any satellite receiving apparatus, earth receiving station, antenna, or any other structure as hereinabove defined. 
(c)  Except as otherwise provided in this chapter, accessory uses or structures shall be permitted only in rear yards and shall be set not less than ten (10) feet from any property line. 
(d)  No accessory structure shall be erected on a lot prior to the time of construction of the principal building to which it is an accessory. 
(e)  Accessory uses or structures shall be permitted subject to the following requirements: 
(1)  Only one (1) garage for storage of automobiles and one (1) utility building, with the exception of a receiving devices and antennas, shall be permitted on a zoning lot and shall be located in the rear yard of said lot. 
(2)  Said accessory uses or structures shall be set back not less than ten (10) feet from any lot line. 
(3)  An accessory structure or use located on a typical subdivision lot shall not exceed twenty-four (24) feet by thirty-two (32) feet without the prior approval of the building inspector. 
(4)  Each lot shall be permitted one (1) receiving device, located in the rear yard only, and one (1) antenna located in the rear yard only or mounted to the rear of the main structure. 
(5)  Accessory structures shall not be used for any type of commercial operation whether permanent, part-time, or as part of a limited home occupation except as otherwise provided for in the code of ordinances. 
(6)  Accessory uses and structures located on property in excess of one (1) acre will not be restricted to size, as long as they meet the building code and the other requirements herein contained. 
(Ord. No. 85-010, 12-16-85; Ord. No. 89-004, 2-20-89; Ord. No. 96-002, 2-5-96; Ord. No. 96-005, 3-18-96) 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 89-004 rewrote subsection (c) and deleted subsection (f) concerning existing uses and structures. 
Sec. 8-8-38. - Approval of conditional uses. 
All decisions referred to any decision-making body of the city on "conditional uses" shall be so referred for the exercises of their sound discretion in determining the appropriateness of such conditional uses. In making these determinations, the governing body shall use both those conditions which may be attached to each conditional use and, in addition, those standards of review which are contained in section 8-8-106. 
(Ord. No. 92-014, 5-4-92, § (e)) 
Sec. 8-8-39. - Places of assembly—Minimum distance requirements. 
(a)  As used herein, the term "place of assembly" shall mean and include places for the gathering of members of social, fraternal, and other organizations and clubs, hotels/motels with public conference/meeting rooms, lodges, funeral homes and parlors, churches, temples, synagogues, and other places of worship including attendant educational and recreational buildings; auditoriums, stadiums, coliseums, dance halls, public libraries, clinics, nursing homes, flea markets, railway stations, theaters, including drive-in theaters, and any other place or building wherein a group, assembly, or company of persons gather together (usually, but not always, for a common purpose). 
(b)  Notwithstanding any other provision in this chapter, no place of assembly shall be permitted to be located in the City of Forest Park within five hundred (500) feet of any other place of assembly. 
(Ord. No. 11-21, § 1, 6-6-2011; Ord. No. 12-19, § 1, 6-18-2012) 
Editor's note— Formerly, Ord. No. 01-06, § 1, adopted June 4, 2001 repealed § 8-8-39 which pertained to special land use permits and derived from Ord. No. 00-12, § 1, adopted Aug. 7, 2000. 
Sec. 8-8-40. - Manufacture of explosives and fireworks prohibited. 
The manufacture of explosives, consumer fireworks, and fireworks is prohibited in all districts. 
(Ord. No. 15-11, § 3, 10-5-2015) 
Secs. 8-8-41—8-8-49. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE E. - PERMITTED USES BY DISTRICTS AND REGULATIONS APPLICABLE THEREIN 

Sec. 8-8-50. - Reserved. 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 04-70, adopted Dec. 20, 2004, deleted § 8-8-50, which pertained to R-60 Cluster Style Single-Family Residential District and derived from Ord. No. 92-0222, § 1, adopted Nov. 2, 1992. 
Sec. 8-8-51. - R-80 Residential District. 
(a)  Within any R-80 Residential District of the city, the following uses are permitted: 
(1)  Single-family residences. 
(2)  Accessory uses and customary incidental home occupations. 
(3)  Agriculture, excluding poultry and livestock in violation of portions of this Code. 
(4)  Noncommercial public and semipublic recreation facilities and grounds. 
(5)  Municipal, county, state or federal buildings, or land uses except cemeteries. 
(6)  Signs in accordance with the provisions set forth in the sign ordinance. 
(7)  Railroad lines. 
(8)  Public utility stations such as electrical substations, if such stations are essential to the immediate area and subject to the following conditions: Such uses shall be enclosed within a woven-wire fence not less than eight (8) feet high; such areas shall be suitably landscaped; and the storage of vehicles and equipment on the premises shall be prohibited. 
(b)  Within any R-80 Residential District the following regulations shall apply: 
(1)  Height. No building shall exceed thirty-five (35) feet in height when used as a residence or forty (40) feet in height when used for nonresidential purposes. 
(2)  Front yard setback. There shall be a minimum front yard setback from the street centerline on major streets of seventy-five (75) feet and on minor streets of sixty (60) feet. 
(3)  Side yard. Side yards at least ten (10) feet in width shall be provided on both sides of the main building. 
(4)  Rear yard. There shall be a rear yard with a depth of at least thirty (30) feet. 
(5)  Lot area per dwelling unit. Every lot shall have an area of not less than eight thousand two hundred (8,200) square feet. However, the requirements of this subparagraph shall not apply to any lot that was platted on a plat recorded in the office of the Clerk of the Superior Court of Clayton County, Georgia, prior to July 16, 1963. In any event, no more than four (4) dwelling units per acre, or four (4) lots per acre is allowed. 
(6)  Floor area. Dwellings shall have at least one thousand four hundred (1,400) square feet of floor space exclusive of porches, garages and carports. 
(7)  Lot coverage. Buildings shall not occupy more than thirty (30) percent of the lot. 
(8)  Lot width. The minimum lot width at the building line shall be not less than eighty (80) feet. 
(9)  Structural integrity and design. The structural integrity and design of a new structure shall be comparable to the majority of existing structures within a one thousand-foot radius and exhibit an exterior finishing of like materials. This subparagraph shall not apply to the consideration of a completely new subdivision. The architectural characteristics, design, and exterior finishing materials may differ from existing structures in the area, at the discretion of the developer, and a recommendation by the planning commission and final approval by the governing authority. 
(c)  Conditional uses. Upon applicant to and recommendation by the planning commission that the same be permitted and, after a review and adoption of the findings of the planning commission by the mayor and council, the uses listed below may be permitted as conditional uses in the area zoned R-80: 
(1)  Cemeteries. 
(2)  Nursery schools, kindergartens and day care centers of every nature, kind and description, provided that such uses meet the minimum requirements of all applicable regulatory agencies. 
(3)  Churches, temples and nonprofit public, private and parochial schools; nonprofit fraternal organizations and clubs; hospitals, clinics and nursing homes, including those for the treatment or confinement of those suffering from mental disorder, psychiatric disorder, insanity, epilepsy, drug addiction, or alcoholic addiction. However, for any use described in this subsection, the following must be observed: 
a.  Adequate and paved off-street parking must be provided; 
b.  Adequate ingress and egress to a major street must be assured and even though location on a major street is not required, it must be determined that no substantial traffic problem will be created which will endanger the health, safety, or welfare of residents of the area or those using the facility; 
c.  No building shall be located within twenty-five (25) feet of any property line; 
d.  Planted buffer strips at least fifteen (15) feet in width shall be maintained along all property lines except those bordering on streets. 
(Ord. No. 04-71, § 1, 12-20-2004; Ord. No. 05-40, § 1, 7-5-2005) 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 04-71, § 1, adopted Dec. 20, 2004, deleted the former § 8-8-51, and enacted a new § 8-8-51 as set out herein. The former § 8-8-51 pertained to R-70 Residential District and derived from Code 1959, § 24-22; Ord. No. 85-005, adopted Aug. 19, 1985; Ord. No. 89-004, adopted Feb. 20, 1989; Ord. No. 96-005, adopted Mar. 18, 1996; Ord. No. 97-010, § 1, adopted Nov. 17, 1997. 
Sec. 8-8-52. - R-95 Residential District. 
(a)  Within any R-95 Residential District of the city, the following uses are permitted: 
(1)  Single-family residences. 
(2)  Accessory uses and customary incidental home occupations. 
(3)  Agriculture, excluding poultry and livestock in violation of portions of this Code. 
(4)  Noncommercial public and semipublic recreation facilities and grounds. 
(5)  Municipal, county, state or federal buildings, or land uses except cemeteries. 
(6)  Signs in accordance with the provisions set forth in the City of Forest Park sign ordinance. 
(7)  Railroad lines. 
(8)  Public utility stations such as electrical substations, if such stations are essential to the immediate area and subject to the following conditions: Such uses shall be enclosed within a woven-wire fence not less than eight (8) feet high; shall be suitably landscaped; and the storage of vehicles and equipment on the premises shall be prohibited. 
(b)  Within any R-95 Residential District, the following regulations shall apply: 
(1)  Height. No building shall exceed thirty-five (35) feet in height when used as a residence or forty (40) feet in height when used for nonresidential purposes. 
(2)  Front yard setback. There shall be a minimum front setback from the street centerline on major streets of seventy-five (75) feet and on minor streets of sixty (60) feet. 
(3)  Side yard. Side yards at least ten (10) feet in width shall be provided on both sides of the main building. 
(4)  Rear yard. There shall be rear yard with a depth of at least fifty (50) feet. 
(5)  Lot area per dwelling unit. Every lot shall have an area of not less than fourteen thousand five hundred (14,500) square feet. (See exceptions and modifications.) 
(6)  Floor area. Dwellings shall have at least one thousand eight hundred (1,800) square feet of floor space exclusive of porches, garages, and carports except where there are existing single-family dwellings within a one thousand-foot radius of the proposed premises. If single-family dwelling(s) described herein exist within the radius then the average heated/cooled square footage of the neighboring home or homes shall be taken and the proposed premises shall be built to provide heated/cooled square footage of at least eighty-five (85) percent of the average of the surrounding home(s) within the radius, or a minimum of one thousand eight hundred (1,800) square feet of space described herein whichever heated/cooled square footage is greater. 
(7)  Lot coverage. Buildings shall not occupy more than thirty (30) percent of the lot. 
(8)  Lot width. The minimum lot width at the building line shall not be less than ninety-five (95) feet. 
(9)  Structural integrity and design. The structural integrity and design of a new structure shall be comparable to the majority of existing structures within one thousand-foot radius and exhibit an exterior finishing of like materials. This subparagraph shall not apply to the consideration of a completely new subdivision. The architectural characteristics, design, and exterior finishing materials may differ from existing structures in the area, at the discretion of the developer, and a recommendation by the planning commission and final approval by the governing authority. 
(c)  Conditional uses. Upon application to and recommendation by the planning commission that the same be permitted and, after a review and adoption of the findings of the planning commission by the mayor and council, the uses listed below may be permitted in the area zoned R-95: 
(1)  Cemeteries. 
(2)  Nursery schools, kindergartens and day care centers of every nature, kind and description, provided that such uses meet the requirements of all applicable regulatory agencies. 
(3)  Churches, temples and nonprofit public, private and parochial schools; nonprofit fraternal organizations and clubs; hospitals, clinics and nursing homes, including those for the treatment or confinement of those suffering from mental disorder, psychiatric disorder, insanity, epilepsy, drug addiction, or alcoholic addiction. However, for any use described in this subsection, the following must be observed: 
a.  Adequate and paved off-street parking must be provided; 
b.  Adequate ingress and egress to a major street must be assured and even though location on a major street is not required, it must be determined that no substantial traffic problems will be created which will endanger the health, safety, or welfare of residents of the area or those using the facility; 
c.  No building shall be located within twenty-five (25) feet of any property line; 
d.  Planted buffer strips at least fifteen (15) feet in width shall be maintained along all property lines except those bordering on streets. 
(Ord. No. 04-69, § 1, 12-20-2004) 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 04-69, § 1, adopted Dec. 20, 2004, deleted the former § 8-8-52, and enacted a new § 8-8-52 as set out herein. The former § 8-8-52 pertained to R-85 Residential District and derived from Code 1959, § 24-21; Ord. No. 85-005, adopted Aug. 19, 1985; Ord. No. 87-001, adopted Mar. 2, 1987; Ord. No. 89-004, adopted Feb. 20, 1989; Ord. No. 96-005, adopted Mar. 18, 1996; Ord. No. 99-022, §§ 1—3, adopted Dec. 31, 1999. 
Sec. 8-8-53. - RM-85 Residential District. 
(a)  Within any R-85 Residential District of the city, the following uses shall be permitted: 
(1)  Single-family residences. 
(2)  Accessory uses and customary incidental home occupations. 
(3)  Agriculture, excluding poultry and livestock in violation of portions of this code. 
(4)  Noncommercial public and semipublic recreation facilities and grounds. 
(5)  Municipal, county, state or federal buildings, or land uses except cemeteries. 
(6)  Signs in accordance with the provisions set forth in the City of Forest Park sign ordinance. 
(7)  Railroad lines. 
(8)  Public utility stations such as electrical substations, if such stations are essential to the immediate area and subject to the following conditions: Such use shall be enclosed within a woven-wire fence not less than eight (8) feet high; shall be suitably landscaped; and the storage of vehicles and equipment on the premises shall be prohibited. 
(9)  Cemeteries. 
(10)  Nursery schools, kindergartens and day care centers of every nature, kind and description, provided that such uses meet the requirements of all applicable regulatory agencies. 
(11)  Churches, temples and nonprofit public, private and parochial schools; nonprofit fraternal organizations and clubs; hospitals, clinics and nursing homes, including those for the treatment or confinement of those suffering from mental disorder, psychiatric disorder, insanity, epilepsy, drug addiction, or alcoholic addiction. However, for any use described in this subsection, the following must be observed: 
a.  Adequate and paved off-street parking must be provided; 
b.  Adequate ingress and egress to a major street must be assured and even though location on a major street is not required, it must be determined that no substantial traffic problems will be created which will endanger the health, safety or welfare of residents of the area or those using the facility; 
c.  No building shall be located within twenty-five (25) feet of any property line; 
d.  Planted buffer strips at least fifteen (15) feet in width shall be maintained along all property lines except those bordering on streets. 
(12)  Two-family residences. 
(13)  Multifamily residences. 
(14)  Rooming and boarding houses, tourist homes, provided they are located on a major thoroughfare. 
(b)  Within any RM-85 Residential District the following regulations shall apply: 
(1)  Height. For single-family and duplex construction height limitations are identical to such limitations in R-85 Residential Districts; for multifamily construction, no building shall exceed forty (40) feet in height. 
(2)  Front yard setback. There shall be a minimum front setback from the street center line on major streets of seventy-five (75) feet and on minor streets of sixty (60) feet. However, when located on a street or highway having an existing or planned right-of-way of one hundred (100) feet or more, a setback from the street center line adequate to insure a minimum front yard of thirty-five (35) feet shall be required. 
(3)  Side yard. The side yard requirements for single-family dwellings shall be identical to such requirements in R-70 Residential Districts. The side yard requirements for duplexes shall be identical to such requirements in R-85 Residential Districts. In multi-family developments each building shall be situated so as to have a side yard of at least fifteen (15) feet parallel to each and from the front yard line to the back yard line. (See group projects.) 
(4)  Rear yard. The rear yard requirements for single-family dwellings shall be identical to such requirements in R-70 Residential Districts. The rear yard requirements for duplexes shall be identical to such requirements in R-85 Residential Districts. In multifamily developments each building shall be situated so as to have a rear yard of at least thirty (30) feet parallel to the rear of the building and extending the entire length of the building plus a minimum of fifteen (15) feet on either side. (See group projects.) 
(5)  Lot area per dwelling unit. For single-family construction, lot area requirements are identical to such requirements in R-70 Residential Districts. For duplex construction each lot shall have an area of at least four thousand four hundred (4,400) square feet per unit and a street frontage of at least eighty (80) linear feet. For multifamily construction, each lot shall have an area of at least four thousand (4,000) square feet per unit and multifamily construction shall not be permitted on any tract that does not contain at least sixteen thousand (16,000) square feet and a road frontage of at least eighty-five (85) linear feet. (See exceptions and modifications.) 
(6)  Floor area. Single-family dwellings shall have at least nine hundred (900) square feet of floor space on the ground floor exclusive of porches, garages and carports. Each unit of multifamily construction shall have at least five hundred (500) square feet of floor space on the same floor, exclusive of porches, garages and carports. Each unit of duplex construction shall have at least seven hundred (700) square feet of floor space on the ground floor, exclusive of porches, garages, and carports. 
(7)  Lot coverage. Buildings shall not occupy more than thirty (30) percent of the lot or tract. 
(8)  Parking space. One and one-half (1½) parking spaces shall be provided for each dwelling unit. 
(Code 1959, § 24-23; Ord. No. 87-001, 3-2-87; Ord. No. 89-004, 2-20-89) 
Sec. 8-8-54. - RM-100 Apartment Dwelling District. 
(a)  Within any RM-100 Apartment Dwelling District of the city, the following uses are permitted: 
(1)  Any use permitted in the RM-85 Residential District. In addition, site-built homes, manufactured homes and modular homes which do not conform to the standards of "dwelling, single-family," shall be a permitted use in the RM-85 district; 
(2)  Accessory use or building and uses customarily incidental to any of the above uses, including the following: 
a.  Single-family and duplex construction. Accessory uses and buildings that are not a part of the main structure shall be located in the rear yard or in the side yard and shall not be less than eight (8) feet from any side or rear lot line. 
b.  Multiple-family construction. All accessory buildings shall be located in the rear yard and not nearer to any lot line than the distance prescribed for side and rear yards, respectively. 
c.  Signs. Signs may be permitted in accordance with the provisions set forth by the city sign ordinance. 
d.  Recreational facilities. Recreational facilities, including but not limited to tennis courts, badminton courts and other open, unenclosed and uncovered recreational facilities, except swimming pools, may be placed in any required side or rear yard, provided, however, that any such use shall not be permitted nearer to any lot line than thirty (30) feet therefrom. 
e.  Swimming pools. Swimming pools may be located within any rear yard or side yard provided, however, that no swimming pool may be placed within thirty (30) feet of any rear lot line or interior side lot line, nor shall any swimming pool or appurtenance thereto be placed in a side yard which is adjacent to a public street line, nearer than fifty (50) feet to the street line. Provided further that when located on property adjacent to single-family dwelling use zones, such pools shall not be located within one hundred fifty (150) feet thereof, except in cases where located so as to be screened from single-family dwelling use zones by a multiple-family dwelling greater in length by a minimum of twenty (20) lineal feet at each pool, the distance of one hundred fifty (150) feet shall not be required. 
f.  Offices. Commercial and professional offices provided a detailed summary of the plans for same is submitted with the application for zoning or if property is already zoned with the application for a building permit and special permission for same is granted by the governing body. 
(b)  Within any RM-100 Apartment Dwelling District the following regulations shall apply: 
(1)  Height. No building may exceed thirty-five (35) feet in height without the prior written approval of the fire marshal of the City of Forest Park. 
(2)  Front yard. There shall be a front yard with a depth of at least one hundred (100) feet exclusive of the street right-of-way. The front yard shall be that yard which is parallel to the street upon which the lot has its primary dimension. 
(3)  Side yard. There shall be two (2) side yards, one (1) on each side of the building as follows: 
a.  For single-family and duplex construction each side yard shall be at least fifteen (15) feet in depth with an additional five (5) feet provided when side yards run along side streets. 
b.  For multiple-family construction each side yard shall be at least thirty (30) feet in depth with an additional fifteen (15) feet provided when side yards run along side streets. 
c.  Where a lot is located at the intersection of two (2) streets the width of the yard along the side street shall not be less than one hundred (100) feet or the average distance established for such street where forty (40) percent of the adjacent street frontage is improved with buildings if such average is less than one hundred (100) feet, but in no case shall such yard be less than seventy-five (75) feet. 
(4)  Rear yard. For single-family and duplex construction there shall be a rear yard of at least thirty-five (35) feet. For multiple-family construction of not more than two (2) stories there shall be a rear yard of at least thirty-five (35) feet. For each additional story an additional five (5) feet shall be required in the rear yard. In any instance where the rear yard abuts property being occupied by single family dwellings, the rear yard shall be at least 75 feet in depth. 
(5)  Lot area per dwelling unit. Every building constructed in this district to be used as a dwelling shall be located upon a lot having a public street frontage of at least 100 feet and in addition shall conform to the following: 
a.  For single family and duplex construction the lot shall contain at least 18,000 square feet. 
b.  For multiple-family construction the lot shall contain square footage in accordance with the following scale: 
1.  One and two stories in height: a minimum of 4,000 square feet per dwelling unit; 
2.  Three stories in height: a minimum of 3,000 square feet per dwelling; 
3.  Four stories in height: a minimum of 2,400 square feet per dwelling unit; 
4.  Five stories in height: a minimum of 1,800 square feet per dwelling unit; 
5.  Six stories in height: a minimum of 1,400 square feet per dwelling unit; 
6.  Seven stories in height: a minimum of 1,200 square feet per dwelling unit; 
7.  Eight stories and above in height: a minimum of 1,000 square feet per dwelling unit. 
(6)  Lot width at building line. The minimum lot width shall not be less than 100 feet. 
(7)  Floor area. Single family dwellings one (1) story in height shall have at least 1200 square feet of floor space on the ground floor exclusive of porches, garages and carports. Single family dwellings of two (2) stories or more in height shall have at least 900 square feet of floor area on the ground floor exclusive of porches, garages and carports and a total floor area of at least 1300 square feet. For duplex construction each dwelling unit shall have at least 900 square feet of floor space on the ground floor exclusive of porches, garages and carports. For multiple-family construction each dwelling unit shall have at least 900 square feet of floor space exclusive of porches, garages and carports. 
(8)  Lot coverage. Buildings shall not occupy more than 35 percent of the area of any lot or tract; however, open unenclosed and uncovered recreation areas and swimming pools shall not be considered as buildings. 
(9)  Parking space. One and one-half (1 ½) parking spaces shall be provided for each dwelling unit in this district. No parking shall be permitted in any front or side yard within 50 feet of the edge of the right-of-way of any public street. Driveways shall not exceed 24 feet in width at the street line and shall not be located nearer than 10 feet to any side or rear lot line. No parking space or driveway shall be located nearer than 10 feet to any lot line. Ingress and egress to parking areas shall be provided by means other than the use of alleys. Parking spaces and driveways shall be constructed of a permanent material as provided by the city engineer. 
(10)  Open spaces. Open space requirements for a multiple dwelling or for more than one multiple dwelling, when placed on the same lot, parcel or tract of land, shall be as follows: 
a.  When a line is projected perpendicularly from any point on a side of a building other than that side having the least dimension and intersects any other side of the same building or any side of another building, the minimum distance between such sides shall not be less than two (2) times the side yard requirements as determined by the height of such building or buildings. 
b.  When a line is projected perpendicularly from any point on a side of a building having the least dimension and intersects a side of the least dimension of the same building or a side of the least dimension of another building, the minimum distance between such sides shall not be less than one and one-half (1 ½) times the side yard requirements as determined by the height of such buildings; provided, however, that any building or buildings are placed on the same lot so as to require a front yard, the minimum distance between such buildings or parts of a building shall not be less than two (2) times the side yard requirements. 
The distance prescribed in subsections (a) and (b) of this section shall control, except that the minimum distances between such buildings and any projections thereto, when so arranged on the same lot, parcel or tract of land, shall be as follows: 
Front to front ..... 50 feet 
Front to rear ..... 60 feet 
Rear to rear ..... 50 feet 
Front or rear to side ..... 40 feet 
All other arrangements ..... Same as side yard,  but in no case less than 30 feet. 
(Code 1959, § 24-23.1, as amended by Ord. No. 89-004, 2-20-89; Ord. No. 92-024, 11-2-92, § 7) 
Sec. 8-8-55. - RM-125 Condominium-Townhouse District. 
(a)  Within any RM-125 Condominium-Townhouse District of the city, the following uses only are permitted: 
(1)  Multi-family dwellings in which each resident enjoys the exclusive fee simple title and ownership in his individual dwelling unit while retaining an undivided interest in the common facilities and areas of the building and grounds which are used by all other residents of the complex. 
(2)  Accessory uses or buildings customarily incidental to the above use such as storage buildings and recreational facilities. 
(b)  Within any RM-125 Condominium-Townhouse District, the following regulations shall apply: 
(1)  Height. No building in this district shall exceed 45 feet in height. 
(2)  Front yard. There shall be a front yard with a depth of at least 65 feet exclusive of the street right-of-way. The front yard shall be that yard which is parallel to the street upon which the lot maintains its primary entrance. 
(3)  Side yards. There shall be side yards with each having a depth of at least 30 feet exclusive of street rights-of-way. 
(4)  Rear yard. There shall be a rear yard at least 35 feet in depth. 
(5)  Floor area. The houses one story in height shall have at least 1500 square feet of floor space on the ground floor, exclusive of porches, garages, and carports. Dwellings of two (2) stories or more in height shall have at least 1000 square foot floor area on the ground floor exclusive of porches, garages and carports, and a total floor area of at least 1,500 square feet. 
(6)  Lot coverage. Buildings shall not occupy more than 35 percent of the area of any lot or tract; however, open, unenclosed, and uncovered recreation areas and swimming pools shall not be considered as buildings. 
(7)  Density and common areas. The formula presented below shall be used to calculate maximum possible densities and required common open areas in RM-125 districts: 
Developments shall contain five (5) acre minimum area. 
FORMULA: 
;frac;Total Development Area (Sq. Ft.) minus 20%;4,320 sq. feet> = Max. Number of Dwelling Units Permitted 
Twenty percent (20%) of the area shall be devoted to common open space. 
(8)  Site planning. 
a.  Off-street parking. All required parking shall be provided within the development. Parking arrangement shall be adequate and sufficient for maneuver and safety of vehicles and pedestrians. Walls and/or buffer zones created by landscaping shall be utilized between parking areas and public or common areas. Off-street parking arrangements shall consist of not less than two (2) parking spaces per unit and shall comply with applicable provisions of off-street parking requirements according to use. 
b.  Circulation. Sidewalks shall be provided from dwelling units to main public streets in developments with two (2) or more dwelling units. Pedestrian circulation shall be separated from vehicle circulation. Car overhang of sidewalks shall not reduce the effective walk clearance to less than four (4) feet. Pedestrian access from auto to dwelling unit shall not exceed 200 feet. 
c.  Access and egress for service and emergency vehicles. Site planning shall provide for access and egress for fire fighting equipment, ambulance, and service vehicles. Fire protection plans shall provide for required access and facilities necessary. Where vehicular access to individual dwelling units becomes unfeasible, a standpipe arrangements may be used. Access arrangements, standpipe arrangements and related features must be reviewed and approved by the chief of the department of fire services. 
d.  Garbage and trash disposal. Outdoor enclosed collection stations shall be provided for garbage and trash removal. The enclosed collection stations shall be located as to not be a nuisance or hazard to occupants. The refuse disposal will be screened and enclosed to prevent pollution of the environment. Screening shall be through use of a permanent screening wall of sufficient height to avoid visual exposure of garbage and trash containers. 
e.  Maintenance facilities. Maintenance facilities and service facilities shall be located to prevent visual nuisance. 
f.  Common areas. Common open areas shall be a minimum of 20 percent of the total development area. Required yard areas, drains, interior streets, and common parking court areas shall not be credited toward the minimum required open space allocation. The maximum ratio of length to width of common open areas shall be two (2) to one. Planning, equipment, and landscaping should be appropriate for the needs of the residents. Adequate recreation facilities for the residents should be provided in common open areas easily accessible to the dwelling units and where they do not impair the view and privacy of dwelling units. 
g.  Convenience and safety. Provisions shall be made for information signs to prevent confusion as to location of specific units. Provisions shall be made for mail and parcel protection. Parking areas, service areas, walks, steps, streets and driveways, and open public spaces within the development shall be illuminated to prevent dark areas and to assure safe and convenient nighttime use. Lighting fixtures shall be properly shaded to screen the windows of habitable rooms from the direct ray of light. Minimum illumination requirements are as follows: 
1.  parks, common open areas, in accordance with current Illuminating Engineering Society Standards; 
2.  parking areas and walks, in accordance with current Illuminating Engineering Society Standards; 
3.  steps, in accordance with current Illuminating Society Standards; and 
4.  recreational areas, in accordance with current Illuminating Engineering Society Standards. 
h.  Orientation of dwelling units. Dwelling units shall be oriented to provide noise buffers between dwelling units themselves and the service activities (communal) and car zone (urban noise). 
i.  Landscaping. New plant material shall be added to the development for privacy, shade, beauty of buildings and grounds, and to screen out objectionable features. 
j.  Screening. Screening walls shall be incorporated into design in such a fashion that they provide dwelling units and private yard areas with a security measure, visual privacy, and an acoustic barrier. 
k.  Street frontage. Lots within a townhouse development shall front only a public street classified as a minor thorough-fare or other street or on a private street having a width of not less than 28 feet, as measured from the back of the curb on one side of the street to the back curb on the other. 
l.  Separate lot required for each townhouse dwelling unit. Each townhouse unit, whether attached or detached shall be located on a separate lot. 
m.  [Conformance to subdivision regulations.] All street right-of-way requirements (public or private) shall conform to the existing subdivision regulations. 
(9)  Dwelling unit planning. 
a.  Dwelling entrances. Private and protected entrances shall be provided for each condominium-townhouse dwelling unit, to include sheltered standing space on the exterior of each unit and an entry hall with a minimum area of 12 square feet in the interior. No entry shall be directly opposite another entry unless shielded from direct view of interior habitable space upon opening entrance door. 
b.  Acoustics. The acceptable standard for acoustics is 50 decibels for interior walls between dwelling units. 
c.  Fire safety. For fire safety, two (2) exits from each dwelling unit shall be provided. All exits shall provide continuous means of egress to the exterior which is accessible to a street or to a common open space leading to a street. The second exit may be a breakout panel in the wall around a yard which is located between the dwelling unit and development property line only when such second exit allows egress to adjacent yards in series terminating at a street or common open space. An alternate means of egress may be provided by a continuous alley with a minimum three (3) foot clear unobstructed width leading to a street or common open space. Fire walls, party walls and/or lot line walls between each unit shall be constructed of non-combustible material with four (4) hour fire rating. No opening shall be permitted in these walls. These walls shall be self-supporting and continuous, extending through all floors, and three (3) feet above roof if roof covering is of combustible material. If roof covering is noncombustible, the wall may be carried up to and tightly against the underside of the noncombustible roof deck or sheathing. Combustible framing members shall not extend through these walls. These walls may be offset at intermediate floors, provided the offset floor constructed has a fire resistance not less than that required for these walls. 
d.  Private yards. Dwelling units in townhouse developments shall provide a minimum of one (1) yard. The minimum area of one (1) yard shall be 150 square feet with a least dimension of 10 feet. Arrangement of yards should afford maximum privacy of occupant. 
(10)  Preservation of common areas. 
a.  Covenants. The developer of a condominium or townhouse development or a homeowners association created by the developer, by recorded covenants and restrictions, shall preserve and maintain for the owners and occupants of the development the lands set aside for open spaces, parks, or recreational use, the common off-street parking spaces established for the development, and garbage and trash disposal. The book and page in which such covenants and restrictions are recorded shall be shown on a final plat of the development and on each deed transferring property within the development. 
(11)  Distances between buildings. Notwithstanding any other provision of this section, the minimum distance between buildings and any projections thereof in an RM-125 District shall be as follows: 
Front to front ..... 50 ft. 
Front to rear ..... 60 ft. 
Rear to rear ..... 50 ft. 
Front or rear to side ..... 40 ft. 
All other arrangements ..... same as side yard  but in no case less than 30 ft. 
(12)  Administrative procedures. Building permit applications.
