In addition, pawnbrokers shall make daily reports of all typewriters, adding machines, and radios coming into and going out of their place of business. The daily report shall be in such form and shall contain sufficient information to identify each such article. 
(Code 1959, § 12A-8) 
Sec. 9-3-8. - Ten-day requirement. 
Any pawnbroker or person operating under a pawnbroker's license who takes goods on pawn or buys goods, taking full title thereto, shall hold such goods so taken in pawn or purchased for at least ten (10) days before disposing of same by sale, transfer, shipment or otherwise. 
(Code 1959, § 12A-8.1) 
Sec. 9-3-9. - Pledge of building glass and plumbing material. 
It shall be unlawful for pawnbrokers to purchase, advance money on, or take in pawn glass taken from buildings, such as mantle mirrors, art glass, and the like, or copper wire, copper lining of bathtubs, lead pipes, or any kind of plumbing material sold as junk, where same is offered for sale or pawn by other than persons of known good character. In all cases where such goods are purchased or money advanced, the pawnbroker shall keep a record of such purchases or advances, showing the names of the persons from whom received, their residence, the goods so taken, and the amount of money paid or advanced, and this shall be at all times open for inspection to any duly authorized law enforcement officer. In addition, it shall be unlawful for pawnbrokers to purchase any such goods, or to advance money thereon, where their appearance indicates that they have been tampered with, or there is an effort to conceal identity, or same are mutilated or otherwise show an effort to destroy evidence of the former location of the property. While such goods are being kept for ten (10) days before being disposed of, they shall be so arranged that they can be inspected by all duly authorized law enforcement officers upon demand. 
(Code 1959, § 12A-9) 
Sec. 9-3-10. - Minors. 
No pawnbroker shall have any business dealings as a pawnbroker with a minor, nor shall a pawnbroker's license be issued to a minor, nor shall a pawnbroker employ a minor to assist him in his business. 
(Code 1959, § 12A-10) 
Sec. 9-3-11. - Stolen goods. 
It shall be the duty of every pawnbroker to report to the police any article pledged with him or which is sought to be pledged with him, if he shall have reason to believe the article was stolen, or lost and found by the person attempting to pledge it in the case of a lost article. No pawnbroker shall accept any item, good, or ware upon which a manufacturer's identity or serial number has been removed, obliterated, or in any way caused to become unreadable. 
(Code 1959, § 12A-11) 
Sec. 9-3-12. - Violation. 
Any person violating any section of this chapter shall be subject to the general penalty provided in section 1-1-8 of the code of ordinances of the city, and, in addition, shall be subject to revocation of their license to do business as a pawnbroker in this city. 
(Code 1959, § 12A-12) 
Sec. 9-3-13. - Availability of additional licenses; procedure for obtaining same. 
(a)  If at any such time the city is authorized to issue a new license by reason of population increase, revocation, or surrender of an existing license or licenses, the city manager shall cause to be published in the legal organ of Clayton County a notice setting forth the following: 
(1)  That the city has the ability to issue a pawnbrokers license. 
(2)  That any party wishing to apply for said license shall make application to the city for same within thirty (30) days of the date of publication of the notice. 
(3)  All applications shall be reviewed and approved as qualifying for the license as provided for in section 9-3-3 of this Code. 
(4)  The city manager shall then notify those applicants that are approved of the fact that they have been approved as qualifying for consideration of the issuance of a license. They shall submit the fee provided for in title 3, chapter 3 of this Code within seventy-two (72) hours of their notification. Any applicant who fails to submit the fee shall forfeit its right to be considered as qualifying. 
(b)  In the event that more applicants qualify than the number of licenses or license available, the city manager shall then notify the applicants of a time and date in which to appear in the council chambers of the city for purposes of selecting by random the applicant to whom the license will issue. 
(c)  Those applications not selected shall immediately be refunded the application fee heretofore paid. 
(d)  By submitting an application pursuant to this process, each applicant consents to the process and procedure by which the licensee will be selected and waives any protest or compliant as to the method and manner of selection, acknowledging that the license granted hereunder is a privilege license. 
(Ord. No. 94-005, 12-19-94) 
Sec. 9-3-14. - Moratorium on the licensing of pawnbrokers. 
(a)  Findings of fact. The mayor and council of the City of Forest Park hereby makes the following findings of fact: 
(1)  It appears that the city ordinance on business licensure, as it relates to pawnbrokers and pawn shops, requires an additional review by the City of Forest Park; 
(2)  Substantial disorder, detriment and irreparable harm would result to the citizens, businesses and City of Forest Park if the current regulatory for pawnbrokers and pawn shops in the city were to be utilized prior to more thorough review; 
(3)  The city's ongoing revision of the aforementioned licensure and regulation provisions requires that a cessation of pawn licensing be enacted; and 
(4)  That it is necessary and in the public interest to delay, for a reasonable period of time, the processing of any applications for such businesses, to ensure that the design, development and location of the same are consistent with the long-term planning objectives of the city. 
(b)  Imposition of moratorium: 
(1)  There is hereby imposed a moratorium on the issuance by the staff of the City of Forest Park of development plans, and permits and licenses for all pawn shops and pawn brokerages seeking to operate in the City of Forest Park. 
(2)  The duration of this moratorium shall be until such time as the city completes the hereinafter described studies and takes any appropriate action thereon, including, without limitation, revocation, or the expiration of thirty (30) days from enactment, whichever first occurs. 
(3)  This moratorium shall be effective as of the date of this section. 
(4)  This moratorium shall have no effect upon approvals or permits previously issued or as to development plans previously approved by the city. The provisions of this section shall not affect the issuance of permits or licenses that have received preliminary or final approval by the city on or before the effective date of this section. 
(5)  As of the effective date of this section, no applications for operation of a pawn shop or pawn brokerage business will be accepted by any agent, employee or officer of the city with respect to any property in the City of Forest Park and any application so accepted for filing will be deemed in error, null and void and of no effect whatsoever. 
(6)  The city shall immediately commission a review of its ordinances concerning pawn shop and pawn brokerage licensure. 
(7)  The city shall, after completion of the study, make such changes or additions to the city's ordinances as its studies may warrant. 
(8)  The following procedures shall be put in place immediately. Under the Supreme Court case of Cannon v. Clayton County, 255 Ga. 63 (1985), the Supreme Court stated, 
"Where a landowner makes a substantial change in position by expenditures and reliance on the probability of the issuance of a building permit, based upon an existing zoning ordinance and the assurances of zoning officials, he acquires vested rights and is entitled to have the permit issued despite a change in the zoning ordinance which would otherwise preclude the issuance of a permit." Pursuant to this case, the City of Forest Park recognizes that, unknown to the city, de facto vesting may have occurred. The following procedures are established to provide exemptions from the moratorium where vesting has occurred: 
a.  A written application, including verified supporting data, documents and facts, may be made requesting a review by the mayor and council at a scheduled meeting of any facts or circumstances which the applicant feels substantiates claim for vesting and the grant of an exemption; 
b.  Within one (1) week of the enactment of this moratorium, the city shall cause to issue an advertisement in its legal newspaper to run once a week for two (2) consecutive weeks providing notice to the public of the imposition of this moratorium and the opportunity for review before the mayor and council. 
(Ord. No. 98-002, § I, 2-26-98) 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 98-002, adopted Feb. 26, 1998, did not specifically amend this Code; hence, Codification of § I of said ordinance as § 9-3-14 herein was at the editor's discretion. 
Sec. 9-3-15. - Pawnbroker's license transferrable. 
(a)  Notwithstanding any other provision contained in this Code, a pawnbroker duly licensed by, and in good standing with, the City of Forest Park may transfer his pawnbroker's license to another person as follows: 
(1)  The holder of the pawnbroker's license shall notify the mayor and council in writing of its desire and intent to transfer its pawnbroker's license, and attach to such notice a completed license application of the intended transferee, including a check for the license fee from the intended transferee. 
(2)  The chief of police shall review and investigate the intended transferee's application, using the same standards as are used for initial applications and forward his recommendation thereon to the mayor and council for their consideration, approval or denial. 
(3)  Upon approval of the intended transferee by the mayor and council, the city clerk shall have authority to amend the existing pawnbroker's license to reflect the transfer. 
(b)  Any misrepresentation on the intended transferee's license application shall be grounds for rejection of the application for transfer. 
(Ord. No. 98-010, § 1, 6-15-98) 
Editor's note— Section 1 of Ord. No. 98-010, adopted June 15, 1998, amended the Code by the addition of § 9-3-14 added a new § 9-3-14 to the Code. Inasmuch as provisions already exist under § 9-3-14, said section has been redesignated as § 9-3-15 at the editor's discretion. 
CHAPTER 4. - WRECKERS AND WRECKER SERVICES 

Sec. 9-4-1. - Definition. 
The term "wrecker" as used in this chapter means any vehicle equipped and used for the purpose of towing wrecked or disabled automobiles or vehicles; and the term "wrecker service" shall mean any person, firm, partnership, or corporation which is engaged solely or partially in the business of towing wrecked or disabled automobiles or vehicles. 
(Code 1959, § 23A-1(a)) 
Sec. 9-4-2. - Compliance with chapter. 
It shall be unlawful for any person, firm or corporation, either as principal, agent or employee, to use or operate upon any of the streets of the city or any area inside the corporate limits, any wrecker without complying with the provisions of this chapter except as provided herein. 
(Code 1959, § 23A-1(b)) 
Sec. 9-4-3. - Business license required; non-transferable. 
It shall be unlawful for any person, partnership, firm, association, or corporation to operate or cause to be operated, any wrecker, as defined in section 9-4-1 within the corporate limits of the city, which maintains its principal, or any branch office within the corporate city limits, or any wrecker services which generates 50 percent of its gross income by conducting business within the corporate city limits, without first having obtained a business license from the revenue collection division of the city. 
(Code 1959, § 23A-2) 
State Law reference— Municipal license fees and business taxes on wrecker services limited, O.C.G.A., § 48-13-10.1. 
Sec. 9-4-4. - Registration decals required. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to operate or cause to be operated, a wrecker as defined in subsection 9-4-1, unless the wrecker bears a current registered decal. The decal shall be valid for a period of one (1) year from date of issue and shall bear the registration decal number, the date of issue and the date of expiration, together with any other information deemed appropriate by the chief of police or his delegate. The decal shall be placed on the lower corner of the windshield of the wrecker on the driver's side. 
(Code 1959, § 23A-3) 
Sec. 9-4-5. - Exemption from license and registration decal requirements. 
(a)  No business license shall be required for any wrecker or wrecker service which is operated within the city when the wrecker company is duly licensed and registered in accordance with the laws, if any, of the place having jurisdiction over the business. 
(b)  Any wrecker, or wrecker service, which uses the streets of the city, for purposes of either point of pickup of a motor vehicle or point of delivery of same on a regular basis, shall be required to obtain and display a registration decal as provided in sections 9-4-4 and 9-4-6 of this chapter. A "regular basis" shall be defined for purposes of this chapter as meaning more than one time in a calendar year. 
(c)  The wrecker or wrecker service is not engaged in any activity whereby neither the point of pickup or the point of delivery of any wrecked or disabled vehicle is within the city, or otherwise does not engage in business in the city; provided, that the burden is upon the wrecker, wrecker service, or his agent to prove either the point of pickup or the point of delivery is not within the city limits; specifically a wrecker or wrecker service which merely passes through the city limits is exempt from complying with the terms of this chapter. 
(Code 1959, § 23A-4) 
Sec. 9-4-6. - Application for registered decal; information required in application. 
Application for the registration decal required by section 9-4-4 shall be made to the inspection and permits unit of the city police department on forms prescribed and provided by that department. The application form, which shall be completed under oath, shall contain the name, address and telephone number of any person, partnership, firm, association or corporation operating or causing the operation of the wrecker; the name, address and telephone number of the owner of the wrecker, if different from the operator; the make, model, color, year of manufacture, tag number and vehicle identification number of the wrecker; the date the wrecker was put into service; the state emergency light permit number; and the business license number, if any, and the name and policy number of the casualty insurance carrier covering said vehicle. 
(Code 1959, § 23A-5) 
Sec. 9-4-7. - Required information to be printed on side of wrecker. 
It shall be unlawful for any person, partnership, firm, association or corporation, either as principal, agent or employee, to operate or cause to be operated within the city any wrecker as defined in section 9-4-1, unless this vehicle shall have lettered in permanent paint on each side in plain view the following information: the name of the person, partnership, firm, association or corporation owning and causing its wrecker to operate on the streets of the city, the address from which the wrecker is operating and the telephone number. This lettering shall be in contrasting color to the color of the wrecker and shall be at least two and one half (2-½) inches in height. Temporary or removable magnetic signs shall not be permitted. 
(Code 1959, § 23A-6) 
Sec. 9-4-8. - Typed, weekly reports of certain vehicles stored by certain businesses required. 
(a)  Wrecker services; storage facilities. The owner or operator of any business providing wrecker service or storage facilities for vehicles shall furnish to the criminal investigation division of the police department, on forms of the type approved by the department, a typed, weekly report listing all motor vehicles towed or stored within the city and remaining within the possession of the business on the Friday following the towing or storage. The vehicle shall be listed in each subsequent weekly report so long as it remains in the possession of the business. 
(b)  Auto salvage; crushing businesses; junk yards. Any person, partnership, firm, association or corporation in the business of auto salvage or otherwise in the business of selling used parts from vehicles within the seller's possession and any person, partnership, firm, association or corporation in the business of crushing, cutting up or otherwise permanently destroying vehicles for scrap metal shall furnish to the criminal investigation division of the police department, on forms of a type approved by the department, a typed, weekly report listing all vehicles obtained for the purpose of salvage, used parts, or scrap metal, during the weekly reporting period. The weekly reporting period shall begin at 12:01 a.m. each Saturday. 
(c)  Contents of report. The weekly reports required by subsections (a) and (b) shall be due each Tuesday and shall contain the name of the person, partnership, firm, association, or corporation reporting; the authority under which the vehicle was towed, stored or salvaged for parts or scrap metal; a description of the vehicle; the location of its present storage site, if applicable its tag number, if any; its year and make; its color; and its vehicle identification number. 
(d)  Inability to obtain information without damaging vehicle. If any of the information required by subsection (c) cannot be obtained for the weekly report required by subsection (a) without damaging the vehicle, the fact shall be conveyed by the owner or operator of the wrecker service or storage facility to the police department by telephonic communication and shall also be set forth in the weekly report. 
(Code 1959, § 23A-7) 
Sec. 9-4-9. - Call to scene of accident by certain persons only. 
It shall be unlawful for the owner of any wrecker, or his agent, representative or employee, to go to any place where an accident has occurred unless called by the driver or the owner of the disabled vehicle or the owner's authorized representative, or by the police division dispatcher. It shall be unlawful for the owner of any wrecker, or his agent, representative or employee to go to the place of the wreck by reason of information received by police radio. 
(Code 1959, § 23A-8) 
Sec. 9-4-10. - Responsible for cleaning debris from street and right-of-way. 
All wrecker operators, after having been called to the scene of an accident for the purpose of removing a damaged vehicle, shall clean all debris caused by the accident from the street and right-of-way before they leave. In the event two (2) or more wreckers are called to the same accident, they shall be equally responsible for cleaning. 
(Code 1959, § 23A-9) 
State Law reference— Similar requirement under state law, O.C.G.A., § 40-6-277. 
Sec. 9-4-11. - Solicitation for business by city employees prohibited. 
It shall be unlawful for any city employee to solicit business for any wrecker owner or operator. 
(Code 1959, § 23A-10) 
Sec. 9-4-12. - Cruising or parking for purpose of soliciting towing work. 
It shall be unlawful to cruise or park on any street or bridge in a wrecker and solicit towing work. 
(Code 1959, § 23A-11) 
Sec. 9-4-13. - Revocation of license and recall and cancellation of decals generally. 
(a)  The chief of police, or his delegate, may petition the city business license section to revoke the business license and recall and cancel the decals of any wrecker or owner or operator when he has been found in violation of any of the terms of this chapter or upon any of the following grounds: 
(1)  if the registration was procured by fraudulent conduct or false statement of a material fact as to ownership, use, possession or operation; 
(2)  if the owner or licensee is found at the scene of an accident in violation of the provisions of this chapter; 
(3)  if the licensee uses a police radio to obtain information as to the location of the scene of the accident; or 
(4)  if the licensee shall pay in the form of gratuity any person not involved in the accident for information as to the location of the accident. 
(b)  This revocation shall terminate all authority and permission granted by the registration to the wrecker owner. Any person whose registration has been revoked shall not be eligible to again apply for a license for a period of one (1) year from the date of issuance of the original license. 
(c)  Any person whose license has been revoked or decal has been cancelled by the business license section may file an appeal therefrom to the mayor and council within 20 days from the date of this revocation. The mayor and council shall give the operator at least 10 days' notice in advance of the date of a public hearing for the purpose of determining whether or not his business license and/or wrecker decal to operate a wrecker shall be revoked and/or cancelled. Upon hearing the facts, the mayor and council, by majority vote, may reverse, vacate, or modify the order of the business license section. 
(Code 1959, § 23A-12) 
Sec. 9-4-14. - Notification of police department upon removal of vehicles at request of any person other than the active duty police officer. 
The operator of any wrecker removing a private motor vehicle at the request of another person not the owner thereof, other than a city police officer on duty shall report this action to the city police along with the following information: the location of its present storage place, a description of the vehicle, the tag number and the vehicle identification number. This report shall be made by the wrecker operator by telephonic communication to the police within one (1) hour of the deposit of the vehicle at its storage point. 
(Code 1959, § 23A-13) 
Sec. 9-4-15. - Penalties for violation of this chapter. 
Any person, partnership, firm, association or corporation that violates any of the provisions of this chapter shall, upon conviction in municipal court, be punished as provided in section 1-1-8 of this code. Each day's unlawful violation shall constitute a separate offense hereunder. The chief of police or his delegate shall have authority to issue citations for violations of this chapter. 
(Code 1959, § 23A-14) 
CHAPTER 5. - TAXICABS[5] 
Footnotes: 
--- (5) --- 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 01-05, § 1, adopted May 21, 2001 amended Ch. 5 in its entirety to read as herein set out. Former Ch. 5, §§ 9-1—9-5-19, 9-5-21—9-5-26 pertained to similar subject matter and derived from 1959 Code, §§ 22-1—22-3, 22-8, 22-9, 22-13—22-17, 22-19, 22-21; Ord. No. 85-004, adopted July 1, 1985; Ord. No. 86-007, adopted May 5, 1986; Ord. No. 89-003, adopted Feb. 6, 1989; Ord. No. 96-011, adopted Aug. 5, 1996; Ord. No. 99-007, adopted Apr. 5, 1999; Ord. No. 99-008, § 1, adopted Apr. 5, 1999; Ord. No. 00-02, § 1, adopted Feb. 7, 2000. 

ARTICLE A. - GENERAL PROVISIONS 

Sec. 9-5-1. - Definitions. 
The following words and phrases, when used in this chapter have the meanings as set out herein: 
(1)  Taxicab is hereby defined to be a motor vehicle operated for hire, the destination of which is under the direction of the passenger transported therein. 
(2)  Highway means any of the public streets, alleys, lanes, boulevards, avenues, drives, circles, or roads of the city. 
(3)  Owner shall mean and include any person having control of the operation or maintenance and collection of the revenue derived from cabs. 
(4)  Driver and operator shall mean and include any and every person in charge of driving or operating a taxicab, as defined herein, whether as owner, agent, employee or otherwise. 
(5)  License shall mean the license or authority granted by the governing body to engage in the taxicab business within the city. 
(6)  Driver's permit means the permission granted by the governing body to a person to drive a taxicab within the city. 
(7)  Limousine service shall mean a service whereby a vehicle is held out for hire, including the services of the driver of said vehicle, for purposes of traveling from one destination to another for a specified fee, or is contracted for or engaged on an hourly basis. The provisions of this chapter of the Code of Ordinances are hereby made applicable to any limousine service which wishes to be located and operate within the city. 
(8)  Operator of taxicab business shall mean any person who shall engage in the operation of furnishing taxi or limousine service within the corporate limits of the city, whether by being physically located within the corporate limits thereof, or by actively soliciting and regularly offering service to persons located within the corporate limits. It shall not include those operations delivering passengers to the city from points exterior to the city limits. 
(Ord. No. 01-05, § 1, 5-21-2001) 
Sec. 9-5-2. - Compliance with chapter provisions prerequisite to operation. 
It shall be unlawful for any taxicab to be operated within the limits of the city unless and until the owner and operator shall have complied with the provisions of this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 01-05, § 1, 5-21-2001) 
Sec. 9-5-3. - Licensees responsible for violations by drivers. 
Licensees under this chapter are responsible for violations of this chapter by their vehicle operators whether such operators are direct employees or independent contractors. 
(Ord. No. 01-05, § 1, 5-21-2001) 
Sec. 9-5-4. - Requirement for registered agent; service of notice. 
(a)  All businesses licensed under this chapter must have and continuously maintain in the county a registered agent upon whom any process, notice or demand required or permitted by law or under this chapter to be served upon the licensee or owner may be served. This person must be a resident of Clayton County. The licensee shall file the name of such agent, along with the written consent of such agent with the city and shall be in such form as prescribed. 
(b)  Service of notice under this chapter shall be as follows: 
(1)  By delivery to the owner or registered agent personally; 
(2)  By registered or certified mail with postage prepaid deposited in the United States mail addressed to the owner's or occupant's last known address; or 
(3)  If service of notice cannot be accomplished by using the methods stated in subsections (b)(1) or (b)(2) of this section, by posting a copy of the notice in a conspicuous place on the premises of the company base of operations in the county. 
(Ord. No. 01-05, § 1, 5-21-2001) 
Sec. 9-5-5. - Appearance and hygiene of drivers; responsibility of licensees for driver dress and conduct. 
Drivers shall, while on duty, practice good personal hygiene and wear proper dress while operating a vehicle for hire. Proper dress shall mean the wearing of shoes, ankle-length pants, as well as a shirt or blouse with sleeves and collar. Clothing must be clean and not visibly soiled. Licensees under this chapter are responsible for driver dress and conduct. 
(Ord. No. 01-05, § 1, 5-21-2001) 
Sec. 9-5-6. - Drivers smoking, playing radios, possessing alcohol or controlled substances. 
(a)  A driver while operating a vehicle for hire is not to smoke or play a radio or tape player if objected to by a passenger. 
(b)  No person operating a vehicle under the provisions of this chapter shall transport or have in his possession any alcoholic beverage or illegal drug or controlled substance. 
(Ord. No. 01-05, § 1, 5-21-2001) 
Sec. 9-5-7. - Storage or transport of hazardous materials. 
The storage or transport of hazardous material in the exterior, interior compartment, or trunk of a taxicab is prohibited. 
(Ord. No. 01-05, § 1, 5-21-2001) 
Sec. 9-5-8. - Lost articles. 
Every taxicab driver shall inspect his or her vehicle after the departure of each passenger to ascertain that no article has been left behind. In the event that a passenger does leave an article in a cab, the driver shall immediately attempt to return it. If the driver is unable to immediately return the article, the dispatcher shall be notified and the article shall be turned in to the business office not later than the end of the driver's shift. The taxicab owner and business shall make a diligent effort to locate the owner of any lost article and shall retain the article at its business office for at least thirty (30) days. 
(Ord. No. 01-05, § 1, 5-21-2001) 
Sec. 9-5-9. - Stands. 
Taxicabs shall be operated only from an established place of business, and before using the streets as parking places, operators of such taxicab must secure a permit from the city traffic engineer to park at a particular place, which permit shall not be granted except by and with the consent of adjacent property owners, and no space shall allow more than two (2) vehicles in one (1) particular locality; provided that nothing herein shall prohibit the concentration of a larger number of taxicabs at places where the public is assembled in large groups, such as baseball and football games, city auditorium, churches, schools, and like gathering places. 
(Ord. No. 01-05, § 1, 5-21-2001) 
Sec. 9-5-10. - Receiving and discharging passengers; away from traffic. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any taxicab operator to stop his or her taxicab for the purpose of discharging or receiving passengers except at a point as near his or her right-hand sidewalk or curb as possible. 
(b)  Taxicab divers carrying passengers for hire on the streets of the city shall receive and discharge passengers through the door(s) away from the vehicular portion of the streets. 
(Ord. No. 01-05, § 1, 5-21-2001) 
Sec. 9-5-11. - Safe and legal operation. 
Every taxicab driver shall operate his or her taxi in accordance with the laws of the state and the city, and with due regard for the safety, convenience and comfort of passengers and the general public. 
(Ord. No. 01-05, § 1, 5-21-2001) 
Sec. 9-5-12. - Rates of fare, meters; deception of passengers prohibited. 
(a)  The governing body reserves the right to regulate the rates and fares from time to time to be charged by taxicabs and owners of taxicabs in the city. 
(b)  The owner and driver of every taxicab operated in the city shall have posted at a conspicuous place inside the taxicab where all passengers may see the same, the rates charged for carrying passengers and the manner of determining the fare to be charged passengers. This provision shall not be applicable to limousines. 
(c)  If a fare is to be determined by time or mileage or both, then the taxicab shall be equipped with a meter in good condition to record the amount to be charged on each trip, which amount shall be shown in figures visible to the passenger. The meters shall be subject to inspection from time to time by the city police department. This provision shall not be applicable to limousines. 
(d)  No taxicab driver shall deceive or attempt to deceive any passenger who may ride in his or her taxicab or who may desire to ride in his or her taxicab as to the destination or the rate of fare to be charged, nor shall the driver convey or cause to be conveyed any passenger to a place other than the one (1) designated by the passenger. 
(Ord. No. 01-05, § 1, 5-21-2001) 
Sec. 9-5-13. - Transfer. 
All business licenses, driver permits and individual vehicle stickers required by this chapter are nontransferable. 
(Ord. No. 01-05, § 1, 5-21-2001) 
Sec. 9-5-14. - Penalties. 
(a)  Penalty for violation of chapter provisions. Any person who drives a taxicab upon the streets of the city without a permit required by this chapter or who drives a taxicab upon such streets while his or her driver's permit is suspended or revoked, or who violates any of the provisions of this chapter shall be deemed guilty of a misdemeanor. 
(b)  Liability of vehicle owner. Any person who knowingly authorizes or permits a taxicab, limousine or other vehicle for hire, owned by him or her or under his or her control, to be operated for hire within the city by any person who is not authorized under this chapter, or who is not permitted under this chapter, or in violation of any of the provisions of this chapter, shall be guilty of a misdemeanor. Each day that a person knowingly authorizes or permits a taxicab, limousine, or other vehicle for hire, owned or operated by him or under his control, to be driven within the city by any person who is not authorized under this chapter or in or in violation of any of the provisions of this chapter shall be considered a separate violation. 
(c)  Revocation of driver's permit upon conviction. In addition to other penalties provided in the Charter of the city, this Code of Ordinances, and laws of the state, the judge of the municipal court of the city shall have the authority to revoke a taxicab driver's permit when the holder thereof is convicted of a violation of the Code of the Ordinances of the city. 
(Ord. No. 01-05, § 1, 5-21-2001) 
Sec. 9-5-15. - Conflicts between provisions. 
Where there is an apparent conflict in this chapter between specific and general provisions, it is the intention hereof that the specific shall control. 
(Ord. No. 01-05, § 1, 5-21-2001) 
Secs. 9-5-16—9-5-30. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE B. - LICENSES AND PERMITS 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 9-5-31. - Operation of business; driving vehicle; permit and license prerequisite. 
No person shall operate any taxicab business within the city until the license provided for in this chapter has been granted and issued. No person shall drive a taxicab within the city without first having obtained a driver's permit as provided in this chapter. Incidental, intermittent and unscheduled passenger deliveries into the city by taxicab operators located and situated exterior to the city shall not require the driver's permit as described herein. 
(Ord. No. 01-05, § 1, 5-21-2001) 
Sec. 9-5-32. - Investigation of applications and renewals. 
The chief of police shall cause an investigation to be made into the truthfulness of the information provided by the applicant and into the personal and occupational history of the applicant. The chief of police shall determine on the basis of the investigation whether the license or permit should be issued or renewed. If the chief of police decides that the license or permit should be issued or renewed, he shall immediately notify the applicant. If the chief of police decides that the permit or license should not be issued or renewed, he shall immediately notify the applicant and inform the applicant of the reasons for the denial. 
(Ord. No. 01-05, § 1, 5-21-2001) 
Sec. 9-5-33. - Suspension or revocation; preliminary investigation; show cause hearing. 
(a)  Grounds for suspension or revocation. A business license or driver's permit may be suspended or revoked for the following reasons: 
(1)  The applicant furnishes fraudulent or untruthful information or omits information requested in the application for a license or permit. 
(2)  Failure to pay all fees, taxes or other charges. 
(3)  Failure to maintain all of the general qualifications applicable to the initial issuance of a license or driver's permit. 
(4)  Failure to have the driver's permit posted in the taxicab in a place and manner clearly visible to all passengers at all times. 
(5)  Charging a fare in excess of those fares on file with the chief of police. 
(6)  Having four (4) or more moving traffic violations while operating any taxicab, limousine or passenger-carrying vehicle, during any twelve-month period. 
(7)  Refusing to accept a passenger solely on the basis of race, color, national origin, religious belief, gender or sexual orientation. Sexual orientation shall mean the state of being heterosexual, homosexual or bisexual. Operators shall not refuse to accept a passenger unless the passenger is obviously intoxicated or dangerous. 
(8)  Allowing the required insurance coverage to lapse or allowing a vehicle to operate in the city without an inspection sticker. 
(9)  For violation of any part of this chapter. 
(b)  Preliminary investigation; show cause hearing; findings of fact. Where it is reported to the chief of police that a business licensee or driver permittee is engaged in any conduct set forth in subsection (a) of this section, the chief of police shall conduct a preliminary investigation in order to determine whether there is a basis for the report. If his preliminary investigation reveals that there may be a basis for revocation or suspension of the license or permit, the license or permit holder shall be notified to appear before the chief of police on a date certain and show cause why the license or permit should not be revoked or suspended. The license or permit holder may appear in person at such hearing or be represented by counsel. At the conclusion of the hearing, the chief of police, based upon the evidence submitted at such hearing, shall enter an order make a finding of fact, and then: 
(1)  Find that the evidence does not authorize a revocation or suspension; 
(2)  Issue a warning to the license or permit holder; 
(3)  Suspend the license or permit and probate suspension; 
(4)  Suspend the license or permit for up to thirty (30) days; or 
(5)  Suspend the license or permit pending a hearing by the mayor and counsel on revocation. 
(Ord. No. 01-05, § 1, 5-21-2001) 
Sec. 9-5-34. - Appeals from decisions of chief of police as to applications, renewal, revocation or suspension. 
(a)  Appeals. Decisions of the chief of police that adversely affect or aggrieve any applicant, renewal applicant, licensee, or permittee may be appealed to the city council. Such appeal shall be by written petition, filed in the office of the chief of police within ten (10) days after the decision of the chief of police. The chief of police shall schedule a hearing before the mayor and council and notify the petitioner of the time and date of the hearing. Either party shall have the right to subpoena witnesses at the hearing. At the conclusion of the hearing, the mayor and council may affirm, overrule, partially affirm and partially overrule the decision of the chief of police. 
(b)  Remedies within the authority of the mayor and council. The mayor and council shall be authorized to: 
(1)  Find in favor of the applicant, licensee or permittee; 
(2)  Deny the grant or renewal of the application; 
(3)  Issue a warning to the licensee or permittee; 
(4)  Suspend the license or permit and probate suspension; 
(5)  Revoke the license or permit and probate revocation; 
(6)  Suspend the license or permit for a definite period of time; 
(7)  Revoke the license or permit; 
(8)  Take any other appropriate action regarding the licensee or permittee. 
(c)  Disposition of decisions. The decisions of the mayor and council shall be in writing, indicating therein the reasons for the hearing, the evidence and/or testimony presented, a finding of fact, the final decision, and the reasons therefor. A copy of the decision shall be sent by certified or registered mail to the last address furnished by the applicant, licensee, or permittee. 
(Ord. No. 01-05, § 1, 5-21-2001) 
Secs. 9-5-35—9-5-45. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - LICENSE 

Sec. 9-5-46. - Taxicab owner's business license; application. 
(a)  No owner shall operate, or allow others to operate a taxicab on the streets of Forest Park, Georgia, without first obtaining a taxicab owner's business license. The taxicab owner's business license application form will be obtained from the office of the Police Chief of Forest Park, Georgia. The application form will require the following information: 
(1)  Full name and address of person proposing to operate or conduct a taxicab business within the city. A statement that the applicant is twenty-one (21) years of age or older. No license to operate a taxicab business shall be granted to any person under twenty-one (21) years of age. 
(2)  A full and complete statement of the business to be engaged in and the type of equipment to be used. 
(3)  Addresses of the dispatch location or place from which the business is to be operated or conducted, the telephone switchboard location, and the parking area location for the taxicab businesses' vehicles. 
(4)  Whether the operator of the taxicab business for which the license is sought is a corporation, partnership, or individual. 
(5)  Trade name of the taxicab business to be operated. 
(6)  If an individual, the owner's name and home address. 
(7)  If a partnership, the names and addresses, including street and post office boxes, of all partners and the extent of each partner's interest. 
(8)  If a corporation, the names and addresses of all officers and the amount of its capital stock. 
(9)  General description of identifying words and color scheme of the taxicab fleet. 
(10)  A list of all drivers who will be scheduled for licensing under this chapter. The list must indicate whether the drivers are employees of the business or independent contractors. 
(11)  The make, model, year, and passenger capacity of all vehicles to be operated under the license. 
(12)  Name and policy number of the insurance carrier providing liability coverage for the taxicabs, as well as the amount of coverage, which in no event shall be less than the amount of coverage required under section 9-5-48 of this chapter. 
(13)  An affirmative statement that any business conducted under the license granted upon such application shall be in full and complete compliance with all national, state, county, municipal and local laws, ordinances, rules and regulations, with a particular reference to wages, hours, conditions of employment, and the protection by liability insurance of all persons whom the law requires the operators of such a business to protect. 
(14)  A copy of the rate schedule. 
(15)  The daily hours of operation for the business. 
(16)  Any and all other information as may be required by the chief of police. 
(b)  Upon approval by the chief of police of the taxicab owners' business license, the owner must have on record with the chief of police the original and a copy of the insurance policy of the business covering all taxicabs, evidence that the business has purchased the required business license from the city, and each taxicab to be operated must have an inspection sticker properly affixed, before beginning operation in the city. 
(Ord. No. 01-05, § 1, 5-21-2001) 
Sec. 9-5-47. - License fee and business tax. 
Every person engaged in the business of conducting a taxicab business in the city shall pay to the city an annual license fee in advance for the privilege of using the streets for carrying on the same as provided in chapter 1 of this title. In addition, the license holder shall pay such business and occupation tax as provided in title 3, chapter 3. 
(Ord. No. 01-05, § 1, 5-21-2001) 
Sec. 9-5-48. - Insurance required. 
No license to operate any taxicab business within the city shall be issued or continued in operation unless the operator of the taxicab business has in full force and effect a liability insurance policy for each taxicab in an amount that shall not be less than twenty-five thousand dollars ($25,000.00) for bodily injury to any one (1) person; fifty thousand dollars ($50,000.00) for injuries to more than one (1) person which are sustained in the same accident; and twenty-five thousand ($25,000.00) for property damage resulting from any one (1) accident. Such insurance policy shall inure to the benefit of any person who shall be injured, or who shall sustain damage to property proximately caused by the negligence of the holder of any taxicab license, his servants, or agents. Such insurance shall be with a company authorized to do business in the state, and such insurance shall be kept in force. It shall be the duty of the chief of police of the city to enforce this requirement. Such insurance shall be subject to approval of the city, and termination of the insurance protection shall automatically operate as a revocation of the license to operate a taxicab business within the city. License holders shall file policies of insurance with the police department, and license holders shall ensure that their insurance carriers provide the city a written notice at least ten (10) days before the cancellation of any policy. 
(Ord. No. 01-05, § 1, 5-21-2001) 
Secs. 9-5-49—9-5-59. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - PERMIT 

Sec. 9-5-60. - Taxicab driver permits; application. 
No driver shall operate or be allowed to operate a taxicab for hire on the streets of Forest Park, Georgia, unless the operator shall have a current and unrevoked taxicab driver's permit. The taxicab driver's permit application form will be obtained from the office of the police chief. The application form will require the following information: 
(1)  Name and home address of driver. 
(2)  A statement that the applicant is twenty-one (21) years of age or older. No driver's permit shall be granted to any person under twenty-one (21) years of age. 
(3)  Name, address, and license number of the taxicab company under which the driver operates or is to operate the taxicab. 
(4)  A statement that the applicant is a citizen of the United States or an alien admitted for permanent residence or who has otherwise been granted employment authorization by the United States Immigration and Naturalization Service. 
(5)  A statement that the applicant is proficient with the English language so as to be able to comprehend and interpret traffic signs, issue written receipts to passengers, and obey lawful orders of police and others in lawful authority. No driver's permit shall be granted to any person who does not exhibit such a proficiency. 
(6)  A statement that the applicant has not been convicted of or pled guilty or nolo contendere to or forfeited bond as to any of the violations and offenses set forth in section 9-5-61 of the Code of Ordinances. No driver's permit shall be granted to any person who has committed any such violations and offenses. 
(7)  A statement from a licensed physician that the driver has no physical infirmities which will adversely affect his or her ability to drive. 
(8)  Driver's license number issued by the State of Georgia and its date of expiration, as well as a statement that the applicant's license is not limited as defined in O.C.G.A. § 40-5-58 and O.C.G.A. § 40-5-64. No driver's permit shall be granted to any person who does not possess a current valid Georgia driver's license or whose license is limited as defined in O.C.G.A. § 40-5-58 and O.C.G.A. § 40-5-64. 
(9)  A copy of chapter 5 of the Code of the city shall be provided to each taxicab driver by the city police department at the time a taxicab driver receives an original taxicab driver permit. 
(10)  A signed statement consenting and granting to the city the right to investigate the applicant's personal and occupational history, including, but not limited to, the right to fingerprint the applicant and to conduct a criminal history background check. 
(11)  Any and all other information as may be required by the city manager or chief of police which in his opinion is needed to protect the health and welfare of the persons in the city. 
(Ord. No. 01-05, § 1, 5-21-2001) 
Sec. 9-5-61. - Criminal record of driver applicant. 
(a)  Before issuing any driver permit to a taxicab driver applicant, the police chief shall make a background check of the applicant to determine whether or not he has a criminal record. 
(b)  No person who has been convicted of or pled guilty or nolo contendere to or forfeited bond on any federal or state felony offense within five (5) years of the application for a driver permit shall be issued such a permit, nor shall such permit be renewed. 
(c)  No person who has been convicted of or pled guilty or nolo contendere to or forfeited bond on any federal or state misdemeanor offense involving moral turpitude or alcohol or drugs within three (3) years of the application for a driver permit shall be issued such a permit, nor shall any such permit be renewed. 
(d)  No person who has been convicted of or pled guilty or nolo contendere to or forfeited bond on any ordinance violation involving alcohol or drugs or sexual conduct in Forest Park, Georgia, or any other political subdivision within one (1) year of the application for a driver permit, shall be issued such a permit, nor shall any such be renewed. 
(e)  No person who has been convicted of or pled guilty or nolo contendere to or forfeited bond on four (4) or more moving traffic violations under either state or local or federal law within one (1) year of the application for a driver permit shall be issued such a permit, nor shall any such permit be renewed. 
(Ord. No. 01-05, § 1, 5-21-2001) 
Sec. 9-5-62. - Report of changes in qualifications or permitting information. 
Drivers are responsible for reporting any change(s) in the qualifications or other permitting information previously supplied to the chief of police within ten (10) days of the change. 
(Ord. No. 01-05, § 1, 5-21-2001) 
Sec. 9-5-63. - Notification of dismissal of taxicab driver. 
Whenever a taxicab driver is dismissed from the employment of a taxicab business, the licensee shall notify the chief of police in writing within forty-eight (48) hours of such dismissal. 
(Ord. No. 01-05, § 1, 5-21-2001) 
Sec. 9-5-64. - Application fee and permit renewal. 
The applicant shall pay to the city such sum as fixed from time to time by the mayor and council when the application is filed. Should it be granted, the applicant's license fee will then be considered as paid in full for the remainder of the calendar year. Within the first ten (10) days of December of each year, all taxicab drivers who expect to drive in the following year shall make application for renewal of their permits. The chief shall provide a form for this purpose, and the applicant shall pay an additional fee as fixed from time to time by the mayor and council with each renewal application filed. 
(Ord. No. 01-05, § 1, 5-21-2001) 
Sec. 9-5-65. - Content of permit and the posting of permit and inspection sticker; responsibility of licensees. 
(a)  A taxicab driver's permit shall bear the name, address and age of the driver. Additionally, the permit shall show the name of the driver's employer and shall have thereon a specimen signature of the driver and shall display a current photograph of the driver. 
(b)  The permit shall be posted in the taxicab being driven in such a place as to be in full view of all passengers while the taxicab is being operated. 
(c)  Licensees under this chapter are responsible for checking to ensure that each driver has in his or her possession a current driver permit and that the permit is posted in the taxicab in such a place as to be in full view of all passengers along with a visible vehicle inspection sticker. 
(Ord. No. 01-05, § 1, 5-21-2001) 
Secs. 9-5-66—9-5-76. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE C. - VEHICLE CONDITIONS AND EQUIPMENT; INSPECTION 

Sec. 9-5-77. - Responsibility for vehicle maintenance. 
Drivers and licensees are responsible for maintaining each vehicle for hire in a clean and mechanically safe condition. The interior and exterior shall meet the requirements set out under inspection requirements outlined in section 9-5-79. 
(Ord. No. 01-05, § 1, 5-21-2001) 
Sec. 9-5-78. - Operating requirements generally. 
Drivers are not to drive and licensees are not to allow drivers to operate a vehicle without the required markings, top light, and inspection sticker as outlined in this article. Limousines are excepted from having markings, top lights, two-way radios or taximeters; however, limousines are required to have a plate attached to their front or rear bumper indicating the business name of the licensee. 
(Ord. No. 01-05, § 1, 5-21-2001) 
Sec. 9-5-79. - Annual inspection; sticker; vehicle requirements. 
All vehicles for hire to be used by a licensee in the city shall be inspected annually and approved by the chief of police, such inspection to be made prior to the issuance or renewal of a company license. Once a vehicle meets the requirements of the inspection, a sticker will be affixed to the left side of the windshield. The requirements that each vehicle must meet are as follows: 
(1)  Exterior inspection. Exterior inspection shall ensure that headlights, taillights, brake lights, directional signal lights, license plate lights, windshield wipers, all vehicle glass, window cranks or electric windows, doors and door locks, trunk lid, trunk, hood, door handles, exhaust system, bumpers, fenders, body, tires and other vehicle parts are in good condition and functioning properly. The tire tread depth shall be no less than three thirty-seconds inch ( 3/32 ) on an original or retreaded tire, with no cuts or breaks in the side wall. There shall be no tears or rust holes in the vehicle body and no loose pieces hanging from the vehicle body. All vehicles for hire operated by a single company or licensee shall be painted a uniform color. There shall be no unrepaired body damage or any body condition which would create a safety problem or interfere with the operation of the vehicle. 
(2)  Interior inspection. Interior inspection shall include the rearview mirror, steering wheel, foot brakes, parking brakes, air conditioning and heating systems to ensure each item is in good operating condition. The upholstery, floor mats, headlining, door panels and the trunk compartment shall be inspected to ensure there are no tears, that they are clean and have no offensive odors and that the trunk has sufficient space for passenger luggage. Vehicles for hire shall have posted therein in a place plainly visible to passengers hiring such vehicle a schedule of rates, the size, form and substance of which shall be approved by the police chief. 
(3)  Other required features and equipment. The vehicle shall have a spare tire and jack. The spare tire shall be securely attached and in proper serviceable condition. 
(4)  Random inspection; removal; sticker removal; additional requirements. Vehicles shall be subject to random inspections at any time. Vehicles found to be substandard shall be removed from service immediately and shall be subject to immediate vehicle inspection sticker removal by the chief of police. 
(5)  Sticker proof of meeting licensing and insurance and last inspection requirements. The inspection sticker is proof that the company met the licensing and insurance requirements at the time of license issuance and that the vehicle passed the last vehicle inspection. Each vehicle operator must have in the vehicle proof of current insurance coverage. Any company or vehicle letting insurance coverage lapse shall have the inspection sticker removed by the chief of police and be subject to suspension of its business license. Business operations shall not be resumed until proof of insurance is provided to the chief of police, the license reinstated and the vehicle or vehicles reinspected and new inspection stickers issued by the chief of police. 
(Ord. No. 01-05, § 1, 5-21-2001) 
Sec. 9-5-80. - Inspection and sticker required for vehicle use. 
No business licensed for operating vehicles for hire shall use any vehicle that has not been inspected and had the city inspection sticker affixed. 
(Ord. No. 01-05, § 1, 5-21-2001) 
Sec. 9-5-81. - Sticker restrictions. 
Inspection stickers are not transferable from vehicle to vehicle and are nonrefundable if the vehicle is wrecked or taken out of service for any reason. The chief of police must be notified within ten (10) days of any vehicle being taken out of service. Stickers from vehicles taken out of service must be turned in to the chief of police. Stickers for replacement vehicles or additional vehicles are issued under the same procedures as original inspection stickers. 
(Ord. No. 01-05, § 1, 5-21-2001) 
Sec. 9-5-82. - Inspection fees; re-inspections; inspection stickers; renewals. 
(a)  A fee shall be charged for the first initial inspection of the vehicle in an amount established by the governing body from time to time in a separate ordinance, and for each renewal inspection annually in an amount established by the governing body from time to time in a separate ordinance. Each vehicle for hire must be inspected each year. The inspection stickers shall expire on December 31 of each year, provided that if an initial inspection sticker is obtained on or after July 1, it shall not expire until December 31 of the following year. Renewal inspections are conducted each year between October 1 and December 31. There are a limited number of inspections which can be conducted each day within this time period and failure to obtain a renewal inspection shall not be excused by the inability of the city to conduct more inspections than are done on any given day during said period. 
(b)  Reinspection fees. If vehicle fails to pass the requirements of any initial or renewal inspection, then the operator shall be issued a correction slip listing the items that need correction. The correction slip must be kept with the vehicle until it passes inspection, and the vehicle may not be operated as a vehicle for hire within the city until it successfully passes inspection. The owner of any vehicle that does not pass inspection shall be charged an additional fee for each reinspection of the vehicle, in an amount established by the governing body from time to time in a separate ordinance. 
(c)  Fees nonrefundable and not prorated. Fees for vehicle inspections are nonrefundable and are not prorated. 
(d)  Responsibility for fees. The owner of the vehicle shall be responsible for the payment of all inspection fees. 
(Ord. No. 01-05, § 1, 5-21-2001; Ord. No. 08-11, §§ 29, 30, 3-17-2008) 
Sec. 9-5-83. - Random inspections. 
(a)  Vehicles for hire shall be subject to random inspections at any time and such inspections are hereby authorized by the city personnel as the chief of police may designate. 
(b)  The owner of any taxicab may also be notified to produce his or her vehicle for a random inspection at the driver's convenience within twenty-four (24) hours from the time of notification. 
(c)  Authorized city personnel who find that any of the requirements of this article are not met shall report the deficiency to the owner of the vehicle and to the chief of police. In the event the deficiency is not repaired within fifteen (15) days, the owner of the vehicle shall be cited to appear in municipal court. 
(Ord. No. 01-05, § 1, 5-21-2001) 
Sec. 9-5-84. - Duty to inspect vehicle. 
Every taxicab driver prior to the beginning of each shift and at the end of each shift shall inspect the vehicle to make sure that all equipment on the vehicle is operating properly and that there is no major body damage to the cab. All equipment defects or body damage shall immediately be reported to the owner of the vehicle and the taxicab business licensee. No driver shall operate any taxi vehicle which is unsafe or which has major body damage. 
(Ord. No. 01-05, § 1, 5-21-2001) 
Sec. 9-5-85. - Suspension of vehicles found to be unsafe. 
The chief of police may suspend from operation any vehicle for hire found to be unsafe, and any vehicle so suspended shall not be operated again until repaired and put in proper condition for use, and then only after its condition has been approved by the chief of police. All vehicles in excess of fifteen (15) years of age may be deemed unsafe. 
(Ord. No. 01-05, § 1, 5-21-2001) 
Sec. 9-5-86. - Information to be painted on vehicle. 
The correct name or trade name and telephone number of the owner of each taxicab, his license number and a taxicab number to distinguish such taxicab from other taxicabs operated in the city shall be painted or otherwise firmly and substantially affixed on each side of such taxicab, such numbers and lettering to be prescribed by the city manager and chief of police, all such words, letters, and figures shall be of sufficient size and height to be readily distinguished at a distance of fifty (50) yards in the daytime. 
(Ord. No. 01-05, § 1, 5-21-2001) 
CHAPTER 6. - PEDDLERS AND SOLICITORS[6] 
Footnotes: 
--- (6) --- 
State Law reference— Licensing of peddlers by counties, O.C.G.A., § 43-32-1 et seq.; transient merchants, O.C.G.A., § 43-46-1 et seq. No person shall stand in a roadway for the purpose of soliciting business or contributions from the occupant of any vehicle, O.C.G.A., § 40-6-98; solicitation of sale of merchandise on public roads prohibited, O.C.G.A., § 32-6-1. 

ARTICLE A. - COMMERCIAL SOLICITING 

Sec. 9-6-1. - Permit required. 
It shall be unlawful for a peddler, canvasser, solicitor, transient merchant, itinerant merchant or itinerant vendor as defined below to engage in such business within the city without first obtaining a permit therefor in compliance with the provisions of this article. 
Sec. 9-6-2. - Definitions. 
(a)  For the purpose of this article, a transient merchant, itinerant merchant or itinerant vendor is defined as any person, firm or corporation, whether as owner, agent, consignee or employee, whether a resident of the city or not, who engages in a temporary business of selling and delivering goods, wares and merchandise within said city, and who, in furtherance of such purpose, hires, leases, uses or occupies any building, structure, motor vehicle, tent, railroad box car, or boat, public room in hotels, lodging houses, apartments, shops, or other place within the city, for the exhibition and sale of such goods, wares and merchandise, either privately or at public auction provided that such definition shall not be construed to include any person, firm or corporation who, while occupying such temporary location, does not sell from stock, but exhibits samples only for the purpose of securing orders for future delivery only. The person, firm, or corporation so engaged shall not be relieved from complying with the provisions of this article merely by reason of associating temporarily with any local dealer, trader, merchant or auctioneer, or by conducting such transient business in connection with, as a part of, or in the name of any local dealer, trader, merchant or auctioneer. 
(b)  The word peddler as used herein shall include any person, whether a resident of the city or not, traveling by foot, wagon, automotive vehicle, or any other type of conveyance, from place to place, from house to house, or from street to street, carrying, conveying or transporting goods, wares, merchandise, meats, fish, vegetables, fruits, garden truck, farm products or provisions, offering and exposing the same for sale, or making sales and delivering articles to purchasers, or who, without traveling from place to place, shall sell or offer the same for sale from a wagon, automotive vehicle, railroad car, or other vehicle or conveyance, and further provided that one who solicits orders and as a separate transaction makes deliveries to purchasers as a part of a scheme or design to evade the provisions of this article shall be deemed a peddler subject to the provisions of this article. The word "peddler" shall include the words "hawker" and "huckster." 
(c)  A canvasser or solicitor is defined as any individual, whether resident of the city or not, traveling either by foot, wagon, automobile, motor truck, or any other type of conveyance, from place to place, from house to house, or from street to street, taking or attempting to take orders for sale of goods, wares and merchandise, personal property of any nature whatsoever for future delivery, or for services to be furnished or performed in the future, whether or not such individual has, carries or exposes for sale a sample of the subject of such sale or whether he is collecting advance payments on such sales or not, provided that such definition shall include any person who, for himself, or for another person, firm or corporation, hires, leases, uses, or occupies any building, structure, tent, railroad box car, boat, hotel room, lodging house, apartment, shop, or any other place within the city for the sole purpose of exhibiting samples and taking orders for future delivery. 
Sec. 9-6-3. - Application. 
Applicants for permits under this article must file with the chief of police a sworn application in writing on a form to be furnished by the city, which shall give the following information: 
(1)  name and description of the applicant; 
(2)  address; 
(3)  a brief description of the nature of the business and the goods to be sold; 
(4)  if employed, the name and address of the employer; 
(5)  the length of time for which the right to do business is desired; 
(6)  if a vehicle is to be used, a description of the same, together with license number or other means of identification; and 
(7)  a statement as to whether or not the applicant has been convicted of any crime, misdemeanor, or violation of any municipal ordinance, the nature of the offense and the punishment or penalty assessed therefor. 
Sec. 9-6-4. - Investigation and issuance. 
(a)  Upon receipt of such application, the chief of police shall cause such investigation of the applicant's business and moral character to be made as he deems necessary for the protection of the public good. 
(b)  If, as a result of such investigation, the applicant's character or business responsibility is found to be unsatisfactory, the chief of police shall endorse on such application his disapproval and his reasons for the same, and notify the applicant that his application is disapproved and that no permit will be issued. Any person aggrieved by a decision of the chief of police may appeal such decision to the city manager. 
(c)  If, as a result of such investigation, the character and business responsibility of the applicant are found to be satisfactory, the chief of police shall, upon receipt of payment of the prescribed permit fee, deliver to the applicant his permit. The chief shall keep a permanent record of all permits issued. 
Sec. 9-6-5. - Fees. 
The permit fee which shall be charged by the city for such permit shall be as fixed from time to time by the mayor and council, provided that no fee shall be charged to farmers engaged in direct sales of produce or other farm products produced on their own farms. 
Sec. 9-6-6. - Exhibition of permits. 
(a)  Itinerant merchants. The permit issued hereunder for itinerant merchants and dealers and transient merchants shall be posted conspicuously in the place of business named therein. In the event that such person or persons applying for said permit shall desire to do business in more than one place within the city, separate permits may be issued for each place of business, and shall be posted conspicuously in each place of business. 
(b)  Peddlers. Peddlers, solicitors and canvasses are required to exhibit their permit at the request of any citizen. 
Sec. 9-6-7. - Transfer. 
No permit or badge issued under the provisions of this article shall be used or worn at any time by any person other than the one to whom it was issued. 
Sec. 9-6-8. - Use of streets. 
It shall be unlawful for any person issued a permit under the provisions of this article to conduct any business transaction in any area which is within 35 feet of any street, alley, road or highway. 
Sec. 9-6-9. - Revocation of permits. 
Permits issued under the provisions of this article may be revoked for any of the following causes: 
(1)  Fraud, misrepresentation or false statement contained in the application for permit; 
(2)  Fraud, misrepresentation or false statement made in the course of carrying on any business contemplated hereunder; 
(3)  Any violation of this article; 
(4)  Conviction of any crime or misdemeanor involving moral turpitude; or 
(5)  Conducting any business contemplated hereunder, in an unlawful manner or in such a manner as to constitute a breach of the peace or to constitute a menace to the health, safety, or general welfare of the public. 
Sec. 9-6-10. - Regulation of hours. 
All activity regulated hereunder shall occur only between the hours of 9:00 a.m. and 6:00 p.m. Eastern Standard Time or between the hours of 9:00 a.m. and 7:00 p.m. Eastern Daylight Time. 
Sec. 9-6-11. - Door-to-door activities. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person holding a valid permit under this article to make a call at any residence, where the owner or any person residing therein has posted a sign reading as follows: NO SOLICITORS, without the express prior permission of the occupant. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for any person holding a valid permit under this article to fail to immediately leave the premises of any person when requested to do so. 
Sec. 9-6-12. - Peddling ice cream, other refreshments. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to peddle, sell, or offer to sell at retail upon the streets, alleys, lanes, roads or highways within the city from any automobile, truck, pushcart or other vehicle within the city, any ice cream, ice cream product in modified form, or any other cold or frozen food, refreshment, soft drink or delicacy. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for any person to use any sort of musical instrument upon the streets, roads, lanes, alleys and highways within the limits of the city, for the purpose of advertising and soliciting and attracting sales and customers with respect to such articles, foods, and refreshments, whether the same is attached to or used in connection with a truck or vehicle which is used for making such sales. 
Sec. 9-6-13. - Penalty. 
Any person violating any of the provisions of this article shall upon conviction thereof be punished by a fine or imprisonment or both, to be set by the city's municipal court judge presiding at the time. 
(Ord. No. 08-11, § 31, 3-17-2008) 
Secs. 9-6-14—9-6-20. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE B. - CHARITABLE SOLICITATIONS 

Sec. 9-6-21. - Definitions. 
Whenever used in this article unless a different meaning clearly appears from the context: 
(1)  Solicit and solicitation shall mean the request directly or indirectly of money, credit, property, financial assistance or other things of value on the plea or representation that such money, credit, property, financial assistance or other thing of value will be used for a charitable or religious purpose as those purposes are defined in this article. These words shall also mean and include the following methods of securing money, credit, property, financial assistance or other things of value on the plea or representation that it will be used for a charitable or religious purpose as herein defined: 
a.  Any oral or written request; 
b.  The distribution, circulation, mailing, posting or publishing of any handbill, written advertisement, or publication; 
c.  The making of any announcement to the press, over the radio, by telephone or telegraph concerning an appeal, assemblage, athletic or sports event, bazaar, benefit, campaign, contest, dance, drive, entertainment, exhibition, exposition, party, performance, picnic, sale or social gathering, which the public is requested to patronize or to which the public is requested to make a contribution for any charitable or religious purpose connected therewith; or 
d.  The sale of, offer or attempt to sell, any advertisement, advertising space, book, card, chance, coupon, device, magazine, membership, merchandise, subscription, ticket or other thing in connection with which any appeal is made for any charitable or religious purpose, or where the name of any charitable or religious person is used or referred to in any such appeal as an inducement or reason for making any such sale, or when or where in connection with any such sale, any statement is made that the whole or any part of the proceeds from any such sale, or any part of the proceeds from any such sale, will go or be donated to any charitable or religious purpose. 
"Solicitation" as defined herein shall be deemed completed when made, whether or not the person making the same receives any contribution or makes any sale referred to in this section. 
(2)  Charitable shall mean and include the words patriotic, philanthropic, social service, welfare, benevolent, educational, civic, or fraternal, either actual or purported. 
(3)  Religious and religion as used herein shall not mean and include the word "charitable" as herein defined, but shall be given their commonly accepted definitions. 
(4)  Contributions shall mean the promise or grant of any money or property of any kind or value. 
(5)  Person shall mean any individual, firm, co-partnership, corporation, company, association, or joint stock, organization or league, church, religious sect, religious denomination, society, and includes any trustee, receiver, assignee, agent, or other similar representative thereof. 
(6)  Promoter shall mean any person who promotes, manages, supervises, organizes, or attempts to promote, manage, supervise, or organize a campaign or solicitations. 
(Code 1959, § 13-5) 
Sec. 9-6-22. - Solicitations permit; required. 
No person shall solicit contributions within the city without a permit from the police department authorizing such solicitation; provided, however, that the provisions of this section shall not apply to any established persons organized and operating exclusively for religious or charitable purposes and not operated for the pecuniary profit of any person if the solicitations by such established person are conducted among the members thereof by other members or officers thereof, voluntarily and without remuneration for the making of such solicitations, or if the solicitations are in the form of collections or contributions at the regular assemblies or services of any such established person. 
Sec. 9-6-23. - Same; application. 
An application for a permit to solicit shall be made to the police department upon forms provided by the city. The application herein required shall contain the following information, or in lieu thereof, a detailed statement of the reason or reasons why such information cannot be furnished: 
(1)  The name and address or headquarters of the person applying; 
(2)  The purpose of the solicitation; 
(3)  The name and address of the person or persons who will be in direct charge of conducting the solicitation and the names of all promoters connected or to be connected with the proposed solicitations; 
(4)  An outline of the method or methods to be used in conducting the solicitations; 
(5)  The time when such solicitations shall be made, giving the preferred dates for the beginning and ending of such solicitation; 
(6)  The amount of any wages, fees, commissions, expenses or emoluments to be expended or paid to any person in connection with such solicitations, and the names and addresses of all such persons; 
(7)  A full statement of the character and extent of the charitable work being done by the applicant within the city; and 
(8)  Such other information as may be reasonably necessary and required by the police department in order for the department to determine the kind and character of the proposed solicitation and whether such solicitation is in the interest of, and not inimical to, the public welfare. 
Sec. 9-6-24. - Same; investigation of application. 
The police department shall examine all applications filed under this article and shall make, or cause to be made, such further investigations as deemed necessary to perform the duties hereunder. Upon request by the department any applicant shall make available for inspection by the department, or any person designated by the department, all of the applicant's books, records and papers at any reasonable time. 
Sec. 9-6-25. - Same; standards for issuance. 
The police department shall issue the permit herein provided for provided the following facts are found to exist: 
(1)  That all of the statements made in the application are true; 
(2)  That the applicant has a good character and reputation for honesty and integrity, or if the applicant is not an individual, that every person responsible for such organization is of good character and has a reputation for honesty and integrity; 
(3)  That the control and supervision of the solicitation will be under responsible and reliable persons; 
(4)  That the applicant has not engaged in any fraudulent transaction or enterprise; and 
(5)  That the solicitation is promoted solely by a desire to finance the charitable cause described in the application and will not be conducted primarily for private profit. 
Sec. 9-6-26. - Use of fictitious name. 
No person shall directly or indirectly solicit contributions for any purpose by misrepresentation of his name, occupation, financial condition, social condition or residence, and no person shall make or perpetrate any other misstatement, deception or fraud in connection with any solicitation of any contribution for any purpose in the city, or in any application or report filed under this article. 
(Code 1959, § 13-10) 
ARTICLE C. - MOBILE FOOD VENDORS 

Sec. 9-6-27. - Definitions. 
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meaning ascribed to them in this section, except when the context clearly indicates another meaning: 
Base of operation means any permitted location in which food is kept, handled, prepared, packaged, stored or placed in containers for subsequent transport, sale or service elsewhere. 
Director means the Director of the Planning, Building and Zoning Department of the City of Forest Park, including his or her designee. In the absence of the employment by the city of a director of the planning, building and zoning department, the term shall mean the individual designated by the city to oversee the enforcement of this article. 
Ice cream truck means a motor vehicle primarily carrying ice cream, popsicles, ice sherbets, or other frozen desserts of any kind for the purpose of retail sale on the streets of the city. 
Mobile food truck means a retail food establishment that reports to and operates from a base of operation and is readily moveable, is a motorized wheeled vehicle, or a towed wheeled vehicle designed and equipped to serve food. 
Mobile food vendor unit means an ice cream truck, a mobile food truck or a pushcart. 
Person means any individual, firm, partnership, association, corporation, company, organization or any other entity of any kind. 
Pushcart means a non-self-propelled vehicle limited to serving commissary prepared or prepackaged food and non-potentially hazardous food, unless the equipment is commercially designed and approved to handle food preparation and service. Pushcarts shall not be required to comply with mobile vehicular safety requirements. 
Vendor permit means a permit issued under this article for the operation of a mobile food vendor unit. 
Vendor permit fee means the monetary charge required to be paid pursuant to this article for the issuance of a vendor permit. 
(Ord. No. 16-14, § 1 (Exh. A), 9-19-2016) 
Sec. 9-6-28. - Permit requirement. 
(a)  In general. No person shall operate a mobile food vendor unit without first obtaining the proper licenses and/or permits from the State of Georgia, Clayton County and the city. The operator of any mobile food vendor unit shall comply at all times with the provisions of this article and all other applicable local, state and federal laws, rules and regulations. 
(b)  Specific requirements. Any person intending to operate a mobile food vendor unit within the municipal limits of the city, prior to commencing such operation, shall obtain: 
(1)  All permits or licenses as may be required by the State of Georgia, including the Department of Public Health, and Clayton County, including the Clayton County Health Department;
