No business license shall be issued to a used motor vehicle dealer unless the applicant presents proof of a current state license to operate as a used car dealer under O.C.G.A., Title 43, Chapter 47. No person holding a state license as a used motor vehicle dismantler, rebuilder or salvage dealer, (O.C.G.A., Title 43, Chapter 48) shall be allowed to operate in the City as a used motor vehicle dealer. Responsibility for compliance with the terms of this chapter shall rest jointly on the license holder and upon any person involved in the management of said business. 
(Ord. No. 91-013, 6-17-91) 
Sec. 9-11-5. - Open storage of vehicles. 
The open storage and/or display of used motor vehicles, other than junk vehicles, is permitted by used motor vehicle dealers, provided the location of such storage or display areas meets all requirements of the city zoning ordinance. 
(Ord. No. 91-013, 6-17-91) 
Sec. 9-11-6. - Display of junk vehicles. 
Junk vehicles may not be maintained on open lots or be located upon premises of a used motor vehicle dealer so as to be readily visible from any public place or from any surrounding private property. All junk vehicles shall be completely enclosed within a building or stored behind a solid opaque fence at least eight (8) feet in height. Such fence shall meet the setback requirements of sections 8-8-36 and 8-8-78 of the city zoning ordinance. The use of webbing in chain-link fences to meet the requirements of this section is specifically prohibited. 
(Ord. No. 91-013, 6-17-91) 
Sec. 9-11-7. - Notice to remove: service. 
(a)  Whenever the director of public services, or his authorized designee, determines that a junk vehicle has been maintained in public view in violation of section 9-11-6, he shall provide notice to the owner and/or operator of the business to remove the junk vehicle from the premises or to otherwise bring the premises into compliance with the standards of section 9-11-6. Such notice shall be in writing, shall describe the offending vehicle by color and make, and shall provide five (5) days within which to comply with this chapter. 
(b)  The notice of violation shall be served by one of the following methods: 
(1)  Personal service. 
(2)  Certified mail, return receipt requested. 
(3)  Where service has been attempted and cannot be accomplished by either personal service or certified mail, the notice may be served by mailing a copy of the notice by first class mail, with adequate postage attached thereto, to the last known address of the owner and by posting of a copy of the notice on the business premises. 
(Ord. No. 91-013, 6-17-91) 
Sec. 9-11-8. - Failure to comply with notice. 
Upon receipt of a notice to remove a junk vehicle from licensed premises or to otherwise to come into conformance with this chapter, and upon failure of the owner or operator of those premises to so conform within the period of time stated in the notice, the director of public services or his designee, may proceed to cite the owner and/or operator of the business for violation of this chapter. Such notice of violation shall include a summons to appear in the municipal court of the city on a date certain to answer the charge of violation of the ordinance. Each and every vehicle maintained in violation of this chapter shall be considered a separate offense, and each day beyond the five (5) day notice period during which such vehicle or vehicles remain(s) on the property shall also be considered a separate offense. 
(Ord. No. 91-013, 6-17-91) 
Sec. 9-11-9. - Inspection authority. 
The director of public services, or his designee, shall have the right to enter onto premises licensed under this chapter, at reasonable times, to inspect the premises for compliance with this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 91-013, 6-17-91) 
Sec. 9-11-10. - Penalties for violation. 
Upon conviction of or the entering of a plea of guilty or nolo contendere to a citation under this chapter, the person cited shall be subject to the penalties as set out in section 1-1-8 of this Code. In addition to the criminal penalties prescribed by the preceding sentence, upon the third conviction or plea of guilty or nolo contendere within a 12 month period, the business license of the license holder shall be suspended for a period of six (6) months. A fourth conviction or plea to a similar offense within 12 months shall result in forfeiture of the business license. No new business license shall issue to a person whose license has been forfeited for the same category of business within the city for a period of 12 months. Suspension and/or forfeiture of licenses shall be accomplished through use of the procedures outlined in section 9-1-12 of this Code. 
(Ord. No. 91-013, 6-17-91) 
CHAPTER 12. - ADULT ENTERTAINMENT ESTABLISHMENTS[12] 

Footnotes: 
--- (12) --- 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 14-25, § 1, adopted Oct. 27, 2014, repealed former Ch. 12, §§ 9-12-1—9-12-15, and enacted a new Ch. 12 as set out herein. Former Ch. 12 pertained to similar subject matter and derived from Ord. No. 11-48, § 1, 12-28-2011. 

Sec. 9-12-1. - Findings; public purpose. 
The governing body of the City of Forest Park, Georgia is aware of the following evidence concerning the adverse secondary effects of adult entertainment on the community presented in hearings and in reports made available to the mayor and city council for the City of Forest Park, Georgia (hereinafter the "governing body"): 
(a)  Findings incorporated in the cases of City of Renton v. Playtime Theatres, Inc., 475 U.S. 41 (1986), Young v. American Mini Theatres, 426 U.S. 50 (1976), and Barnes v. Glen Theatre, Inc., 501 U.S. 560 (1991), and on studies in other communities including, but not limited to, Rome, Georgia; Adams County, Colorado; Ellicottville, New York; Newport News, Virginia; St. Croix County, Wisconsin; Centralia, Washington; Whittier, California; Denver, Colorado; Dallas, Texas and environs; Fort Worth and Dallas, Texas; Jewett, New York; El Paso, Texas; Palm Beach, Florida; American Center for Law and Justice; Oconee County, Georgia; City of Lilburn, Georgia; City of Roswell, Georgia; City of Sandy Springs, Georgia; City of Carrollton, Georgia; Manatee County, Florida; St. Paul, Minnesota; Troup County, Georgia; Gwinnett County, Georgia; Phoenix, Arizona; Minneapolis, Minnesota; Houston, Texas; Indianapolis, Indiana; Amarillo, Texas; Garden Grove, California; Los Angeles, California; Austin, Texas; Seattle, Washington; Oklahoma City, Oklahoma; Cleveland, Ohio; and Beaumont, Texas, and numerous other studies, articles, and court decisions, all of which have been presented to the mayor and city council in bound form and/or on diskette and incorporated into the record of the proceedings before the governing body of the City of Forest Park, Georgia; and 
(b)  Certain affidavits and other written evidence of criminal activity, improper conduct, and other adverse secondary effects in adult entertainment establishments in the past which have been produced to the mayor and city council through litigation involving the adult clubs, and copies of which have been presented to the mayor and city council and incorporated into the record of proceedings before the governing body of the City of Forest Park, Georgia; and 
(c)  A presentation and accompanying report given to the mayor and city council by Dr. Richard McCleary of the University of California at Irvine detailing the criminal activities and other adverse secondary effects of adult entertainment businesses, explaining the criminological theories supporting ties between adult entertainment and criminal activity, and documenting evidence of the adverse secondary criminological effects of adult entertainment establishments, incorporated into the record of proceedings before the governing body of the City of Forest Park, Georgia; and 
(d)  A presentation and accompanying report given to the mayor and city council by Ms. Connie Cooper detailing the adverse secondary effects of adult entertainment establishments in the areas of planning and development and property values, incorporated into the record of proceedings before the governing body of the City of Forest Park, Georgia; and 
(e)  A presentation and report given to the mayor and city council by private investigator Guy Watkins of BCI, Inc. detailing the findings and observations of private investigators who recently visited adult entertainment establishments in the nearby City of Sandy Springs, Georgia, finding evidence of criminal activity, including crimes of assault and prostitution, which has been incorporated into the record of proceedings of the City of Forest Park, Georgia; and 
(f)  The transcript of proceedings before the city council of the City of Sandy Springs, Georgia of December 20, 2007 and December 27, 2007 which documents extensive evidence of adverse secondary effects of adult entertainment, a copy of which has been presented to the mayor and city council, and incorporated into the record of proceedings of the City of Forest Park, Georgia; and 
(g)  The following special reports relating to the secondary effects of adult entertainment establishments on real property values: September 2004 Survey of Appraisers, Fort Worth and Dallas, Texas; May 2008, Survey of Appraisers, Palm Beach County, Florida; and June 2008 Survey of Texas Appraisers, Texas City Attorneys Association incorporated into the record of the proceedings before the governing body of the City of Forest Park, Georgia; and 
(h)  Certain documents and information consisting of thirty-nine (39) pages relating to the guilty plea and plea agreement in the criminal prosecution case of former Fulton County Police Lieutenant Mark Timothy Lance incorporated into the record of the proceedings before the governing body of the City of Forest Park, Georgia; and 
(i)  A report by BCI private investigators relating to adult bookstores in Sandy Springs, Georgia incorporated into the record of the proceedings before the governing body of the City of Forest Park, Georgia; and 
(j)  A report by BCI private investigators relating to adult cabarets in Sandy Springs, Georgia incorporated into the record of the proceedings before the governing body of the City of Forest Park, Georgia; and 
(k)  Affidavits and reports of BCI private investigators relating to and reporting inappropriate and criminal activity taking place within adult entertainment establishments; and 
(l)  Police records of prosecutions of criminal charges relating to activities taking place within adult entertainment establishments; and 
(m)  The affidavits of Police Chief Dwayne Hobbs and Captain Mark Harris in connection with litigation in the City of Forest Park, Georgia over adult entertainment establishments incorporated into the record of the proceedings before the governing body of the City of Forest Park, Georgia; and 
(n)  The opinion of the Eleventh Circuit Court of Appeals in Flanigan's Enterprises, Inc. of Georgia v. Fulton County, Ga., 596 F.3d 1265 (11th Cir. 2010), which discusses extensive evidence of negative secondary effects of adult entertainment establishments in Fulton County, Georgia incorporated into the record of the proceedings before the governing body of the City of Forest Park, Georgia; and 
(o)  Three (3) articles authored or co-authored by Dr. Richard McCleary, Professor at the University of California, Irvine, entitled "Rural Hotspots: The Case of Adult Business" (2008); "Do Peep Shows 'Cause' Crime? A Response to Linz, Paul, and Yao" (2006); and "Do 'Off-Site' Adult Businesses Have Secondary Effects? Legal Doctrine, Social Theory, and Empirical Evidence" (2009), incorporated into the record of the proceedings before the Governing Body of the City of Forest Park, Georgia; and 
(p)  Other evidence presented at various hearings and meetings of the mayor and city council relating to adverse secondary effects of adult entertainment, which has been recorded and incorporated into the record of proceedings of the City of Forest Park, Georgia, including past meetings of the governing body. 
Based upon all of this evidence, the governing body of the City of Forest Park, Georgia finds: 
(1)  Sexually oriented businesses, also known as adult entertainment establishments, lend themselves to ancillary unlawful and unhealthy activities that are presently uncontrolled or inadequately controlled by the operators of the establishments. The commercial exploitation of human sexuality, in all forms in which such exploitation may be manifested has a deleterious effect on the community where it takes place as heretofore mentioned. Sexually oriented businesses cause an increase in criminal behavior in nearby areas, including, but not limited to, disorderly conduct, prostitution, solicitation, drug trafficking, drug use, assaults and batteries, and corruption of public officials. 
(2)  Sexual acts, including masturbation, and oral and anal sex, occur at sexually oriented businesses. Offering or providing private or semi-private space encourages such activities, which creates unhealthy conditions. 
(3)  Adult entertainment establishments escalate and exacerbate undesirable community conditions, including, but not limited to, blight, diminished property values, increased need for law enforcement and emergency medical response resources, and increased burden on the judicial system as a result of the criminal behavior which the governing body finds such business establishments bring to a community. The secondary negative effects that are caused by such businesses are not limited to such facilities that offer live or recorded performances with human nudity or the depiction of sexual acts but other forms of sexually oriented businesses that also have a deleterious effect on nearby neighborhoods, commercial districts and on urban life in general. These other types of such businesses include, but are not limited to, adult bookstores, peep shows, massage parlors, bath houses, adult gift and novelty shops, and lingerie or nude modeling studios. 
(4)  Persons frequent certain adult theatres, adult arcades, and other sexually oriented businesses for the purpose of engaging in sex within the premises of such sexually oriented businesses. 
(5)  Communicable diseases may be spread by activities occurring in sexually oriented businesses. 
(6)  AIDS and HIV infection may be transmitted through sexual contact, intravenous drug abuse, exposure to infected blood and blood components. 
(7)  According to the best scientific evidence, AIDS and HIV infection, as well as syphilis and gonorrhea, are principally transmitted by sexual acts. 
(8)  Sanitary conditions in some sexually oriented businesses are unhealthy, in part, because the activities conducted there are unhealthy, and, in part, because of the unregulated nature of the activities and the failure of the owners and the operators of the facilities to self-regulate those activities and maintain those facilities. 
(9)  Numerous studies and reports have determined that semen is found in some areas of some sexually oriented businesses. 
(10)  The findings noted in subsections (1) through (9) raise substantial governmental concerns. 
(11)  Sexually oriented businesses have operational characteristics which should be reasonably regulated in order to protect those substantial governmental concerns. 
(12)  Removal of doors on adult booths and requiring sufficient lighting on premises with adult booths advances a substantial governmental interest in curbing the illegal and unsanitary sexual activity occurring in adult entertainment establishments as defined herein. 
(13)  Requiring licensees of sexually oriented businesses to keep information regarding current employees and certain past employees will help reduce the incidence of certain types of criminal behavior by facilitating the identification of potential witnesses or suspects and by preventing minors from working in such establishments. 
(14)  The disclosure of certain information by those persons ultimately responsible for the day-to-day operation and maintenance of the sexually oriented business, where such information is substantially related to the significant governmental interest in the operation of such uses, will aid in preventing the spread of sexually transmitted diseases and other secondary negative effects as described herein. 
(15)  It is desirable in the prevention of the spread of communicable diseases to obtain a limited amount of information regarding employees who may engage in the conduct which this chapter is designed to prevent or who are likely to be witnesses to such activity. 
(16)  The fact that an applicant for an adult entertainment license has been convicted of a sexually related crime leads to the rational assumption that the applicant may engage in that conduct in contravention of this chapter. 
(17)  The barring of such individuals from the management of adult entertainment establishments for a period of years serves as a deterrent to and prevents conduct which leads to the transmission of sexually transmitted diseases. 
(18)  The general welfare, health, morals and safety of the citizens of the City of Forest Park, Georgia will be promoted by the enactment of this chapter. 
Based on the experiences of other counties and municipalities as described above, which experiences are found to be relevant to the problems faced by the City of Forest Park, Georgia; and based on the documentary and oral evidence presented at the public hearings before the governing body of the City of Forest Park, Georgia held prior to the adoption of this chapter and in particular on July 21, 2009; and based on the evidence and statements of persons who have appeared before members of the governing body on other occasions, and on other documentary evidence submitted to the governing body, the governing body for the City of Forest Park, Georgia takes note of the well-known and self-evident conditions and secondary effects attendant to the commercial exploitation of human sexuality, which do not vary greatly among the various communities within our country. 
It is the finding of the governing body that public nudity (either partial or total) under certain circumstances in establishments offering live nude entertainment or "adult entertainment," begets criminal behavior and tends to create undesirable community conditions. In the same manner, establishments offering cinematographic or videographic adult entertainment have the same deleterious effects on the community. 
Among the undesirable community conditions identified in other communities with commercial nudity and cinematographic or videographic adult entertainment, are criminal activity, depression of property values and acceleration of community blight in the surrounding neighborhoods, increased allocation of and expenditure for law enforcement personnel to preserve law and order, and increased burden on the judicial system as a consequence of the criminal behavior hereinabove referenced. The governing body finds it is reasonable to believe that some or all of these undesirable community conditions will result in the City of Forest Park, Georgia, as well unless these regulations are adopted. 
Furthermore, it is the finding of the governing body that nude or semi-nude live entertainment and other forms of adult entertainment including, but not limited to, adult book stores, adult novelty shops, adult video stores, peep shows, adult theaters, and massage parlors have an adverse effect upon the quality of life in the city and surrounding communities. 
The governing body further finds that each separate adverse secondary effect of adult entertainment businesses and sexually oriented businesses constitutes a substantial government interest, that each substantial government interest includes, but is not limited to, preventing future adverse secondary effects of both pre-existing sexually oriented businesses and adult entertainment businesses in the City of Forest Park, Georgia and those that may open in the future, and the viability of each separate substantial government interest of the City of Forest Park, Georgia addressed herein does not depend upon any comparative analysis between adult entertainment businesses and non-adult entertainment businesses. 
The governing body therefore finds that it is in the best interests of the health, welfare, safety and morals of the City of Forest Park, Georgia, the community and the preservation of its businesses, neighborhoods, and of churches, schools, residential areas, public parks and children's day care facilities to prevent or reduce the adverse impacts of adult entertainment establishments. Therefore, the governing body of the City of Forest Park, Georgia finds that licensing and regulations are necessary for any adult entertainment establishment, and finds that these regulations promote the public welfare by furthering legitimate public and governmental interests, including, but not limited to, reducing criminal activity and protecting against or eliminating undesirable community conditions. The governing body further finds that such will not infringe upon the protected Constitutional rights of freedom of speech or expression. To all of these ends, this chapter is hereby adopted. 
Also based upon all of the information, studies, reports, statements, findings in court decisions, and testimony referenced above, as well as the well known and self evident conditions and secondary effects caused by the commercial exploitation of commercial nudity combined with the sale, dispensing and consumption of alcoholic beverages, the governing body also finds and concludes that the sale, dispensing, or consumption of alcoholic beverages of any kind in an adult entertainment establishment as defined herein tends to independently create, aggravate, exacerbate, and add to all of those negative secondary effects set forth in this section. The purpose and intent of this chapter is to address and forestall those negative secondary effects in the City of Forest Park, Georgia within the permissible limits and parameters of the Georgia and United States constitutions. 
Simultaneously upon restatement of this chapter, the city has executed a settlement document by and between Jack Galardi, Red Eyed, Inc. d/b/a Crazy Horse Saloon, (hereinafter referred to as "Crazy Horse") Walleye, LLC ("Walleye"), Mia Luna, Inc. d/b/a Pink Pony South (hereinafter referred to as "Pink Pony South"), and JGP&P, LLC (hereinafter referred to as "JGP&P"), (hereinafter "Settlement Agreement") and a consent order in litigation in both the United States District Court for the Northern District of Georgia, Atlanta Division, styled as Jack Galardi, Red Eyed, Inc. d/b/a Crazy Horse Saloon, Walleye, LLC, Mia Luna, Inc. d/b/a Pink Pony South, and JGP&P, LLC v. City of Forest Park, Corine Deyton, Sparkle Adams, Maudie McCord, Linda Lord, and John Parker, individually (Civil Action File No. 1:12-CV-0531-SCJ), and in the Court of Appeals of the State of Georgia, styled as Jack Galardi, Red Eyed, Inc., dba Crazy Horse Saloon, and Walleye, LLC; Mia Luna, Inc., dba Pink Pony South and JGP&P, LLC, v. City of Forest Park, Georgia (Appeal No. A15A0023) (hereinafter the "Court Order") which Settlement Agreement and Court Order are elsewhere referred to in this regulation. 
(Ord. No. 14-25, § 1, 10-27-2014) 
Sec. 9-12-2. - Definitions. 
Except as specifically defined herein, all words used in this chapter shall be as defined in the most recent edition of the New Illustrated Book of Development Definitions (Rutgers). Words not defined herein or in the foregoing book shall be construed to have the meaning given by common and ordinary use, and shall be interpreted within the context of the sentence and section in which they occur. 
Adult bookstore means any commercial establishment in which either: (1) more than fifty (50) square feet of floor space is used for the display or offer for sale or rental of any book or publication, film, or other medium which depicts sexually explicit nudity or sexual conduct by its emphasis on matter depicting, describing or relating to specified sexual activities or specified anatomical areas, and/or (2) twenty-five (25) percent or more of its display area is used for the display or offer for sale or rental of those media or materials. 
Adult entertainer means any person employed by an adult entertainment establishment who performs live in a manner so as to feature, depict, show, or emphasize their genitals, pubic region, anus, female breasts, or "specified anatomical areas," as defined herein. For purposes of this chapter, adult entertainers include employees as well as independent contractors, and persons who are not compensated or paid. Adult entertainers may appear in a state of nudity or semi-nudity as applicable provided said nude or semi-nude appearances comply with the provisions of this chapter. 
Adult entertainment means entertainment that is characterized by an emphasis on the depiction or the featuring of "specified anatomical areas." Adult entertainment includes trade, books, magazines or other periodicals, videotapes, movies, photographs, or films, as well as live performances, that predominantly feature, simulate, or depict performances by persons that are distinguished or characterized by an emphasis on "specified sexual activities" as defined herein, and/or performances that feature, depict, or emphasize performers' genitals, pubic region, anus, female breasts below the top of the point immediately above the areola, or "specified anatomical areas." 
Adult entertainment establishment shall be defined to include the following types of businesses: 
(1)  Any commercial establishment which provides live entertainment where such performances are distinguished or characterized by a simulated depiction of "specified sexual activities" as defined herein, which performances are considered "live adult entertainment" as defined below; 
(2)  Any commercial establishment in which persons perform live in a manner so as to feature, depict, or emphasize their genitals, pubic region, anus, female breasts, or "specified anatomical areas" as defined herein, which performances are considered "live adult entertainment" as defined below; 
(3)  Any commercial establishment which holds, promotes, sponsors or allows any contest, promotion, special night, event or any other activity where live patrons of the establishment are encouraged or allowed to engage in any of the conduct described in subsections (1) and/or (2) above; 
(4)  Any commercial establishment having a substantial or significant portion of its stock in trade, books, magazines or other periodicals, videotapes or movies or other reproductions, whether for sale or rent which are distinguished or characterized by their emphasis on matter depicting, describing, or relating to "specified sexual activities" as defined herein or "specified anatomical areas" as defined herein or having a segment or section comprising more than fifty (50) square feet of its total floor space, devoted to the sale or display of such material, or which utilizes twenty-five (25) percent or more of its display area for the display or offer for sale or rental such media or materials, or which derives more than five (5) percent of its net sales from the sale or rental of such material; 
(5)  Any commercial establishment utilizing an enclosed building with a capacity of fifty (50) or more persons used for cinematographic or videographic presentation of material distinguished by or characterized by an emphasis on matter depicting, describing, or relating to "specified sexual activities" or "specified anatomical areas," as defined herein, for observation by patrons therein; 
(6)  Any adult motion picture theater, adult motion picture arcade, adult mini-motion picture theater, adult bookstore, adult video store, adult hotel, or adult motel, as defined herein; 
(7)  The definition of "adult entertainment establishment" shall not include traditional or mainstream theater, which means a theater, movie theater, concert hall, museum, educational institution, bar, restaurant, dinner theater, karaoke bars or restaurants, or similar establishment which regularly features live or other performances or showings which are not distinguished or characterized by an emphasis on the depiction, display, or description or the featuring of specified anatomical areas or specified sexual activities in that the depiction, display, description or featuring is incidental to the primary purpose of any performance. For purposes of this subsection, such performances and showings are regularly featured when they comprise at least eighty (80) percent of all annual performances or showings. 
Adult hotel or motel means a hotel or motel which: 
(1)  Makes available to patrons any material distinguished or characterized by an emphasis on matter depicting, describing or relating to specified sexual activities or specified anatomical areas, and has a sign visible from any public right-of-way advertising that such material is available; or 
(2)  Regularly offers a room or rooms for rent for any period of time that is less than twelve (12) consecutive hours; or 
(3)  Regularly allows a tenant or occupant of a room or rooms to sub-rent the room or rooms for a period of time that is less than twelve (12) consecutive hours. 
Adult mini-motion picture theater means an enclosed building with a capacity for fewer than fifty (50) persons used for presenting material distinguished or characterized by an emphasis on matter depicting or relating to specified sexual activities or specified anatomical areas for observation by patrons therein. 
Adult motion picture arcade means any place to which the public is permitted to be invited wherein paper currency, coin- or slug-operated or electronically, electrically or mechanically controlled still or motion picture machines, projectors or other image-producing devices are maintained to show images to five (5) or fewer persons per machine at any one (1) time and where the images so displayed are distinguished or characterized by an emphasis on depicting or describing specified sexual activities or specified anatomical areas. 
Adult motion picture theater means an enclosed building with a capacity of fifty (50) or more persons, used for presenting material distinguished or characterized by an emphasis on matter depicting, describing or relating to specified sexual activities or specified anatomical areas for observation by patrons therein. 
Adult video store means any establishment having a substantial or significant portion of its stock in trade, video tapes or movies or other reproductions, whether for sale or rent, which are distinguished or characterized by an emphasis on matter depicting, describing or relating to specified sexual activities or specified anatomical areas, or an establishment with a segment or section, comprising more than ten (10) square feet of its total floor space or wall space, or floor and wall space combined, devoted to the sale or display of such material. 
Application fee shall mean the fee required to accompany an application for a permit to work or perform services as an employee of an adult entertainment establishment, and/or the fee required to accompany an application to obtain a license to operate an adult entertainment establishment under this chapter. The application fee shall vary depending on the permit or license being sought. This term shall not include the annual regulatory fee for such establishments as established by the city's governing body. All application fees shall be non-refundable and payable in cash or certified check in an amount established by the city's governing body. The amounts of the application fees are set forth on the fee schedule maintained by the city and available upon request from the chief of police. 
Chief of police shall mean and include the duly appointed and serving chief of police for the City of Forest Park, Georgia, or his designee, i.e., that person designated by the chief of police to act on his behalf and under his supervision in connection with this chapter. 
Children's day care facility shall be defined as a structure or portion of a structure wherein is provided care and supervision of children away from their place of residence for less than twenty-four (24) hours per day on a regular basis for compensation. For the purpose of this chapter the term "children's day care facility" shall include, but not be limited to, the terms "nursery school," "early learning center," "pre-kindergarten," "private kindergarten," "play school," or "pre-school." 
City shall mean the City of Forest Park, Georgia. 
Convicted shall mean and include an adjudication of guilt or a plea of guilty or a plea of nolo contendere or the forfeiture of a bond when charged with a crime or an ordinance violation in a court of competent jurisdiction. 
Employee or adult entertainment establishment employee shall mean any person who performs any service on the premises of an adult entertainment establishment on a full-time, part-time, or contract basis, whether or not the person is an employee, an independent contractor, or any other kind of agent, and whether or not said person performs such services only for tips or is paid a salary, wage, or any other type of compensation by the adult entertainment establishment. The term "employee" or "adult entertainment establishment employee" shall include, but is not limited to, adult entertainers, wait staff, clerks, ushers, parking attendants, security personnel, cooks and dishwashers. The term "employee" or "adult entertainment establishment employee" shall not include a person who is temporarily on the premises for the sole purpose of repair or maintenance of the premises, any building or equipment on the premises, or for the delivery of any goods or merchandise to the premises. 
Georgia Crime Information Center is an operating division within the Georgia Bureau of Investigation that serves as the chief provider of criminal justice information services in Georgia by maintaining an electronic database of crime data. The "GCIC" provides access to all officials and agencies of the criminal justice system within the State of Georgia to computerized criminal history databases twenty-four (24) hours a day, seven (7) days a week. 
Governing body shall mean the mayor and city council for the City of Forest Park, Georgia. 
Human female or female shall mean any individual human possessing female breasts and/or female genitals, whether said individual was born with these anatomical areas or acquired them via an elective medical procedure. 
Human male or male shall mean any individual human possessing male genitals, whether said individual was born with said genitals or acquired said genitals via an elective medical procedure. 
License shall mean a license issued by the city under this chapter to a licensee that authorizes the licensee to operate, engage in, or carry on the business of an adult entertainment establishment as defined in this chapter. The terms of these licenses is as described in § 9-12-3 below. 
Licensee shall mean the holder of an adult entertainment establishment license issued under this chapter. The licensee must be an owner of the adult entertainment establishment. 
Live adult entertainment shall mean adult entertainment performed live by an adult entertainer at an adult entertainment establishment in which the "specified anatomical areas" of the adult entertainer are displayed or depicted. 
National Crime Information Center is an electronic database of crime data that can be accessed and utilized by virtually every criminal justice agency nationwide. The National Crime Information Center ("NCIC") is operated under a shared management concept between the FBI and federal, state, local, and tribal criminal justice users. The NCIC may be searched by criminal justice professionals, including police officers, to locate missing persons, recover stolen property, identify sex offenders, identify fugitives, locate protective orders, identify wanted individuals, and utilize the national instant criminal background check system. Like the GCIC, the NCIC provides a computerized database that is accessible twenty-four (24) hours a day, seven (7) days a week. 
Nude shall mean, in the case of a human female, the showing of female genitals, pubic area, anus, and the female breast with a completely exposed nipple or areola. In the case of a human male, "nude" shall mean the showing of male genitals, pubic area, and anus. An individual shall be considered nude if all of the above-mentioned anatomical areas are exposed with no covering whatsoever. 
Operator means the manager or other person principally in charge of an adult entertainment establishment. 
Owner means any individual or entity holding more than a twenty (20) percent interest in an adult entertainment establishment. 
Permit shall mean an annual permit issued by the city which authorizes a person to work or perform services as an employee of an adult entertainment establishment as those terms are defined in this chapter. Operators and employees of adult entertainment establishments, including adult entertainers, shall be required to obtain one (1) of two (2) different categories of permits available from the city: one (1) for operators and adult entertainers, and one (1) for all other employees of adult entertainment establishments. All employees of an adult entertainment establishment, including adult entertainers, as well as the operator of said adult entertainment establishment, shall apply for their permits before they can begin working or performing services for an adult entertainment establishment. 
Permit fee shall mean the annual fee that must be submitted by an operator or employee of an adult entertainment establishment, including adult entertainers, to the city before that operator or employee may acquire his or her permit and begin working or performing services for an adult entertainment establishment. All permit fees shall be non-refundable and are payable in cash or certified check in an amount determined by the city's governing body. The amount of these permit fees vary depending on an employee's position of employment with an adult entertainment establishment. There are two (2) categories of permit fees for employees of adult entertainment establishments: one (1) fee for operators and adult entertainers, and a second fee for other employees of an adult entertainment establishment. The amount of these permit fees are set forth on the fee schedule maintained by the city and available upon request from the chief of police. 
Premises or licensed premises shall mean the property or premises where an adult entertainment establishment licensed under this chapter operates, conducts, or carries on its business, and shall include the entire tract or parcel of land where such business is conducted. 
Regulatory fee shall be the annual regulatory fee to be paid by each adult entertainment establishment when it is issued an adult entertainment establishment license or a renewal of an adult entertainment establishment license by the city. 
Semi-nude shall mean, in the case of a human female, showing any portion of the female breast below the top of the areola and/or displaying the pubic area, anus, buttocks, or female genitals with a covering that is less than fully opaque. In the case of a human male, "semi-nude" shall mean showing, with a covering that is less than fully opaque, the male genitals, pubic area, buttocks, and/or anus. Examples of attire that, when worn, would categorize an individual as "semi-nude" include, but are not limited to, pasties, g-strings, dental floss, and thongs. In the event an individual displays all of the above-described anatomical areas with no covering whatsoever, the individual shall be considered "nude." 
Specified sexual activities shall be defined to mean and include any of the following: 
(1)  Actual or simulated vaginal intercourse, oral vaginal copulation, anal intercourse, oral anal copulation, bestiality, direct physical stimulation of genitals, flagellation or torture in the context of a sexual relationship, or the use of excretory functions in the context of a sexual relationship and any of the following sexually oriented acts or conduct: anilingus, buggery, coprophagy, coprophilia, cunnilingus, fellatio, necrophilia, pederasty, pedophilia, piquerism, zooerasty; 
(2)  Use of human or animal ejaculation, sodomy, oral copulation, coitus or masturbation; 
(3)  Fondling or other erotic touching of human genitals, pubic region, buttocks or female breast; 
(4)  Masochism, erotic or sexually oriented torture, beating or the infliction of pain; or 
(5)  Erotic or lewd touching, fondling or other sexual contact with an animal by a human being. 
Specified anatomical areas shall include human genitals, pubic area, buttocks, anus, and/or the female breast below a point immediately above the top of the areola whether or not such areas are completely exposed, partially covered, or completely covered. 
(Ord. No. 14-25, § 1, 10-27-2014) 
Sec. 9-12-3. - License required. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person, association, partnership, or corporation to operate, engage in, conduct, or carry on, in or upon any premises within the corporate city limits of the City of Forest Park, Georgia any adult entertainment establishment as defined in this chapter without first procuring an annual license to do so (except as provided in section 9-12-11(b) when the chief of police or his designee fails to approve or deny an application for an adult entertainment license within the ninety-day period provided for therein). In no event shall any license issued to an adult entertainment establishment under this chapter be in force or effect after midnight of December 31 of the year in which it is issued. The issuance of such an annual license shall not be deemed to authorize, condone or make legal any activity thereunder if the same is deemed illegal or unlawful under the laws of the State of Georgia or the United States. 
(b)  There shall be an annual regulatory fee (as defined above in section 9-12-2) for each adult entertainment establishment licensed within the city in an amount established by the city's governing body. The annual regulatory fee must be paid to the city within ten (10) days after the chief of police or his designee approves the application for an adult entertainment establishment license or a renewal thereof. This annual regulatory fee is in addition to and separate from any application fee that must be submitted pursuant to section 9-12-5 below. No adult entertainment establishment license or renewal thereof shall be issued until the most recent annual regulatory fee has been paid. All licenses granted hereunder shall expire at midnight on December 31 of the year in which they are issued. Licensees who desire to renew their license shall file an application with the chief of police or his designee on the form provided for renewal of the license for the ensuing year. Applications for renewal must be filed before November 30 of each year. Any applicant filing a renewal application which is received by the city after November 30 shall pay, in addition to said annual regulatory fee, a late charge of twenty (20) percent, and shall cease conducting business on the premises effective midnight December 31 until a renewal license is duly issued under this chapter. If a license renewal application is received after January 1, such application shall be treated as an initial application and the applicant shall be required to comply with all rules and regulations for the granting of licenses as if no previous license had been held, and the applicant shall cease conducting business on the premises until a license is duly issued under this chapter. If a license application is received after January 1, investigative and administrative costs as set forth in this chapter will be assessed. All licenses granted hereunder shall be for the calendar year and the full annual regulatory fee must be paid for a license renewal application filed prior to July 1 of the license year. One-half (½) of a full annual regulatory fee shall be paid for a license renewal application filed after July 1 of the license year. Any person renewing any license issued hereunder who shall pay the annual regulatory fee, or any portion thereof, after January 1, shall, in addition to said annual regulatory fee and late charges, pay simple interest on the delinquent balance at the annual rate then charged by the Internal Revenue Service of the United States on unpaid federal income taxes. 
(c)  Except as may be allowed by virtue of the settlement agreement and/or court order, licenses and permits issued under this chapter shall not be transferable, except for a license or ownership interest under the following circumstances: in case of the death of an owner or a licensee as defined herein, the license pertaining to the owner's or licensee's adult entertainment establishment shall remain in force and effect for a period of up to ninety (90) days in order to allow the beneficiary (or beneficiaries) who will inherit the ownership interest or license an opportunity to apply for and qualify to hold the interest or license under this chapter. In order to qualify to hold said interest or license, the beneficiary (or beneficiaries) shall make application to the city within the ninety-day period as if he or she were applying for a new ownership interest or license under this chapter. If a completed application is filed within the ninety-day period, then the existing license shall remain in effect for an additional period of up to ninety (90) days following the date of filing in order to allow the chief of police to grant or deny the application under this chapter. If the chief of police grants the application, or if the chief of police fails to approve or deny the same within the ninety-day period provided for in this chapter, then the beneficiary applicant(s) shall be deemed the new owner(s) of the interest or license, which shall be considered transferred without any interruption of ownership interest which may have existed from the original approval of same, said interest or license being thereafter subject to all of the terms and conditions of this chapter. If the beneficiary fails to file a completed application under this subsection within the thirty-day period, or if the application is denied (and if appealed, the denial is upheld on appeal), then the ownership interest or license shall terminate at midnight on the thirtieth day or at midnight on the day that a final judgment upholding the appeal is entered, and the adult entertainment establishment shall close its business on that day; provided, however, that nothing herein shall be construed to allow or permit any license to remain in force and effect beyond midnight on December 31 of the year in which the death occurs, unless necessary to allow for one (1) or both of the two (2) thirty-day periods provided for in this subsection. If an appeal of a denial might remain pending on December 31 of the year in which it is filed, then in such an event, the beneficiary applicant shall file a new application for a license or approval of an ownership interest for the next succeeding calendar year under the terms of this chapter. 
(d)  All other changes in an ownership interest in an adult entertainment establishment or a license issued under this chapter must be reported in writing to the city's chief of police or his designee prior to such transfer, and the person who is intended to receive such ownership interest shall be required to make an application for a license as if he or she were applying for a new license hereunder: No licensee may change the location of the licensee's operation; any change in location shall require application for a new license under this chapter, so that such application process is completed before the relocation takes place. 
(Ord. No. 14-25, § 1, 10-27-2014) 
Sec. 9-12-4. - On-premises operator required. 
An adult entertainment establishment shall have a designated person(s) to serve as an on-premises operator. The operator(s) shall be principally in charge of the establishment and shall be located on the premises during all operating hours. Prospective operator(s) must submit an application and obtain an employment permit pursuant to section 9-12-6(b) below. If an adult entertainment establishment is found open for business without the presence of an on-premises operator, the licensee shall be cited for a violation of this chapter, and the business shall be ordered to close until an on-premises operator is present and remains present during all operating hours. If an operator of an adult entertainment establishment loses his or her permit to operate said establishment pursuant to section 9-12-6(b)(6)(b) below, the licensee or owner(s) of an adult entertainment establishment must immediately install another licensed operator to oversee said adult entertainment establishment so that there is at least one (1) operator overseeing each establishment at any given time. 
(Ord. No. 14-25, § 1, 10-27-2014) 
Sec. 9-12-5. - Application process and qualifications. 
(a)  Process. Any person, association, partnership or corporation desiring to obtain a license to operate, engage in, conduct, or carry on any adult entertainment establishment in the city shall make application for a license under this chapter to the chief of police or his designee. Such application shall be made on forms furnished by the city, shall be made in the name of the adult entertainment establishment by an applicant who is a natural person and an agent of the adult entertainment establishment and shall include the name(s) of the operator(s) as defined herein and of the owner(s) as defined herein. If the adult entertainment establishment is a corporation, then the agent for purposes of making application for a license hereunder shall be the president or chief executive officer of the corporation. If the adult entertainment establishment is a partnership, the agent for such purposes shall be a general partner. At the time of submitting such application, a nonrefundable application fee payable in cash or by certified check in an amount established by the city's governing body shall be paid to the city to defray, in part, the cost of investigation and report required by this chapter. The chief of police or his designee shall issue a receipt showing that such application fee has been paid. The application for a license does not itself authorize the operation of, engaging in, conducting or carrying on of any adult entertainment establishment. 
(b)  Contents. Each application for an adult entertainment establishment license shall contain the following information: 
(1)  The full true name and any other names used by the applicant, the operator(s) and owner(s); 
(2)  The present address and telephone number of the applicant, the operator(s) and owner(s); 
(3)  The previous addresses of the applicant, the operator(s) and the owner(s), if any, for a period of five (5) years immediately prior to the date of the application and the dates of residence at each; 
(4)  Acceptable written proof that the applicant, the operator(s) and the owner(s) are at least eighteen (18) years of age; 
(5)  The height, weight, color of eyes and hair and date and place of birth of the applicant, the operator(s) and the owner(s); 
(6)  Two (2) photographs of the applicant, the operator(s) and the owner(s) at least two (2) inches by two (2) inches taken within the last six (6) months; (and in addition, the applicant and the operator(s) must agree to be photographed by the city police department prior to issuance of the license applied for); 
(7)  The business, occupation or employment history of the applicant, the operator(s) and owner(s) for the five (5) years immediately preceding the date of application; 
(8)  The business license history of the applicant and whether such applicant, in previous operations in this or any other location under license, has had such license or permit for an adult entertainment business or similar type of business revoked or suspended, the reason therefore, and the business activity or occupation subsequent to such action of revocation or suspension; 
(9)  If the application is made on behalf of a corporation, the name of the corporation, exactly as shown in its articles of incorporation or charter, together with the place and date of incorporation. If the application is on behalf of a limited partnership, a copy of the certificate of limited partnership shall be provided. If one (1) or more of the partners is a corporation, the provisions of this subsection pertaining to corporations shall apply to each such corporation; 
(10)  The names and addresses of the owner and if applicable, the lessor of the real property upon which the adult entertainment establishment is to be operated, engaged in conducted or carried on and a copy of the lease or rental agreement, if any; 
(11)  With respect to the applicant, the operator(s) and the owner(s), all convictions, (excluding misdemeanor traffic violations unrelated to driving under the influence of drugs or alcohol) within the past ten (10) years, including a complete description of the crime or violation, the date of the crime or violation, date of conviction including plea of guilty or nolo contendere), jurisdiction and any disposition including any fine or sentence imposed and whether the terms of disposition have been fully completed. Each person required to disclose convictions hereunder shall also provide a signed and notarized consent, on forms prescribed by the GCIC and the NCIC, authorizing the release of his or her criminal records to the city police department; 
(12)  A complete set of fingerprints of the applicant and the operator(s); 
(13)  If the person or business entity on whose behalf application for a license is made is doing business under a trade name, a copy of the trade name as properly recorded. If the application is made on behalf of a corporation, a copy of its authority to do business in the state should be provided, including articles of incorporation, and a trade name affidavit, if any, and last annual report, if any; 
(14)  The address of the premises where the adult entertainment establishment will be operated, engaged in, conducted, or carried on; 
(15)  A plat prepared by a registered engineer or a registered land surveyor, licensed by the State of Georgia, showing the location of the proposed premises where the adult entertainment establishment will be operated, engaged in, conducted or carried on in relation to the neighborhood, the surrounding zoning, its proximity to any residential area, church, school, public park or children's day care facility, any other adult entertainment establishment, and any establishment licensed by the city to sell alcoholic beverages, beer or wine for consumption on the premises; the survey should depict the location and distance of the property use closest to the proposed premises that would disqualify the property if it were within the prohibited distance pursuant to section 9-12-6(a); 
(16)  Each application for an adult entertainment establishment license shall be verified and acknowledged under oath to be true and correct by: 
a.  If application is made on behalf of an individual, the individual; 
b.  If application is made on behalf of a partnership, by a general partner; 
c.  If application is made on behalf of a corporation, by the president or chief executive officer of the corporation; 
d.  If application is made on behalf of any other organization or association, by the chief administrative official. 
(c)  Appearance by applicant. The applicant shall personally appear before the chief of police or his designee with payment of the nonrefundable application fee in the amount established by the governing body of the city, and shall present the application containing the aforementioned and described information. 
(d)  Investigation; standards for granting of license. The city shall have ninety (90) days from the date of actual receipt of a fully completed application to investigate the facts provided in the application and the background of the applicant, the operator(s) and owner(s). The chief of police or his designee shall stamp the date of receipt of each application on the first page thereof and shall provide the applicant a photocopy of the stamped first page signifying the date of receipt of the application. The chief of police or his designee may search the GCIC and the NCIC to determine whether the applicant, operator(s), and owner(s) appear as part of any record maintained therein. The chief of police shall approve or deny the completed application for an adult entertainment establishment license within ninety (90) days of actual receipt of a fully completed application. If any application is received that is not fully complete for any reason, then in such event, the incomplete application shall be returned to the applicant as soon as possible following the discovery of the incompleteness, and the applicant shall be required to submit a newly completed application along with payment of an additional application fee in an amount established by the governing body of the city, and the ninety-day time period specified above shall begin over again upon the actual receipt of the fully completed application. 
The application for an adult entertainment establishment license shall be granted if the chief of police finds: 
(1)  The required license application fee has been paid; 
(2)  The application contains all of the information provided for in subsections (b)(1)—(16) above, and the applicant has made no material misrepresentation of fact in the application; 
(3)  Neither the applicant nor any of the operator(s) or owner(s) has been convicted or pled guilty or entered a plea of nolo contendere to any crime involving assault, illegal possession or use of a controlled substance, battery, keeping a place of prostitution, pandering, pimping, public indecency, prostitution, sodomy, solicitation of sodomy, masturbation for hire, sexual battery, rape, child molestation, enticing a child for indecent purposes, or any offense included in the definition of a "criminal offense against a victim who is a minor" as defined in O.C.G.A. § 42-1-12 within a period of ten (10) years preceding the date of the application. If there has been any such conviction or plea, then the application shall be denied, For purposes of this chapter, a conviction or plea of guilty or nolo contendere shall be ignored as to any offense for which the applicant was allowed to avail himself of the Georgia First Offender Act unless the applicant is later adjudicated guilty of having violated the terms of his first offender treatment; 
(4)  Except as may be allowed by virtue of the settlement agreement and/or court order, neither the applicant nor any of the operator(s) or owner(s) has had an adult entertainment establishment license or permit revoked for cause by this city or any other municipal corporation or county located in or out of the State of Georgia within the five-year period immediately preceding the date of the application; 
(5)  The building, structure, equipment and location of the premises of the adult entertainment establishment as proposed by the applicant is in compliance with all applicable laws, including, but not limited to, health, zoning, distance, fire and safety requirements and standards based on information provided by or through other city departments or Clayton County; 
(6)  The applicant, operator(s) and owners(s) are all at least eighteen (18) years of age; 
(7)  Except as may be allowed by virtue of the settlement agreement and/or court order, the proposed premises will be located at least the minimum distances set forth in this chapter from any residential use, church, school, public park or children's daycare facility, any other adult entertainment establishment, and any other establishment licensed by the city to sell alcoholic beverages, beer or wine for consumption on the premises pursuant to section 9-12-6(a); 
(8)  The grant of such license will not cause a violation of any law of the State of Georgia or the United States. 
The chief of police shall deny the application for an adult entertainment establishment license if the application fails to meet any requirement contained in this section. 
(e)  Alcoholic beverages. In the event the applicant, licensee, and/or owner(s) of an adult entertainment establishment desire(s) to sell or dispense spirituous liquors, beer, wine, and/or any other alcoholic beverage for consumption on the premises of an adult entertainment establishment, said applicant, licensee, and/or owner(s) must first apply for and obtain a permit to serve alcohol on the premises as a retail consumption dealer in accordance with the provisions of Title 9, Chapter 2 of the Code of the City of Forest Park, Georgia regulating the sale of alcoholic beverages, as may hereinafter be amended, before said sales can commence. Application and receipt of a license to sell or dispense alcoholic beverages as a retail consumption dealer shall require payment of an additional alcohol license fee pursuant to Title 9, Chapter 2 of the Code of the City of Forest Park, Georgia. The number of adult entertainment establishments that may be permitted to sell or dispense alcoholic beverages for on-premises consumption is further limited by the provisions of section 9-12-7(e) below. 
(Ord. No. 14-25, § 1, 10-27-2014) 
Sec. 9-12-6. - Regulation of adult entertainment establishments. 
(a)  Location. Except as may be allowed by virtue of the settlement agreement and/or court order, no adult entertainment establishment shall be located: 
(1)  Within one thousand (1,000) feet of any parcel of land that is zoned residential under the city's then current zoning ordinance; 
(2)  Within one thousand (1,000) feet of any parcel of land on which a church, school, college campus, public park or children's day care facility is located; 
(3)  Within one thousand (1,000) feet of any parcel of land containing another adult entertainment establishment; 
(4)  Within five hundred (500) feet of any parcel of land upon which any establishment licensed by the city to sell alcoholic beverages or malt beverages or wine for consumption on the premises is located; 
(5)  In any area of the city that lies outside the adult entertainment overlay district as defined and set forth in section 8-8-62.1 of the Code of Ordinances, City of Forest Park, Georgia, as amended. 
For purposes of this section, distance shall be by straight line, measurement from property line to property line, using the closest points on the property lines of the parcels of land involved. The term "parcel of land" means any parcel with a tax ID number assigned by the county tax assessor. 
(b)  Adult entertainment establishment employees. 
(1)  Qualifications. All employees of an adult entertainment establishment shall be not less than eighteen (18) years of age. No employee employed in an adult entertainment establishment shall have been convicted of an offense described in section 9-12-5(d)(3) of this chapter within the five (5) years immediately preceding the proposed employment at or by an adult entertainment establishment Any adult entertainment establishment employee who is convicted of any such crimes while so employed shall not thereafter work on any licensed premises in the city for a period of five (5) years from the date of such conviction, unless a longer time is ordered by a court of competent jurisdiction. The terms "licensed premises" and "convicted" are defined in section 9-12-2 of this chapter. 
(2)  Permit for employment. Before any person may work as any type of employee of a licensed adult entertainment establishment, he or she shall complete and file an application with the chief of police or his designee of his or her intended employment, which application is available from the city. When submitting his or her application, the prospective employee must also submit the applicable application fee to the chief of police or his designee. Said fee amount shall be set forth on the fee schedule maintained and kept by the chief of police or his designee. The prospective employee shall also supply a signed and notarized consent, on forms prescribed by the GCIC and the NCIC, authorizing the release of his or her criminal records to the city's police department. The prospective employee shall also provide a list of all of his or her convictions of offenses described in section 9-12-5(d)(3) herein (including pleas of nolo contendere) within the past five (5) years. The chief of police or his designee may search the GCIC and the NCIC to determine whether the prospective employee appears as part of any record maintained therein. 
The chief of police or his designee shall approve or deny the application for an annual employment permit within five (5) days of receipt. If the prospective employee is found to meet the requirements of this subsection (b), the city shall issue. the permit approving such employment immediately upon receipt of the permit fee from the prospective employee. Upon receipt of an annual permit under this chapter, the employee may begin or continue working on the premises of the licensed adult entertainment establishment. If approval of an annual permit is denied, the chief of police or his designee shall provide the prospective adult entertainment employee the reasons for the denial and the applicant may, within ten (10) days of said denial, appeal to the city manager who shall uphold or reverse the decision within thirty (30) days of such appeal. The applicant may begin or continue working at the adult entertainment establishment during the pendency of said appeal. If the chief of police or his designee neither approves nor denies an application for an annual permit within five (5) days of the date such application was received, then on expiration of the fifth day, the applicant shall have the right to begin or continue his or her employment in the manner allowed by the permit for which application was made with the understanding that the chief of police may, at any time after said employee begins or continues his or her employment under these circumstances, deny said application, at which time the employee must cease working at the adult entertainment establishment. Furthermore, notwithstanding the provisions of subsection (b)(6) of this section, if at any time after an employee is issued his or her permit, it is discovered by the city police department that said employee provided false information on his or her application to acquire that permit, the chief of police may revoke said employee's permit immediately. 
(3)  Categories of permits. There shall be two (2) employee permit categories: (1) a category for operator permits and adult entertainer permits, and (2) a category for permits for all other employees of an adult entertainment establishment. 
(4)  Permit fees. The governing body of the city shall establish a separate fee for each category of permit as further described in section 9-12-2 above. Each annual employee permit fee shall be in an amount which is reasonably tied to the costs of investigating the employee's record and background. The schedule of permit fees is available upon request from the chief of police or his designee. 
(5)  Permits to be worn by employees. All permits issued under this chapter to employees shall be kept in the premise's office and will be available for inspection by any city police officer or other law enforcement officer immediately upon request. It is the responsibility of the operator and/or licensee of an adult entertainment establishment to maintain an up-to-date. list and/or book containing a copy of the employment permits and the corresponding photographs of every employee of that adult entertainment establishment. Said list and/or book must be updated by the operator and/or licensee of an adult entertainment establishment each time said establishment acquires a new employee. A complete copy of this list and/or book must be provided to the chief of police or his designee within three (3) days of its creation and within three (3) days of the date it is updated each time it is updated. Furthermore, all employees of an adult entertainment establishment must wear an abbreviated form of their employment permits at all times while in or upon the licensed premises in such a manner that the abbreviated form is readily visible to any city police officer or other law enforcement officer as follows: 
a.  Each adult entertainer must wear a wristband on the adult entertainer's wrist which clearly displays the number of the adult entertainer's employment permit and the expiration date of said employment permit thereon. Said wristband shall be provided to the adult entertainer by the licensee or operator of the adult entertainment establishment at which the adult entertainer is employed and performs. The permit number and expiration date displayed on an adult entertainer's wristband must correspond to the permit number and expiration date displayed on the corresponding adult entertainer's employment permit, which shall be kept in the office of the premises, and also to the permit information on record with the city for that adult entertainer (including the list and/or book of employee permit information and photographs supplied by the adult entertainment establishment to the chief of police or his designee). Should an adult entertainer be present on the premises wearing no wristband, wearing a wristband displaying any other employee's permit number and/or expiration date, or wearing a wristband displaying a false permit number and/or expiration date that does not correspond to any other active employment permit, such action shall constitute a violation of this chapter by said adult entertainer. 
b.  Each other employee of an adult entertainment establishment, including operators (but not including adult entertainers), must wear on his or her person at all times while on the premises an identification card which clearly displays the number of the employee's employment permit, the expiration date of the employee's employment permit, and the employee's name as it appears on the employee's employment permit. This identification card must be worn by the employee in a location that is clearly visible to any city police officer or other law enforcement officer, such as around the employee's neck or elsewhere outside of said employee's clothing. This identification card shall be provided to the employee by the licensee or operator of the adult entertainment establishment at which the employee is employed. The information displayed on the employee's identification card must correspond to the information contained on said employee's employment permit, which shall be kept in the office of the premises, and to the information on record with the city for that employee's permit (including the list and/or book of employee permit information and photographs supplied by the adult entertainment establishment to the chief of police or his designee). Should an employee be present on the premises not wearing his or her identification card, wearing another employee's identification card, or wearing an identification card that does not correspond to any other active employment permit, such action shall constitute a violation of this chapter by said employee. 
c.  Any and all employees of an adult entertainment establishment must cooperate with the request of an officer of the city's police department or any other law enforcement agency to view an employee's wristband or identification card and said officer's efforts to confirm that an employee is validly and currently permitted to work at said adult entertainment establishment. Should any person be actively employed at an adult entertainment establishment in any capacity requiring the issuance of a permit under this chapter without having applied for an employment permit from the city, or having applied for an employment permit and been denied said permit, or having let a previously issued employment permit expire without renewing or reapplying for a permit, then this action shall constitute a violation of this chapter by said individual as well as by the operator of said adult entertainment establishment. 
(6)  Revocation of permit; procedure. 
a.  Any city regulatory authority may issue a citation to any adult entertainment employee, excluding operators, for violating the provisions of subsections (b), (c), (d), or (g) of this section; section 9-12-7(c), (d), (e), or (f) of this chapter. If three (3) such citations are affirmed within a twelve-month period, or if the adult entertainment employee is convicted of, or enters a guilty plea to an offense described in section 9-12-5(d)(3) of this chapter, said employee's permit to work or perform in an adult entertainment establishment shall be revoked by the chief of police or his designee. 
b.  Any city regulatory authority may issue a citation to any operator of an adult entertainment establishment for knowing violations of the provisions discussed in subsection (a) above, or of sections 9-12-3, 9-12-4, 9-12-6(a), (b), (d), (e), or (g)—(j), 9-12-7(a), (d), or (e), 9-12-10, 9-12-13, or 9-12-14 of this chapter. In addition, any city regulatory authority may issue a citation to any operator of an adult entertainment establishment if three (3) non-operator employees of the adult entertainment establishment each have three (3) citations affirmed against them for violating any of the code provisions set forth in subsection (b)(6)(a) above within a twelve-month period. If any three (3) citations are affirmed against an operator within a twelve-month period, or if the operator is convicted of, or enters a guilty plea to, an offense described in section 9-12-5(d)(3) of this chapter, then the permit of the operator to work at said adult entertainment establishment shall be revoked by the chief of police or his designee. 
c.  Furthermore, should any employee of an adult entertainment establishment wish to appeal or challenge the revocation of his or her permit, he or she must comply with the procedure set forth in section 9-12-12. 
(7)  Independent contractors. For the purpose of this chapter, independent contractors working for an adult entertainment establishment shall be considered as employees and shall be required to satisfy the provisions of this chapter relating to employees of adult entertainment establishments. As used in this chapter, the terms "employee" and "adult entertainment establishment employee" shall include any person who performs any service on the premises of an adult entertainment establishment on a full-time, part-time, or contract basis, whether or not the person is an employee, an independent contractor, or any other kind of agent, and whether or not said person performs such services only for tips or is paid a salary, wage, or any other type of compensation by the adult entertainment establishment. The term "employee" or "adult entertainment establishment employee" shall not include a person on the premises for the sole purpose of repair or maintenance of the premises, or any building or equipment on the premises, or for the delivery of any goods or merchandise to the premises. 
(c)  Amateurs. Any person performing as an adult entertainer must have a permit, regardless of their status or performance history. 
(d)  Hours and days of operation. An adult entertainment establishment that does not feature, show, or present live adult entertainment and does not employ, feature, or allow adult entertainers to perform within its premises may only be open between the hours of 9:00 a.m. and 2:00 a.m., and shall only be open on those days and hours when businesses selling or dispensing alcoholic beverages for on-site consumption are permitted to be open under the city's ordinances or Georgia state law. Notwithstanding any other provision of the Code of the City of Forest Park, Georgia, an adult entertainment establishment that does feature, show, or present live adult entertainment and does employ, feature, or allow adult entertainers to perform within its premises may be open from 9:00 a.m. until 3:30 a.m. Monday through Saturday (meaning that the establishment may be open until 3:30 a.m. on Sunday morning), provided that if said adult entertainment establishment featuring live adult entertainment is licensed to and does sell or dispense alcoholic beverages for on-site consumption, all alcohol service must cease by 3:00 a.m., and in the event of a conflict between this provision and any provision of the alcohol beverage ordinance of the city, this provision as to hours of authorized alcohol service, shall control. 
(e)  Display of licenses. An adult entertainment establishment licensee shall conspicuously display the license required by this chapter at the front entrance to the interior premises of the adult entertainment establishment or within twenty (20) linear feet of the front door entering the interior premises of the adult entertainment establishment. 
(f)  Consent to jurisdiction and service. Any licensee issued a license under this chapter and any employee issued an employee permit under this chapter shall be deemed to have consented to the jurisdiction of the Municipal Court of the City of Forest Park, Georgia, the State Court of Clayton County, Georgia, and the Superior Court of Clayton County, Georgia, for purposes of the enforcement of this chapter, and shall also be deemed to have consented to service of any citation or summons issued under this chapter via the United States mail with sufficient first class postage affixed and properly addressed to the licensee or employee at the address set forth on the application for such license or permit, as the case may be. Nothing herein shall be interpreted to preclude a police officer or deputy sheriff from personally serving a licensee or employee. 
(g)  Lighting. All areas of an adult entertainment establishment licensed hereunder shall be fully lighted at all times patrons are present. Full lighting shall mean at least illumination equal to 3.5 foot candles per square foot. 
(h)  Covering of windows and doors. All adult entertainment which is licensed and permitted by this chapter shall be carried on inside a closed building with all windows and doors covered so that the activities carried on inside cannot be viewed from the immediate areas surrounding the outside of the building. 
(i)  Retention of records. All adult entertainment establishments shall be required to: 
(1)  Retain all records pertaining to its employees for a period of five (5) years from the employees' respective dates of hire; and 
(2)  Retain all video footage taken of the premises for security, monitoring, or any other purpose for a period of ninety (90) days from the date said footage was recorded. 
All such records, whether in physical, electronic, or video format, shall be open to inspection by any city police officer for official police business during normal operating hours upon twenty-four (24) hours' notice and request from the chief of police or his designee to the operator, owner, or licensee of any adult entertainment establishment.
