If any special event poses higher risks than would be covered by such insurance, the applicant and/or the producer shall be responsible for assessing the risk of such event and obtaining additional insurance coverage. 
(Ord. No. 16-13, § 2 (Exh. A), 9-19-2016) 
Sec. 9-15-17. - Save harmless agreement. 
The applicant is required to provide a save harmless agreement in which the applicant agrees to defend, indemnify and save harmless the city, including its officers, employees and agents, from any and all claims or lawsuits for personal injury or property damage arising from or in any way connected to the special event; excepting any claims arising solely out of the intentional acts of the city, its officers, employees and agents. 
(Ord. No. 16-13, § 2 (Exh. A), 9-19-2016) 
Sec. 9-15-18. - Limitations of liability. 
This chapter shall not be construed as imposing upon the city, including its officers, employees and agents, any liability or responsibility for any injury or damage to any person in any way connected to the use for which the special permit has been issued. The city, including its officers, employees and agents, shall not be deemed to have assumed any liability or responsibility by reasons of inspections performed, the issuance of any permit, or the approval of any use of a street, a sidewalk, or other public property. 
(Ord. No. 16-13, § 2 (Exh. A), 9-19-2016) 
Sec. 9-15-19. - Other permits. 
The applicant shall obtain any other permits that may be required by other chapters of this Code of Ordinances and by other jurisdictions for the special event. 
(1)  Alcoholic beverages. Any temporary permit for the sale of alcoholic beverages shall be in accordance with the provisions of state law and chapter 2 of title 9 of the Code of Ordinances. 
(2)  Signs . Permits for the erection of any sign during the period in which the special event is to occur shall be in accordance with the provisions of the Code of Ordinances regulating signs. 
(Ord. No. 16-13, § 2 (Exh. A), 9-19-2016) 
Sec. 9-15-20. - Exemptions. 
This chapter shall not apply to the following activities: 
(1)  Funeral processions; 
(2)  Students going to and from school classes or participating in school sponsored educational activities or athletic events, provided such conduct is under the immediate direction and supervision of the proper school authorities; 
(3)  A public event which is directly related to a recognized function of city, state or local government and which is in a major part initiated, financed and executed by the city, state, local or United States government; 
(4)  Private social gatherings which will make no use of streets other than for lawful parking; and 
(5)  Peaceful picketing in connection with labor disputes. 
(Ord. No. 16-13, § 2 (Exh. A), 9-19-2016) 
Title 10 - Motor Vehicles and Traffic 
Chapter 1.  General Provisions 
Chapter 2.  Regulation of Traffic 
Chapter 3.  Parking and Loading 
Chapter 4.  Enforcement 
CHAPTER 1. - GENERAL PROVISIONS 

Sec. 10-1-1. - Uniform rules of the road adopted. 
Pursuant to Chapter 6 of Title 40 of the Official Code of Georgia Annotated, Code Sections 40-6-372 through 40-6-376, Code Sections 40-6-1 to 40-6-395 of that chapter known as the Uniform Rules of the Road and the definitions contained in Code Section 40-1-1 are adopted as and for the traffic regulation of the city with like effect as if recited herein. 
Unless another penalty is expressly provided by law, every person convicted of a violation of any provision of the ordinance codified in this section shall be punished by fine or imprisonment, or both, as provided elsewhere in this Code. 
(Ord. No. 91-008, 5-20-91) 
Sec. 10-1-2. - City traffic engineer; office created; general duties. 
The chief of police shall serve as the city traffic engineer until such time as the governing authority specifically otherwise designates by ordinance or resolution. It shall be the general duty of the city traffic engineer to determine the installation and proper timing and maintenance of traffic-control devices, to conduct engineering investigation of traffic conditions, and to cooperate with other city officials in the development of ways and means to improve traffic conditions, and to carry out the additional powers and duties imposed by ordinance and resolution of the city. 
Sec. 10-1-3. - Same; specific duties. 
The traffic engineer, in addition to his other duties, shall: 
(1)  Lend technical assistance to those engaging or desiring to engage in the business of off-street parking. 
(2)  Make studies, as necessary, of the parking or traffic problems in any section of the city and report his recommendations to the city manager and the governing authority. 
(3)  Examine all applications for permits to operate new off-street parking facilities or to expand existing facilities in the city and report his recommendations to the city manager and to the governing authority. 
(4)  Make a continuous and systematic study of traffic and parking conditions in the city with the purpose of recommending any and all changes that would help traffic flow and parking within the city. Such recommendations shall be made periodically to the city manager and the governing authority. 
(5)  Make any and all studies and give reports thereon to the city manager and the governing authority concerning the use of streets, alleys and public property insofar as the same relate to transportation, parking and use by emergency and official vehicles. 
(6)  Cooperate with the governing authorities of other governmental units endeavoring to promote more efficient use of the streets and parking facilities of the city in every manner whatsoever. 
(7)  Perform such other duties as may be designated by the city manager or the governing authority. 
(Code 1959, § 20-35) 
Sec. 10-1-4. - Emergency and experimental regulations. 
(a)  The chief of police, by and with the approval of the city manager is hereby empowered to make regulations necessary to make effective the provisions of this title and other traffic ordinances of this city and to make and enforce temporary or experimental regulations to cover emergencies or special conditions. No such temporary or experimental regulation shall remain in effect for more than 90 days. 
(b)  The city traffic engineer may test traffic-control devices under actual conditions of traffic. 
(Code 1959, § 20-44) 
Sec. 10-1-5. - Appeal from regulations, rule or order of police chief. 
Any traffic regulation, rule or order promulgated under section 10-1-4 by the chief of police or upon his authority, may be appealed by any person affected to the governing body. Said appeal shall be filed with the city clerk and addressed to the governing authority, in writing, and shall state the facts, and set forth the reasons for making the appeal. The governing body shall thereupon investigate any such appeal, and thereafter grant a hearing on the issues formed by the appeal. The action taken by the governing authority shall be final and binding upon the chief of police. 
Cross reference— Traffic division, § 4-1-2 et seq.; traffic violations bureau, § 2-5-21 et seq. 
Sec. 10-1-6. - Permits for parades and processions. 
No procession (except funerals) or parade shall occupy, march or proceed along any street, except in accordance with the following procedure: 
(1)  All requests for parades or processions (except funerals) must be filed two (2) weeks in advance with the police department. 
(2)  All requests must contain date of parade or procession, time to start parade or procession, place of beginning and place of ending of the parade or procession. The request must state route to be taken. Each request must state the reason or purpose for holding the parade or procession. 
(3)  All parades and processions must be escorted when possible by police escort. 
(4)  All permits for parades or processions, except funerals, must be reviewed by the chief of police and approved by the city manager. 
Sec. 10-1-7. - Funeral processions; route of procession. 
All funeral processions will take the most direct feasible route to the church and to the cemetery or place of burial. 
(Code 1959, § 20-10(c)) 
Sec. 10-1-8. - Same; right-of-way for vehicles. 
(a)  Vehicles of a funeral procession shall have the right-of-way over all vehicles, except authorized emergency vehicles, provided each shall identify itself by activating regular headlights, shall keep in close formation, and shall display such identifying markings or devices as directed as required by the city. 
(b)  When the lead vehicle in a funeral procession has entered an intersection on a green light, all other cars in the procession may proceed through the intersection, even though such signal may change to red. 
Sec. 10-1-9. - Driving through funeral or other procession. 
No driver of a vehicle shall drive between the vehicles comprising a funeral or other authorized procession while they are in motion and when such vehicles are conspicuously designated as required in section 10-1-8. 
(Code 1959, § 20-72) 
Sec. 10-1-10. - Drivers in a procession. 
Each driver in a funeral or other procession shall drive as near to the right-hand edge of the street or roadway as practicable and shall follow the vehicle ahead as close as is practicable and safe. 
(Code 1959, § 20-73) 
Sec. 10-1-11. - Use of coasters, roller skates and similar devices restricted. 
(a)  No person upon roller skates, or riding in or by means of any coasters, toy vehicle, or similar device, shall go upon any roadway except while crossing the street on a crosswalk and when so coasting such person shall be granted all of the rights and shall be subject to all of the duties applicable to pedestrians. 
(b)  There shall be no such skating or riding on the sidewalks except under such terms and conditions as expressly allowed by the governmental authority by resolution or ordinance. 
(c)  It shall be unlawful for persons so skating or riding to gather in crowds, or to create noise or be guilty of any disorderly conduct, or to take hold of or hang on to any automobile or other vehicle, or in any way to interfere with the natural progress of automobiles or other vehicles along and in the streets of the city, or for two (2) or more persons to join hands while skating on the sidewalk. Any persons so skating or riding shall give the right-of-way to, and no way interfere with, persons walking on the sidewalks. 
Sec. 10-1-12. - Title not to interfere with rights of owners of real property with reference thereto. 
Nothing in this title shall be construed to prevent the owner of real property used by the public for purposes of vehicular travel by permission of the owner, and not as matter of right, from prohibiting such use, or from requiring other or different or additional conditions than those specified herein, or otherwise regulating such use as may seem best to such owner. 
(Code 1959, § 20-28) 
Sec. 10-1-13. - Obstruction of view and use of streets by trees and shrubs; notice. 
(a)  No person owning, occupying or in anywise controlling property in the city shall permit any tree, bush or shrub on the property to project over any street, sidewalk or right-of-way of the city, so as to obstruct or interfere with the view and use of persons walking or riding in a vehicle on the street or sidewalk or of other persons or vehicles approaching from cross or intersecting streets. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for any person owning, occupying or in anywise controlling property in the city to permit shrubbery or other vegetation to grow or to accumulate to a height of more than three (3) feet within seven (7) feet of the curb or any public street, alley or right-of-way when, in the opinion of the chief of police or the mayor and council, the same shall constitute a menace or a hazard to traffic. 
(c)  It shall be unlawful for any person, whether the owner, tenant, agent or person controlling property in the city to fail to remove or trim any tree, bush or other obstruction from the streets or sidewalks of the city in violation of this section after 10 days' notice from the city to do so. 
Sec. 10-1-14. - Bicycles; effect of regulations. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to do any act forbidden or fail to perform any act required in this title. 
(b)  The parent of any child and the guardian of the person of any ward shall not authorize or knowingly permit any such child or ward to violate any of the provisions of this title. 
(c)  These regulations to bicycles shall apply whenever a bicycle is operated upon any street or upon any public path set aside for the exclusive use of bicycles, subject to those exceptions stated herein. 
(Code 1959, § 20-163) 
Sec. 10-1-15. - Same; parking. 
No person shall park a bicycle upon a street other than upon the roadway against the curb or upon the sidewalk in a rack to support the bicycle or against a building or at a curb, in such manner as to afford the least obstruction to pedestrian traffic. 
(Code 1959, § 20-177) 
Sec. 10-1-16. - Same; riding on sidewalks. 
(a)  No person shall ride a bicycle upon a sidewalk within a business district, or the central traffic district. 
(b)  No person 13 or more years of age shall ride a bicycle upon any sidewalk in any district. 
(c)  Whenever any person is riding a bicycle upon a sidewalk, such person shall yield the right-of-way to any pedestrian and shall give audible signal before overtaking and passing such pedestrian. 
(Code 1959, § 20-178) 
Sec. 10-1-17. - Same; acrobatic or fancy riding on streets. 
No rider of any bicycle shall remove both hands from the handle bars, or feet from the pedal, or practice any acrobatic or fancy riding on any street; nor shall any person operating a bicycle upon a street participate in any race of speed or endurance in a contest with any other bicycle or vehicle, except where permitted in closely supervised activities conducted by the parks and recreation department. 
CHAPTER 2. - REGULATION OF TRAFFIC 
ARTICLE A. - GENERAL PROVISIONS 

Sec. 10-2-1. - Motor vehicle colliding with object. 
No driver of any vehicle shall operate the vehicle in such manner so as to collide with any object legally placed upon or adjacent to any street or highway. 
(Code 1959, § 20-79) 
Sec. 10-2-2. - Vehicle leaving street or roadway. 
No driver of any vehicle shall operate same in such a manner so as to enter or leave any street or highway except at an intersection or at an alley or private drive. 
(Code 1959, § 20-80) 
Sec. 10-2-3. - Motor vehicle involved in a collision with parked vehicle. 
No driver of any vehicle shall operate the vehicle in such a manner so as to collide with any vehicle which is legally parked in the city. 
Sec. 10-2-4. - Speed restrictions. 
After having conducted engineering and traffic investigations, the results of which indicate a need for reasonable and safe exceptions to the vehicle speed limits set forth in the Uniform Rules of the Road, the city traffic engineer, upon approval by ordinance of the mayor and council, is authorized to designate and maintain speed zones on city streets with appropriate traffic control signs, markings and devices. A current schedule of all speed zones shall be maintained by the traffic engineer and shall be available for public inspection in the police department and the office of the city clerk. 
Sec. 10-2-5. - Speed signs. 
The traffic engineer shall erect or cause to be erected throughout the city signs indicating the maximum speed limit and/or such other information as will be informative to drivers of motor vehicles as pertains to traffic control regulations at said location or in the city. 
(Code 1959, § 20-83) 
Sec. 10-2-6. - Maximum speed in parks and school zones. 
No person shall drive a motor vehicle in parks in excess of 25 miles per hour nor on streets adjoining school property during school days in excess of 25 miles per hour. 
Sec. 10-2-7. - Slowly moving vehicles. 
Slowly moving or heavily laden vehicles shall not be driven upon the streets or highways abreast, but one must follow behind the other and keep as near the right-hand curb as possible. 
Sec. 10-2-8. - Driving past men working on streets and roadways. 
The maximum rate of speed shall be 15 miles per hour when approaching or driving past men working in the street or roadway, who are city employees, public utility employees, or those granted permission of the city, provided such workmen have erected a sign reading: "Slow—Men Working" and such sign is in accordance with the specifications of the city traffic engineer. 
(Code 1959, § 20-87) 
Sec. 10-2-9. - Regulation of speed by traffic signals. 
The city traffic engineer is authorized to regulate the timing of traffic signals so as to permit the movement of traffic in an orderly and safe manner at speeds slightly at variance from the speeds otherwise applicable within the district or at intersections and shall erect appropriate signs giving notice thereof. 
(Code 1959, § 20-88) 
Sec. 10-2-10. - Authority to place restricted turn signs. 
After having received the results of engineering and traffic investigations which indicate a need for restricted turns at certain intersections, the mayor and council shall designate, by ordinance, those intersections at which drivers of vehicles shall not make a right, left, or U turn. Upon such designation the city traffic engineer shall place proper signs at such intersections. The making of such turns may be prohibited between certain hours of any day and permitted at other hours, in which event the same shall be plainly indicated on the signs or they may be removed when such turns are permitted. 
Sec. 10-2-11. - Authority to place and duty to obey turning markers. 
(a)  The city traffic engineer is authorized to place markers, buttons, and signs within or adjacent to intersections indicating the course to be traveled by vehicles turning at such intersections, and such course to be traveled as so indicated shall conform to this title or other law or ordinance. 
(b)  When authorized markers, buttons or other indications are placed within an intersection indicating the course to be traveled by vehicles turning thereat, no driver of a vehicle shall disobey the directions of such indications. 
Sec. 10-2-12. - Limitations on turning around. 
The driver of any vehicle shall not turn such vehicle so as to proceed in the opposite direction upon any street in a business district, or upon any street between intersections. Such turns may be made outside of a business district at intersections not controlled by a traffic signal. 
(Code 1959, § 20-98) 
Sec. 10-2-13. - Authority to install traffic-control devices. 
The city traffic engineer shall cause to be placed and maintained traffic-control signs, signals and devices when and as required under this chapter and other traffic ordinances of the city to make effective the provisions of this title and such ordinances. He may cause to be placed and maintained such additional traffic-control devices as he shall deem necessary to regulate traffic under this title and other traffic ordinances of the city or under state law, or to guide or warn traffic. 
(Code 1959, § 20-99) 
Sec. 10-2-14. - Designation of crosswalks, safety zones, and traffic lanes. 
The city traffic engineer is hereby authorized: 
(1)  To designate and maintain, by appropriate devices, marks or lines upon the surface of the roadway, crosswalks at intersections where in his opinion there is particular danger to pedestrians crossing the roadway and at such other places as he may deem necessary. He shall make proper studies of all existing crosswalks not at roadway intersections, and shall abolish those which he deems unnecessary. 
(2)  To establish safety zones of such kind and character and at such places as he may deem necessary for the protection of pedestrians. 
(3)  To make lanes for traffic on street pavements at such places as he may deem advisable, consistent with this title and other traffic ordinances of the city. 
(Code 1959, § 20-100) 
Sec. 10-2-15. - Type of traffic-control devices. 
All traffic-control signs, signals and devices shall conform generally to specifications set out in the manual on Uniform Traffic-Control Devices adopted by the state department of transportation; however, any and all signs and signals placed pursuant to this or other ordinance shall be official, and shall so far as practicable be uniform as to type and location throughout the city. All traffic-control devices so erected shall be official traffic-control devices. 
(Code 1959, § 20-101) 
Sec. 10-2-16. - Location and legibility of required signs. 
No provision of this title for which signs are required shall be enforced against an alleged violator if at the time and place of the alleged violation an official sign is not so located and sufficiently legible to be seen by an ordinarily observant person. Whenever a particular section does not state that signs are required, such section shall be effective even though no signs are erected or in place. 
(Code 1959, § 20-107) 
Sec. 10-2-17. - Through streets; designated. 
The governing body may by ordinance or resolution specifically designate certain streets or parts of streets as through streets. 
(Code 1959, § 20-152) 
Sec. 10-2-18. - Same; authority to erect stop signs. 
Whenever this title or any ordinance of the city designates and describes a through street it shall be the duty of the city traffic engineer to place and maintain a stop sign or yield-right-of-way sign on each and every intersection of such through street or intersection on that portion thereof described and designated as such by this title or any ordinance of the city. 
(Code 1959, § 20-153) 
Sec. 10-2-19. - Erection of stop signs and yield right-of-way signs at other than through street intersections. 
After having conducted engineering and traffic investigations, the results of which indicate particular hazards at certain intersections, the city traffic engineer shall report such results to the mayor and council. The mayor and council shall determine and designate intersections where particular hazards exist upon streets other than those designated by this title or any other ordinance of the city as through streets, and shall direct the city traffic engineer to place at such determined and designated hazardous intersections at one (1) or more entrances to any such intersection either a stop sign or yield-right-of-way sign. 
Sec. 10-2-20. - Authority to sign one-way streets and alleys. 
Whenever this title or any ordinance of the city designates any one-way street or alley the city traffic engineer shall place and maintain signs giving notice thereof, and no such regulation shall be effective unless such signs are in place. Signs indicating the direction of lawful traffic movement shall be placed at every intersection where movement of traffic in the opposite direction is prohibited. 
(Code 1959, § 20-26) 
Sec. 10-2-21. - Vehicles and employees of department of public works to have right-of-way on streets. 
All employees and vehicles of the department of public works when engaged or used in performance of the services rendered by such department, shall have the right-of-way in the use of the streets, and are hereby given permission to use any part thereof in the operation of such vehicles in cleaning up and washing the streets of the city. 
(Code 1959, § 20-25) 
Sec. 10-2-22. - Unlawful riding. 
No persons shall ride on any vehicle upon any portion thereof not designed or intended for the use of passengers. This provision shall not apply to an employee engaged in the necessary discharge of a duty, or to persons riding within truck bodies in space intended for merchandise. 
(Code 1959, § 20-64) 
Secs. 10-2-23—10-2-30. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE B. - TRUCK ROUTES AND VEHICLE WEIGHT LIMITS 

Sec. 10-2-31. - Motor trucks or trailers prohibited from traversing certain areas during designated hours. 
It shall be unlawful for any motor truck or motor drawn trailer to traverse any street or part of the area of the city during periods hereinafter specifically designated by the governing body by resolution or ordinance. Whenever said streets or areas are designated, nothing in this section shall prevent any truck, when not accompanied by a trailer, from traversing any of the streets or areas solely for the purpose of making delivery or the purpose of picking up or receiving goods, wares or merchandise for transportation; but this shall not include permission for trailers to enter, park or stand in such area for any purpose whatsoever. 
(Code 1959, § 20-13) 
Sec. 10-2-32. - Truck routes; certain vehicles required to use certain streets; exceptions. 
All motor vehicles having a gross weight in excess of 36,000 pounds including the load thereon, or having an overall length in excess of 30 feet, except vehicles designed to carry passengers, are prohibited from using any street within the city except those authorized by ordinance and designated as truck routes except: 
(1)  When the terminal, parking lot, repair garage or headquarters of the restricted motor vehicle is not on a designated truck route, ingress to and egress from such places shall be made by the most direct route available between the terminal, parking lot, repair garage or headquarters and nearest designated truck route. 
(2)  When a delivery or pickup is to be made at a location which is not on a designated truck route (to be set forth by the governing authority by ordinance or resolution) ingress to and egress from such location shall be made by the most direct route available between such location and nearest truck route. 
(3)  When a delivery or pickup is to be made within certain areas of the city, to be specifically designated by the governing authority by ordinance or resolution, by a truck tractor, road tractor, combination truck tractor, semi-trailer or combination road tractor-trailer, same shall be done at times and under conditions specified by the governing authority. 
(Code 1959, § 20-15) 
Sec. 10-2-33. - Same; drivers of vehicles to possess certain information when off designated routes. 
Any person driving or in charge or control of any of the restricted vehicles referred to in the preceding section when upon streets or in areas other than those specifically designated by the governing authority as truck routes, shall be prepared to present for the inspection of police officers his log book, weight slips, delivery slips, or other written evidence of his destination and point of origin to justify the presence of the restricted vehicle on a street or in an area other than a designated truck route. 
(Code 1959, § 20-16) 
Sec. 10-2-34. - Same; temporary routes. 
If any designated truck route, or portion thereof, shall be for any reason out of use, the driver of any restricted vehicle shall use such temporary truck route as may be designated by the governing authority. 
(Code 1959, § 20-17) 
Sec. 10-2-35. - Limitation as to weight of vehicles. 
The governing authority shall have the right to proclaim by ordinance or resolution the maximum weight of any vehicle, including tractors and trailers which may proceed upon certain designated streets or areas of the city. 
(Code 1959, § 20-18) 
CHAPTER 3. - PARKING AND LOADING 
ARTICLE A. - PARKING 

Sec. 10-3-1. - Prohibition of or restrictions on parking or stopping. 
When traffic and engineering surveys indicate that stopping or parking may impede the free flow of traffic on any particular street, the city traffic engineer shall report such matter to the mayor and council, who may, by ordinance, prohibit or restrict the parking or standing of vehicles on such street or a portion of such street at all times or between certain hours. 
Sec. 10-3-2. - Parking prohibited during certain hours. 
When prohibited by this title or other ordinance, no person shall park a vehicle during the hours prohibited at places so indicated by official signs. 
Sec. 10-3-3. - Stopping prohibited during certain hours. 
When prohibited by this title or other ordinance, no person shall stop a vehicle during the hours prohibited at places so indicated by official sign. 
Sec. 10-3-4. - Parking signs required. 
When by this title or other ordinance any parking time limit is imposed or parking is prohibited on designated streets it shall be the duty of the city traffic engineer to erect appropriate signs giving notice thereof and no such regulations shall be effective unless such signs are erected and in place at the time of any alleged offense. At least one (1) sign shall be erected in each block on each side of the street where parking is either prohibited or restricted. 
Sec. 10-3-5. - Parking for certain purposes prohibited. 
No person shall park a vehicle upon any roadway for: 
(1)  Displaying such vehicle for sale; 
(2)  Washing, greasing or repairing such vehicle except repairs necessitated by sudden emergency; in such emergency such vehicles shall be moved or towed away with all due haste; or 
(3)  For displaying advertising. 
(Code 1959, § 20-117) 
Sec. 10-3-6. - Parking adjacent to schools. 
(a)  Upon approval by ordinance of the mayor and council, the city traffic engineer shall erect signs indicating no parking upon that side of any street adjacent to any school property when such parking would interfere with traffic or create a hazardous situation. 
(b)  When official signs are erected indicating no parking upon that side of a street adjacent to any school property, no person shall park a vehicle in any such designated place. 
Sec. 10-3-7. - Parking prohibited on narrow streets. 
(a)  Upon approval by ordinance of the mayor and council, the city traffic engineer shall erect signs indicating no parking upon any street when the width of the roadway does not exceed 20 feet, or upon one (1) side of a street as indicated by such signs when the width of the roadway does not exceed 30 feet. 
(b)  When official signs prohibiting parking are erected upon narrow streets as authorized herein, no person shall park upon any such street in violation of any such sign. 
Sec. 10-3-8. - Standing or parking on one-way streets. 
Upon approval by ordinance of the mayor and council, the city traffic engineer shall erect signs upon the left-hand side of any one-way street to prohibit the standing or parking of vehicle, and when such signs are in place, no person shall stand or park a vehicle upon such left-hand side in violation of any such sign. 
Sec. 10-3-9. - Standing or parking on one-way roadways. 
In the event a highway includes two (2) or more separate roadways and traffic is restricted to one (1) direction upon any such roadway, no person shall stand or park a vehicle upon the left-side of such one-way roadway unless signs are erected to permit such standing or parking. The city traffic engineer shall conduct engineering and traffic investigations to determine when standing or parking may be permitted upon the left-hand side of any such one-way roadway and, upon approval by ordinance of the mayor and council, shall erect signs giving notice thereof. 
Sec. 10-3-10. - Stopping, standing or parking near hazardous or congested places. 
(a)  When engineering and traffic investigations indicate the stopping, standing or parking of vehicles would create an especially hazardous condition or would cause unusual delay to traffic, the mayor and council may, by ordinance, determine and designate places in which the parking or stopping of vehicles is prohibited. 
(b)  When official signs are erected at hazardous or congested places as authorized herein no person shall stop, stand or park a vehicle in any such designated place. 
Sec. 10-3-11. - Maximum time for parking of trucks. 
No person shall park or stand any truck or other freight carrying vehicles in excess of one-half (½) ton capacity upon any public street or highway for a period longer than one (1) hour at any time during the day or night unless authorized by the chief of police or his designated representative. 
Sec. 10-3-12. - Maximum width and height of vehicles without driver. 
No person shall stop or stand any truck or bus with a body more than eight (8) feet wide or 10 feet high on any street or public place without the driver or chauffeur being actually present and in charge thereof. 
(Code 1959, § 20-123(c)) 
Sec. 10-3-13. - City hall parking lot. 
No person shall park in the city hall parking lots, except those having official business with the city and only in such places therein and for such time as designated by markings placed therein. 
Sec. 10-3-14. - Public off-street parking facilities; permit required; application. 
Before any lot, building or parking garage may be used for off-street public parking, or before any existing facility may be expanded, the owner of the lot, building or parking garage or the operator of the facility must first obtain from the city manager a permit for such use. The application for such a permit shall be filed with the city manager and shall contain the following information: 
(1)  The address and location of the lot or building involved; 
(2)  The capacity of the proposed facility; 
(3)  The proposed location of entrances and exits to the facility; 
(4)  The capacity and location of the reservoir space to be used for the receiving and temporary storage of incoming vehicles; 
(5)  The proposed parking plan showing the size and location of the parking stalls and the aisles to serve them; 
(6)  The location, width and general design of ramps or elevator to be used inside of structures; and 
(7)  Any other information required to enable the governing authority to make a fair and complete appraisal of the operation of the proposed parking facility. 
Sec. 10-3-15. - Same; investigation of applications for permit. 
Upon receipt of any application for a permit required by the preceding section, the city manager shall request the city traffic engineer to make a thorough and complete investigation and within 30 days report thereon to the city manager and governing authority on such factors as: 
(1)  The size of the proposed facility and the vehicular capacity of streets to be used for ingress and egress; 
(2)  The physical arrangements provided for ingress and egress; 
(3)  The reservoir space for incoming and outgoing vehicles; 
(4)  The effects, if any, of any plan for traffic improvement (such as the expressway program, or major street plan) on the flow or the pattern of traffic adjacent to the affected streets; and 
(5)  The financial responsibility of the applicant. 
Secs. 10-3-16—10-3-30. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE B. - LOADING AND UNLOADING 

Sec. 10-3-31. - Permit for loading or unloading at an angle to the curb. 
The city traffic engineer is authorized to issue special permits to permit the backing of a vehicle to the curb for the purpose of loading or unloading merchandise or materials subject to the terms and conditions of such permits. Such permits may be issued either to the owner or lessee of real property or to the owner of the vehicle and shall grant to such person the privilege as therein stated and authorized herein, and it shall be unlawful for any permittee or other person to violate any of the special terms or conditions of any such permit. 
(Code 1959, § 20-111) 
Sec. 10-3-32. - Designation of curb loading zones. 
Upon approval by ordinance of the mayor and council, the city traffic engineer shall designate passenger and freight curb loading zones and shall place and maintain appropriate signs indicating the same and stating the hours during which the provisions of this section are applicable. 
Sec. 10-3-33. - Standing in passenger curb loading zone. 
No person shall stop, stand or park a vehicle for any purpose or period of time other than for the expeditious loading or unloading of passengers in any place marked as a passenger curb loading zone during hours when the regulations applicable to such curb loading zone are effective. 
(Code 1959, § 20-125) 
Sec. 10-3-34. - Standing in freight curb loading zone. 
(a)  No person shall stop, stand or park a truck for any purpose or length of time other than for the expeditious unloading and delivery or pickup and loading of materials in any place marked as a freight curb loading zone during hours when the provisions applicable to such zones are in effect; nor stop, stand or park any other vehicle for such unloading or loading of materials. 
(b)  The driver of a passenger vehicle may stop temporarily at a place marked as a freight curb loading zone for the purpose of and while actually engaged in loading or unloading passengers when such stopping does not interfere with any motor vehicle used for the transportation of materials which is waiting to enter or about to enter such zone. 
(Code 1959, § 20-126) 
Sec. 10-3-35. - Designation of public carrier stands. 
The city traffic engineer is hereby authorized to create and abolish open taxicab stands subject, however, to approval of the mayor and council and to the applicable provisions of the zoning ordinance of the city. The city traffic engineer shall represent the city in determining the location of bus stops and stands for other passenger common carrier motor vehicles on such public streets, in such places and in such number as he shall determine to be of the greatest benefit and convenience to the public, subject to final approval of the mayor and council, and every such stop, taxicab stand, or other stand shall be designated by appropriate signs. 
Sec. 10-3-36. - Parking of buses and taxicabs regulated. 
The driver of a bus or taxicab shall not park upon any street in any business district at any place other than at a bus stop, or taxicab stand, respectively, except that this provision shall not prevent the driver of any such vehicle from temporarily stopping in accordance with other stopping or parking regulations at any place for the purpose of and while actually engaged in loading or unloading passengers, and except for making emergency repairs. The provisions of this section shall not apply to common carriers stopping at regular designated passing or layover locations. 
(Code 1959, § 20-128) 
Sec. 10-3-37. - Restricted use of bus and taxicab stands. 
No person shall stop, stand, or park a vehicle other than a bus in a bus stop, or other than a taxicab in a taxicab stand when any such stop or stand has been officially designated and appropriately signed, except that the driver of a passenger vehicle may temporarily stop therein for the purpose of and while actually engaged in loading or unloading passengers when such stopping does not interfere with any bus or taxicab waiting to enter or about to enter such zone. 
(Code 1959, § 20-129) 
Sec. 10-3-38. - Length of bus stops; marking; manner of stopping. 
(a)  A no parking zone of 40 feet shall be created at all bus stops for the purpose of loading and unloading passengers. 
(b)  Such no parking zones shall be marked by signs and, in addition, such zones in all congested areas shall have the curbs painted yellow. This proper marking of zones shall be maintained by the companies operating buses in and out of such zones. 
(c)  Buses or any vehicles parked in such zones for the purpose of loading or unloading passengers shall pull as close to the curb as possible. 
(d)  This section does not prohibit buses from loading and unloading at platforms at loading zones where they are provided for that purpose in the street. 
(Code 1959, § 20-130) 
CHAPTER 4. - ENFORCEMENT[1] 

Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference— Traffic division of police department, § 4-1-2 et seq.; traffic violations bureau of municipal court, § 2-5-21 et seq. 

Sec. 10-4-1. - General penalty. 
Any person convicted of violating any provision of this title shall be punished as provided in section 1-1-8 of this code. 
(Code 1959, § 20-223) 
Sec. 10-4-2. - Presumption in reference to illegal parking. 
(a)  In any prosecution charging a violation of any law or regulation governing the standing or parking of a vehicle proof that the particular vehicle described in the complaint was parked in violation of any such law or regulation, together with proof that the defendant named in the complaint was at the time of such parking the registered owner of such vehicle, shall constitute in evidence a prima facie presumption that the registered owner of such vehicle was the person who parked or placed such vehicle at the point where, and for the time which, such violation occurred. 
(b)  The foregoing stated presumption shall apply only when the procedure as prescribed in sections 10-4-3 through 10-4-5 has been followed. 
(Code 1959, § 20-224) 
Sec. 10-4-3. - Notice on illegally parked vehicle. 
Whenever any motor vehicle without a driver is found parked or stopped in violation of any of the restrictions imposed by this title or other ordinance of the city or by state law, the officer finding such vehicle shall take its registration number and may take other information displayed on the vehicle which may identify its user, and shall conspicuously affix to such vehicle a notice in writing, on a form provided by the chief of police, for the driver to answer to the charge against him at the time and place specified in the notice. The officer shall send one (1) copy to the traffic violations bureau. 
Sec. 10-4-4. - Owner liable for parking violation. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to allow, permit, or suffer any vehicle registered in his name to stand or park in any street, in violation of this title or any other ordinance of the city regulating the parking of vehicles. Such person shall be equally liable with the operator for such violation. 
Sec. 10-4-5. - Failure to comply with notice attached to parked vehicle. 
If a violator of the restrictions on stopping, standing, or parking under this title or other traffic laws or ordinances does not appear in response to a notice affixed to such vehicle, at the time and place specified, the traffic violations bureau shall send to the owner of the motor vehicle to which the notice was affixed a letter informing him of the violation and warning him that in the event such letter is disregarded for a period of five (5) days from the date of the letter, a summons of arrest will be issued. 
(Code 1959, § 20-227) 
Sec. 10-4-6. - When person charged may elect to appear at bureau or before municipal judge. 
(a)  Any person charged with an offense for which payment of a fine may be made to the traffic violations bureau shall have the option of paying such fine within the time specified in the notice of arrest at the traffic violations bureau upon entering a plea of guilty and upon waiving appearance in court; or may have the option of depositing required lawful bail and upon a plea of not guilty shall be entitled to a trial as authorized by law. 
(b)  The payment of a bond to the bureau shall be deemed as acknowledgement of conviction of the alleged offense, and the bureau, upon accepting the prescribed bond shall issue a receipt to the violator acknowledging the payment thereof. 
Sec. 10-4-7. - When summons for arrest to be issued. 
In the event any person fails to comply with a notice given to such person or attached to a vehicle or fails to make appearance pursuant to a summons directing an appearance in the traffic violations bureau, or if any person fails or refuses to deposit bail as required and within the time permitted by ordinance, the traffic violations bureau shall forthwith secure and issue a summons for his arrest. 
(Code 1959, § 20-228) 
Sec. 10-4-8. - Disposition of traffic fines and forfeitures. 
All fines or forfeitures collected upon conviction or upon the forfeiture of bail of any person charged with a violation of any of the provisions of this title shall be paid into the city treasury. 
(Code 1959, § 20-232) 
Sec. 10-4-9. - Issuance of summons. 
It shall be the duty of any member of the police division, in all cases where complaint is made or information obtained of any violation of any of the laws or ordinances of the city, to issue a summons, directed to the accused, requiring him to appear before the municipal court to answer such charge, which summons shall designate the time and place of trial. It shall be signed by the patrolman or officer issuing same and a copy thereof shall be served upon the accused either personally or by leaving the copy at his place of residence. 
(Code 1959, § 20-233) 
Sec. 10-4-10. - Penalty for failure to appear when served with copy of charges. 
Any person who has been lawfully served with a copy of charges to appear in the municipal court and shall fail to appear at the time and place indicated in such copy of charges shall be guilty of an offense and upon conviction in the municipal court shall be punished as provided in section 1-1-8 of this code. 
(Code 1959, § 20-235) 
Sec. 10-4-11. - Failure to appear as provided in summons or notice. 
Any person who fails to appear as provided in the notice or summons provided for in section 10-4-10 of this code for any traffic violation is guilty of an offense for such failure to appear regardless of the disposition of the charge on which he was originally arrested. 
(Code 1959, § 20-236) 
Sec. 10-4-12. - When warrants for arrest to be issued. 
When it shall be made to appear to the municipal court that any person has been lawfully served with a copy of charges to appear in such court for trial and shall fail to appear at the time and place set forth in such copy of charges, it shall be the duty of the municipal judge to forthwith issue a warrant, signed by the judge, for the arrest of such person and deliver same to the chief of police. 
Sec. 10-4-13. - Issuance of warrants. 
Any person witnessing a violation of a city ordinance by another person may appear before the municipal court and there swear out a complaint for said violation. Upon the signing under oath of said complaint by said complainant a warrant may be issued by the municipal court, signed by the municipal judge, and directed to the alleged violator to be and appear in said court to answer the charges as contained in said complaint. 
Title 11 - Offenses 
Chapter 1.  General Provisions 
Chapter 2  Nuisances 
Chapter 3  Animals 
Chapter 4.  Litter 
CHAPTER 1. - GENERAL PROVISIONS[1] 

Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Editor's note— Municipalities are prohibited by law from enacting ordinances covering matters which have been preempted by general law and are prevented from regulating conduct which has been made a violation of any criminal law of the state. See O.C.G.A., § 36-35-6 (a(2)); Ga. Const. of 1976, Art. I, § II, ¶ VII. 
State Law reference— Abandonment of airtight containers, O.C.G.A., § 16-11-100; fireworks, O.C.G.A., § 25-10-1 et seq.; peeping toms, O.C.G.A., § 16-11-61; gambling, O.C.G.A., § 16-12-20 et seq.; prostitution, O.C.G.A., § 16-6-9 et seq.; distributing obscene materials, O.C.G.A., § 16-12-80 et seq.; criminal trespass, O.C.G.A., § 16-7-21. 

Sec. 11-1-1. - Maintaining standards of neighborhood; maintaining standards of business establishment; prohibition of keeping junk, abandoned appliances, inoperative vehicles, and other equipment on property. 
(a)  In order to eliminate unsightly, unhealthy or dangerous situations, and in order to protect property values and to enhance the beauty of the city, it shall be unlawful for any person to own, rent, lease or be in possession of any premises, dwelling, dwelling unit or other structure, place or vacant lot wherein are kept dilapidated furniture, appliances, machinery or equipment, including automobiles, which are either in a wholly or partially wrecked, junked, dismantled or inoperative condition and which are not completely enclosed within a building. 
(b)  Should the chief of police determine that any person is violating the terms of this section, the city manager or, if there be no city manager, the mayor, shall give the offending party five (5) days' notice within which to eliminate the unsightly, unhealthy, or dangerous situation. The notice shall be in writing and shall be a prerequisite to the bringing of charges against an offender. Should the person to whom the notice is directed fail to comply with the request made therein within the five-day period, a law enforcement officer of the city shall be authorized to proceed with the bringing of charges as for the violation of any city ordinance. Each day the unsightly, unhealthy, or dangerous situation exists shall be deemed a separate offense. 
(c)  Furniture, appliances, machinery or equipment, including automobiles, as hereinabove defined, which remain on the same property for a period of thirty (30) days after either a plea or a finding of guilty shall be presumed to be abandoned and subject to being removed from the property by the chief of police or his duly authorized agent or employee. After removal, the chief of police shall determine whether or not the property has any value. If he finds it to have value, it shall be disposed of as provided in section 3-1-21. If the chief of police finds the property to have no value, he shall immediately and personally see to its destruction. 
(Code 1959, § 12-6.1; Ord. No. 01-13, § 1, 10-1-01) 
Cross reference— Unhealthy and unsanitary conditions on property, § 5-2-3 et seq. 
Sec. 11-1-2. - Public property; injuring, defacing, etc. 
(a)  It is unlawful for any unauthorized person wilfully, maliciously, wantonly, negligently or otherwise, to injure, deface, destroy, tamper or interfere with any property, real or personal, or any improvements to any real property belonging to or under the supervision or control of the city, including but not limited to water meters, pipes, conduits, wires, lines, posts, lamps or other apparatus. 
(b)  It is equally unlawful to commit any of the acts hereinabove stated to any such property owned by any private company or other unit of government, to suffer injury, damage, destruction or interference, as hereinabove stated. 
(c)  Injury, damage, destruction or the attempt to tamper with a meter, or other device to measure municipal or utility services, shall be prima facie evidence of the intention of the person to whom such meter or device has been issued, to violate the provisions of this section. 
(d)  The penalty for the violation of this section, or any provision thereof, shall be as provided in section 1-1-8 of this Code. 
(Code 1959, § 12-47; Ord. No. 90-005, 7-16-90; Ord. No. 00-04, § 1, 4-3-2000) 
Sec. 11-1-3. - Same; removing dirt, materials, etc. 
It shall be unlawful for any unauthorized person to move, disturb, or take any earth, stone or other material from any public property. 
(Code 1959, § 12-48) 
Sec. 11-1-4. - Trees, cutting or defacing. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to cut, deface or destroy any shade tree on public property in the city unless authorized by the city manager. 
(Code 1959, § 12-50) 
Sec. 11-1-5. - Encroachments on public property. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to erect, maintain or permit to be erected or maintained, any encroachment or obstruction whatsoever upon, over or under the public property or ways of the city without the written permission of the governing body. The city manager is hereby authorized to issue permits for temporary encroachments or obstructions of public property or ways which encroachments or obstructions shall not exceed ninety (90) days. 
(b)  If at any time it shall appear that any person is unlawfully encroaching upon, or maintaining any unlawful obstruction in any part of a public way, it shall be the duty of any law enforcement officer to give notice to said party, ordering the removal of such encroachment or obstruction; and if such encroachment or obstruction is not removed within twenty-four (24) hours after receipt of said notice, or such other reasonable time as may be designated by the governing body, it shall be the duty of the law enforcement officer to cause any such encroachment or obstruction to be summarily removed, and the cost and expense thereof shall be charged to the person maintaining the same. 
(Code 1959, § 12-16) 
Sec. 11-1-6. - Safe sidewalks and streets. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to stand in, sit in, or otherwise obstruct any public passage, public place, or public way, as such is defined by the law of the state, so as to impede the normal, free and uninterrupted passage of the public, and to refuse to desist from so doing when ordered to do so by the police or other lawful authority. 
(b)  A public passage, public place or public way shall include all public passages and buildings, as well as private businesses open to the public. 
(Code 1959, § 12-16.1) 
Sec. 11-1-7. - Reserved. 
Editor's note— Section 1 of Ord. No. 99-010, adopted June 21, 1999, repealed § 11-1-7 in its entirety. Formerly, § 11-1-7 pertained to false alarms and derived from § 12-17 of the 1959 Code. 
Sec. 11-1-8. - False reports of crimes. 
No person within the city shall make to, or file with, the police department of the city or any police officer of the city any false, misleading, or unfounded statement, or report concerning the commission or alleged commission of any ordinance violation occurring within the city. 
(Code 1959, § 12-18) 
Sec. 11-1-9. - Children playing in streets. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any minor child to play in the streets of the city. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for any parent, guardian, or other person having the control or custody of any minor to permit, allow, or encourage such minor to play in any street in the city. 
Sec. 11-1-10. - Curfew for minors. 
(a)  Purpose. It is the responsibility of the City of Forest Park to protect the health, safety and welfare of the citizens of the city. As a part of this responsibility, the city recognizes the need to protect our children from being victims of crimes that occur after hours as well as lessen the risk that a juvenile become a violator of the law as the result of after hours conduct. It is also the purpose of the ordinance to make parents more responsible for their children. It is believed that it is in the best interest of the citizens of Forest Park, Georgia to have a juvenile curfew ordinance. 
(b)  Definitions. The following words and phrases, whenever used in this section, shall be construed as defined hereinbelow. 
(1)  Adult means: 
a.  A person who is at least eighteen (18) years of age and authorized by a parent or guardian to have the care and custody of a minor; or 
b.  An emancipated minor. 
(2)  Curfew hours means: 
a.  11:00 p.m. on Sunday, Monday, Tuesday, Wednesday or Thursday until 6:00 a.m. on the following day; 
b.  12:00 p.m. until 6:00 a.m. on any Friday or Saturday; and 
c.  9:00 p.m. until 6:00 a.m. every day for those individuals specified in subsection (c)(1). 
(3)  Emancipated Minor means: 
a.  Any person under the age of eighteen (18) who is married or who is not under the care, custody, and control of a parent, parents, guardian, person standing in locus parentis, or the juvenile court of competent jurisdiction; or 
b.  Any person under the age of eighteen (18) who has had the disabilities of minority removed by a court of competent jurisdiction. 
(4)  Emergency means an unforeseen combination of circumstances or the resulting state that calls for immediate action. The term includes, but is not limited to, a fire, a natural disaster, or automobile accident, or any situation requiring immediate action to prevent serious bodily injury or loss of life. 
(5)  Establishment means any privately owned place of business operated for a profit to which the public is invited, including, but not limited to any place of amusement or entertainment. 
(6)  Guardian means: 
a.  A person who, under court order, is the guardian of the person of a minor; or 
b.  A public or private agency with whom a minor has been placed by the court. 
(7)  Minor means any person seventeen (17) years of age or under. 
(8)  Operator means any individual, firm, association, partnership, or corporation operating, managing, or conducting any establishment. The term includes the members or partners of an association or partnership and officers of a corporation. 
(9)  Parent means a person who is a natural parent, an adoptive parent, or step parent of another person. 
(10)  Public place means any place to which the public or a substantial group of the public has access that includes, but is not limited to, streets, highways, and the common areas of schools, hospitals, apartment houses, office buildings, transport facilities and shops. 
(11)  Remain means: 
a.  Linger or stay; or 
b.  Fail to leave premises when requested to do so by an officer or the owner, operator, or the person in control of the premises. 
(12)  Serious bodily injury means bodily injury that causes death or creates a substantial risk of, serious permanent disfigurement, or protracted loss or impairment of the function of any bodily member or organ. 
(c)  Acts prohibited. 
(1)  Minors 14 years of age or younger. It is unlawful for any minor fourteen (14) years of age or younger, to loiter, idle, wander, stroll or play in or upon the public place, streets, highways, roads, alleys, parks, playgrounds or other public grounds, establishments, public buildings, places of amusement, eating places, vacant lots or anyplace in the city, unsupervised by an adult, parent or guardian having the lawful authority to be at such places, between the hours of 9:00 p.m. on any day and 6:00 a.m. on the following day. 
(2)  Minors 15 years of age and older. It is unlawful for any minor fifteen (15) years of age or older, to loiter, idle, wander stroll or play in or upon the public place, streets, highways, roads, alleys, parks, playgrounds or other public grounds, establishments, public buildings, places of amusement, eating places, vacant lots or anyplace in the city, unsupervised by an adult, parent or guardian having the lawful authority to be at such places, between the hours of 11:00 p.m. on any day and 6:00 a.m. on the following day; provided, however, that on Fridays and Saturdays the effective hours are between 12:00 midnight and 6:00 a.m. of the following day. 
(3)  It shall be unlawful for the parent, guardian, or other person having custody or control of any minor seventeen (17) years of age or younger to knowingly or by insufficient control, to allow, such minor to violate the prohibitions set forth in paragraph (c)(1) and (c)(2) above. 
(4)  It shall be unlawful for any owner, operator or employee of an establishment to knowingly allow a minor to be in or upon the premises of an establishment in the city between the hours of 11:00 p.m. on any day and 6:00 a.m. the following day, or on Fridays and Saturdays between the hours of 12:00 midnight and 6:00 a.m. the following day. 
(d)  Offenses. 
(1)  A minor commits an offense if he or she remains in any public place or on the premises of any establishment in the city during curfew hours. 
(2)  A parent or a guardian of a minor commits an offense if he or she knowingly permits, or by insufficient control, allows the minor to remain in any public place or on the premises of any establishment in the city during curfew hours. 
(3)  An owner, operator or employee of an establishment commits an offense if he or she knowingly allows a minor to remain in or upon the premises of any establishment in the city during curfew hours. It is a defense to prosecution under this section that the owner, operator or employee of an establishment promptly notified the Forest Park police department that a minor was present on the premises of the establishment during curfew hours and refused to leave. 
(e)  Exceptions. The provisions of the City of Forest Park Curfew Ordinance [this section] shall not apply in the following instances: 
(1)  When a minor is accompanied by his or her parent, guardian or other adult having the lawful care and custody of the minor; 
(2)  When the minor is upon an emergency errand directed by his or her parent or guardian or other adult person having the lawful care and custody of such minor, or if such minor is seeking medical treatment; 
(3)  When the minor is returning directly home from an activity, entertainment function, recreational activity or dance associated with a school. 
(4)  When the minor is returning directly home from lawful employment that makes it necessary to be in the above referenced places during the prescribed period of time; 
(5)  When the minor is in a motor vehicle of parental consent for normal travel; or 
(6)  When the minor is an emancipated minor. 
(f)  Violations and penalties. 
(1)  Upon conviction of violations of this section, an adult, parent, guardian or owner, operator or employee of an establishment shall be subject, after having been charged with the same and found guilty in the municipal court of the city, to punishment as provided in section 1-1-8 in this Code of Ordinances. 
(2)  Adjudication of violations of this ordinance by minors shall be made in accordance with Title 15 of the Official Code of Georgia Annotated. 
(g)  Enforcement. Before taking any enforcement action under this section, a City of Forest Park police officer shall ask the apparent offender's age and the reason for being in the public place. The officer shall not issue a citation or make an arrest under this section unless the officer reasonably believes that an offense has occurred and that based on any response and other circumstances that no exception is present. 
(h)  Conflict. All laws and ordinances, or parts thereof, which conflict with the provisions of this ordinance are hereby repealed. 
(i)  Effective date. This section shall become effective upon its approval [Oct. 7, 1996] by the city council of the City of Forest Park. 
(j)  Invalidity in Part. In the event any section, subsection, sentence, clause or phrase of this ordinance shall be declared of judged invalid or unconstitutional, such adjudication shall in no matter effect the other sections, subsections, sentence, clauses or phrases of this ordinance, which shall remain in full force and effect, as if the section, subsection, sentence, clause or phrase so declared or judged invalid or unconstitutional was not originally a part hereof. 
(k)  It shall be the duty and responsibility of the department of policy services to disseminate copies of this ordinance to places that those affected by it congregate and to explain its effect and enforcement. 
(Code 1959, § 12-9; Ord. No. 96-016, 10-7-96) 
State Law reference— Juvenile proceedings, O.C.G.A., § 15-11-1 et seq. 
Sec. 11-1-11. - Disorderly conduct. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person within the corporate limits of the city to violate any of the following subsections: 
(1)  Any person who shall act in a violent or tumultuous manner toward another; 
(2)  Any person who shall endanger the lawful pursuits of another by acts of violence, threats or abusive conduct; 
(3)  Any person who shall cause, provoke or engage in any fight, brawl or riotous conduct; 
(4)  Any person who shall assemble or congregate with another or others for the purpose of causing, provoking or engaging in any fight or brawl; 
(5)  Any person who shall be found jostling or roughly crowding or pushing any person in public; 
(6)  Any person who shall collect in bodies or in crowds for unlawful purposes as defined by the current ordinances of the city or laws of this state; 
(7)  Any person who shall assemble or congregate with another or others for the purpose or with the intent to engage in gaming; 
(8)  Any person who shall frequent any public place with intent to obtain money from other persons by illegal and fraudulent schemes, tricks, artifices or devices; 
(9)  Any person who assembles for the purpose of engaging in any fraudulent scheme, device or trick to obtain any valuable thing in any place or from any person in said city, or who shall aid or abet therein; 
(10)  Any person who shall accost or attempt to force his company upon any female or attempt to pick up any female; 
(11)  Any person who utters in the presence of another, any bawdy, lewd or obscene words or epithets; 
(12)  Any person who frequents any place where gaming or illegal sale or possession of alcoholic beverages or narcotics or dangerous drugs is practiced, allowed or tolerated; 
(13)  Any person who shall act in a dangerous manner toward others; 
(14)  Any person who shall use "fighting words" directed towards any person; 
(15)  Any person who shall assemble or congregate for the purpose of trouncing upon another; 
(16)  Any person who shall by acts of violence interfere with another's pursuit of a lawful occupation; 
(17)  Any person who shall congregate with another or others in or on any public way so as to halt the flow of vehicular or pedestrian traffic and refuses to clear such public way when ordered by the city police or other lawful authority; 
(18)  Any person, participant, or official who is in attendance at any sporting event over which the city has any supervisory capacity, who through speech or physical conduct acts unseemly and who repeatedly annoys, offends, and imposes himself upon others in attendance; or 
(19)  Any person within the city limits who directs language to another in an abusive or demeaning manner which contains epithets relating to sexual reproduction, lineage, incest, chastity or excretion. 
(b)  Any person who shall violate any subsection of this section may be charged with the offense of "disorderly conduct" and on conviction thereof, may be found guilty of disorderly conduct. 
State Law reference— Authority of cities to punish for disorderly conduct, O.C.G.A., § 16-11-34. 
Sec. 11-1-12. - Disorderly houses. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to keep, rent or let any house, hall or room, within the corporate limits of the city, for the congregating of disorderly, noisy or riotous persons, or where disorderly, riotous or noisy persons assemble to the disturbance of the neighborhood or some part thereof. 
(Code 1959, § 12-12) 
Sec. 11-1-13. - Drunkenness in public places. 
Any person who shall be and appear in an intoxicated condition on any public street or highway or within the curtilage of any private residence, not in the exclusive possession of the person or persons so intoxicated, or upon any fairgrounds, ballgrounds, showgrounds, park or any other place of public gathering or assembly, or private property used by the public, which said drunkenness or intoxication may be caused by the excessive use of intoxicating wines, beers, liquors or drugs, and has manifest itself by boisterous or disorderly conduct, or by indecent condition, or acts, or by vulgar profane or unbecoming language, or loud and violent discourse of the person or persons so intoxicated or drunken; shall be guilty of public drunkenness. 
State Law reference— Authority of city to punish public drunkenness, O.C.G.A., § 16-11-41. 
Sec. 11-1-13.1. - Regulation of the sale, purchase and distribution of alcoholic beverages by and to persons under twenty-one years of age. 
(a)  No person knowingly, directly, or through another person, shall furnish, cause to be furnished, or permit any person in such person's employ to furnish any alcoholic beverages to any person under twenty-one (21) years of age. 
(b)  No person under twenty-one (21) years of age shall purchase, or knowingly possess, any alcoholic beverage. 
(c)  No person under twenty-one (21) years of age shall misrepresent such person's age in any manner whatever for the purpose of obtaining illegally any alcoholic beverage. 
(d)  No person knowingly or intentionally shall act as an agent to purchase or acquire any alcoholic beverage for, or on behalf, of a person under twenty-one (21) years of age. 
(e)  No person under twenty-one (21) years of age shall misrepresent his identity or use any false identification for the purpose of purchasing or obtaining any alcoholic beverage. 
(f)  The exceptions contained in O.C.G.A. section 3-3-23 (b), (c) and (d) of the laws of the State of Georgia are hereby incorporated by reference, and shall serve as exemptions for any person charged under subsections 1(a) through (e) of this section. 
(g)  (1)  No person shall allow or require a person in his employment under eighteen (18) years of age to dispense, serve, sell, or take orders for any alcoholic beverages for consumption on the premises. 
(2)  This subsection shall not prohibit persons over eighteen (18) years of age who are employed in supermarkets, convenience stores, breweries, or drug stores, from selling or handling alcoholic beverages which are sold for consumption off the premises. 
(h)  Penalties. 
(1)  Any person convicted of violating any prohibition contained in subsections (a), (c), (d) and (e) of this section shall, upon the first conviction, be guilty of a misdemeanor and punished as set forth in section 1-1-8 of the Code of Ordinances of the City of Forest Park. 
(2)  Any person convicted of violating subsection (b) of this section shall, upon the first conviction, be guilty of a misdemeanor and shall be punished by not more than thirty (30) days' imprisonment, or a fine of not more than three hundred dollars ($300.00), or both. However, upon a second or subsequent conviction, said person shall be punished as provided for violation of any ordinance of the Code of the City of Forest Park as set forth in section 1-1-8 of the Code of Ordinances of the City of Forest Park. 
(Ord. No. 86-020, 12-15-86) 
Sec. 11-1-14. - Loitering. 
(a)  Loitering shall mean remaining idle in essentially one (1) location and shall include the concepts of spending time idly, loafing, walking about aimlessly, or sitting on cars, trucks, or other vehicles, and shall include the colloquial expression "hanging around." It shall be unlawful for any person to loiter within the city public property or private property used by the public in such a manner as to: 
(1)  Create or cause to be created a danger of a breach of the peace; 
(2)  Create or cause to be created any disturbance or annoyance to the comfort and repose of any person; 
(3)  Obstruct the free passage of pedestrians or vehicles; 
(4)  Obstruct, molest, or interfere with any person lawfully in any public place; or 
(5)  Be at a place, at a time, or in a manner not usual for law-abiding individuals under circumstances which would warrant a justifiable and reasonable alarm or immediate concern for the safety of persons or property within the vicinity. 
(6)  Near business establishments. It shall be unlawful for any person or persons to congregate or loiter on any private property which is adjacent to or used by any business or commercial establishment in the city for the use of said business establishment or its customers for parking of vehicles or other uses incidental to the operation of said business. 
(7)  Congregating on sidewalks or streets. It shall be unlawful for any person or persons to obstruct the sidewalks or streets of the city, or sidewalks or drives within private property which is open to the public, by standing, sitting, or laying in crowds. 
(b)  Relocating from one (1) position to another and regrouping or generally "hanging around" shall be "prima facie" evidence of intent to continue an unlawful act under this section and shall constitute a new offense after having been dispersed or cited for an offense under these provisions. 
(c)  A person commits the offense of loitering if said person refuses to leave the premises or place after being asked to leave by the owner of the premises, the authorized agent of the owner, or a law enforcement officer. 
(d)  Among the circumstances, which may be considered in determining, whether alarm is warranted is the fact that the person takes flight upon the appearance of a law enforcement officer, refuses to identify him or herself or any object. Unless flight by the person or other circumstances make it impractical, a law enforcement officer shall, prior to any arrest for an offense under this section, afford the person an opportunity to dispel any alarm or immediate concern which would otherwise be warranted by requesting the person to identify himself or herself and explain his or her presence and conduct. No person shall be convicted of an offense under this section if the law enforcement officer failed to comply with the foregoing procedure or if it appears at trial that the explanation given by the person was true and would have dispelled the alarm or immediate concern. 
(Ord. No. 04-22, § 1, 3-30-2004) 
Sec. 11-1-15. - Loitering for illegal sexual purposes. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to loiter, while a pedestrian or in a motor vehicle, in or near any thoroughfare or place open to the public, parking lots of hotels and motels, in a manner and under circumstances manifesting the purpose of inducing, enticing, soliciting or procuring another to commit an act of prostitution, sodomy, masturbation for hire or pandering. Among the circumstances which may be considered in determining whether this purpose is manifested are: that person is a known prostitute, pimp, sodomist, masturbator for hire or panderer and repeatedly beckons to, stops or attempts to stop, or engages passersby in conversation, or repeatedly stops, or attempts to stop motor vehicle operators by hailing, or waving of arms or any bodily gesture for the purpose of inducing, enticing, soliciting or procuring another to commit an act of prostitution, sodomy, masturbation for hire or pandering. No arrest shall be made for a violation of this subsection unless the arresting officer first affords that person the opportunity to explain his conduct. 
(b)  For the purpose of subsection (a), a "known prostitute, pimp, sodomist, panderer or masturbator for hire" is a person who, previous to the date of arrest for violation of this section, had been convicted of a violation of a sexual related law of any city or law of any state defining and punishing acts of soliciting, committing or offering or agreeing to commit prostitution, sodomy, masturbation for hire or pandering. 
(c)  For the purpose of subsection (a), "any person" shall also include panderers or solicitors of sexual acts, commonly referred to as "johns" or "trick.," who loiter in a manner and under circumstances manifesting the purpose of participating in, procuring, purchasing or soliciting any sexual act for hire made illegal by state law. Among the circumstances which may be considered in determining whether this purpose is manifested are: that person, while a pedestrian or in a motor vehicle, repeatedly beckons to, attempts to stop, engages or attempts to engage in conversation with any person by hailing, waving arms or any bodily gesture for the purpose of inducing, enticing, 
soliciting or procuring another to commit an act of prostitution, sodomy, masturbation for hire or pandering. 
State Law reference— Authority of city to adopt ordinances proscribing loitering and related acts for purposes of procuring others to engage in sexual acts for hire, O.C.G.A., § 16-6-24. 
Sec. 11-1-16. - Fortunetelling. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to carry on within the corporate limits of the city, the business of telling fortunes or carrying on the trade, business or profession of phrenology, clairvoyance, palmistry or other business of like kind or nature in which the future of any person is foretold or attempted to be foretold. Excepted from the provisions of this section are those persons practicing astrology and who are members of the Astrological Association of Georgia, Inc. and who have procured a business license in accordance with the applicable paragraph of title 9, chapter 1 of this code. 
(Code 1959, § 12-20) 
Sec. 11-1-17. - Open wells and excavations. 
It shall be unlawful for any owner, occupant or person to permit any open well or hazardous excavation to remain or exist on the property under the control of such owner, occupant or person. 
(Code 1959, § 12-30) 
Sec. 11-1-18. - Police officers; resisting; obstructing; following. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to resist any police officer, any member of the police department, or any other person duly empowered with police authority, while in the discharge or apparent discharge of his duty, or in any way interfere with, obstruct or hinder him in the discharge of this duty. 
(b)  No person shall follow any police officer, while in charge of any prisoner, after such person has been commanded to desist such following, or after any crowd has been commanded to disperse. 
(Code 1959, § 12-38) 
State Law reference— Obstruction or hindering law enforcement officers, O.C.G.A., § 16-10-24. 
Sec. 11-1-19. - Same; impersonating. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to wear or carry the uniform, apparel, badge, identification card or any other insignia of office, like or similar to, or a colorable imitation of that adopted and worn or carried by the official police officers of the city, unless such person is an official officer of the city. 
(Code 1959, § 12-39) 
State Law reference— Impersonating public officer or employee, O.C.G.A., § 16-10-23. 
Sec. 11-1-20. - Police radios; intercepting. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to intercept radio calls of the police department for any unlawful purpose. 
(Code 1959, § 12-41) 
Sec. 11-1-21. - Prisoners, escapes. 
No person within the city shall do any act set forth in this section in connection with the escape of prisoners: 
(1)  Assisting in the escape of prisoners. No person shall make available to, present, or place within the reach of, any person confined under authority of the city, any intoxicating or malt liquors, or any tool, implement, or other thing calculated to aid in the escape of such person so confined or any other person confined under authority of the city or confined by police officers of the city. 
(2)  Aiding escapees. No person shall assist or aid, or attempt to assist or aid any person in the custody of or confined under the authority of the city, to escape from jail, place of confinement, or custody. 
(3)  Escape from jail. No person while a prisoner in the city jail, or in any other place where prisoners are confined, or otherwise in custody of and confined by the city or police officer of the city, shall escape or attempt to escape or to assist others to escape or attempt to escape from such custody or confinement. 
(Code 1959, § 12-43) 
Sec. 11-1-22. - Knives, razors and ice picks. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to have, possess, or carry upon the streets, alleys, sidewalks or in any public place in the city any of the following implements unless same are securely wrapped so as not to be readily available for harmful use: 
(1)  Any knife which has a blade which opens automatically by hand pressure applied to a button, spring, or other device in the handle, the blade of which when open projects from the handle more than two (2) inches. 
(2)  Any knife which has any obstruction or other device of any kind which holds the blade partly open, the blade of which when open projects from the handle more than two (2) inches. 
(3)  Any knife of any kind, the blade of which when open projects from the handle more than three (3) inches. This is intended to include all knives such as butcher knives and/or knives which do not close and any type knife with the blade open. 
(4)  Any razor or razor blade. 
(5)  Any ice pick or similar device having a sharp point, except this shall not apply to any person delivering ice. 
(Code 1959, § 12-52) 
Sec. 11-1-23. - Discharging firearms in city. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to discharge any firearm in the corporate limits of the city except in defense of person.
